Diversity of human cultures; nature of culture, social organizations, subsistence patterns, economics, law, politics, religion, language and other institutions of culture viewed in cross-cultural perspective.

Name: Introduction to Forensic Anthropology
Desc: Exploration of medico-legal discipline of forensic anthropology with a focus on human skeletal anatomy.

Name: Introduction to Archaeology
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Archaeological goals, methods, techniques and interpretations; particular prehistoric cultural sequences or projects; relationship of archaeology with other social, life and earth sciences.

Name: Field Methods in Archaeology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Techniques of survey, mapping, excavation and recording; participation in one or more archaeological excavations.

Name: World Archaeology
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Survey of human culture history from the stone age to the present; spread of humanity around the globe; major cultural developments including hunting and gathering, origins of agriculture, discovery and spread of metalworking, rise of ancient civilizations, and development of the modern world.

Name: Introduction to World Ethnography
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Sex roles, economic pursuits, values, beliefs, families and other institutions of selected nonwestern peoples; implications for American culture.

Name: Introduction to Folklore
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. See ENGL 2423.

Name: Archaeology and the Bible
Desc: See REL 3004.

Name: Bones, Bodies, and Disease: Introduction to Paleopathology
Desc: Introduction to the field of Paleopathology- the study of health and disease in ancient populations. Topics covered include the major diseases and syndromes identifiable in skeletal and mummified tissues, methods for identifying injury and disease in bones and teeth and their limitations, and the application of paleopathology data for understanding health in past populations.

Name: Introduction to Anthropological Linguistics
Desc: Also offered as LING 3060. Cultural variation in language and its uses; problems of language classification and areal linguistics; practice in phonemic and morphemic analysis of nonwestern languages.

Name: The Study of Folklore
Desc: Also offered as ENGL 3401. History of the study of folklore; methods of collection, interpretation and analysis of folklore materials; myth, folktale, legend, folk song, ballads, folk humor, festival and folk speech; psychological, contextual and structural analysis of oral literature; specific reference to the heritage of Louisiana and the South.

Name: Selected Topics in Anthropology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: South Asian Society, Polity and Culture
Desc: See INTL 4002.

Name: The North American Indians
Desc: Also offered as LING 4004. Origin, distribution, language and culture of the aboriginal population.

Name: Ancient Civilizations of Middle America
Desc: Ancient settlement, development of agriculture, rise and fall of ancient civilizations in Middle America including Olmec, Maya and Aztecs.

Name: Human Osteology
Desc: Evolutionary biology and functional anatomy of the human skeleton.

Name: Forensic Anthropology
Desc: Fundamental concepts and application of techniques in forensic anthropology.

Name: Louisiana Archaeology
Desc: Two overnight field trips. Archaeological data relative to the Indian cultures dating from the end of the Pleistocene period to the early historic era.

Name: Historical Archaeology
Desc: Also offered as HIST 4151. Broad range of archaeological goals, methods and interpretations unique to the study of the historic past; colonial and plantation archaeology in the southeastern U.S.

Name: Geoarchaeology
Desc: See GEOL 4019.

Name: Method and Theory in Archaeology
Desc: Empirical method and theory in archaeological research emphasizing the logic of scientific argument; history of American archaeology, survey of modern archaeological interpretations, types of explanation, logic of archaeological classification and formation of research designs.
Reqs: ANTH 1001 or ANTH 1003 and ANTH 2015 or equivalent

Name: Advanced Field Methods in Archaeology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Advanced techniques of surveying, mapping, excavation, soil sampling and recording.
Reqs: ANTH 2015 and ANTH 2016 or equivalent and at least one upper-division or graduate course in archaeology

Name: Ancient Civilizations of South America
Desc: Survey of South American prehistory and the development of human civilizations. Archaeological perspective used to explore the various ways of life and cultural achievements in the various regions of the continent from the Amazon lowlands to the Andean highlands and the Pacific desert coast.

Name: Latin American Cultures
Desc: Spanish-American cultures in Latin America; their relationship to current societal changes.

Name: Aerial Photo Interpretation and Image Processing
Desc: See GEOG 4020.

Name: Archaeology of Foodways
Desc: Exploration of foodways through the material remains preserved in the archaeological record. Examination of the variability of foodways in the past from early human consumption patterns to the emergence of food production and ancient civilizations.

Name: Ancient Maya in the Media
Desc: Study of how ancient Maya are portrayed in the media including documentary and feature films, Internet, written texts, radio and television.

Name: Comparative Religions
Desc: Also offered as REL 4031. Religious systems in different levels of sociocultural evolution.

Name: Religion, Gender and Society
Desc: See REL 4032.

Name: Biological Anthropology
Desc: Evolutionary theory, human variation, fossil record of human evolution and primate behavior.

Name: Enterprise Geographic Information Systems
Desc: See GEOG 4042.

Name: Black Music in America
Desc: Cultural and historical survey of musical genres created and developed by black Americans.

Name: Africa
Desc: People and cultures of Africa; emphasis on cultural transformation and contemporary societies. Topics include: kinship, gender, economics, religion, healing, politics, urbanism, post-colonialism, and transnationalism.

Name: African-American Cultures
Desc: Cultures of African-Americans in the western hemisphere; their origins, development and present distinctiveness.

Name: Language and Culture
Desc: Relationships between various aspects of language and culture.

Name: Medicine, Bodies and Power
Desc: Examines bodily practice, social theory and cultural analysis of the body in health, illness and healing. Cross-cultural perspectives and ethnography are considered in relation to forms of social power.

Name: Place and Culture
Desc: Also offered as GEOG 4074. Consideration of place and culture as two core concepts in geography and anthropology.

Name: Social and Cultural Anthropology
Desc: For graduate students with little or no anthropology background. Culture, society and language in primitive and complex settings.

Name: Environmental Change of the Ice Age
Desc: See GEOG 4083.

Name: Human-Environment Interactions
Desc: See GEOG 4086.

Name: Gender, Place and Culture
Desc: Also offered as GEOG 4087 and WGS 4087.

Name: Ethnographic Methodology
Desc: Theories and techniques of ethnography; emphasis on utilization of informants.

Name: Human Evolutionary Biology
Desc: Anatomy, physiology, and behavior of humans in functional, comparative, and evolutionary perspectives.

Name: Vernacular Architecture and Material Culture
Desc: Also offered as ARCH 4440. Subject matter and instructor may vary; additional details available from department. World vernacular architecture, including indigenous and folk buildings; other forms of material culture.

Name: African American Folklore
Desc: Also offered as AAAS 4450. History, theories and methodologies used in the study of African American folklore in the United States.

Name: Folklore of the African Diaspora
Desc: African, Caribbean and African-American cultures from the viewpoint of the diaspora.

Name: American Folklore
Desc: See ENGL 4475.

Name: Undergraduate Seminar in Anthropology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. when topics vary.

Name: Internship
Desc: See GEOG 4995.

Name: Special Topics in Anthropology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Anthropology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. Supervised reading or research selected by qualified advanced students.

Name: Honors: Independent Reading and Research in Anthropology
Desc: Same as ANTH 4998, with special honors emphasis for qualified students.

Name: Comparative Studies in World Costume
Desc: See TAM 7032.

Name: Conversation and Discourse
Desc: Analysis of language in use; conversation, narrative, culturally specific genres; emphasis on discourse structures in naturally occurring context.
Reqs: completion of one course in linguistics

Name: Ritual: Theory, Context and Performance
Desc: Investigates influential theories and key debates, range of activities and contexts and performance of rituals.

Name: Poetics of Place
Desc: Combination of the observational method of social science with the literary insights of poetry and fiction; understanding of how places where humans live out their lives convey a variety of meanings beyond that of the strictly utilitarian.

Name: Conceptual Issues in Human Evolution
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Consideration of the various conceptual issues on human evolution.

Name: History of Anthropological Theory
Desc: Major theories in all branches of anthropology; emphasis on cultural and social anthropology.

Name: Mesoamerican Archaeology Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Human Fertility
Desc: Biological, behavioral and demographic aspects of human reproduction.

Name: Readings in Creolization
Desc: A seminar on linguistic, literary, historical and anthropological creolization and creolized cultures.

Name: Readings in the Caribbean and Louisiana
Desc: Seminar on the theoretical interpretation of Caribbean and Louisiana cultures.

Name: Introduction to Graduate Study
Desc: Same as GEOG 7901. Techniques and methods of the profession for incoming graduate students.

Name: Nature of Culture
Desc: No description provided

Name: Selected Topics in Anthropology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Advanced Qualitative Research in Geography and Anthropology
Desc: Also offered as GEOG 7936.

Name: Paleoclimatology
Desc: See GEOG 7943.

Name: Anthropology of Complex Societies
Desc: Anthropological assumptions of theory and technique; problems generated by applying these assumptions to contemporary Africa, India, Latin America and Anglo-America.

Name: Field Methods in Linguistics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 1 hr. individual consultation. Recording and analyzing a living non-European language and using a native-speaking informant.
Reqs: at least one upper-division or graduate linguistics course

Name: Research in Anthropology
Desc: May be repeated for credit. Total credit earned in ANTH 4998 and ANTH 7999 cannot exceed 9 sem. hrs. Individual supervision of advanced research and field work in anthropology.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading. Permission of instructor.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S/U” grading.

Name: Beginning Arabic
Desc: [LCCN: CARB 1014, Elementary Arabic I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Native speakers of Arabic will not receive credit for this course. Supplementary work in language laboratory. Introduction to alphabet, vocabulary and grammar; elementary language study with oral, written and reading practice.

Name: Beginning Arabic
Desc: Native speakers of Arabic will not receive credit for this course. Supplementary work in language laboratory. Continuation of ARAB 1101. Elementary language study with oral, written and reading practice.

Name: Arabic Culture
Desc: Taught in English; knowledge of Arabic not required. Introduction to Arabic history and the varieties in Arabic Culture.

Name: Arabic Conversation
Desc: Intensive oral drills, supplemented with exercises in grammar and vocabulary.

Name: Intermediate Arabic
Desc: Native speakers of Arabic will not receive credit for this course. Continuation of the study of Arabic. Supplementary work in language laboratory. Development of writing, reading, and speaking skills.

Name: Intermediate Arabic
Desc: Native speakers of Arabic will not receive credit for this course. Continuation of the study of Arabic. Supplementary work in language laboratory. Development of writing, reading and speaking skills.

Name: Advanced Arabic I
Desc: Introduces authentic classical and modern Arabic texts; continuing development of reading, writing, speaking and listening.

Name: Advanced Arabic II
Desc: Introduces authentic classical and modern Arabic texts, especially poetry; continuing development of reading, writing, speaking and listening.

Name: Special Topics in Middle Eastern Cinema
Desc: Also offered as SCRN 3501. Can be repeated when topics vary by permission of instructor. Introduction to contemporary Middle East cinema covering the period from after the 1950s to the present in countries including Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Israel, Palestine, Lebanon, Turkey, and Iran.

Name: Classical Arabic Literature
Desc: An examination of the development of Arabic literature from the sixth to the fourteenth century.

Name: Contemporary Arabic Literature
Desc: This course examines the often turbulent relationship between indigenous Arabic forms of poetry and prose and European literature which defines the development of modern Arabic literature.

Name: Independent Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Readings in Arabic literature directed by a senior faculty member.

Name: Architectural Design I
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on two-dimensional representation of three-dimensional forms; development of basic skills in architectural design drawing and modeling.

Name: Architectural Design II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 1102. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the organization of spaces, form and process, and development of skills in architectural design drawing and modeling.

Name: Honors: Architectural Design II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 1002. 12 hrs. studio.

Name: Architectural Design III
Desc: ARCH 2003. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 2101. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on abstract and theoretical organizational concepts; space, form, function and resolution of materials and structural systems.

Name: Architectural Design IV
Desc: ARCH 2006. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 2102. Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on process, materials theory, site inventory and analysis and impact of regionalism.

Name: Architectural Techniques
Desc: ARCH 2001. Exploration of drawing, modeling and digital applications to the design process; specific techniques will vary based on projects assigned in ARCH 2001.

Name: Architectural Topics
Desc: ARCH 2002. Use of case studies to contrast the meanings of buildings designed in urban or rural environments.

Name: History of Architecture I
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. The development of architectural and spatial forms as they relate to changing perceptions of self, society and the natural world. From prehistory to the 13th century.

Name: History of Architecture II
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. The development of architectural and spatial forms as they relate to changing perceptions of self, society and the natural world from the Italian Renaissance through modern times.

Name: Honors: Architectural Design III
Desc: ARCH 2003; Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 2001. 12 hrs. studio.

Name: Honors: Architectural Design IV
Desc: ARCH 2006. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 2002. Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio.

Name: Appreciation of Architecture
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Architectural concepts and principles; architectural vocabulary, style, symbolic form characteristics, spatial character and refinements.

Name: Supervised Independent Study and Research
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Investigation of areas of interest not covered in other departmental courses.

Name: Architectural Design V
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 3101. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on programming, site analysis and planning, functional planning and resolution of structural and architectural systems.
Reqs: approval for advancement to upper division in architecture

Name: Architectural Design VI
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 3102. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on planning buildings while incorporating studies in the technologies of materials, structure, environmental controls, lighting and acoustics.

Name: Architectural Structures I
Desc: Building structural mechanics, statics, strength of materials and theories of structures.
Reqs: approval for advancement to upper division in architecture

Name: Architectural Structures II
Desc: Design and application of timber and steel structures in architecture.

Name: Architectural Systems
Desc: Detailed treatment of construction materials and systems, with emphasis on large scale application of enclosure systems and steel and concrete structures.
Reqs: approval for advancement to upper division in architecture

Name: Environmental Control Systems
Desc: Principles and practices of selection and design of mechanical systems, including lighting, electrical distributions, acoustics, plumbing, vertical transportation and fire suppression.
Reqs: approval for advancement to upper division in architecture

Name: Honors: Architectural Design V
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 3001. 12 hrs. studio.
Reqs: approval for advancement to upper division in architecture

Name: Honors: Architectural Design VI
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 3002. 12 hrs. studio.

Name: Delta Research Colloquium
Desc: 1 hr. seminar. Students from multiple disciplines will discuss, develop, and present research conclusions related to applied delta research through faculty lecture, guest lecture, and student project presentations.
Reqs: open to students with credit for OCS 2050 and ARCH 4444, or by permission of instructor

Name: Architectural Design VII
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 4101. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the advancement of sustainable communities through analysis, building design and the study of socially responsible approaches to development and building practice.

Name: Architectural Design VIII
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 4102 or ARCH 4202. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the design of urban buildings based on the advancement of urban systems through analysis, building design, and the study of socially responsible approaches to development and building practice.
Reqs: ARCH 3002 or ARCH 3102 or permission of instructor

Name: Intensive Design Studio
Desc: rch program. 12 hrs. studio. Introduction to design, analysis, and the development of basic architectural skills.

Name: History of Architecture III
Desc: Majors only or by permission of department. Development of architectural and spatial forms as they relate to changing perceptions of self, society and the natural world in the 20th century.

Name: Architectural Structures III
Desc: Design and application of concrete structures in architecture.

Name: Advanced Architectural Technology
Desc: Seminar relating to topics of architectural technologies including, but not limited to building structures, environmental concerns, electronic transfer of information.

Name: Issues in Sustainability
Desc: Examination of issues in sustainability as they relate to the practice of architecture.

Name: Advanced 20th Century Architectural History
Desc: Topics in 20th century architectural history and theory; writing component.

Name: Urban Design and Planning
Desc: Fundamentals of urban morphology in relation to historical, social, political and economic systems.

Name: Community Design Studies
Desc: Study of community design and community-based practice with emphasis on contemporary participatory action research and techniques.

Name: Restoration Studies
Desc: Theory and methodology of architectural restoration; tools and techniques of restoration.

Name: Honors: Architectural Design VII
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 4001. 12 hrs. studio. Theory and methodology of architectural restoration; tools and techniques of restoration.

Name: Honors: Architectural Design VIII
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 4002 or ARCH 4202. 12 hrs. studio.
Reqs: ARCH 3002 or ARCH 3102 or ARCH 4001 or ARCH 4101 or permission of instructor

Name: Recording Historic Structures
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Hands-on field and laboratory experience in current methods of documenting historic buildings, including hand methods, photography and photogrammetry.

Name: Architectural Design VIII Off-Campus
Desc: For off-campus study only. Permission of department required. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 4002 or ARCH 4102. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the design of single or multiple buildings in an urban setting.

Name: Selected Topics in Architecture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Studies in various subjects related to architecture.

Name: Principles and Practices of Land Development
Desc: Environmental, physical and financial aspects of land development.

Name: Vernacular Architecture and Material Culture
Desc: See ANTH 4440.

Name: The D.E.L.T.A. Studio
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Interdisciplinary design projects investigating physical issues affecting the Gulf of Mexico Coastal Plain, Lower Mississippi Alluvial Delta, and coastal environment tectonics as defined by the material culture and how it contributes to the design and conceptual framework of projects.
Reqs: open to students with credit for OCS 2050 or by permission of instructor

Name: Research Methods
Desc: Major research methods in architecture; hypothesis formulation and testing, data gathering and analysis.

Name: Advanced Computer Aided Architectural Graphics
Desc: The development and application of advanced computer-based architectural design and communication skills.

Name: Option Design Studio
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. 12 hrs. studio. Option studios are topical in nature and engage contemporary issues in architectural practice and research.
Reqs: ARCH 3002 or ARCH 3102 or ARCH 7004 or permission of instructor

Name: Comprehensive Architectural Design
Desc: Coreq.: ARCH 5005. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 5101. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the comprehensive design of a single building integrating material selection, mechanical, acoustical, structural, lighting and two- and three-dimensional studies.
Reqs: ARCH 4002 or ARCH 4102 or ARCH 4202 and ARCH 5000 or ARCH 5100

Name: Architectural Design Concentration
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 5102 or ARCH 5202. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on architectural problems developed around faculty expertise and emerging opportunities in the profession.

Name: Advanced Architectural Topics
Desc: Seminar relating to various topics in architecture; writing component.

Name: Concentration Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Various topics relating to architectural issues.

Name: Advanced Architectural Techniques
Desc: ARCH 5001, ARCH 5101 or ARCH 7006. Preparation and correlation of working drawings, specifications and/or manuals associated with various project phases and through a digital workflow.
Reqs: ARCH 4002 or ARCH 4102 or ARCH 4202 or ARCH 7005; Coreq

Name: Professional Practice
Desc: Exploration and analysis of project acquisition, contract negotiations, governmental regulations, personnel, office management and the architect’s societal role.

Name: Community Design Practicum
Desc: Minimum 280 hours of supervised experience. Supervised learning experience in the Office of Community Design and Development or approved off-campus site with emphasis on pre-professional services for community-based projects.
Reqs: ARCH 3002 or ARCH 3102, LA 3002 or permission of department

Name: HONORS: Option Design Studio
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 5000. 12 hrs. studio.
Reqs: ARCH 3002 or ARCH 3102 or ARCH 7004 or permission of instructor

Name: Honors: Comprehensive Architectural Design
Desc: Coreq.: ARCH 5005. 12 hrs. studio. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 5001.
Reqs: ARCH 4002 or ARCH 4102 or ARCH 4202 or ARCH 5000 or ARCH 5100

Name: Honors: Architectural Design Concentration
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 5002 or ARCH 5202.

Name: Architectural Design Concentration Off-Campus
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. For off-campus study only. Credit will not be given for this course and ARCH 5002 or ARCH 5102. Permission of department required. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on architectural problems developed around faculty expertise and emerging opportunities in the profession.

Name: Graduate Design Studio I
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. The use of space and form in relation to concept in the exploration of basic architectural elements.

Name: Graduate Design Studio II
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the design of buildings in a variety of physical settings.

Name: Graduate Design Studio III
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on architectural programming and the design of buildings incorporating technologies of materials and various architectural systems.

Name: Graduate Design Studio IV
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the design of buildings incorporating technologies of environmental systems.

Name: Graduate Design Studio V
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Introduction to contextual building design in an urban setting with emphasis on site and context analysis and community planning in a collaborative working environment.

Name: Graduate Design Studio VI
Desc: Coreq.: ARCH 5005. Credit will not be given for both this course and ARCH 8000. 12 hrs. studio. Emphasis on the synthesis of all issues addressed in previous studios in the comprehensive design of buildings.

Name: Modern Architecture: History and Theory
Desc: The development of architectural history and theory from the nineteenth to the mid-twentieth century.

Name: Contemporary Architecture: History and Theory
Desc: The development of architectural history and theory from the mid-twentieth century to the present day.

Name: Seminar in Architecture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics in architecture.

Name: Architectural Studies/Research
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Selected readings and/or research under the supervision of graduate faculty.
Reqs: written consent of School of Architecture Graduate Committee

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: ”S”/”U”grading. Credit will not be given for both this course and ARCH 7006.

Name: Introduction to Ceramics: Handbuilding
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Exploration of hand-building techniques, surface applications and kiln firing.
Reqs: majors/minors only, ART 1009 or ART 1012 or consent of instructor

Name: Introduction to Ceramics: Wheel Throwing
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Problems in ceramic forming techniques, mixing of clays and glazes and kiln firing.
Reqs: ART 1009 or ART 1012 or consent of instructor

Name: Basic Jewelry/Metalsmithing
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Piercing, construction, cold connection, soldering, forming, and stone setting; studio problems in bronze, copper, and sterling silver.

Name: Intermediate Jewelry/Metalsmithing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6, 12 hrs. studio. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Intermediate studio work in jewelry/metalsmithing involving model making and the casting processes.

Name: Intermediate Ceramics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2662. 6 hrs. studio. Studio techniques and issues in ceramics; continued investigation of hand-building and wheel-throwing.
Reqs: ART 1661 and/or ART 1662 and ART 1762 or permission of instructor

Name: Honors: Intermediate Ceramics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Credit will not be given for this course and ART ART 2661. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio.
Reqs: ART 1661 and/or ART 1662 and ART 1762 or permission of instructor

Name: Special Studies in Ceramics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. of studio. Advanced studio work in predetermined area of specialization with emphasis on formulation of clay bodies, glazes and practice of kiln operation, building and maintenance.
Reqs: ART 1661 or ART 1662 or permission of instructor

Name: Special Studies in Jewelry/Metalsmithing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 15 hrs. of credit.
Reqs: consent of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Advanced Jewelry/Metalsmithing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 15 hrs. of credit. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6, 12 hrs. studio. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Advanced studio work in one specific process such as: forging, forming, reproduction processes, advanced construction techniques, CAD/CAM, mechanisms, clasps, chain construction. Emphasis on historical and contemporary aesthetic in art jewelry and metalsmithing.
Reqs: consent of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Advanced Ceramics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Studio problems in ceramics.
Reqs: ART 2661, ART 2761, and permission of instructor

Name: Senior Project
Desc: hrs. of credit in ART 4641 or ART 4651 or ART 4661 or ART 4761. This course is not offered during the summer term. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Proposal and execution of a ceramics project under the direction of a major professor during the final semester of the senior year.

Name: Graduate Ceramics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 36 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 or 12 hrs. studio each.

Name: Digital Art I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture/2 hrs. studio. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Introduction to digital applications in art.

Name: Creative Coding
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. An introduction to computer programming for creative applications focusing on languages useful for web development.

Name: Moving Image
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Introduction to digital video production and editing systems; concepts will include basic compositing and motion graphics.

Name: Virtual Space
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Introduction to modeling and animation using three-dimensional objects and spaces in a virtual environment.

Name: Intermediate 3D Modeling
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. 3D character and prop modeling through digital sculpting and painting with emphasis on anatomy, form, and style in addition to texture creation, lighting, and rendering.

Name: Intermediate 3D Animation
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. 3D character animation and rigging focusing on body mechanics, acting, and dialog with emphasis placed on communicating personality and emotion.

Name: Typography for Visual Communications
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Historical overview of type and letter forms; introduction to professional typography in print and digital environments; primary focus will be applications to contemporary communications.
Reqs: consent of instructor and ART 1008 or ART 1011, ART 2050

Name: Digital Media Capstone
Desc: Credit will not be given for both EE 4859 and ART 4059. 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Culminating capstone project experience requiring interdisciplinary teams to prototype a digital media work or application.
Reqs: at least 15 hours credit towards the Digital Media-Arts minor

Name: Advanced Moving Image
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Exploration of advanced topics in video through workshops, screenings, and selected readings on time based media; topics will also include intermediate compositing and motion graphics.
Reqs: ART 2220, ART 2230 and permission of instructor

Name: Virtual Space and Motion
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Investigation of advanced techniques and issues in the creation of virtual narrative and animation in three-dimensional space.
Reqs: ART 2220, ART 2230 and permission of instructor

Name: Topics in Digital Art
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit.

Name: Digital Art Studio
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Advanced studio focused on the development of a large scale digital media project.

Name: Digital Art Practicum
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. An internship or supervised learning experience at a digital art related firm or agency.
Reqs: completion of all 2000-level digital art courses and consent of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Digital Art Synthesis
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Advanced studio focused on the completion and presentation of a large scale digital media project.

Name: Digital Imaging for Visual Communications
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Basic exploration of digital photographic technology and its application in communications; topics include: scanning, image processing and manipulation, digital filtering, and imaging peripherals; emphasis on emerging technology and preparing images for multimedia applications.
Reqs: consent of instructor and ART 2551 or equivalent

Name: Digital Art Praxis
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 24 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Collaborative research, development, and implementation of experimental digital media project.

Name: Digital Art Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 21 sem. hrs. of credit. Creative and theoretical project critique, discussion of contemporary issues and research-based investigations in digital media.

Name: Introduction to Fine Arts
Desc: [LCCN: CART 1023, Introduction to Visual Arts] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Fundamental problems and concepts of art in the fields of design, sculpture, graphics, painting and ceramics, as related to home, community, religion, commerce and industry.

Name: Introduction to Two-Dimensional Composition
Desc: [LCCN: CART 1113, Art Structure/2-D Design] Credit will not be given for both this course and ART 1011. 6 hrs. studio. An introduction to two-dimensional art and design practices using a variety of materials and techniques.

Name: Introduction to Three-Dimensional Art
Desc: [LCCN: CART 1123, 3-D Design] Credit will not be given for both this course and ART 1012. 6 hrs. studio. Introduction to fundamental concepts of three-dimensional art; projects will explore line, plane, spatial organization, surface and volume using a variety of materials and techniques.

Name: Introduction to Drawing
Desc: [LCCN: CART 2203, Beginning Drawing] Credit will not be given for both this course and ART 1847. 6 hrs. lab. Drawing from observation and invented images; various drawing materials, methods and subjects are explored as a mean to develop perceptual ability and descriptive drawing skills; drawing concepts including composition, line, perspective, shape, space and value.

Name: Two-Dimensional Design
Desc: 4 hrs. lab; 1 hr. lecture. Studio projects in visual literacy; fundamentals of the structure of two-dimensional works of art; principles of organization and elements of art; role of the visual arts in society.
Reqs: majors and interior design majors only

Name: Three-Dimensional Design
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ART 1009. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Introduction to the fundamental concepts of three-dimensional art. Projects will explore line, plane, spatial organization, surface and volume; using a variety of materials and techniques.

Name: Studio Art Abroad
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Studio art fundamentals within the specific medium of faculty members participating in Academic Programs Abroad.

Name: Special Topics in Art
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 semester hrs. of credit when topics vary. 6 hrs. studio. Introductory studio work in a predetermined area of specialization.

Name: Digital Art II
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Introductory work in digital animation and multimedia applications.

Name: Special Topics in Art
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 semester hrs. of credit when topics vary. 6 hrs. studio. Intermediate level studio work in a predetermined area of specialization.

Name: Independent Study in Studio Art
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Proposal and execution of an individual creative research project under the direction of a studio art faculty member.

Name: Digital Art III
Desc: Primarily for students majoring in art. 6 hrs. studio. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Intermediate work in digital animation.

Name: Digital Art IV
Reqs: ART 4050 or equivalent and permission of instructor

Name: Performance Art
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Multi-disciplinary “live” art studio problems utilizing a diverse range of media such as drawing and painting, sound and movement and poetry; lectures and discussions on the history of performance art.

Name: First Year Seminar
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. First-semester orientation to artistic and campus resources; emphasizes skills for the effective development of a studio practice.

Name: Group Critique
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Group critique format as a means to critically develop creative work.

Name: Special Topics Graduate Studio
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Individual creative research in a predetermined area of specialization.

Name: Independent Study Graduate Studio
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 semester hours of credit. 6 hrs. studio Proposal and execution of an individual creative research project under the direction of a studio art faculty member.

Name: Graduate Teaching Seminar
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Emphasizes the connection between pedagogical theory and practice; development of course materials for teaching art foundations.

Name: Visiting Artist Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit. Seminar with visiting artist: contemporary art, criticism, individual and group projects.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Basic Design
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Basic design projects that investigate form and the delineation of space within a two-dimensional field; emphasis on hand skills and traditional design media.

Name: Typography I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2545. 6 hrs. studio. Drawn letter form studies; traditional and contemporary variations.
Reqs: ART 1008 or ART 1011, ART 2050 and permission of instructor

Name: Honors: Typography I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2544. 6 hrs. studio.
Reqs: ART 1008 or ART 1011, ART 2050 and permission of instructor

Name: Color Design
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Color as a functional design element of perception and visual communication.
Reqs: ART 1008 or ART 1011 and permission of instructor

Name: Graphic Design I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2555. 6 hrs. studio. Professional procedures for solving design problems from first ideas through finished presentations; emphasis on the integration of letter forms and graphics.
Reqs: ART 1008 or ART 1011, ART 2544 or ART 2545 or ART 2551, and permission of instructor

Name: Honors: Graphic Design I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2554. 6 hrs. studio.
Reqs: ART 1008 or ART 1011, ART 2544 or ART 2545 or ART 2551 and permission of instructor

Name: Graphic Abstraction
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Simplification of pictorial images as graphic elements.
Reqs: ART 1008 or ART 1011, ART 2050, and permission of instructor

Name: Digital Imaging Techniques
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Digital imaging technology and its application in art and design areas; scanning, image processing, manipulation, digital filtering and imaging peripherals; emphasis on digital imaging aesthetics, emerging technology and preparing images for printed and multimedia applications.
Reqs: ART 2544 or ART 2545 or ART 2551, and permission of instructor

Name: Experimental Design
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Advanced experimental work in a predetermined area of graphic design.
Reqs: consent of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Prepress Production Techniques
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Studio techniques related to production problems in the graphic design profession; typesetting methods; primary printing processes, mechanical and digital systems.
Reqs: ART 2554 or ART 2555, and consent of instructor

Name: Typography II
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Developing and understanding typographic skills through functional and aesthetic use of type and its application within the digital environment.
Reqs: ART 2554 or ART 2555, and consent of instructor

Name: Special Studies in Graphic Design
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Advanced work in a predetermined area of specialization.
Reqs: consent of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Graphic Design II
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Problems in design related to the professional design field; methods of reproduction, exhibition techniques and digital applications.

Name: Graphic Design III
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Principles of visual communication through graphic design; problems in design theory and application.
Reqs: ART 3553, ART 4551, and permission of instructor

Name: Interactive Media for Visual Communications
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Basic application of interactive digital technology: design and application of Internet-based communications, hypermedia language, virtual reality, sound and visual synchronization, communications standards, emerging technologies and multimedia; special focus on the study and application of interactive multimedia theory.
Reqs: consent of instructor and ART 4550 or equivalent

Name: Survey of Graphic Design
Desc: Overview of graphic design, covering its development from its inception to the present; its relationship to other arts; and the cultural influences and technological advances that have shaped its present role in the field of visual communications.

Name: Senior Graphic Design
Desc: May not be taken concurrently with ART 4555. This course is not offered during the summer term. 6 hrs. studio. Design projects investigating problems of visual communication; individual and group projects with professional-level presentations.

Name: Interactive Multimedia Design
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Design and application of interactive multimedia; Application of user interface and user experience design strategies, user research methods and prototyping, communication and accessibility standards, emerging technologies and multimedia; emphasis on study and application of interaction design theory.

Name: Graphic Design Internship
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Internship approved by graphic design faculty committee.
Reqs: permission of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Graduate Graphic Design
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 36 sem. hrs. of credit. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 or 12 hrs. studio each.

Name: Graduate Research in Design
Desc: 6 hrs. studio.

Name: Graduate Research in Design
Desc: 6 hrs. studio.

Name: Graduate Research in Design
Desc: 6 hrs. studio.

Name: Drawing and Composition
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ART 1010. 6 hrs. studio. Basic principles of observation; emphasis on graphic analysis and delineation of spatial structure.
Reqs: majors and Interior Design majors or permission of instructor

Name: Beginning Figure Drawing
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Studies from the live model; introduction of graphic representation, structure and form.
Reqs: ART 1010 or ART 1847 or permission of instructor

Name: Introduction to Painting
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Basic studio practice and theory in painting; traditional and modern materials and terminology; value and color experiences involving simple forms and space.

Name: Honors: Painting II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2881. 6 hrs. studio.

Name: Figure Drawing II
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Continuing studies in life drawing.

Name: Painting II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2800. 6 hrs. studio. Studio problems in painting directed toward conceptual attitudes, analysis of structure and color in composition; individual criticism, class discussion.

Name: Water Media Painting
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Objects and landscape; composition in water-soluble media on paper.
Reqs: ART 1847 or ART 1010 or permission of instructor

Name: Senior Project Painting
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Proposal and execution of a painting project under the direction of a major professor.

Name: Special Studies in Painting and Drawing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 hrs. of studio. Advanced studio work in a predetermined area of specialization.
Reqs: majors/minors only, consent of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Figure Painting
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Studies from the life model.

Name: Painting III
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Contemporary concepts in painting; individual criticism, class discussion.

Name: Advanced Water Media Painting
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Advanced studio work in water-soluble media on paper.

Name: Painting IV
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Research into advanced visual schema through self-initiated studio problems.

Name: Landscape Painting
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. On-location and studio development of the landscape.

Name: Advanced Figure Drawing III
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Study of the human figure using various media.

Name: Advanced Drawing Workshop
Desc: hrs. of drawing or permission of instructor. May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Directed studies for the advanced student.

Name: Graduate Painting
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 36 sem. hrs. of credit. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 or 12 hrs.

Name: Reading Seminar
Desc: Pass/fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. 3 hrs. seminar. Readings and discussion of formal and conceptual issues in the visual arts.
Reqs: students currently enrolled in the graduate painting program

Name: Basic Photography
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Basic concepts and techniques of black and white photography; emphasis on photography as a visual art.

Name: Intermediate Photography
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2997. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Continued investigation of basic photographic principles, utilizing specific subject areas drawn from major themes in visual art.

Name: Honors: Intermediate Photography
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2996. 6 hrs. studio.

Name: Advanced Photography
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Technical investigation of contemporary materials; critical testing of equipment, films and printing papers; emphasis on process control as an expressive tool.
Reqs: ART 2996 and ART 3996 and permission of instructor

Name: Digital Color Photography I
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Introduction to color theory, color perception, and contemporary color printing materials; emphasis on color print portfolio.

Name: Special Studies in Photography
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Individual creative research in a predetermined area of specialization.
Reqs: ART 3994 or ART 3996 and permission of instructor

Name: Large Format Photography
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Fundamentals of the view camera.
Reqs: ART 2996 and ART 3996 or permission of instructor

Name: Digital Color Photography II
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Continued investigation of color photography; digital tools and printing processes.

Name: Alternative Photographic Processes
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Exploration of alternative photographic processes; emphasis on historical printmaking techniques.
Reqs: ART 3994 or ART 3996 and permission of instructor

Name: Senior Project: Photography
Desc: To be taken in the last full semester of the senior year. This course is not offered during the summer term. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Proposal for and execution of an independent photography project under the direction of a major professor.

Name: Graduate Photography
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 36 sem. hrs. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 or 12 hrs. of studio. Emphasis on personal vision and contemporary issues in photography.

Name: Introduction to Printmaking
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Basic concepts, materials and processes in printmaking.
Reqs: majors/minors only, ART 1008 or ART 1011 and ART 1010 or ART 1847

Name: Silkscreen Printing
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Basic silkscreen techniques using stencils, hand-drawn and photomechanical applications and digital transparencies.

Name: Papermaking
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Introduction to the art and technology of making paper by hand.

Name: Relief Printmaking
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Investigation of relief printing techniques.

Name: Intermediate Printmaking
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2361. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Comprehensive investigation of printmaking concepts, materials, and techniques; emphasis on color printing.

Name: Honors: Intermediate Printmaking
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Credit will not be given for this course and ART 2360. 6 hrs. studio.

Name: Intaglio
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Intaglio printmaking processes, including drypoint, soft ground, line etching and aquatint methods.

Name: Lithography
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Planagraphic processes in lithography emphasizing drawing with crayon, wash and transfer methods.

Name: Digital Printmaking
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Exploration of personal imagery by means of digital and photomechanical application for contemporary printmaking.

Name: Senior Project: Printmaking
Desc: of 4000-level printmaking courses and senior status. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. This course is not offered during the summer term. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Proposal and execution of a printmaking project under the direction of a major professor.

Name: Special Studies in Printmaking
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. To be taken in the last semester of the senior year. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 or 12 hrs. studio. Individual creative research in a predetermined area of specialization.

Name: Monotype and Monoprint
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Creative image development using monotype and monoprint processes, with a focus on making unique prints.
Reqs: ART 1847 and ART 1360 or permission of instructor

Name: Advanced Book Arts
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 or 12 hrs. studio. Advanced exploration, design and production in the book arts; emphasis on self-initiated book art problems.

Name: Letterpress Printmaking
Desc: May be taken for a max. 6 sem. hrs of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Fundamental concepts, design and processes using digital and traditional letterpress printing technologies.

Name: Large Format Printmaking
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. studio. Advanced work in printmaking emphasizing multiple color and mixed media applications for creating large-scale prints.

Name: Digital & Alternative Print Media
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. 6 hrs. studio. Advanced investigation of digital, photomechanical and alternative processes in printmaking.

Name: Graduate Printmaking
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 36 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 or 12 hrs .

Name: Introduction to Sculpture
Desc: Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Introduction to a variety of materials and techniques for generating sculptural form.
Reqs: ART 1009 or ART 1012 or permission of instructor

Name: Intermediate Sculpture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Studies in sculpture involving various materials and methods. May include metal fabrication, metal casting and mixed media.
Reqs: ART 1762 and ART 1661 or ART 1662, or permission of instructor

Name: Special Studies in Sculpture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 or 12 hrs. studio. Advanced studio work in predetermined area of specialization.
Reqs: consent of instructor based on review of student’s portfolio

Name: Advanced Sculpture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. 6 hrs. studio. Studies with various materials and methods, course content may include kinetics, installation, and mixed media.
Reqs: ART 2761 and credit or registration in ART 2661, or permission of instructor

Name: Senior Project: Sculpture
Desc: hrs. of credit from ART 4761. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. To be taken in the last semester of the senior year. 6 hrs. studio. Independent study requiring the proposal and execution of a sculpture project, under the direction of a major professor.

Name: Graduate Sculpture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 36 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for studio fee associated with course. Registration for all multiple-credit courses taken for over three credits in a given semester will require the prior permission of the instructor. 6 or 12 hrs.

Name: Theory and Processes of Cultural Preservation
Desc: May be taken for a maximum of 6 credit hours. 3 hrs seminar. Research and discussion seminar in which subject areas in cultural preservation are represented through presentations together with readings and emphasis on the evolution of theories and current “best practices” in each area.

Name: Research Methods
Desc: Survey of qualitative and quantitative methodologies including the selection of research topic, definition of primary questions and terminologies, determination of relevant data types and collection strategies, and preparation of project research strategy including development of a research bibliography and interviews with potential thesis committee members.

Name: Digital Culture
Desc: Provides a common, theoretical ground for the exploration of Cultural Preservation with respect to digital culture, and reviews key digital approaches, tools, representational techniques, and resources for advancing scholarship in Cultural Preservation through case studies exploring tactics and strategies for creating and deploying computational resources in research.

Name: Introduction to Material Culture Studies
Desc: Research and discussion seminar on the study of materiality as an integral dimension of culture through focus on the social and cultural roles of physical things, the built environment and cultural landscape.

Name: Special Topics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit with consent of graduate advisor. Investigation of areas of interest not covered in other departmental courses.

Name: Supervised Research
Desc: Permission of instructor.  “S”/”U” grading. May be taken for a max. 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Independent research directed by a member of the student’s thesis committee exploring defining attributes of the proposed thesis topic.

Name: Advanced Research
Desc: Permission of instructor. “S”/”U” grading. May be taken for a max. 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Focused research based on thesis proposal under the direction of designated faculty directed toward student’s area of specialization.

Name: Thesis Definition
Desc: Permission of instructor.  “S”/”U” grading. Development of a thesis WORKPLAN including identification of thesis committee (At least three faculty, inclusive of chair); development of thesis prospectus; identification of research question(s) and articulation of research methodology. Successful completion required for entry into the Third Year of the program.

Name: Thesis Preparation
Desc: Permission of instructor. “S”/”U” grading. Production of first thesis chapter based on research WORKPLAN developed in DART 9001 and supervision of faculty.

Name: Thesis Completion
Desc: Permission of instructor. “S”/”U” grading. Completion of approved thesis based on research WORKPLAN development in DART 9001 representing student’s area of research interest.

Name: Historical Survey of the Arts
Desc: [LCCN: CART 2103, Art History I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Prehistoric, Near-Eastern, Greek, Roman and medieval art.

Name: Historical Survey of the Arts
Desc: [LCCN: CART 2113, Art History II] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Renaissance to modern art.

Name: Art of the Ancient Near East and Egypt
Desc: Development of art and architecture in the ancient Near East and Egypt over three millennia; influences of one culture on another and subsequent contributions to Western art.

Name: Classical Art and Archaeology
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Survey of the art and archaeology of the ancient Greek and Roman worlds, ca. 1000 BCE-300 CE.

Name: Survey of Asian Art
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. The arts of China, India and Japan in relation to religious and philosophical beliefs that affected their production.

Name: Italian Renaissance Art
Desc: Italian painting, sculpture and architecture from 1400 to 1600.

Name: Survey of Modern to Contemporary Art
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Survey of major art movements from the 1880s to the present day.

Name: Introduction to Museum Studies
Desc: Introduction to art and history museums, their missions and functions; practical aspects and philosophical issues related to museums.

Name: History of Prints
Desc: History of prints from the 15th century to the present.

Name: The Art of Rome
Desc: Development of architecture, sculpture and painting from Rome’s early beginnings (600-200 B.C.) to the end of the 4th century.

Name: Early Christian and Byzantine Art
Desc: Painting, sculpture and architecture of the Christian era through 12th century Byzantium.

Name: Romanesque Art
Desc: Architecture, sculpture, manuscripts and painting from the 9th through the 12th centuries in France, Germany and England.

Name: Early Greek Art
Desc: Greek art to the time of the Persian Wars.

Name: Later Greek Art
Desc: Greek art from the time of Themistocles to the age of Augustus.

Name: Gothic Art
Desc: Architecture, sculpture and painting of Northern Europe from 1150 to 1450.

Name: Early Netherlandish and German Painting
Desc: Painting in the Netherlands and Germany in the 15th and 16th century.

Name: Studies in Art History
Desc: May be repeated for credit when topics vary. Advanced work in a predetermined area of specialization.

Name: History of Modern Design
Desc: Aesthetic theory and stylistic evolution of decorative arts from mid-19th century to the present; emphasis on crafts, architectural decoration, furniture, interior design and industrial design; Victorian period, arts and crafts movement, art nouveau, Bauhaus and international style.

Name: Early Renaissance Painting in Italy
Desc: The origins and early development of Italian Renaissance painting in Florence and Siena.

Name: High Renaissance and Mannerist Painting in Italy
Desc: The climax and aftermath of Italian Renaissance painting in Florence, Rome and Venice.

Name: Northern Baroque Painting
Desc: Dutch, Flemish and French painting of the 17th century.

Name: Southern Baroque Art
Desc: Painting, sculpture and architecture of the 17th century in Italy and Spain.

Name: 18th Century European Art
Desc: European art from the age of absolutism to the beginning of the Napoleonic era, including Rococo art, the influence of Enlightenment thought, the rediscovery of classical antiquity, Neoclassicism and the impact of the French Revolution on the visual arts.

Name: African Art
Desc: History of the traditional arts and architecture of Sub-Saharan Africa, emphasizing geographical origins, religious context, social practices, and aesthetic choices that defined the creation of the objects and monuments under investigation.

Name: Chinese Painting
Desc: History of Chinese painting from prehistoric times through the 20th century.

Name: Japanese Art
Desc: History of Japanese painting, sculpture, architecture and ceramics from prehistoric times through the early 20th century.

Name: Indian Art
Desc: History of Indian painting, sculpture and architecture from prehistoric times through the 16th century.

Name: Islamic Art and Architecture
Desc: Architecture, painting, and sculpture in regions associated with the emergence and prominence of Islam as a world religion from the 7th/8th century to the present.

Name: 19th Century European Painting
Desc: History of painting in European countries from the French Revolution (1789) to 1900; emphasis on neoclassicism, romanticism, realism, impressionism, post-impressionism and symbolism.

Name: Early 20th Century European Art
Desc: History of painting and sculpture in European countries from 1900 to 1960; emphasis on Fauvism, Cubism, geometric abstraction, Futurism, Dada and Surrealism, German Expressionism, British figurative art, and the School of Paris.

Name: American Art to 1900
Desc: North American painting, architecture, and sculpture from the colonial beginnings to 1900; emphasis on painting.

Name: Postmodern Art and Theory
Desc: Major movements and theories in art from World War II through the present, including the wane of modernism and the rise and fall of postmodernism.

Name: Latin American Art
Desc: Pre-Hispanic, colonial, and contemporary architecture, painting, sculpture, and related arts throughout Latin America.

Name: Issues in Contemporary Art
Desc: Principal issues confronting contemporary artists and the sources and theories behind the issues.

Name: Art of the American South: 1560-1861
Desc: History of architecture, painting, sculpture and decorative arts made in the states below the Mason-Dixon Line.

Name: History of Photography
Desc: History of photography from its inception in the 1830s until the present; technological development of the medium and its inherent aesthetics; interrelationships between photography and more traditional media.

Name: Video Art and Theory
Desc: Sources and origins of artists’ video from the late 1960s to the present day; consideration of theoretical, political and technological aspects; survey of single-channel, projected, installation and Internet formats for video art display.

Name: History of Electronic and Digital Art
Desc: Survey of art and technology focusing on the development of computer art and digital, interactive, and network-based art forms from the 1950s to the present.

Name: New Media Art Theory
Desc: A reading intensive course that introduces students to issues and theories of new media art.

Name: Independent Study in Art History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Undergraduate Seminar
Desc: Intensive reading, writing and classroom discussion; introduction to art-historical research and methodologies.
Reqs: ARTH 1440, ARTH 1441 and any four additional art history courses; only open to art history majors of junior and senior standing

Name: Art Theory and Criticism
Desc: Critics; building of art collections from ancient to modern times.

Name: Colloquium in Art Historical Methods
Desc: Pass-fail grading. An introduction to the historical development of the discipline of art history and art historical methodology.

Name: Special Topics in Art History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced topics in art history.
Reqs: graduate standing in art or consent of instructor

Name: Graduate Research Seminar in History of Art
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary; no more than 3 hrs. per semester.

Name: Graduate Research Seminar in History of Art
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary; no more than 3 hrs. per semester.

Name: Independent Study in Art History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading. Thesis preparation under the supervision of a graduate faculty member serving as the student’s major professor.

Name: Emergency Medical Response
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and KIN 2400. Role and responsibilities of the athletic trainer and other medical professionals in pre-hospital trauma care, components of EMS systems, medical/legal considerations, and communications in basic and advanced life support settings. Students will learn base skill components in emergency trauma response.
Reqs: Kinesiology majors and Coach Education minors only or permission of department

Name: Foundations of Patient Clinical Assessment
Desc: Athletic Training majors and Fitness Studies concentration students only or permission of instructor. Athletic Training majors must be accepted to professional (clinical) phase of program to enroll in this course. Designed to give the entry-level athletic training student in-depth instruction in appropriate techniques of soliciting, organizing, and interpreting patient-specific medical information from patients of all ages, cultures, socioeconomic backgrounds and abilities; patient observation; surface topography/palpation skills; and other basic evaluation techniques.

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Practice and Research I
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must be accepted to professional (clinical) phase of program to enroll in this course.
Reqs: ATRN 2000 and concurrent registration in ATRN 2001

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Practice and Research II
Desc: Athletic Training majors only or permission of instructor. Students must earn a grade of “B” or better in ATRN 2200 and receive a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. clinical. Understanding, demonstrating, and applying the broad base of knowledge/skills/abilities required of the athletic trainer in managing patient problems in assigned clinical rotations under direct preceptor supervision. Conducting a critical appraisal of medical literature and healthcare informatics using the Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) model.
Reqs: ATRN 2200 and credit or registration in ATRN 2505

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Immersion
Desc: Athletic Training majors must be accepted to professional (clinical) phase of program to enroll in this course.  Coreq.: ATRN 2200, ATRN 2201, ATRN 3200, ATRN 3201, ATRN 4200, or ATRN 4201. This course can be taken a maximum of 3 times. Under direct preceptor supervision the athletic training student will be provided the opportunity to understand, demonstrate, and apply the broad base of knowledge/skills/abilities required of the athletic trainer in managing patient problems during intensive clinical rotations during a non-traditional semester.

Name: Protective Taping/Bracing and Equipment Fitting
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must be accepted to professional (clinical) phase of program to enroll in this course. Basic principles associated with the design, construction, fit, maintenance, and reconditioning of protective equipment, including the rules and regulations established by the associations that govern its use; fit standard protective equipment following manufacturers’ guidelines; apply preventive taping and wrapping procedures, splints, braces, and other special protective devices.
Reqs: ATRN 2000 and concurrent registration in ATRN 2200

Name: Orthopedic Injury Evaluation Techniques I
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must have earned a grade of “B” or better in ATRN 2001 and ATRN 2200 and received a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. Specialized course in the initial on-field and clinical evaluation of orthopedic injuries and conditions of the lower extremities and the spine, including emergency care procedures, signs/symptoms, and treatment of various injuries/conditions.

Name: Physical Therapeutic Modalities
Desc: Athletic Training majors only or permission of instructor. Athletic Training majors must have earned a “B” or better in ATRN 2001 and ATRN 2200 amd received a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. Operational physics, physiological action, and clinical rationale/decision-making of various therapeutic agents used in physical rehabilitation settings. Application of various therapeutic agents such as light, sound, heat, cold, traction, and compression addressed using the evidence-based problem solving approach.

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Skills I
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must be accepted to professional (clinical) phase of program to enroll in this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Essential clinical knowledge and skills for the athletic training profession, including but not limited to, measurement of vital signs, flexibility, resistance exercises, and assisted and self-stretching techniques.
Reqs: ATRN 2000 and credit or registration in ATRN 2200

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Practice and Research III
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Students must earn a “B” or better in ATRN 2201 and receive a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. clinical. Understanding, demonstrating, and applying the broad base of knowledge/skills/abilities required of the athletic trainer in managing patient problems in assigned clinical rotations under direct preceptor supervision and applying previously acquired problem-solving skills in patient care. Understanding Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) through developing the clinical question using PICO method; reviewing and writing literature reviews; making written and oral presentations on selected patient conditions.

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Practice and Research IV
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Students must earn a “B” or better in ATRN 3200 and receive a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. clinical. Understanding, demonstrating, and applying the broad base of knowledge/skills/abilities required of the athletic trainer in managing patient problems in assigned clinical rotations under direct preceptor supervision and applying previously acquired problem-solving skills in patient care. Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) research design; common research measures; reliability and validity; research proposal design; formulating/writing methods; making written and oral presentations on selected patient conditions.

Name: Clinical Pharmacology
Desc: Athletic Training majors and Fitness Studies concentration students only or permission of instructor. Credit will not be given for this course and KIN 4605. Broad overview of pharmacology and nutritional supplementation with an emphasis on its application in healthcare practice. Fundamental principles of drug actions and interactions, the role of exercise in drug metabolism, clinical applications, and current issues in legal and ethical issues in drug administration.

Name: Orthopedic Injury Evaluation Techniques II
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must have earned a grade of “B” or better in ATRN 2505 and received a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. Specialized course in the initial on-field and clinical evaluation of orthopedic injuries and conditions of the upper extremities, cervical spine, head and face, including emergency care procedures, signs/symptoms, and treatment of various injuries/conditions.

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Skills II
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must have earned a grade of “B” or better in ATRN 2600 and received a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Acquisition, evaluation, synthesis, and application of advanced clinical skills in the prevention, clinical evaluation and diagnosis, immediate care and treatment, and rehabilitation and reconditioning of injuries and illnesses.

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Practice and Research V
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must have earned a grade of “B” or better in ATRN 3201 and received a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. clinical. Demonstrating advanced understanding, application and synthesis of broad base of knowledge/skills/abilities required of the athletic trainer in managing patient problems in assigned clinical rotations under direct preceptor supervision and applying previously acquired problem-solving skills with a focus on developing clinical decision-making and mid-level practitioner autonomy. Apply and interpret statistical techniques, analysis of variance, repeated measures design, and correlation analysis.

Name: Athletic Training Clinical Practice and Research VI
Desc: Athletic Training majors only. Athletic Training majors must have earned a grade of “B” or better in ATRN 4200 and received a favorable program progression evaluation to enroll in this course. 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. clinical.
