Desc: Analysis and design of prestressed concrete structural elements; full and partial prestressing; service ability and strength requirements; code criteria for bridges, buildings and other structures.

Name: Structural Engineering
Desc: Fundamental principles applied to planning, analysis and design of structures; introduction to computer-aided design approach to solving structural engineering problems using mainframe and microcomputer software.
Reqs: CE 4750, CE 4400 and CE 4410 or equivalent

Name: Indeterminate Structural Analysis
Desc: Analysis of statically indeterminate structures; methods of consistent deformations, elastic energy, virtual work, slope deflection, moment distribution and matrix formulations.

Name: Advanced Mechanics of Materials
Desc: Mechanics of materials; emphasis on needs of students interested in structural and machine design.
Reqs: CE 3400 and MATH 2065 (a grade of “C”or better is required in CE 3400)

Name: Hurricane Engineering
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CE 4745. Analysis and design of structures to resist hurricanes and other natural hazards; wind engineering, flood engineering; hazard phenomena and probabilities of occurrence; estimation of loads, loading provisions of major building codes and standards; damage mechanisms; design strategies for life safety and damage mitigation.

Name: Finite Element Methods
Desc: Basic theory of finite element methods with applications to a wide class of physical problems; matrix representation of stress, strain and material relations; principle of virtual work, discrete finite element models of continuous systems, construction of basic finite element algorithms and solutions of physical problems by using existing finite element computer programs.
Reqs: CE 3400 and either MATH 2065 or MATH 2090 or MATH 2070 (a grade of “C”or better is required in CE 3400)

Name: Design of Bridges
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Design of concrete and steel bridges in accordance with the latest AASHTO specifications; understanding of theoretical background behind the codes such as risk and reliability concepts; load rating of bridges and hands-on bridge design using computer software and hand calculations.
Reqs: CE 4410, CE 4750 and credit or registration in CE 4400 or CE 4420 or equivalent

Name: Geodetic and Photogrammetric Surveying
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Geodetic surveying for control surveys; photogrammetry and photointerpretation; calculation and field procedures used in ground control surveys and photogrammetry.

Name: Advanced Surveying
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Electronic surveying, simultaneous conveyances, subdivision surveys, flood plain management, state plane coordinates, solar azimuths, horizontal and vertical curves and earthwork.

Name: Control Surveying with GPS
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Understanding of spatial positioning capabilities available using satellite positioning system (GPS) receivers to calculate positions and to evaluate results; topics include classical geodetic methods, geometric geodesy, GPS receivers, static and kinematic GPS surveys, GPS computations, GPS mapping, vertical GPS and gravimetric geodesy; lab includes demonstration and hands-on use of GPS equipment and software.

Name: Boundary Surveying
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Designed to prepare engineers to complete Land Surveyor Registration requirements in Louisiana. Procedures and laws governing surveying of boundaries; emphasis on U. S. Land Survey System and Louisiana surveying laws and grids.

Name: Engineering Applications of Remote Sensing
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Photographic and digital image processes related to interpretation, principles, methods and techniques; engineering applications in materials, land use, energy, hydrology, transportation, geology, geomorphology and water resources.

Name: Geometric Design of Highways and Airports
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles of design and practice for rural and urban highway facilities and airport installations; design criteria and controls, capacity analysis, cross-section selection, design of horizontal and vertical alignment, intersections, interchanges and computer applications to design problems.

Name: Introduction to Asphalt Mixture Design
Desc: Principles of design and practice of hot mix asphalt mixture design; fundamental properties and analysis of binder rheology, aggregates and mixture design.
Reqs: CE 3400 and CE 3700 (a grade of “C”or better is required in CE 3400)

Name: Infrastructure Condition Assessment
Desc: Deterioration mechanisms in civil infrastructure systems, state-of-the-art nondestructive and sensoring technologies and applications, and use of new technologies to optimize infrastructure condition assessment and management.

Name: Fundamentals of Pavement Design
Desc: Flexible and rigid pavement design procedures; subgrade, base and surfacing characteristics; loads; stresses in pavement systems; material characterization; pavement response models; pavement performance models; structural design systems; effects of natural forces; and construction practices.

Name: Natural Hazards and the Built Environment
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CE 4445. Engineering impacts and implications of hurricanes, floods, earthquakes and other natural hazards on the built environment; effects of hazards on buildings and infrastructure systems; damage mechanisms; principles of wind, flood and seismic resistant design; hurricane evacuation and sheltering; engineering preparedness, response and recovery issues; design strategies for life safety and damage mitigation; building codes, land use zoning, floodplain management and insurance as mitigation tools.

Name: Professional Issues and Concept Design in Civil Engineering
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Engineering Graphics. Civil engineering design processes and systems; constructability and sustainability; use of consultants and contractors; project management, scheduling; economics and costing; ethical, health and safety; social, political and environmental considerations.

Name: Civil Engineering Design
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Design of civil engineering facilities; feasibility studies for subdivisions, airports, shopping centers, interchanges.
Reqs: credit in EVEG 3200, CE 3300, CE 3600, CE 4410 or equivalent, CE 4750 and credit in at least one of the following courses: CE 4200, CE 4300, CE 4400, CE 4600 or CE 4670

Name: Special Topics in Civil Engineering Science
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. More than one section may be taken concurrently for credit if topics differ. Topics in specialized civil engineering technical or analysis areas.

Name: Special Topics in Civil Engineering Design
Desc: May be taken for a maximum of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. More than one section of this course may be taken for credit concurrently when topics differ. Selected topics in civil engineering design.

Name: Theory and Operation of Wastewater Treatment Facilities
Desc: Theoretical principles, design criteria and analysis of treatment systems for domestic and industrial wastewaters and sludges; includes modeling of ideal biochemical reactors and design criteria for suspended-growth and biofilm processes applicable to applicable to wastewater treatment.
Reqs: EVEG 3110 or equivalent undergraduate preparation, or consent of instructor

Name: Physical/Chemical Processes in Water and Wastewater Treatment
Desc: Theoretical principles, design criteria, and analysis of physical and chemical unit operations in water and wastewater treatment; includes process applications in municipal and industrial settings.

Name: Advanced Topics in Water Quality and Treatment
Desc: Theory and application of advanced chemical principles to water quality and treatment; advanced equilibrium chemistry calculation; redox and colloidal chemistry as applied to environmental engineering.

Name: Advanced Topics in Biodegradation
Desc: Biological waste treatment applications in civil and environmental engineering, including current and emerging techniques for characterization, analysis, control and mathematical modeling of biological processes in municipal and industrial waste treatment systems.

Name: Biological Treatment of Recirculating Systems in Aquaculture
Desc: Theory, design and management of fixed film biofiltration processes used to recondition water in recirculating aquaculture systems and to provide tertiary treatment of domestic and industrial wastes characterized by low substrate regimes.

Name: Water Quality Simulations
Desc: Water quality modeling from a perspective of practicality and reliability; emphasis on model calibration and verification procedures and methodologies for quantifying uncertainties associated with model predictions.

Name: Advanced Hydraulics
Desc: Transportation of sediment, mixing current and other phenomena.

Name: Advanced Subsurface Hydrology and Hydraulics
Desc: Properties of porous media and fluid mixtures; dynamics of flow in single phase and multiphase flow systems; miscible and immiscible flow; basic concepts in saturated and unsaturated flow; solution procedures and applications in engineering design; physics and mathematics of transport processes in ground water; governing equations, solution procedures and applications; waste management and pollution control in subsurface environments.

Name: Modeling for Management of Groundwater
Desc: Identification of management problems; applications of systems theory to develop modeling techniques; analytical and numerical techniques of groundwater modeling; development and application of models and computer codes for simulation and optimization management of surface and groundwater systems.

Name: Modeling in Physical Hydrology
Desc: Principles of mathematical physics applied to hydrologic processes; methods of solution and model building; application to water resource problems.

Name: Advanced Geotechnical Engineering I: Stress Distribution, Seepage, Compressibility
Desc: Advanced theories of soil mechanics including stress distribution, seepage through soils, consolidation and settlement analysis; their applications in foundation engineering.

Name: Advanced Geotechnical Engineering II: Shear Strength, Bearing Capacity, Slope Stability
Desc: Shear strength of cohesive and cohesionless soils; stability problems including bearing capacity, slope stability and earth pressure distribution.

Name: Principles of Soil Behavior
Desc: Analysis of the effect of compositional and environ-mental factors on conduction phenomena, volume change behavior, deformation, strength stress-strain-time behavior in soils; soil composition, mineralogy, soil-water electrolyte systems in identification of influencing variables.

Name: Soil Improvement and Stabilization
Desc: Methodology and analysis of soil placement and improvement techniques; properties of mineral and organic salts, principles of soil compaction; methods of soil placement and improvement, chemical stabilization of soils, lime columns, stone columns, ultimate strength and bearing capacity of columns, compression by surcharging and drains, dynamic consolidation, vibro stabilization, thermal properties of soils, thermal stabilization.

Name: Theory and Practice of Geotechnical Laboratory Experiments
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab Theory and practice of laboratory experimental techniques used in geotechnical designs and analyses.
Reqs: CE 3300, CE 3350, and CE 4300 or equivalent

Name: Statically Indeterminate Structures
Desc: Analysis of statically indeterminate structures by modern methods.

Name: Advanced Concrete Theory
Desc: Analysis and design of reinforced concrete structural elements according to ultimate strength and limit design theories; prestressed indeterminate structures, shrinkage and creep.

Name: Structural Reliability
Desc: Fundamentals of reliability analysis of structures, load and resistance models, first-order reliability methods, probabilistic simulation techniques, calibration of design codes, system reliability, sensitivity analysis.

Name: Limit Analysis and Design
Desc: Analysis of steel structural behavior beyond elastic limit; design for ultimate load and use of load factors; application of linear programming and other computational techniques to optimization of structures designed by aid of concepts of limit analysis.

Name: Advanced Bridge Engineering
Desc: Recent advancement in bridge engineering in terms of analysis, design, and performance assessment, including both practice and research aspects.

Name: Structural Design for Dynamic Loads
Desc: Sources, intensities and methods of transmission of dynamic loads;response of structural systems to dynamic loading; modern computation techniques.

Name: Random Vibrations
Desc: Description and characterization of stochastic processes and random fields; classical random vibrations; response of linear elastic structural systems subject to stochastic excitations; structural design of random systems with applications to earthquake engineering and wind engineering.

Name: Finite Element Method in Engineering
Desc: Finite element method as an extended Ritz technique based on variational concepts for continua with applications to heat transfer, flow through porous media, fluid dynamics, elasticity, plasticity and stability and vibrations of elastic systems.

Name: Theory of Plates
Desc: Laterally loaded plates with various boundary conditions; approximate methods of plate analysis; large deflections of plates; elastic stability of plates.

Name: Solid Mechanics
Desc: Mathematical approach to statics and dynamics of deformable solids; tensors in curvilinear coordinates and variational calculus used to formulate elasticity and visco-elasticity theory; energy theorems and conservation laws.
Reqs: CE 4440 and credit or registration in MATH 4038 or MATH 4340 or ME 4563

Name: Plasticity and Viscoelasticity: Theory and Applications
Desc: Elements of the theory of plasticity; yield criteria and stress-strain relations for perfectly plastic and strain hardening materials; boundary value problems of plasticity; the slip-line theory and applications; constitutive equations of viscoelastic bodies and methods of solution of the boundary value problems of viscoelasticity.

Name: Mechanics of Composite Materials
Desc: Modeling of the mechanical behavior of fibrous composites for application to structural components; emphasis on interlaminar stresses, strength and failure theories, thermal effects, nonlinear material response, test methods and micromechanics.

Name: Damage Mechanics in Metals and Matrix Composites
Desc: Theoretical formulation and application of the different constitutive models to metals and metal matrix composites but with consideration of other materials; analysis of isotropic and anisotropic damage in materials.

Name: Transportation Engineering Data Collection Methods
Desc: Applications of sampling theory to data collections for transportation studies; determination of sample sizes; calculation of sampling error; expansion of sample survey data; survey methodologies, including interviews, counting programs, moving observer surveys, self-administered surveys. Simple panel surveys, etc.; design of survey instruments; conduct of data collection activities; data reduction techniques.

Name: Traffic Engineering Operations and Control
Desc: Traffic regulations, operational problems and engineering organization; theory and practice of application, design, operation and maintenance of traffic control devices; methods and devices studied include signing, markings, delineation and illumination, signals and signal systems, one-way street and unbalanced-flow street operations, speed zoning and freeway monitoring and control.

Name: Advanced Highway Design and Traffic Safety
Desc: Theoretical development and application of highway design principles, particularly as they relate to safety; analysis of accident statistics, diagnosis of high-hazard locations, risk management, tort liability and design treatments to address high accident locations; design principles of traffic calming, highway-railroad grade crossings, highway work zones and roadway cross-sections.

Name: Mass Transit Systems
Desc: Historical development, role in society, federal participation and institutional and legislative development of transit; description of conventional and innovative forms, and characteristics of users; planning, vehicle scheduling, environmental impact and energy consumption; system costs, pricing and financing; future systems and policies.

Name: Urban Transportation Policy and Planning
Desc: Introduction to and definition of transportation planning; transportation planning context; characteristics of travel; politics, decision-making and models of decision makers; systems analytic approaches to transportation planning; inventory, data management and spatial representation of data; land use and transportation; inputs to travel forecasting.

Name: Urban Transportation Planning Models
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Theories of travel demand modeling; conventional four-step modeling procedures; network development for highways, transit, high-occupancy vehicles; development of trip generation, distribution and mode-choice models; highway and transit assignment procedures; use of current software for microcomputers.

Name: Bituminous Materials and Mixtures
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Properties of asphalts and tars used in bituminous materials; historical developments; properties and design of bituminous mixtures; theory and practice of asphalt concrete mix design for pavements and bases including specification and construction methods for hot-mixes and surface treatments.

Name: Pavement Materials Characterization
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. laboratory and field test methods for determining engineering properties of pavement materials; interpretation of test data for selecting property values; use of fundamental engineering properties in design and analysis of pavement response to environmental and vehicular loads.

Name: Advanced Pavement Analysis and Design
Desc: Analysis and design of highway pavements with an advanced coverage of related topics, including flexible and rigid pavements, and with a focus on mechanistic-empirical pavement design methods.
Reqs: CE 4670 or consent of the instructor

Name: Pavement Management Systems
Desc: Concepts of pavement, evaluation of pavement performance, serviceability concepts, structural evaluation, safety, maintenance and rehabilitation, economic considerations, selection of alternatives and life cycle cost analysis.

Name: Special Topics in Civil Engineering
Desc: Each course may be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Specialized civil engineering areas.

Name: Special Topics in Civil Engineering
Desc: Each course May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Specialized civil engineering areas.

Name: Master’s Report
Desc: Comprehensive report with oral defense on subject approved by the major professor.

Name: Seminar
Desc: Pass-fail grading. All graduate students are expected to enroll every semester. Only one semester hour of credit will be allowed toward degree.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Introduction to Chemical Engineering
Desc: Overview of what chemical engineers do, including guiding principles of the discipline and basics of large-scale chemical engineering problem solving.

Name: Chemical Engineering Fundamentals: Material and Energy Balances
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Emphasis on basic principles and concepts used to make chemical engineering calculations; techniques used in these calculations applied to typical industrial problems. A three hour computer lab will reinforce lecture material and give practical experience with computer simulation packages.

Name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
Desc: Basic concepts and chemical engineering applications of thermodynamics; emphasis on flow processes and real gas thermodynamics.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2171 and a grade of “C” or better in BIOL 1201, CHEM 1201, CHEM 1202, MATH 1550, MATH 1552, MATH 2090, PHYS 2110, and PHYS 2113

Name: Numerical Methods and Programming for Chemical Engineers
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab Basic concepts and techniques in analysis of engineering processes; mathematical description of physical systems and application of modern computers to solution of resulting equations. A three-hour computer lab will reinforce lecture material and give practical experience in scripting/programming.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better CHE 2171 and a grade of “C” or better in BIOL 1201, CHEM 1201, CHEM 1202, MATH 1550, MATH 1552, MATH 2090 and PHYS 2110 and PHYS 2113

Name: Chemical Equilibrium and Kinetics of Environmental Processes
Desc: Not open to chemical engineering majors. Introductory chemical thermodynamic concepts extended to heterogeneous equilibrium, dilute solutions, surfaces and colloids of significance in environmental engineering processes; chemical reaction kinetics concepts applied to the environment; applications to waste treatment process design; property estimations for elucidating the fate and transport of chemicals in the environment.

Name: Transport Sciences: Momentum Transfer
Desc: Fundamentals of momentum transfer; applications to the fluid problems of engineering.
Reqs: A grade of “C” or better CHE 2171, credit with a grade of “C” or better or registration in CHE 2176, and a grade of “C” or better in BIOL 1201, CHEM 1201, CHEM 1202, MATH 1550, MATH 1552, MATH 2057, MATH 2090, PHYS 2110 and PHYS 2113

Name: Transport Sciences: Heat and Mass Transfer
Desc: Fundamentals of heat and mass transfer; similarities of heat, mass and momentum transfer and their interrelation; engineering applications.
Reqs: A grade of “C” or better in CHE 2176 and CHE 3101

Name: Engineering Measurements Laboratory
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Laboratory work to accompany CHE 2172, CHE 3101, CHE 3102, and CHE 3173.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2176 and credit with a grade of “C” or better or registration in  CHE 3102

Name: Introduction to Design and Process Safety
Desc: Introduction to process design, equipment selection, capital and operating economics, optimization and process safety.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2176 and credit with a grade of “C” or better or registration in CHE 3101  and CHE 3173

Name: Heterogeneous Equilibrium
Desc: Theory of vapor-liquid, liquid-liquid, and solid-liquid equilibrium, including the effects of chemical reactions; application of thermodynamic theory to the correlation of equilibrium data and the prediction of equilibrium compositions.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2172 and CHE 2176

Name: Chemical Reaction Engineering
Desc: Credit will not be given for btoh this course and CHE 3100. Basic principles of reactor design; selection of best design alternatives; achievement of optimum reactor operation.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3173 and CHEM 3492 and a grade of “C” or better or registration in CHE 3102

Name: Co-op in the Chemical Engineering Industry
Desc: Pass/fail grading. A minimum of 13 weeks of full-time employment (520 hrs. min) with a company in the chemical engineering related industry working in a chemical engineering capacity and participating in the ChE Co-op Program. (CHE 3249 must be taken the semester after the completion of the co-op assignment.)  Students will engage in coursework related to their experiences garnered during their co-op assignment.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2171 and consent of instructor

Name: Sustainability in Chemical Engineering
Desc: Methods of engineering and life cycle analysis in a contemporary sustainability context. Topics include resources assessment, energy extraction/capture, conversion, distribution, storage, and consumption; environmental and economic consequences; local to global scales; and exergy and exergy analysis with examples from CO2 capture.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2172

Name: Independent Research I
Desc: , and consent of instructor.  Midterm presentation, final presentation, and final written report required. Credit will not be given for both this course and CHE 3910. Individual study of a specific chemical engineering problem or individual laboratory research.
Reqs: A grade of “C” or better in CHE 2171 and CHE 2176, an overall GPA of at least 3

Name: Independent Research II
Desc: , and consent of instructor. Midterm presentation, final presentation, final written report, and poster presentation at a recognized scientific event or contribution to a scientific manuscript required. Credit will not be given for both this course and CHE 3911. A continuation of CHE 3900, individual study of a specific chemical engineering problem or individual laboratory research.
Reqs: A grade of “C” or better in CHE 3900, an overall GPA of at least 3

Name: Honors Independent Research I
Desc: , and consent of instructor. Midterm presentation, final presentation, and final written report required. Credit will not be given for both this course and CHE 3900.
Reqs: A grade of “C” or better in CHE 2171 and CHE 2176, an overall GPA of at least 3

Name: Honors Independent Research II
Desc: , and consent of instructor. Midterm presentation, final presentation, final written report, and poster presentation at a recognized scientific event or contribution to a scientific manuscript required. Credit will not be given for both this course and CHE 3901.
Reqs: A grade of “C” or better in CHE 3910, an overall GPA of at least 3

Name: Unit Operations Design
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Unit operations analyzed as applications of chemical engineering fundamentals and transport sciences; use of these principles in design calculations.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3102 and CHE 3171

Name: Unit Operations Laboratory
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 6 hrs. lab. Obtaining and interpreting data needed to solve typical problems in design or operation of chemical engineering equipment.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3104 and credit or registration in CHE 4151

Name: Process Design
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Chemical plant design from initial concept through preliminary estimate; flow diagrams, equipment cost estimation, economic analysis, safety, and environmental issues; computer-aided process design.
Reqs: CHE 4151 and credit or registration in CHE 4198

Name: Process Dynamics
Desc: Principles and practices of process dynamics and automatic control; mathematical modeling of process dynamics, feedback control and feed forward control.
Reqs: A grade of “C” or better in CHE 3190

Name: Industrial Catalysis
Desc: Principles of the industrial utilization of heterogenous catalysis; topics include absorption phenomena, methodology in catalyst preparation, characterization and evaluation of catalysts, diffusion and reaction in porous catalysts and a survey of major industrial processes.
Reqs: credit with a grade of “C” or better or registration in CHE 3190

Name: Genetic Engineering
Desc: Designed for engineers with little or no experience in the biological sciences. Introduction to the basic molecular biology topics including DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis; tools for studying and manipulating macromolecules and the application of these tools.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2171 (or equivalent) and BIOL 1201

Name: Chemical Engineering Project I
Desc: (in CHE) and consent of instructor. Not open to graduate students. 3 hrs. lab. Comprehensive development project of a practical nature, involving a team effort over two semesters (fall and spring periods).
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2171, CHE 2172, and CHE 2176, GPA of at least 2

Name: Chemical Engineering Project II
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. A continuation of CHE 4221, comprehensive development project of a practical nature, involving a team effort over two semesters (fall and spring periods).
Reqs: CHE 4221  Not open to graduate students

Name: Advanced Process Control Systems
Desc: Advanced process control tools; modern industrial control technology; process optimization and control; integrated systems control.

Name: Introduction to Industrial Pollution Control
Desc: Quantitative application of chemical engineering principles to removal of objectionable components from effluents, with emphasis on industrial processing effluents; currently available techniques for controlling air and water pollution and solid wastes; concept of pollution control through basic process alterations developed by specific examples.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3102 or equivalent introductory course in transport science

Name: Biochemical Engineering
Desc: Application of chemical engineering fundamentals to microbiological and biochemical systems; problems peculiar to industrial operations involving microbial processes; growth conditions and requirements, metabolisms, product separations, enzyme catalysis, sterilization and aseptic operations.
Reqs: credit with a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2176  or equivalent

Name: Environmental Chemodynamics
Desc: Environmental chemodynamics: interphase equilibrium, reactions, transport processes and related models for anthropogenic substances across natural interfaces (air-water-sediment-soil) and associated boundary regions.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3102 or equivalent introductory course in transport science

Name: Processing of Advanced Materials
Desc: Treatment of coupled chemical reaction and mass, energy and momentum transport in the manufacturing and processing of semiconductors and advanced ceramic materials; engineering models for chemical and physical vapor deposition methods and condensed phase processes.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3102 or equivalent transport course

Name: Chemical Processing of Nanomaterials
Desc: Chemical engineering principles applied to preparation, handling and applications of nanomaterials. Emphasis will be on manufacturing and processing steps. Case studies will be developed to focus on specific device or material applications.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3102 or equivalent introductory course in transport science

Name: Electrochemical Engineering
Desc: Introductory course in transport science. Principles of electrochemistry applied to engineering problems; potential distribution theory, kinetics, mass transport and thermodynamic principles; quantification of controlling factors in microfabrication, corrosion, battery design and electrochemical synthesis.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 3102 or equivalent

Name: Principles of High Polymers
Desc: Solution and solid-state properties of high polymers; microstructure of polymer chains and effect on macromolecular physical properties of the final plastics.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2172 and CHEM 3492

Name: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering Design
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. One or more phases of current chemical engineering design.

Name: Special Topics in Chemical Engineering Science
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. One or more phases of current chemical engineering science.

Name: Colloids and Interfacial Engineering
Desc: Focuses on the fundamentals of colloids and interfacial engineering, including: interactions between surfaces, particles, surfactants, and biomolecules; the theory of colloidal characterization by scattering methods and their manipulation by external fields; and the introduction of colloidal-based technologies such as soft robotics, micropatterning, bioarrays, and nanostructured multi-responsive material.
Reqs: a grade of “C” or better in CHE 2172 or equivalent

Name: Technical Leadership in Chemical Engineering
Desc: Reserved for chemical engineering students; open to others with permission of department. Focuses on technical leadership fundamentals for chemical engineers, including: ethics and professionalism; time management; building trust and credibility; risk taking; leadership through questions; creating a vision; team building and teamwork; running an effective meeting; conflict management and resolution; communication; and presenting difficult messages.
Reqs: Senior standing and consent of instructor

Name: Process Separations Design and Synthesis
Desc: Synthesis and design of separation processes in the chemical manufacturing industry.
Reqs: credit with a grade of “C” or better or registration in CHE 3173

Name: Chemical Engineering Fluid Mechanics
Desc: Foundations of continuum fluid mechanics and the equations of motion; solution methods for lubrication flows, creeping flows, boundary layer problems, laminar flows with strong convection; introduction to selected topics including: turbulence, non-Newtonian fluids, interfacial flows, computational fluid dynamics, microfluidics, particle motion, droplet dynamics.

Name: Mathematical Methods in Chemical Engineering
Desc: Review of physicochemical problem formulation; analytical and approximate techniques for the solution of linear and nonlinear differential equation models in chemical engineering systems.

Name: Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
Desc: Thermodynamic properties, first and second laws of thermodynamics, entropy, Maxwell relations, and relationship of thermodynamic properties to intermolecular forces; physical equilibrium with emphasis on partial free energy, fugacity, Raoult’s law, K-values, equations of state, and activity coefficients; chemical equilibrium and free energies; fundamentals of statistical mechanics.

Name: Fundamentals of Heat and Mass Transport
Desc: Foundations of heat and mass transport in continua; modeling and solution techniques; transport by diffusion, convection, and turbulence; forced convection; buoyancy-driven transport; introduction to computational modeling.

Name: Chemical Reactor Design Methods
Desc: Basic principles of chemical kinetics, fluid flow, heat transfer and mass transfer used in design of chemical reactors; chemical equilibria, chemical kinetics, design of isothermal reactors, effects of nonideal flow, nonisothermal reactors and solid-gas catalytic reactions.

Name: Optimization
Desc: Techniques of optimization including analytical methods, linear and nonlinear programming, geometric and dynamic programming and variational methods with application to systems of interest to chemical engineers.

Name: Advanced Materials
Desc: Advanced topics in engineering materials systems. Inorganic and organic materials with nanoscale and macroscale dimensionalities.

Name: Advanced Topics in Biochemical Engineering
Desc: Overview of current research topics in biochemical engineering, including metabolic engineering to produce commodity products, genetic engineering for enhanced therapeutics, enzyme kinetics, cell growth dynamics, data mining and managing large data sets generated by ‘omics fields, and mathematical modeling of biological systems.

Name: Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering
Desc: Advanced computational modeling techniques widely used in one or more of the following areas that are relevant to the modern chemical engineering discipline, including: catalysis and reaction engineering; thermodynamics; transport phenomena; process control.

Name: Catalysis
Desc: Heterogeneous catalysis; adsorption phenomena, physical methods, solid state spectroscopies and reaction mechanisms as applicable to fundamental and industrially significant processes.

Name: Design Problems in Chemical Engineering
Desc: Prior to registration students should discuss a prospective design problem with faculty member under whom they plan to study and obtain departmental approval. Design problem cannot be directly related to student’s research. Integration of technology into design of systems or plants for accomplishing specific objectives; emphasis on producing a design package considering technical, economic, manning and scheduling aspects of the project.

Name: Advanced Topics in Chemical Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit with consent of instructor. One or more phases of advanced chemical engineering practice.

Name: Seminar
Desc: Pass/fail grading. Full-time graduate students are expected to enroll in this course every fall and spring semester. Only 1 semester hour of credit will be allowed toward degree.

Name: Speaking of Macromolecules
Desc: See CHEM 7901.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Chemical Fundamentals
Desc: For those students whose curricula require only one year of chemistry or physical science. Also may be taken as a preparatory course for CHEM 1201. An overview of chemical theory and principles with emphasis on the role of chemistry in the modern world.
Reqs: ACT mathematics score of at least 21 or eligibility for MATH 1021

Name: Chemistry of Life and the Environment
Desc: An overview of organic chemistry and biochemistry; emphasis on the molecular basis for the biological, materials and environmental sciences.

Name: General Chemistry I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and CHEM 1421. For science/engineering curricula. Modern chemical theories and principles; quantitative approach and problem solving; descriptive chemistry of selected elements and compounds.
Reqs: credit or registration in MATH 1022, MATH 1023, MATH 1431, MATH 1550 or MATH 1551

Name: General Chemistry II
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 1422. For science/engineering curricula. Continuation of CHEM 1201. Additional theory with emphasis on solution chemistry and a quantitative approach; descriptive chemistry of selected elements and compounds from the main groups and the first transition series.

Name: General Chemistry Laboratory
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 1431. Students registering for laboratory courses in chemistry are charged a laboratory usage deposit on their fee bill. 6 hrs. lab. Basic laboratory operations including selected experiments and introductory inorganic qualitative analysis.
Reqs: credit or registration in CHEM 1002, CHEM 1202 or CHEM 1422

Name: HONORS: General Chemistry I
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 1201. Chemistry majors who qualify should take this course. For well-prepared students with a special interest in chemistry.
Reqs: credit or registration in MATH 1550 or MATH 1551

Name: HONORS: General Chemistry II
Desc: Chemistry majors who qualify should take this course. Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 1202. Continuation of CHEM 1421.
Reqs: CHEM 1421 or CHEM 1201 with consent of department chair

Name: HONORS: General Chemistry Laboratory
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 1212. For chemistry majors and other well-prepared students with special interest in chemistry. Students registering for laboratory courses in chemistry are charged a laboratory usage deposit on their fee bill.
Reqs: credit or registration in CHEM 1422 or credit or registration in CHEM 1202

Name: Analytical Chemistry
Desc: Basic principles and practices of modern methods of analysis.

Name: Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
Desc: Students registering for laboratory courses in chemistry are charged a laboratory usage deposit on their fee bill. 3 hrs. lab. Experiments in modern methods of analysis.
Reqs: CHEM 1212 or CHEM 1431; credit or registration in CHEM 2001

Name: Survey of Organic Chemistry
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 2261 and CHEM 2461. Aliphatic and aromatic compounds; biological aspects of organic chemistry.

Name: Organic Chemistry I
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 2060 and CHEM 2461. Representative classes of organic compounds; emphasis on varied professional goals of students, e.g., life sciences, physical sciences, engineering.

Name: Organic Chemistry II
Desc: Continuation of CHEM 2261.Credit will not be given for this course and CHEM 2462.

Name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
Desc: Students registering for laboratory courses in chemistry are charged a laboratory usage deposit on their fee bill. 6 hrs. lab. Fundamental laboratory operations of organic chemistry.
Reqs: CHEM 1212 and CHEM 2060 or credit or registration in CHEM 2262 or CHEM 2462  Credit will not be given for this course and CHEM 2463

Name: HONORS: Organic Chemistry I
Desc: Chemistry majors who qualify should take this course. For well-prepared students with a special interest in chemistry. Credit will not be given for this course and CHEM 2060 or CHEM 2261. Studies of structure, mechanism and synthesis in organic chemistry.
Reqs: a grade of “A” or “B” in CHEM 1202 or CHEM 1422

Name: HONORS: Organic Chemistry II
Desc: Chemistry majors who qualify should take this course. For well-prepared students with a special interest in chemistry. Credit will not be given for both this course and CHEM 2262. Continuation of CHEM 2461.
Reqs: CHEM 2461 or a grade of “A” in CHEM 2261

Name: HONORS: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
Desc: Same as CHEM 2364; primarily for chemistry majors. Credit will not be given for this course and CHEM 2364. Students registering for laboratory courses in chemistry are charged a laboratory usage deposit on their fee bill.

Name: Introduction to Research in Chemistry
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken 6 times for credit; no more than 8 sem. hrs. of credit may be earned in CHEM 2900 and CHEM 3900. By permission of the department. Introduction to chemical research.

Name: Physical Chemistry I
Desc: Principles of physical chemistry including quantum mechanics and spectroscopy.
Reqs: MATH 2057 or MATH 2090; PHYS 1202 or PHYS 2113; and CHEM 1202 or CHEM 1422; all three courses with a grade of “C” or better

Name: Physical Chemistry II
Desc: Principles of physical chemistry including kinetics and thermodynamics.
Reqs: MATH 2057 or MATH 2090; PHYS 1202 or PHYS 2113; and CHEM 1202 or CHEM 1422; all 3 courses with a grade of “C” or better

Name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
Desc: Students registering for laboratory courses in chemistry are charged a laboratory usage deposit on their fee bill. 1 hr. lecture; 6 hrs. lab. Selected experiments to accompany physical chemistry.
Reqs: PHYS 1209 or PHYS 2109; CHEM 1212 or CHEM 1431; CHEM 3491 and credit or registration in CHEM 3492

Name: Inorganic Chemistry I
Desc: Introduction to the bonding, structure, reactivity, and periodic trends of inorganic compounds and materials; emphasis on varied professional goals of students, e.g. life sciences, physical sciences, engineering.

Name: Research in Chemistry
Desc: Coreq.: CHEM 3491 or CHEM 3492. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit; no more than 8 sem. hrs. of credit may be earned in CHEM 2900 and CHEM 3900. By permission of the department. Course requires 3 hours of lab work per credit hour. Chemical research under the direction of chemistry faculty mentor. Requires an oral presentation and a report of research work in the format of scientific paper.

Name: Science Teaching in Secondary School III: Instructional Strategies in Science
Desc: See BIOL 4003.

Name: Seminar in Teaching Secondary School Science
Desc: See BIOL 4004.

Name: Science Research Methods
Desc: See BIOL 4005.

Name: Macromolecular Systems I
Reqs: CHEM 2262 and CHEM 3492 or BIOL 4001 or equivalent

Name: Macromolecular Systems II
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Behavior of large molecules, emphasizing theory and practice of modern and classical methods for molecular characterization.

Name: Environmental Chemistry
Desc: Applying the fundamentals of quantitative analysis and organic chemistry to understand the natural and human influenced chemical processes that occur in the environment.
Reqs: CHEM 2001 and CHEM 2261 or CHEM 2461 or CHEM 2060  Credit will not be given for this course and ENVS 4101

Name: Industrial Organic Chemistry
Desc: Review of major industrial processes with special emphasis on polymer synthesis and applications.

Name: Instrumental Methods of Measurement and Analysis
Desc: Selected topics in analytical instrumentation and chemical analysis using spectroscopy, chromatography, microscopy, and electroanalytical methods.
Reqs: CHEM 2001, CHEM 2002 and CHEM 3491; all courses with a grade of “C” or better

Name: Laboratory in Instrumental Methods of Measurement and Analysis
Desc: Laboratory usage deposit. 6 hrs. lab. Applications of molecular analysis.

Name: Analytical Spectroscopy
Desc: Basic principles of spectroscopy for chemical analysis emphasizing optical methods: UV/VIS absorbance, fluorescence, vibrational spectroscopy and atomic spectroscopy.
Reqs: CHEM 2001, CHEM 2002, CHEM 3491; all courses with a grade of “C” or better

Name: Analytical Separations
Desc: Basic principles of chemical separations emphasizing analytical separations and chromatography. Gas chromatography, liquid chromatography, electrophoresis and related detection techniques.
Reqs: CHEM 2001, CHEM 2002, and CHEM 3492; all courses with a grade of “C” or better

Name: Mass Spectrometry
Desc: Fundamentals of mass spectrometry, including ion formation, mass separation, detection and structure determination.
Reqs: CHEM 2001, CHEM 2002, and CHEM 3491 ; all courses with a grade of “C” or better

Name: Electroanalytical Chemistry
Desc: Basic principles of electrochemical reactions, electroanalytical voltammetric methods for analysis, the chemistry of heterogeneous electron transfers, electrochemical instrumentation, micro- and nano- electrodes, surface modification for electro-catalysis and sensing.
Reqs: CHEM 2001, CHEM 2002, and CHEM 3492; all courses with a grade of “C” or better

Name: Physical Organic Chemistry
Desc: Understanding organic reaction mechanisms and kinetics using basic concepts of molecular orbital theory. Related topics include supramolecular chemistry and noncovalent interactions.
Reqs: CHEM 2262 or CHEM 2462 and credit or registration in CHEM 3492

Name: Intermediate Organic Chemistry
Desc: Selected topics in organic synthesis, natural products chemistry, stereochemistry, and organic reactions.

Name: Organic Structure Elucidation
Desc: Focus on interpretation of multiple types of NMR spectra, mass spectra or other spectra relevant to structure elucidation; extensive utilization of actual spectra in problem solving sessions.

Name: Advanced Organic and Inorganic Laboratory
Desc: Students registering for laboratory courses in chemistry are charged a laboratory usage deposit on their fee bill.

Name: Bioorganic Chemistry
Desc: This course introduces topics in the interface of organic chemistry and biology that are relevant in biomedical sciences.

Name: Inorganic Chemistry II
Desc: Principles in advanced inorganic chemistry; modern interpretations.

Name: Organometallic Chemistry
Desc: Chemistry and principles of metal bonds with metal to carbon sigma and pi bonds; bonding concepts, electronic structure, periodic trends and fundamental reaction mechanisms; applications to homogeneous catalysis.
Reqs: CHEM 2262 or CHEM 2462 and credit or registration in CHEM 3492

Name: Introduction to Mathematical Chemistry
Desc: Mathematical methods of chemistry, with application to selected chemical problems.
Reqs: MATH 2057 and credit or registration in CHEM 3491

Name: Introduction to Quantum Chemistry
Desc: Basic ideas of quantum mechanics; application to atomic and molecular structure.

Name: Chemical Thermodynamics
Desc: Principles of macroscopic thermodynamics and application to systems of chemical relevance.

Name: Introduction to Statistical Thermodynamics
Desc: Introductory quantum and classical statistical thermodynamics of some simple systems of chemical relevance.

Name: Chemistry Instruction Through Demonstration and Experiments
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Demonstration techniques for junior and senior high school instruction; hands-on experience.

Name: Chemical Principles for Teachers
Desc: For elementary and middle school teachers. A basic chemistry course with emphasis upon the principles relevant to effective use of educational materials developed by professional societies and national curricular development projects.

Name: Laboratory Methods for Teachers
Desc: For elementary and middle school teachers. 1 hr. lecture; 6 hrs. lab. Analysis of laboratory experiments in current elementary and middle school curricula; selected experiments in modern chemistry.

Name: Seminar in Current Developments in Chemistry
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. For high school and junior college teachers; part of the MNS degree program.

Name: Macromolecular Systems III
Desc: Introduction to representative classes of macromolecules; emphasis on polymerization mechanisms and kinetics; advanced polymer synthesis techniques, including synthesis of inorganic polymers, biopolymers and conjugated polymers.

Name: Macromolecular Systems IV
Desc: Structure property relationships for materials such as liquid crystals; polymer blends and block copolymers; polymer nanocomposites and nanotechnology related materials.

Name: Chemical Dynamics and Kinetics
Desc: Theories of chemical reaction rates in the gas phase and in solution; chemical dynamics; gas phase and solution kinetics; applications of kinetics and chemical dynamics to mechanistic studies; modern experimental techniques.

Name: Special Topics in Chemical Physics
Desc: May be taken 4 times for credit. Specialized areas of physical chemistry.

Name: Special Topics in Analytical Chemistry
Desc: May be taken 4 times for credit. Modern methods and techniques of analytical chemistry.

Name: Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
Desc: May be taken 4 times for credit. Specialized areas of current interest in organic chemistry.

Name: Special Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
Desc: May be taken 4 times for credit. Advanced treatment of areas of current interest in modern inorganic chemistry.

Name: Special Topics in Macromolecular Chemistry
Desc: May be taken 4 times for credit. Advanced treatment of specialized subjects of importance to current macromolecular research.

Name: Seminar
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken 6 times for credit. All graduate students are expected to participate in report and discussion groups in field of chemistry of their particular interest.

Name: Speaking of Macromolecules
Desc: Also offered as CHE 7901. Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit. Multidisciplinary seminar that explores current research concerning macromolecules.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading. Students who receive 6 hrs. of credit for this course cannot obtain more than 9 hrs. of credit for CHEM 8900.

Name: Procedures and Problems in Chemical Research
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Open only to students of proven ability or exceptional potential. Students who receive 6 hrs. of credit for CHEM 8000 cannot obtain more than 9 hrs. of credit in this course. Experimental research methods, design and execution of experiments and analysis and correlation of experimental data.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: of credit in CHEM 8000 or CHEM 8900. “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Personal Financial Management
Desc: Goal setting, budgeting, credit managing, saving and investing, career and retirement planning.

Name: Introduction to Family Science
Desc: A systems approach to examining family processes and development throughout the life span.

Name: Management of Family Systems and Services
Desc: A systems perspective of contemporary families and their processes including environmental influences, elements of family management and management of school and community resources and services.

Name: Special Topics in Child and Family Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Contemporary issues in child and family studies.

Name: Development of Young Children in Context
Desc: Also offered as EDCI 3055. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. field observations. Development of children from prenatal to middle childhood in the family and other developmental contexts; field observations with infants and toddlers, observations and practical experience in the LSU Early Childhood Education Laboratory Preschool and in other early childhood settings. Students are required to pay for a criminal background check through the Louisiana Department of Education.

Name: Young Children’s Cognitive and Linguistic Development
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 3056. An introductory survey of current theory and research on young children’s cognitive and linguistic development; special attention is given to the development of oral language, reading skills and mathematical concepts in young children; emphasis on implications for the early childhood education classroom.

Name: Adult-Child Relationships
Desc: For CFS majors only or consent of instructor. Parent-child and other adult-child interactions and relationships; emphasis on the development and interactive nature of adult-child relationships including the influence of adult-child relationships on child outcomes and adult behavior.

Name: Field Experience in Child and Family Studies
Desc: For CFS majors only. 6 hrs. field experience per week. Supervised professional experience designed to integrate academic learning with practice.
Reqs: CFS 2050 or CFS 2065, credit or concurrent enrollment in CFS 3090, and credit or concurrent enrollment in CFS 3055

Name: Intimate Relationships
Desc: Introduction to the individual and contextual factors affecting the formation and maintenance of intimate relationships.

Name: Professional Practice and Ethics in Child and Family Studies
Desc: For majors only. Pre-internship seminar.

Name: Reading and Research in Child and Family Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Open to advanced students of high academic standing by consent of director. Students are responsible for registering with a faculty member with whom they will select the area of reading and research.

Name: Human Sciences Research Methods
Desc: See SW 4009.

Name: Developmentally Appropriate Play
Desc: Developmentally appropriate play and its influences on child development. Theories of play, culture and gender influences on play, play environments, and therapeutic aspects of play with an emphasis on play in the pediatric healthcare environment.

Name: The Adolescent and the Family
Desc: For CFS majors only or permission of instructor. Growth, development and guidance of the adolescent in the home, family and community.

Name: Families: Policy and Law
Desc: For CFS majors only or permission of instructor. Marriage and family as legal institutions; history and development of family law principles; overview of the public policy process; emphasis on family policy issues.
Reqs: POLI 2051 or POLI 2070 or HIST 3071 or equivalent

Name: Child Life Theory & Practice
Desc: Children in the healthcare environment.

Name: Developmental Perspectives on Death and Dying
Desc: Child and family perspectives related to death, dying, and bereavement with a focus on the pediatric healthcare environment.
Reqs: CFS 2050 or SW 2000 or permission of instructor

Name: Family Finance and Consumer Law
Desc: Development of bases for decision making related to family income, saving, and spending, with special emphasis on low-income families and the working poor.

Name: Family Stress Management
Desc: For CFS majors only or permission of instructor. Strategies used by families to manage stress; current family stress management theory and research.

Name: Family Life Education
Desc: Overview of family life education history, philosophy and topics; planning, implementation and evaluation of family life education programs in diverse settings.
Reqs: CFS 2050; CFS 2065; Credit or concurrent enrollment in CFS 3065; for CFS majors only or permission of instructor

Name: Child Life Internship
Desc: Directed child life internship under the supervision of a Certified Child Life Specialist in a pediatric healthcare facility.

Name: Internship in Child and Family Studies
Desc: For CFS majors only, senior standing. 2 hrs. lecture; 12 hrs. practicum. Supervised professional observation and experience in child and family studies.

Name: Reading & Research in Child and Family Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for registering with a faculty member with whom they will select the area of reading and research.

Name: Research Seminar in Child and Family Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. credit when topics vary. Reports and discussion of current literature and research.

Name: The Contemporary Family
Desc: Also offered as EDCI 7051. Credit will not be given for this course and EDCI 7051. Effects of change on family integration; adaptive responses in family lifestyles, roles and relationships to political, social and technological change.

Name: Topics and Issues in Child and Family Studies
Desc: Also offered as EDCI 7052. Credit will not be given for this course and EDCI 7052.   May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Lectures and research on topics not covered in other child and family studies courses.

Name: Infant Behavior and Development
Desc: See EDCI 7053.

Name: Child Guidance and Behavior
Desc: See EDCI 7054.

Name: Human Development
Desc: Also offered as EDCI 7055. Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 7055. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Dynamics of human development and practical implications.

Name: Theories of Child Development
Desc: Also offered as EDCI 7056. Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 7056. Research and theory in child development; relation to the major domains in the child’s ecology–child development, the family, services and the environment.

Name: Theories in Family Science
Desc: Also offered as EDCI 7057. Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 7057. Historical and contemporary theories and conceptual frameworks in family science.

Name: Research Methods in Child & Family Studies
Desc: Philosophy of child and family studies research, issues, and trends; design and methodology.

Name: Practicum in Child and Family Studies
Desc: Pass/Fail grading. May be taken twice for up to 6 hours. Practical experience in child and family studies under the guidance of in-service practitioners.
Reqs: Twelve hours from CFS 7050, CFS 7051, CFS 7052, CFS 7053, CFS 7054, CFS 7055, CFS 7056, CFS 7057, or CFS 7090; and permission of department

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: Pass/Fail grading. Directed research and focused project development under the supervision of the major professor.

Name: Beginning Mandarin Chinese
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Native speakers of Chinese will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Chinese; development of speaking and listening skills.

Name: Beginning Mandarin Chinese
Desc: Native speakers of Chinese will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Chinese; development of speaking and listening skills.

Name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
Desc: Native speakers of Chinese will not receive credit for this course. Continuation of the study of basic lexicon and structures of Chinese; emphasis on further development of speaking, writing and reading skills.

Name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
Desc: Native speakers of Chinese will not receive credit for this course. Continuation of the study of basic lexicon and structures of Chinese; emphasis on further development of speaking, writing and reading skills.

Name: Chinese for Travelers
Desc: Credit not applicable to a minor in Chinese. Does not count toward satisfying the foreign language requirement for undergraduates. Basic communication patterns, practical everyday vocabulary, with exercises in comprehension and conversation.

Name: Chinese Cinema
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Chinese cinema from 1896 to the present; emphasis on the New Chinese cinema since 1980s; screening and analysis of representative films; knowledge of Chinese not required.

Name: Advanced Chinese
Desc: Introduction of authentic materials of increasing complexity on a variety of topics; emphasis on the use of relatively sophisticated structures of vocabulary in complex communication.

Name: Advanced Chinese
Desc: Introduction of authentic materials of increasing complexity on a variety of topics; emphasis on the use of relatively sophisticated structures vocabulary in complex communication.

Name: Traditional East Asian Literature
Desc: Also offered as JAPN 3801. Taught in English; knowledge of East Asian languages not required. Introduction to the genres, themes and representative works of traditional Chinese and Japanese literature; emphasis on critical reading.

Name: Independent Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 semester hours of credit when topics vary. Permission of department required.  Directed readings in classical Chinese or Chinese literature.

Name: Ancient World in the Cinema
Desc: An examination of how the cinema has interpreted the history and myths of Greece and Rome.

Name: Women in Antiquity
Desc: Knowledge of Greek or Latin not required. The role of women in Greek and Roman society; readings from historical, legal, medical and religious documents.

Name: Greek and Roman Mythology
Desc: Taught in English; knowledge of the Greek and Latin languages not required. Survey of the principal myths of the Greeks and Romans.

Name: Greek and Latin Word Study
Desc: No previous knowledge of Greek or Latin required; credit not applicable toward a major in foreign languages. Etymology of common and scientific words derived from Greek and Latin; emphasis on medical terminology.

Name: Ancient Greek Civilization
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Knowledge of Greek and Latin languages not required. Survey of literature, philosophy, art and culture of ancient Greece from its beginnings to the death of Alexander the Great.

Name: Ancient Roman Civilization
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Knowledge of Greek and Latin languages not required. A survey of the literature, philosophy, art and culture of ancient Rome from its beginnings to the death of Marcus Aurelius.

Name: Classical Epic in Translation
Desc: Knowledge of Greek and Latin languages not required. Growth and development of the Greek and Latin epic; basic themes, the nature of a hero and relevance to modern reader.

Name: Greek and Roman Tragedy in English Translation
Desc: Taught in English; knowledge of Greek and Latin languages not required. Drama of Greece and Rome; origins, major examples and relevance; plays of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides and Seneca.

Name: Greek and Roman Comedy in English Translation
Desc: Knowledge of Greek or Latin languages not required. Masters of stage comedy from the ancient world, with special attention to Aristophanes, Menander, Plautus and Terence; origins and growth of comedy as an art form; problems in staging; social nature of comedy in the ancient world.

Name: Special Topics in Classical Studies
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Taught in English, knowledge of Greek and Latin languages not required.

Name: Comparative Mythology
Desc: Also offered as REL 3090. Introduction to myths from around the world with comparisons to Greek and Roman mythology.

Name: Senior Seminar
Desc: An examination of the influence of the Classical world on Western culture. Focus on literature, history, politics, art and architecture.
Reqs: four semesters of Greek or Latin or permission of instructor

Name: Introduction to Construction Management
Desc: A survey of the construction industry to include an orientation to essential elements of professional practice and development in construction management.

Name: Engineering Graphics for Mechanical Engineering
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CM 1030. Not open to construction management majors. 4 hrs. lab. Conception, visualization and communication of creative design concepts; introduction to engineering drafting and USA Standards Institute standards; freehand sketching; three-dimensional forms used in solution of engineering problems; use of solid modeling software in design and design communication.

Name: Honors Engineering Graphics
Desc: Same as CM 1020, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for both this course and CM 1020.

Name: Introduction to Sustainability in the Built Environment
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Basic principles of sustainability in the built environment; interactions between the built environment and humans/nature; fundamentals of sustainable practices within the built environment to protect the natural environment and human health; overview of green materials, products, and rating systems in the built environment.

Name: Construction Plan Reading
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles of graphic communication applied to reading construction plans with emphasis on residential, commercial, industrial, and heavy highway plans.

Name: Construction Materials and Methods I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this and CM 2100. Principal materials and methods used in building construction, emphasizing common construction systems such as light wood frames, masonry bearing walls, steel frames and reinforced concrete as well as project planning, work methods, materials, equipment, and sustainability. Drawing identification and quantity take off will be introduced.

Name: Construction Materials and Methods I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and CM 1112. Intended for certificate programs. Principal materials and methods used in building construction, emphasizing common construction systems such as light wood frames, masonry bearing walls, steel frames, and reinforced concrete as well as project planning, work methods, materials, equipment, and sustainability.

Name: Construction Materials and Methods I
Desc: Principal materials and methods used in building construction, emphasizing common construction systems such as light wood frames, masonry bearing walls, steel frames, and reinforced concrete as well as project planning, work methods, materials, equipment, and sustainability.

Name: Construction Equipment
Desc: Overview of construction equipment, including economy, selection, and productivity of common construction equipment for commercial, industrial, and heavy civil construction.

Name: Construction Materials and Methods II
Desc: Basic fundamentals of materials and methods used in the industrial and highway construction sectors.

Name: Construction Surveying
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles of construction surveying, fundamental measuring procedures, error analysis, leveling, traverse measurements, horizontal curves, vertical curves, and earthwork calculations.
Reqs: CM 1011, MATH 1022, and MATH 1431 or MATH 1550

Name: Construction Materials and Methods II
Desc: Basic fundamentals of materials and methods used in the industrial and highway construction sectors. Drawing identification, quantity take off and BIM will be introduced.

Name: Construction Equipment
Desc: Overview of construction equipment, including economy, selection, and productivity of common construction equipment for commercial, industrial, and heavy civil construction.

Name: Construction Plan Reading
Desc: Principles of graphic communication applied to reading construction plans with emphasis on residential, commercial, industrial and heavy highway plans. Introduction to BIM.

Name: Construction Safety
Desc: Construction safety relating to accident causation; contractual obligations; project management and coordination.

Name: Structural Principles and Practices
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and CM 2501. Intended for post-baccalaureate leveling for non-CM majors. Statics and strengths of materials; design of ordinary timber, steel, and reinforced concrete for construction applications.

Name: Structural Principles and Practices
Desc: Statics and strengths of materials; design of ordinary timber, steel, and reinforced concrete for construction applications.
Reqs: MATH 1431 or MATH 1550 or ARCH 1002 or ARCH 1102; and PHYS 2001 or PHYS 2110

Name: Construction Estimating
Desc: Intended for post-baccalaureate leveling and certificate programs. Fundamentals of estimating including document review, quantity survey, material, equipment, and labor pricing, and bid package preparation for construction projects.
Reqs: CM 2100 for post-baccalaureate certificate; CM 2100 and CM 2116 for undergraduate certificates

Name: Construction Estimating
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Fundamentals of estimating including document review, quantity survey, material, equipment and labor pricing and bid package preparation for construction projects.
Reqs: CM 2113, CM 2116 and MATH 1431 or MATH 1550

Name: BIM for Construction Management
Desc: CM majors only. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles of BIM and its application to project execution tasks, planning and sequencing, spatial coordination and clash detection, as well as BIM support for field operations and facility management.

Name: Commercial Estimating
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles of estimating including quantity surveys, pricing analysis, and bid package preparation for commercial projects.

Name: Highway Construction
Desc: Basic fundamentals of highway construction including earthmoving, drainage, road paving, bridge and retaining walls, interpretation of plans and specifications, materials, equipment and estimating.

Name: Mechanical and Electrical Systems
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and CM 3201. Intended for certificate programs. For residential and commercial buildings; design and construction of building MEP systems; emphasis on basic terminology, equipment and installation procedures, management of the complete MEP process, code compliance, and quality control issues.

Name: Mechanical and Electrical Systems
Desc: For residential and commercial buildings, design and construction of building MEP systems; emphasis on basic terminology, equipment, and installation procedures; management of the complete MEP process, code compliance and quality control issues.

Name: Residential Development
Desc: Introduction to the principles and procedures of residential development. Land development, market research, and residential company start-up practices are explored.
Reqs: CM 1112 or CM 2100; or permission of department

Name: Residential Design Codes and Specifications
Desc: A study of residential design theory, techniques, and application as it relates to the International Residential Code for one and two family dwellings.

Name: Residential Project Management
Desc: Focus on managing residential projects from construction planning to completion and warranty work. This will include residential industry participants, organization of the project team, outside influences on scope and performance in the residential construction industry, blending proven practices with the experiences of builders in the field.
Reqs: CM 1112 or CM 2100, or permission of department

Name: Maintenance and Turnarounds
Desc: Principles of industrial maintenance and turnarounds including facility types, process equipment, work order systems, safety, preventive maintenance programs, roles, planning, and facility shutdown concepts.

Name: Industrial Construction Estimating
Desc: Principles of estimating including quantity surveys, pricing analysis, and bid package preparation for industrial construction.

Name: Construction and Civil Materials
Desc: Fundamentals involved in design, evaluation, testing, and construction of asphalt, concrete, aggregates, steel, and wood.

Name: Soils in Construction
Desc: In depth coverage of engineering behaviors of soil, soil testing, and characterization, pore water pressure, stresses in soil, consolidation, excavation support, shear strength of soil, soil investigation and exploration; compaction, and retaining walls, and construction of shallow and deep foundations.

Name: Applied Structural Design
Desc: CM 3502 or ARCH 3001 or ARCH 3101. Structural design of ordinary timber, steel, and reinforced concrete buildings and other structures in accordance with appropriate design code specifications; emphasis on contemporary design methodologies and provisions to achieve safe and serviceable resistance to vertical and lateral load effects.
Reqs: Credit or concurrent registration in CM 3503

Name: Construction Scheduling and Cost Control
Desc: Intended for post-baccalaureate leveling and certificate programs. Fundamentals of planning and scheduling including network-based schedules, resource scheduling, probabilistic scheduling, and computer applications. Project control emphasis on goals, flow of information, time and cost control, and change management.

Name: Construction Scheduling and Cost Control
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Fundamentals of planning and scheduling including network-based schedules, resource scheduling, probabilistic scheduling, and computer applications. Project control emphasis on goals, flow of information, time and cost control, and change management.

Name: Construction Productivity
Desc: Productivity measurement and improvement; project organization, stakeholders roles, quantifying labor and equipment productivity.

Name: Professional Practice in Facility Management
Desc: Organizational, managerial, ethical and legal principles for the delivery of facility management services in the industrial setting. Special emphasis includes: the history of facility management; leadership; regulatory issues; legal issues; corporate culture; organizational frameworks; organization of the facility management function and team; policy and procedures; contracts and contract documents; accountability; and personnel management.
Reqs: Admission into an online Post-Baccalaureate Certificate, a graduate program, or with permission of instructor

Name: Human and Environmental Factors
Desc: Develop and implement industry practices that promote and protect health, safety, and security, the quality of work life, the environment and organizational effectiveness; develop and manage emergency preparedness procedures.
Reqs: Admission into an online Post-Baccalaureate Certificate, a graduate program, or with permission of instructor

Name: Building Energy Performance Audits
Desc: Building energy use profile, obstacles and opportunities for efficiency improvement, energy efficiency standards, energy audit, methods for estimating energy savings, energy retrofits, challenges and opportunities, and intelligent building systems.
Reqs: Admission into an online Post-Baccalaureate Certificate, a graduate program, or with permission of instructor

Name: Financial Issues for Facility Management
Desc: Facilities investment decisions; budget development and execution; taxation; control of expenditures; and operational and long-term planning of industrial facilities and the facility management unit.
Reqs: Admission into an online Post-Baccalaureate Certificate, a graduate program, or with permission of instructor

Name: Construction Enterprise
Desc: Senior standing; only for graduating seniors in their last semester of coursework. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. A comprehensive study of construction management as it relates to a single construction enterprise.

Name: Special Topics in Construction Management
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Advanced topics, current issues or recent developments in the construction industry.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Research on a construction topic as chosen by the student under direct supervision of a chosen faculty member.

Name: Internship in the Construction Industry
Desc: Pass/fail grading.

Name: Construction Contracting
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and CM 4211. Intended for post-baccalaureate leveling and certificate programs. Principles and theory of construction company ownership and organization, the estimate and bid process, construction contracts, bonds, insurance, business methods and plans, management, administration, labor law and relations, safety, and avoidance of claims.

Name: Construction Contracting
Desc: Principles and theory of construction company ownership and organization, the estimate and bid process, construction contracts, bonds, and insurance, business methods and plans, management, and administration, labor law and relations, safety, and avoidance of claims.

Name: Construction Safetey Management
Desc: Principles of safety and health management relating to emergency planning, hazardous communication, hearing conservation, and excavation hazards.

Name: Construction Project Management
Desc: Field management of a project from inception to completion, including personnel needed, business aspects, estimating and bidding aspects, communication, record keeping, monitoring and control of project, risk and claims management, safety, and close out.
Reqs: CM 4101 and CM 4211; or CM 4100 and CM 4210

Name: Essentials of Industry Leadership
Desc: Essentials of leadership within the construction industry; emphasis on the complexities of practicing leadership as managers, estimators, schedulers, project managers, and supervisors.

Name: Company Strategic Planning
Desc: Strategic planning within the construction industry; emphasis on strategically formulating, implementing, and evaluating cross functional decisions that enable construction businesses and construction managers to achieve organizational goals.

Name: Disaster Resilient Construction
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and CM 7250. Hazard identification, project siting, building code requirements, and above-code practices for natural hazard/disaster resilient construction.

Name: Driven Pile Construction
Desc: Materials, construction techniques, and testing procedures used in the driven pile construction industry. Topics include: review of geotechnical parameters and testing methods, crane and hammer equipment selection, common construction practices, pile drivability, pile load testing, and dynamic pile testing.
Reqs: senior standing and Construction Management major; or consent of instructor

Name: Industrial Project Controls
Desc: Fundamentals of information management required for effective project control on an industrial construction project; data requirements, data collection, and data processing involved in measuring, evaluating, calculating, and reporting job performance from inception of project through closeout.

Name: Industrial Electrical Installations
Desc: Fundamentals of electrical and instrumentation concepts, systems, plans, and installations relevant to industrial facilities and applications.

Name: Emerging Concrete Technologies for Transportation
Desc: This course is intended to educate undergraduate and graduate students on the manufacture, performance, evaluation, durability and applications of novel concrete materials.
