Desc: Survey of children’s literature across time, genres and media; focus on wide reading in children’s literature and an appreciation of the value of literature for children.

Name: Student Development and Diversity
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab/field experience in multicultural settings. Differences among secondary students (grades 6-12) associated with their development levels, cultural and ethnic backgrounds, genders, learning abilities and special needs.
Reqs: credit or concurrent enrollment in EDCI 2001 and concurrent enrollment in one of the following: ENGL 3203, FREN 3401, HIST 3001, or SPAN 3001

Name: Integrating Children’s Literature Across the Disciplines
Desc: Explore effective integrated literacy experiences for teaching with children’s literature across the disciplines; understanding of the genres, forms, and text features of narrative and informational text, and how particular texts can be used for instruction in English language arts, science, mathematics, and social studies.

Name: Infant/Toddler Curriculum & Assessment
Desc: grade point average; membership in B-K teacher education program. Coreq.: Concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3056, EDCI 3057, & EDCI 3058. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab/field experience in multi-level multicultural setting. Comprehensive integrated curriculum content for children birth through age three, including the process of building the teaching and learning cycle (assessing, planning, teaching, and reflecting) into integrated instruction. A grade of C or better is required for teacher certification.

Name: Development of Young Children in Context
Desc: See CFS 3055.

Name: Young Children’s Cognitive and Linguistic Development
Desc: See CFS 3056.

Name: Learning Environments for Infants and Toddlers
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs field experience. Planning and preparing environments and learning experiences to support optimal physical, social, emotional and cognitive development of young children. A grade of C or better is required for teacher certification.
Reqs: EDCI 2083 and EDCI 3055; concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3058

Name: Social-Emotional Growth & Socialization: Culture, Family & Providers
Desc: 2 hr. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Planning and providing instruction in consideration of infant temperament, stages of emotional development, responsive care-giving and guidance and discipline in the context of culture and identity formation, dealing with cultural differences, program policies for culturally sensitive care and creating partnerships with parents. A grade of C or better is required for teacher certification.
Reqs: EDCI 2083 and CFS 3055 ; concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3057

Name: Curriculum Discipline: Mathematics Theory and Practice
Desc: hrs. of mathematics, including MATH 1201 and MATH 1202; 11 sem. hrs. of natural science; and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3125 and MATH 2203. 3 hrs. lecture; 6 hrs. lab/field experience in multicultural, multi-level settings. Structures of the discipline of mathematics applied to teaching mathematics in grades 1-6; standards-based pedagogical strategies, techniques and materials are coordinated with basic principles of learning.

Name: Curriculum Discipline: Science
Desc: hrs. of natural science, 12 sem. hrs. mathematics, and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3124 and MATH 2203.

Name: Curriculum Disciplines: Social Studies
Reqs: EDCI 2400, EDCI 3000 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3137, EDCI 3200 and either EDCI 4460 or EDCI 4705

Name: Reading in the Content Areas
Desc: Content area reading problems and solutions; the reading process, approaches, skills and materials.

Name: Assessing and Guiding Classroom Reading Instruction
Reqs: EDCI 2400, EDCI 3000 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3200, EDCI 3127 and either EDCI 4460 or EDCI 4705

Name: Reading, Writing and Oral Communication in the Elementary School
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 6 hrs. lab/field experience in multicultural, multi-level settings. Principles and practices of an effective program in reading, writing and the oral language arts in grades 1-5.
Reqs: EDCI 2400, EDCI 3000 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3127, EDCI 3137 and either EDCI 4460 or EDCI 4705

Name: Adolescent Literature
Desc: See ENGL 3223.

Name: Early Childhood Curriculum
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 3 contact hrs. lab/field experience in multi-level multicultural setting. Comprehensive integrated curriculum content for children birth through kindergarten: reading/language arts, mathematics, science, social studies and the arts.
Reqs: EDCI 2083 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3382, EDCI 3383, and CFS 3055/EDCI 3055

Name: Early Childhood Pedagogy
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab/field experience in multilevel, multicultural settings. Ways of instructing children from birth to kindergarten.
Reqs: EDCI 2083 and concurrent enrollment in CFS 3055, EDCI 3381 and EDCI 3383

Name: Assessment and Planning for Reflective Instruction: EC
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 contact hrs. lab/field experience in multi-level, multi-cultural settings. The process of building the teaching and learning cycle (assessing, planning, teaching, reflecting) into integrated instruction of children birth through kindergarten.
Reqs: EDCI 2083; concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3381, EDCI 3382, and CFS 3055/EDCI 3055

Name: Curriculum in Grades 1-3
Desc: Comprehensive, integrated curriculum content for children in grades 1-3: reading/language arts, mathematics, social studies, science and the arts.
Reqs: EDCI 3381, EDCI 3382, EDCI 3383; membership in PK-3 teacher education program; and concurrent enrollment in CFS 3056/EDCI 3056, EDCI 3482 and EDCI 3483

Name: Pedagogy in Grades 1-3
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab/field experience in multi-level, multicultural settings. Instructional strategies and materials for children in grades 1-3.
Reqs: CFS 3055; EDCI 3381, EDCI 3383; membership in PK-3 teacher education program; and concurrent enrollment in CFS 3056, EDCI 3481 and EDCI 3483

Name: Assessment and Planning for Reflective Instruction: Grades 1-3
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 6 hrs. lab/field experience in multi-level, multicultural settings. The process of building the teaching and learning cycle (assessing, planning, teaching, reflecting) into integrated instruction of children in grades 1-3.
Reqs: CFS 3055/EDCI 3055; EDCI 3381, EDCI 3382, EDCI 3383; membership in PK-3 teacher education program; and concurrent enrollment in CFS 3056/EDCI 3056, EDCI 3481 and EDCI 3482

Name: ELA/Social Studies in Grades 1-3
Desc: Coreq.: Must be taken concurrently with EDCI 3485. Content, pedagogy, and assessment methods in English Language Arts and Social Studies for grades 1-3.

Name: Math/Science in Grades 1-3
Desc: Coreq.: Must be taken concurrently with EDCI 3484. Content, pedagogy, and assessment methods in mathematics and science for grades 1-3.

Name: Classroom Interactions
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. field experience in multicultural settings. Classroom interactions in secondary mathematics and science education understood as a process of concept acquisition that encompasses learner’s knowledge and emphasizes student thinking as well as illuminating the critical role of reflection and language in the construction of knowledge. Students in classroom interactions study classroom events that impact learning in mathematics and science and critical issues of student equity.

Name: Student Teaching in the Elementary Grades
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 24 hrs. lab in diverse multicultural settings. All day, all semester student teaching experiences, including observation, participation and a minimum of 180 actual clock hours of teaching (with a substantial portion of the 180 hrs. in full-day teaching) under the professional supervision of an assigned public school mentor teacher.
Reqs: passage of PRAXIS II Elementary Content and PRAXIS II Principles of Learning and Teaching

Name: Student Teaching in the Elementary and Secondary Grades
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 30 hrs. lab.
Reqs: See “Requirements for Student Teaching” Pass-fail grading

Name: Dual Certification General/Special Education Student Teaching: Grades 1-5
Desc: Passage of Praxis 5002, 5003, 5004, 5005, 5543 and 5622. 1 hr. lecture; 30 hrs. internship in diverse classroom settings. All day, all semester, all subject student teaching experience in general and special education, including observation, participation, and direct teaching under supervision of an assigned public school mentor teacher team and LSU faculty/staff member.

Name: Assessment for Special Education Instructional Practice
Desc: Requires practical field experience with student(s) with disabilities in a school environment. Does not satisfy the Louisiana requirements for certification as an Exceptional Diagnostician. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab/field experience. Assessing performance of students with disabilities; interpreting standardized test results; designing and using assessment in the classroom; instructional design based on assessment data.
Reqs: EDCI 2700 and admission to a Teacher Education Program

Name: Instructional Practice for Students with Disabilities I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Instructional methods, procedures and materials for teaching students with mild to moderate learning and behavior problems; overview of various methods and introductory procedures for explicit instruction and ongoing assessment.

Name: Instructional Practice for Students with Disabilities II: Reading and Literacy
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Instructional methods, procedures and materials for teaching reading and literacy to students with mild to moderate learning and behavior problems; includes the use of explicit instruction in academic subjects and ongoing assessment techniques in the context of relevant reading and literacy competencies; emphasis on reflective practice and making informed instructional decisions.

Name: Improving Language Skills in Students with Exceptionalities
Desc: Overview of the basic principles of language intervention and disorders, including etiological categories associated with different profiles of atypical development.
Reqs: EDCI 2700 and admission to a teacher certification program

Name: Secondary Methods and Transition Planning in Special Education
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Application of foundational knowledge in secondary programs for students with mild to moderate disabilities; focus on the design, delivery and evaluation of transition services to post-school environments.

Name: Curriculum and Pedagogy in Secondary Disciplines
Desc: May be repeated for credit in a second subject area. Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 4465. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab/field experience in multicultural settings. Applying instructional approaches in particular subject areas for middle and high school students.
Reqs: EDCI 3136 and concurrent enrollment in one of the following: ENGL 4204, FREN 4403, HIST 4403, or SPAN 4003 or permission of instructor

Name: Critical Issues in Secondary School Content Area Teaching
Desc: May be repeated for credit in a second subject area. Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 4466. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab/field experience in multicultural settings. Critical issues in the nature of knowledge and inquiry in specific school subjects.

Name: Student Teaching in Grades 6-12 Humanities
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 24 hrs. lab/field experience in diverse multicultural settings. All day, all semester student teaching experiences, including observation, participation, and a minimum of 180 actual clock hours of teaching (with a substantial portion of the 180 hrs. in a full day teaching) under the supervision of an assigned public school mentor teacher.
Reqs: EDCI 4003, ENGL 4204 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4004 and in one of the following: FREN 4404, HIST 4404, SPAN 4004

Name: Student Teaching in Grades 6-12 Mathematics and Sciences
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 24 hrs. lab/field experience in diverse multicultural settings. All day, all semester student teaching experiences, including observation, participation, and a minimum of 180 actual clock hours of teaching (with a substantial portion of the 180 hours in a full day teaching) under the supervision of an assigned public school mentor teacher.
Reqs: EDCI 4500, passage of applicable Praxis II content exam and Praxis II Principles of Learning & Teaching

Name: Organization and Administration of Early Childhood Programs
Desc: Historical, cultural, and philosophical foundations; finances, budgeting, staff duties, policies and legal aspects, equipment and physical plant, parent education and communication, public relations.

Name: Leadership in Early Childhood Programs
Desc: This course meets the requirements for Pathways as one of the two required Administrative Courses for Director III status. The process of leading in early childhood programs, topics to include mentoring/coaching, staff development and program improvement.

Name: Student Teaching: Practice and Reflection in B-K
Desc: grade point average; membership in B-K teacher education program. May be taken twice for a maximum of 12 credit hours. 4 hrs. lecture; 32 hrs. lab in multi-level, multicultural settings. Preparing students to be effective classroom teachers in Birth to Three year old settings. Students must earn a grade of C or better to receive credit, which is required for teacher certification.

Name: Art Education Workshop
Desc: Art as an integral part of the school curriculum; art activities and classroom procedures, materials and techniques.

Name: Current Practices in Art Education
Desc: Contemporary trends and practices in art education; critical review of texts, journals and other information sources.

Name: Art Education in the Elementary and Secondary Schools
Desc: For students concentrating in art education. Development of a functional art program for elementary and secondary schools; philosophy of art education, curriculum construction, teaching methods, planning and measurement of the results of instruction.

Name: Student Teaching: Practice and Reflection in PK/K
Desc: grade point average; membership in Early Childhood Education program. May be taken twice for a maximum of 12 credit hours. 4 hrs. lecture; 32 hrs. lab/field experience in multi-level, multicultural settings. Designed to partially fulfill student teaching requirements and to prepare students to be effective classroom teachers in PK/K settings. Students must earn a grade of C or better to receive credit, which is required for teacher certification.

Name: Critical Issues in Early Childhood Education
Desc: Historical and contemporary perspectives on developmental, sociocultural and pedagogical issues in early childhood education.

Name: Principles and Practices in Secondary Education
Desc: Analysis of criticisms of secondary education and of current proposals for reform; conflicting conceptions of teaching, learning, cognition and related approaches to curriculum, instruction and evaluation; current theoretical and research approaches; implications for educational policy and practice.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor

Name: Planning, Managing and Evaluating School Instruction
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Exploration and observation of skills and techniques for organizing and assessing learning in schools.
Reqs: EDCI 2400, EDCI 3000 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3127, EDCI 3137 and EDCI 3200

Name: Seminar: Reflective Teaching in Secondary Subjects
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 4003. Critical issues and pedagogical practices related to the reflective teacher of English, social studies, science or mathematics.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor

Name: Seminar: Critical Issues in Secondary School Teaching
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 4004. Critical issues in the nature of knowledge and inquiry in school subjects: English, mathematics, science and social studies.

Name: Student Teaching: Practice and Reflection in Grades 1-3
Desc: grade point average; Students must earn a grade of C or better to receive credit, which is required for teacher certification. May be taken twice for a maximum of 12 credit hours. 4 hrs. lecture; 32 hrs. lab/field experience in multi-level, multicultural settings. Designed to partially fulfill student teaching requirements and to prepare student to be effective classroom teachers in grades 1-3. Students must earn a grade of C or better to receive credit, which is required for teacher certification.

Name: Capstone Seminar in Early Childhood Education
Desc: Critically analyzing epistemology and contexts of learning; conducting action research; communicating teaching expertise.
Reqs: EDCI 4381 and EDCI 4382; concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4481

Name: Instructional Models for Mathematics and Science
Desc: Applying instructional approaches in mathematics and science for middle and high school students. Includes supervised field experiences in multicultural settings and/or informal learning environments.

Name: Student Teaching in the Elementary Grades 1
Desc: Internship in diverse multicultural settings. Successful completion of Field Experience Professional Practice courses: EDCI 2273; EDCI 3003; EDCI 3124; EDCI 3125; EDCI 3127; EDCI 3137; EDCI 3200.  The student teaching year is scheduled as an all-day, all-week experience. EDCI 4625 is the fall semester and is a prerequisite to EDCI 4626. All day, all semester student teaching experiences, including observation, participation and a minimum of 180 actual clock hours of teaching (with a substantial portion of the 180 hrs. in full-day teaching) each semester, fall and spring, under the professional supervision of an assigned public school mentor teacher. The Office of Professional Experiences assigns mentors based on field work placements in all EDCI pre-requisite field experience courses.
Reqs: Successful passage of Praxis II Elementary Content and Praxis II Principles of Learning and Teaching

Name: Student Teaching in the Elementary Grades 2
Desc: All day, all semester student teaching experiences, including observation, participation and a minimum of 180 actual clock hours of teaching (with a substantial portion of the 180 hrs. in full-day teaching) under the professional supervision of an assigned public school mentor teacher.
Reqs: Successful passage of EDCI 4625 with a C or better

Name: Student Teaching in K-12 Grades
Desc: Pass-fail grading. 1 hr. lecture; 35 hrs. lab. Student teaching practicum in diverse, multicultural K-12 settings.

Name: Internship in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Specific teaching or practicum experience in a public school setting; periodic evening seminars.
Reqs: permission of the College of Human Sciences & Education Office of Field Experiences

Name: Trends and Issues in Educating Learners with Exceptionalities
Desc: Offered in Su Requires field experience with student(s) with exceptionalities in a school environment. Exceptionality and special education; characteristics, educational needs and instructional practice; current trends and issues in service provision.

Name: School and Classroom Management Applied to Students with Exceptionalities
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Skills for behavior management of children with exceptionalities in school settings, emphasizing evidence-based school-wide and classroom application.

Name: Learning and Behavior Principles Applied to Students with Exceptionalities
Consultation, Collaboration and Co-teaching
Desc: Professional roles; models and practices in building cooperative and inclusive environments for education; emphasis on consulting teacher, collaborative consultation, co-teaching and building effective communications among educators, parents and other professionals in providing education and other services to children with exceptionalities.

Name: Teaching Students with Significant Disabilities
Desc: Requires practical field experience with student(s) with disabilities in a school/clinical environment. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab./field experience. Planning, delivery, and evaluation of individualized programming for students with significant disabilities.

Name: Teaching in the Multicultural Classroom
Desc: Strategies and resources for teaching students of cultural diversity in the classroom; development of units and activities of cultural variety.

Name: Special Topics in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Methods, trends and issues in curriculum and instruction.

Name: Special Topics in Education
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. New methods, trends and techniques.

Name: Foundations of Applied Behavioral Analysis in Education
Desc: An introduction to behavior analytic principles, definitions, characteristics, processes, and concepts. An introduction to behavioral consultation.

Name: Measurement of Behavior: Analysis and Evaluation of Behavior Change in Education
Desc: A basic introduction to behavioral assessment and the measurement, display, analysis, and evaluation of behavioral data.

Name: Promoting Positive Behavior Change in Education
Desc: Behavior change procedures and systems support in applied behavior analysis.

Name: Applied Behavior Analysis Practicum in Education
Desc: Supervised practicum in the application of behavior analytic practices in an educational setting.

Name: Trends and Issues in Emotional and Behavioral Disturbance
Desc: An in-depth examination of issues and trends in emotional and behavioral disturbance including diagnosis, etiology, current theory and delivery systems.

Name: Advanced Evaluation and Assessment for Students at-Risk
Desc: Requires practical field experience with students with disabilities in a school environment. Identification and diagnosis of learning and behavior problems; IDEA and Section 504 legal requirements; administration and interpretation of individually administered standardized tests, design of classroom-based assessments and methods of comparative analysis; instructional and service recommendations based on multifaceted assessment.

Name: Advanced Practicum in Evaluation and Assessment
Desc: Supervised experience in educational evaluation and assessment; practical and in-depth approach; procedures for prereferral screening, for conducting individual assessments, including evaluating for eligibility, interpreting data for instructional decision-making and for designing ongoing data collection systems.

Name: Explicit Instructional Models for Students with Disabilities
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Evaluating the research base and theories supporting the use of instructional and assessment models, including Direct Instruction Model and curriculum-based assessment.

Name: Strategic Instructional Models for Students with Disabilities
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Evaluating the research base and theories supporting the use of strategic instructional and assessment models; emphasis on the use of strategic instruction with students with mild to moderate disabilities.

Name: Legal and Ethical Issues in Special Education
Desc: Offered in Su Legal and ethical issues in special education; specific emphasis on IDEA, Section 504, case law, regulatory issues, professional responsibilities and CEC standards for professional practice.

Name: The Contemporary Family
Desc: See CFS 7051.

Name: Topics and Issues in Child and Family Studies
Desc: See CFS 7052.

Name: Infant Behavior and Development
Desc: Also offered as CFS 7053. Infant personality, development and socialization; major transactions in the infant’s life; family and home; child-care facilities and caregivers; support systems within larger societies.

Name: Child Guidance and Behavior
Desc: Normal, age-related behavior patterns; child guidance practices and their consequences; techniques and procedures for successful parenting and for improved classroom management; theoretical bases.

Name: Human Development
Desc: See CFS 7055.

Name: Theories of Child Development
Desc: See CFS 7056.

Name: Theories in Family Science
Desc: See CFS 7057.

Name: Parent Involvement in Early Childhood Education
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Interpersonal relationships and involvement of parents in early childhood education programs; research and existing models of parent involvement.

Name: Literacy for Elementary Grades
Desc: Current instructional procedures and research in literacy instruction in the elementary school; approaches and ideas for teaching literacy to culturally different students.

Name: Teaching Literacy to Students of Diverse Cultural Backgrounds
Desc: Characteristics of learners from different cultural settings; analysis of methods and materials that support literacy instruction for these students.
Reqs: EDCI 7105 or EDCI 7135 or consent of instructor

Name: Topics in Reading Education
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Issues and practices in elementary through adult reading education.

Name: Studies in the Teaching of Elementary School Mathematics
Desc: Techniques and materials for teaching elementary school mathematics; relationship between learning theories and acquisition of mathematical skills and concepts.

Name: Studies in the Teaching of Elementary School Language Arts
Desc: Practices and curricula in the teaching of elementary school language arts.

Name: Early Literacy Development and Instruction
Desc: Current research on early literacy development and learning, with an emphasis on pre-conventional stages of literacy.

Name: Writing Seminar: From Idea to Manuscript
Desc: Current research on scholarly writing productivity with emphasis on expertise, competence, organization, skill sets, supports, and tools for producing manuscripts for publication, prospectuses, presentation proposals, or grants; demonstration and student production.

Name: Techniques and Resources for Literacy Instruction
Desc: Methods and materials in all areas of literacy; demonstration and student production; application of materials and methods for effective literacy instruction.

Name: Disciplinary Literacy
Desc: Relationships between learning skills and content areas; the reading and writing process; materials and research related to literacy.

Name: Techniques for Teaching Literacy in the Middle and Secondary School
Desc: Literacy skills appropriate for the upper levels; approaches for teaching literacy; techniques for improving the school literacy program.

Name: Studies in the Teaching of Social Studies in Secondary Schools
Desc: Theory and research with practical application to areas of study needed to teach social studies in the secondary school.

Name: Studies in the Teaching of Mathematics in Secondary Schools
Desc: Practices and issues in techniques and materials for teaching mathematics in secondary schools; relationship between learning theories and acquisition of mathematical skills and concepts.

Name: Studies in the Teaching of Composition in Secondary Schools
Desc: Theory and research with practical application to the teaching of composition in secondary schools.

Name: The Teaching of Literature in Secondary Schools
Desc: No description provided

Name: Studies in the Teaching of Secondary School Science
Desc: Instructional materials, evaluation practices and science teaching skills for grades 6-12.

Name: Studies in the Teaching of Foreign Languages
Desc: Principles and current research related to the teaching of foreign languages.
Reqs: completion of an undergraduate foreign language methods course and/or teaching experience; or consent of instructor

Name: Critical Analysis of Current Literary Research
Desc: Evaluation of current and needed research; application of research findings in the instructional program.
Reqs: 12 hours of graduate literacy courses or equivalent

Name: Teaching in the Science Laboratory
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Interpreting research in laboratory science instruction; use of results to generate creative laboratory activities.

Name: Critical Race Theory and Education
Desc: This course examines how race has been conceptualized, theorized and researched in education.

Name: Urban and Community Education
Desc: An exploration of urban and community education; introduction to core concepts in urban and community-based education, historic and contemporary challenges in urban education, and engagement with relevant theoretical frameworks.

Name: Poverty in American Schools and Communities
Desc: Overview of research and theory about how poverty interacts with academic achievement, as well as seminal and emerging research on how to minimize the challenges poverty presents for children and families.

Name: Topics in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Science Education
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Mathematics Education
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.
Reqs: EDCI 7109 or EDCI 7141 or consent of instructor

Name: Topics in Language Arts Education
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topic in a specific subject matter, level of instruction or a methodological problem in teaching English language arts.

Name: Diagnostic and Prescriptive Teaching in Mathematics
Desc: Techniques for assessing students’ skill levels and understanding in K-12 mathematics and for tailoring instruction to individual needs.

Name: Teaching Literature in the Elementary School
Desc: Role of literature in elementary education; relevant teaching issues and strategies; integration of literature into the elementary curriculum.

Name: Teaching Written Composition from PK through Grade 6
Desc: Practices and curricula in the teaching of written composition in PK through Grade 6; its relationship to English language arts and literacy instruction.

Name: Teaching Multicultural Children’s Literature
Desc: Multicultural literature for children from elementary through junior high school; historical and contemporary perspectives; implications for the classroom.

Name: Foundations of Secondary or K-12 Educational Theory, Policy and Practice
Desc: Social contexts, history and philosophy of current and perennial issues in education; conflicting purposes and functions of public schooling; economic and political analysis of educational policy; implications of conflicting approaches to teaching and learning; current theory and research.
Reqs: cohort membership and completion of EDCI 7460, EDCI 7461 or consent of instructor

Name: Fall Practicum in Secondary or K-12 Schools
Desc: Pass-fail grading. 1 hr. lecture; 15 hrs. lab. First of two practica in local schools.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor

Name: Spring Practicum in Secondary or K-12 Schools
Desc: Pass-fail grading. 1 hr. lecture; 15 hrs. lab. Second of two practica in local schools.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor

Name: Seminar: The Teacher-Researcher in Secondary School Subjects
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Study of teacher-researcher literature; its application to secondary teaching and curriculum in the subject area (English, mathematics, science or social studies).
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor

Name: Research Project in Secondary or K-12 Teacher Education
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Development, completion and presentation of a research problem in curriculum and instruction that grows out of fifth-year clinical experiences and precedes course work.
Reqs: cohort membership and completion of EDCI 7460 and EDCI 7461 or consent of instructor

Name: Teaching Practicum I
Desc: Pass-fail grading. 20 hrs. lab. Along with the Seminar in Teaching Research and the Master’s Project, this course is designed to partially fulfill student teaching requirements and to prepare students to be effective classroom teachers.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 7482, EDCI 7484

Name: Teaching Practicum II
Desc: Pass-fail grading. 20 hrs. lab. Along with the Seminar in Teaching Research and the Master’s Project, this course is designed to partially fulfill student teaching requirements and to prepare students to be effective classroom teachers.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 7483, EDCI 7485

Name: Seminar in Teaching Research I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. An integral part of the fifth-year teaching research project; along with the Teaching Practicum and the Master’s Project, this course partially fulfills student teaching requirements.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 7480, EDCI 7484

Name: Seminar in Teaching Research II
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. An integral part of the fifth-year teaching research project; along with the Teaching Practicum and the Master’s Project, this course partially fulfills student teaching requirements.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 7481, EDCI 7485

Name: Master’s Project I
Desc: Development and completion of a research problem in curriculum and instruction that grows out of the first semester’s clinical experience.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 7480, EDCI 7482

Name: Master’s Project II
Desc: Development and completion of a research problem in curriculum and instruction that grows out of the second and culminating semester’s clinical experience.
Reqs: cohort membership or consent of instructor and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 7481, EDCI 7483

Name: Advanced Seminar and Practicum in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: The student, major professor and a committee will structure experiences around the student’s needs and interests.

Name: Diagnosis/Assessment in Literacy
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Mastery level skills for evaluating literacy strengths and weaknesses of elementary and secondary school students; theoretical models and a practicum for applying techniques.

Name: Guiding Classroom Literacy Instruction
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Procedures for guiding instruction in literacy; theory and practice.

Name: Advanced Internship in Literacy
Desc: Field experiences in various job-related settings. 1 hr. lecture; 10 hrs. lab. Teaching experiences at the local school and university levels; administrative experience at the parish level and consultant experience at the state level.
Reqs: permission of department, advanced standing in the specialist or doctoral program or equivalent

Name: Applied Research in Literacy
Desc: Individual research projects.
Reqs: enrollment in advanced graduate program and ELRC 4249 or equivalent

Name: Advanced Seminar in Special Education I
Desc: Current trends and issues in special education, including legal/ethical considerations, history, theory and seminal research.

Name: Applied Learning Theory for Exceptional Learners
Desc: A study of the development of human learning theories, experimental research, and the application of these theories and research to evaluating and modifying the behavior of exceptional learners in modern classrooms.

Name: Individual Study in Special Education
Desc: No description provided

Name: Nature and Needs of the Gifted and Talented
Desc: Historical perspective, social, emotional and educational characteristics; administrative considerations; sociological and psychological studies; special populations.

Name: Models and Strategies for Teaching the Gifted
Desc: Examination of models, teaching strategies and resources for planning appropriate learning experiences for gifted and talented students in diverse settings.

Name: Creative Behavior
Desc: Nature and analysis of creative behavior; appraisal and implementation of specific processes designed to encourage creative productivity.

Name: Developing Curriculum for the Gifted
Desc: An examination of curricular theories and models for use in gifted education programs, including the development and evaluation of educational plans for individuals and groups.

Name: Social and Emotional Development of the Gifted
Desc: In depth study of the social and emotional development of the gifted; specific emphasis on underachievement, counseling, youth with special needs and working with other mental health professionals in the school setting.

Name: Practicum in Education for the Gifted
Desc: Planning, implementing and evaluating teaching strategies, materials and counseling techniques in a school program.

Name: Seminar in Current Trends in Education Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Seminar for beginning doctoral students in curriculum and instruction.

Name: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: For advanced graduate students who are qualified to undertake individual problems.

Name: Problems in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: For advanced graduate students who are qualified to undertake individual problems.

Name: Elementary School Curriculum
Desc: Content, organization and evaluation of the elementary school curriculum.

Name: Secondary School Curriculum
Desc: Content, organization, and evaluation of the secondary school curriculum.

Name: Early Childhood Education
Desc: Historical, theoretical, philosophical and programmatic issues that affect contemporary early childhood education.

Name: The Brain and Learning
Desc: The application of current theories of neuroscience for instructional strategies.

Name: Stress in Educational Contexts
Desc: Students will survey contemporary theories, research and approaches to the study of stress and coping within educational contexts in light of developmental theories.

Name: Intervention Research in the Early Childhood Classroom
Desc: Students will be learning about single subject research design and concurrently designing their own single subject research project.

Name: Curriculum Theory
Desc: Means for strengthening the curriculum; links between past and current concepts of curriculum.

Name: Analysis of Research on Teaching
Desc: Theory of design and application of research related to systematized instruction.

Name: Curriculum Planning
Desc: Principles of curriculum needs assessment, design, implementation, and evaluation.

Name: Education and Cognition
Desc: Understanding human cognition and cognitive change; implications for educational theory, practice and research.

Name: Traditions of Inquiry in Education
Desc: Theoretical and methodological issues related to research traditions in education; development of major traditions.

Name: Analysis of Research in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: A max. of 6 sem. hrs. may be earned in this series; only 3 sem. hrs. may be earned in any one area. Factors influencing research and critical analysis of selected research in one of the following areas: curriculum, mathematics, science, language arts, social or early childhood education.

Name: Analysis of Research in Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: A max. of 6 sem. hrs. may be earned in this series; only 3 sem. hrs. may be earned in any one area. Factors influencing research and critical analysis of selected research in one of the following areas: curriculum, mathematics, science, language arts, social or early childhood education.

Name: Seminar: Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: A max. of 6 sem. hrs. may be earned in this series when topics vary. Trends and issues in one of the following areas: curriculum, mathematics, science, language arts, social or early childhood education.

Name: Seminar: Curriculum and Instruction
Desc: A max. of 6 sem. hrs. may be earned in this series when topics vary. Trends and issues in one of the following areas: curriculum, mathematics, science, language arts, social or early childhood education.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Special Topics in Education
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Methods, trends and issues in education.

Name: Introduction to Engineering: Electrical and Computer Engineering
Desc: Pass-fail grading. 1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Survey of engineering concepts with specific focus on the electrical and computer engineering discipline.

Name: Circuits I
Desc: Time-domain analysis of electrical networks.
Reqs: credit or registration in EE 1810, MATH 2070, and PHYS 2113 or consent of division

Name: Circuits II
Desc: Frequency domain analysis of electrical networks.

Name: Electronics I
Desc: Terminal behavior of semiconductor devices and basic circuits.

Name: Electronics Laboratory I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab.

Name: Digital Logic I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Boolean algebra; logic gates; analysis and synthesis of combinational logic circuits; introduction to sequential circuits.

Name: Digital Logic II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Analysis and synthesis of sequential logic circuits; standard logic elements such as multiplexers, counters and registers.
Reqs: EE 2741 and credit or registration in CSC 1253

Name: Tools in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Contemporary tools in the area of electrical and computer engineering.
Reqs: CSC 1253 and credit or registration in EE 2130 and EE 2231

Name: Comprehensive Electrical Engineering
Desc: For nonelectrical engineering majors. Elementary circuits, devices and systems in electrical engineering.

Name: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Prerequisites will vary depending on the topic.

Name: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering with Lab
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Prerequisites will vary depending on the topic. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab.

Name: Special Projects
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Individual work with instructor on special project selected by instructor and student.

Name: Special Projects
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Individual work with instructor on special project selected by instructor and student.

Name: Engineering Practice
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Written final report required. Work experience in solving electrical and computer engineering problems in an engineering environment.
Reqs: permission of department and either completion of one co-op session or six months of full time employment in an appropriate area

Name: Probability for Electrical and Computer Engineering
Desc: Basic concepts of probability theory and statistics with applications to electrical and computer engineering; axioms of probability, continuous, discrete, and conditional probability density and distribution functions, expectations, statistical inference, and random processes.
Reqs: MATH 2057 and credit or registration in EE 2810

Name: Electronics II
Desc: Analysis and design of electronic circuits; emphasis on concepts and device models.

Name: Electronics Laboratory II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab.
Reqs: EE 2231 and concurrent registration in EE 3220

Name: Modern Electronics Lab
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Electronic instruments, semiconductor-device circuits and current nanofabrication.
Reqs: EE 2231 and concurrent registration in EE 3220

Name: Solid State Devices I
Desc: Physics and analysis of basic semiconductor devices; principles of integrated circuit fabrication.

Name: Electrical and Magnetic Fields
Desc: Maxwell’s equations; wave propagation and reflection in isotropic media; static fields.

Name: Electric Power
Desc: Basic principles of electromechanical energy conversion and power system analysis.

Name: Communications in Computing
Desc: Coreq.: EE 3150 or equivalent. Theoretical and practical factors in designing computer communications networks; communication principles and codes; network topology and architecture; protocol layers; security; current and advanced applications.

Name: Discrete Structures for Computer Engineering
Desc: Mathematical logic and proof methods; functions and relations; graph theory; combinatorics; applications in computer engineering.

Name: Microprocessor Systems
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Theory and design of microprocessors; seminconductor technologies, architectures, assembly language, software development, input/output design, applications, and interfacing.

Name: Computer Organization
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and CSC 3501. Structure and organization of computer systems; instruction sets; arithmetic; data path and control design.

Name: Electronics
Desc: For nonelectrical engineering majors. Basic electronics and instrumentation.

Name: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Students in curricula other than electrical engineering should consult the instructor. ABET category: 3 hrs. engineering science. Selected topics of current interest.

Name: Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Students in curricula other than electrical engineering should consult the instructor. ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Selected topics of current interest.

Name: Special Topics in Electrical and Computer Engineering with Lab
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Prerequisites will vary depending on the topic. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab.

Name: Research for Undergraduates I
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Individual work with instructor on research topic selected by instructor and an undergraduate student who is also enrolled in the ECE Accelerated Masters’s Program.

Name: Research for Undergraduates II
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Individual work with instructor on advanced research topic selected by instructor and undergraduate student who is also enrolled in the ECE Accelerated Master’s Program.

Name: Algorithms and Implementations for Digital Signal Processing
Desc: Design algorithms for FIR and IIR filters, adaptive estimation and its applications and multirate digital signal processing; Digital signal processors and implementations for signal processors for spectrum analysis and estimation, FIR and IIR digital filters and adaptive echo cancellation.

Name: Digital Signal Processing Algorithms and Implementations
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Discrete-Time Signals and Systems. Time-Domain Characterization and Transform-Domain Representation. IIR and FIR Digital Filter Design. DSP Algorithm Implementations.

Name: Solid State Devices II
Desc: Physics and analysis of advanced semiconductor devices, including photonic and high-frequency devices.

Name: Linear Circuit Design
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Fabrication and use of discrete and monolithic integrated circuits; use of building blocks for design of analog systems.

Name: VLSI Design
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Design and implementation of logic gates for application-specific integrated circuits; system design methodology using CMOS technology.

Name: Chemical and Biological Sensors
Desc: Fundamentals of chemical and biological sensors; molecular recognition and transduction principles; fundamentals of electrochemical sensors, optical and mass-sensitive sensing techniques, and performance factors of chemical and biological sensors.
Reqs: CHEM 1201 and EE 3232 or their equivalents

Name: Digital Integrated Circuits
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Analysis and design of digital integrated circuit logic gates in bipolar and MOS technology; semiconductor memories and their operations.

Name: Electronic Instrumentation and Metrology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Application of electronic principles to the design and development of practical systems including instrumentation, data analysis and metrology; design and construction of term projects.

Name: Optical Electronics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Interaction of optical radiation with various media; theory of laser oscillations and specific laser systems; modulation and detection of optical radiation; fiber optic applications.

Name: Modern Imaging Techniques
Desc: Tech Elective. Introduction to various major modern imaging techniques, including but not limited to, electrical engineering design principles and physical mechanisms of modern imaging techniques and components, their biomedical applications and limitations, fundamentals of optical and electron microscopy, florescence imaging, and light tissue interaction.

Name: Fiber Optic and Microwave Propagation
Desc: Wave propagation at microwave and optical frequencies in metallic waveguides and optical fibers.

Name: Applied Electromagnetics: RF Systems
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Analysis and design of RF systems, transmission lines, impedance matching networks, RF filter design, antennas, high speed circuits, single and multi-port networks, RF modeling.

Name: Power System Protection
Desc: Broad based introduction to utility and industrial power system protection. Topics of study include transmission, distribution, generation and industrial distribution systems.

Name: Power System Analysis and Modeling
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Basic principles of power system modeling and analysis in steady state operation including, components modeling, network modeling, symmetrical faults, and introduction to asymmetrical faults.

Name: Electric Machine Design
Desc: lecture, 2 hrs. lab. ABET category: 2 hrs. design, 1 hr. engineering science. Design and performance analysis of electric machines in steady-state and dynamic conditions using a simulation on PC and lab experiments.

Name: Modeling and Analysis of Modern Power Systems
Desc: Analysis of power systems with penetration of renewable energy systems, microgrid and smart grid design considerations, load flow algorithms, symmetrical and unsymmetrical fault analysis, basic principles of modern power system modeling and analysis in steady state operation including, components modeling and network modeling.

Name: Renewable Energy Generation Systems
Desc: Conventional power generation issues; introduction to renewable energies and their integration into power grids; design of photovoltaic and wind microgrid generation stations; energy storage applications and models.

Name: Power System Reliability
Desc: Fundamental knowledge on the reliability evaluation of engineering systems with emphasis on electric power systems; models and methodologies for power systems reliability assessment; application of probability theory for design and management of power generation, transmission and distribution systems.

Name: Power System Operation and Control
Desc: Introduction to operation and control of major utility interconnected power system. Control of generation and operation of interconnected utility grid, transmission systems, utility distribution systems and large industrial power systems.

Name: Distribution System Design
Desc: ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Power distribution systems; emphasis on design and applications.

Name: Power Electronics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Design of power semiconductor converters including controlled rectifiers, inverters, AC voltage controllers and DC-DC converters.

Name: Adjustable Speed Drives
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. ABET category: 2 hrs. design, 1 hr. engineering science. Design and test of DC and AC motor variable speed drives combined with an analysis of their static and dynamic properties.

Name: Topics in Control System Design
Desc: ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Compensation of single loop and multiloop systems; state estimation; stability; application to industrial controllers; design using computer simulation packages.

Name: Discrete Control System Design
Desc: ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Sampling and reconstruction of signals; analysis and design of sampled data systems; discrete time systems and controllers.

Name: Digital Communication and Networking
Desc: Digital coding of analog information, baseband transmission, decision theory, modulation, design considerations, applications.

Name: Random Processes I
Desc: Probability spaces; random variables and processes; second order processes; spectral analysis; filtering.

Name: Special Topics in Computer Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Students in curricula other than computer engineering should consult the instructor. ABET category: 3 hrs. engineering science. Selected topics of current interest.

Name: Special Topics in Computer Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Students in curricula other than computer engineering should consult the instructor. ABET category: 2 hrs. design; 1 hr. engineering science. Selected topics of current interest.

Name: Computer Architecture
Desc: Memory hierarchy; pipelining techniques; design philosophies; parallel computing fundamentals.

Name: 3D Graphical and Geometric Modeling
Desc: Theory and design in computer graphics modeling and processing; 3D shape representation and manipulation; interactive 3D shape design, deformation and editing.
Reqs: CSC 3102 and MATH 2090 or equivalent in the areas of C/C++ programming and linear algebra

Name: Neural Computing
Desc: Neural networks and automata; network architecture; learning models; applications to signal processing, vision, speech, and robotics; VLSI implementations.

Name: Digital Design Using Hardware Description Languages
Desc: Design of digital systems using a hardware description language (HDL). Basic and intermediate language topics; structural and behavioral models as synthesis sources; synthesis tools; coding for efficient synthesis; coding strategies for common digital circuits.

Name: Networked Games and their Algorithms
Desc: Algorithms for computer games including path finding and artificial intelligence. Compensating for latency and bandwith constraints in massively multiplayer online games.

Name: Structure of Computers and Computations I
Desc: Hardware and software complexity analyses; structures of both computers and computations.

Name: Senior Design I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Senior design projects.
Reqs: ENGL 2000, EE 3610 or EE 3752, senior standing in the College of Engineering, and one of EE 3160, EE 3220, EE 3410, EE 3530, EE 3755 and credit or registration in EE 3150

Name: Senior Design II
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Continuation of senior design projects from EE 4810. Construction and test.

Name: Digital Media Capstone
Desc: Credit will not be given for both EE 4859 and ART 4059. 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Culminating capstone project experience requiring interdisciplinary teams to prototype a digital media work or application.
Reqs: At least 15 hours credit towards the Digital Media TECH minor

Name: Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Electrical Engineering Research I
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Individual study.

Name: Electrical Engineering Research II
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Advanced individual study.
Reqs: EE 7091 and permission of the department

Name: Advanced Topics in Signal Processing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Theory and Application of Digital Signal Processing
Desc: Digital filter design, spectrum analysis, digital hardware implementations and applications.

Name: Signal and Information Processing: Foundations, Modeling, and Filtering
Desc: Contemporary signal and information processing methods prevalent in modern applications including but not limited to telecommunications, medical technology, radar and sonar, and data analysis: signal representation in vector spaces, linear inverse and least squares problems, signal modeling, and iterative and recursive methods for signal and information processing.

Name: Multirate Signal Processing and Filter Banks
Desc: Multi-rate signal processing operations, multi-rate system analysis, maximally decimated and perfect reconstruction filter banks, time frequency analysis, and fundamentals of wavelets.
Reqs: EE 4160 or equivalent and knowledge of linear algebra and vector space analysis

Name: Advanced Topics in Electronics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Semiconductor Devices I: Bipolar
Desc: Semiconductor material properties, equilibrium and nonequilibrium processes, physical principles of p-n junctions and quasi-neutral material; modeling of diodes and bipolar transistors.

Name: Semiconductor Devices II: Field Effect
Desc: Surface effects; metal-insulator-semiconductor structure; modeling of MOS capacitors and IGFETs.

Name: Physics of Device Electronics
Desc: Semiconductor physics and necessary assumptions for tractable device analysis; elements of statistical physics, transport phenomena in solids, band theory of solids and semiconductor junctions.

Name: Small-Geometry and High-Speed Devices
Desc: Charge carrier transport in small and high-electron mobility semiconductor devices, hot-electron effects, size effects and heterojunction boundaries, heterostructure devices, tunneling devices, ballistic transport devices and surfaces and interfaces in heterostructures.

Name: Integrated Circuit Engineering
Desc: Fabrication processes and device design for monolithic integrated circuits; relation to circuit performance; thin- and thick-film circuits.

Name: Nanoelectronics
Desc: Nanoscale devices, Circuits and Integration.
Reqs: Credit or registration in EE 4242 or permission of instructor

Name: VLSI Systems
Desc: Design and implementation of very large scale integrated systems; structured design methodology using MOS technology.

Name: Advanced Lithography and Metrology
Desc: Physical principles used in state-of-the-art microlithography; optical systems, x-rays, e-beams, resists, measurement and inspection techniques.

Name: Integrated Sensors and Actuators
Desc: Sensor principles and design considerations; bulk and surface micromachining fabrication technologies including LIGA; microactuators and microelectromechanical devices; integration of sensors/actuators and electrical circuitry on the same chip.
Reqs: EE 7240 and EE 4242 or consent of instructor

Name: BioMEMS
Desc: Fundamentals and fabrication techniques of biomicroelectromechanical systems (BioMEMS); technical issues and applications of biomedical microdevices; emerging BioMEMS and lab-on-a-chip technologies.

Name: Mixed-Signal Integrated Circuit Design
Desc: Design and technology of analog and mixed analog-digital intergrated circuits for signal processing including applications; mixed-signal integrated circuit testing and measurements.
Reqs: EE 4240 and EE 4242 or consent of instructor

Name: Semiconductor Power Devices
Desc: Operation and characteristics of semiconductor energy conversion devices with emphasis on physical mechanisms involved; fabrication of energy conversion devices.

Name: Semiconductor Materials
Desc: Theory and application of crystal growth from melt and chemical vapor deposition; preparation and purification of elemental and compound semiconductors; structural properties and their effect on electrical and physical parameters; amorphous semiconductors.

Name: Advanced Topics in Power
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: No title provided
Desc: Topics on special purpose electric motors used in automation, robots and electric or magnetically levitated vehicles.

Name: Dynamics of Microgrids
Desc: Transient stability analysis in micro grids, modeling of power systems for control and stability analysis, flexible ac transmission systems, renewable energy integration, and voltage stability.

Name: Static Power Converters
Desc: Design of power converters and AC drives, including voltage controllers, PWM inverters, cycloconverter and switched-mode power supplies.

Name: Intelligent Control with Application to Power Systems
Desc: Nonlinear systems stability analysis, Lyapunov stability criteria, feedback linearization, backstepping and sliding mode control, adaptive neural network control, overview of power system nonlinear modeling, and nonlinear control for power systems.

Name: Power Systems Operation and Optimization
Desc: Concepts, models, and solution methodologies for power systems operation; application of optimization techniques for power generation and transmission management.

Name: Harmonics in Power Systems
Desc: Power flow in nonsinusoidal systems, measurements, compensation, symmetrization and harmonic suppression.

Name: Grid Integration of Renewable Energy
Desc: Grid requirements for Photovoltaic and wind energy systems; Generators and converter structures for wind energy systems; Photovoltaic converter structures; Grid converter control for photovoltaic and wind energy systems.

Name: Advanced Electrical Drives
Desc: Advanced topics in electric drives including vector control of induction motor drives and permanent magnet synchronous motor drives.

Name: Electric and Hybrid Electric Vehicles
Desc: Power system architecture of electric and hybrid electric vehicles, components of electrified powertrains including energy storage system, power electronics converters and electric machines, torque and speed control of electric propulsion motors, fundamentals of chargers.

Name: Advanced Topics in Controls
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Advanced Linear Systems
Desc: Modern approaches for the analysis and identification of linear, discrete and continuous time, control systems; state variable and fractional description techniques, functional analytic methods.

Name: Robust Control
Desc: Internal stability, model uncertainty, robust stability, robust performance, controller parameterizations, design limitations, loop shaping H∞ control and other optimal robust control design techniques.

Name: System Identification
Desc: Conventional parameter estimation and adaptive modeling; control oriented identification; model uncertainties; model validation; review of research literature on system identification.

Name: Topics in Modern System Science
Desc: Research literature, operator theory and functional analysis applied to control engineering problems.

Name: Advanced Digital Control Systems
Desc: Theory and design of sampled-data control systems: including discretization of continuous-time systems and lifting of sampled-data systems; performance analysis in frequency and time domain; design techniques based on optimal controls; robustness analysis of sampled-data feedback control systems under plant perturbations.

Name: Advanced Topics in Communications
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Digital Communication I
Desc: Decision theory, geometric representation of signals, optimum receiver principles, digital modulation schemes, bandwidth and power efficiency, coded modulation.

Name: Advanced Topics in Digital Communications
Desc: Time and Frequency domain approaches to transceiver design for communication over frequency selective, inter-symbol-interference (ISI) and multiuser channels.

Name: Detection and Estimation Theory
Desc: Hypothesis testing, detection of known and unknown signals, estimation of signal parameters, signal resolution.

Name: Information Theory, Coding and Cryptography
Desc: Measures of information, channel capacity, Shannon and Huffman coding, rate-distortion theory, linear codes, cyclic codes, BCH and Goppa codes, convolutional codes, problems of data security, probabilistic ciphers, computational complexity ciphers.

Name: Random Processes II
Desc: Sequences of random variables, renewal processes, Markov chains and queueing models.

Name: Wireless Communication Networks
Desc: Theory, implementation, standards and security issues in mobile wireless communication networks.

Name: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Computer Arithmetic
Desc: Number systems; arithmetic algorithms; high performance adders, multipliers, dividers; floating-point arithmetic; residue number systems; hardware implementation.

Name: Advanced Computer Architecture
Desc: High performance computer architectures; vector processing; parallel processing and interconnection networks.

Name: GPU Microarchitecture
Desc: Organization, programming, and design of graphics processing units (GPUs) and similar devices.

Name: Interconnection Networks
Desc: Interconnection network theory, analysis and implementation; shared memory, coherent caches and related topics.

Name: Multiprocessor Computer System Design
Desc: Symmetric shared memory multiprocessors, distributed shared memory systems, simultaneous multithreading and chip-multiprocessors.

Name: Image Analysis I
Desc: Basic fundamentals and techniques of digital image processing; hardware and software applications, 2D transforms, preprocessing, texture analysis and edge detection; emphasis on application of theory to practical problems.

Name: Machine Recognition of Patterns
Desc: Decision functions; Bayesian decision theory; cluster analysis; design of deterministic, stochastic and fuzzy classifiers; unsupervised learning; feature selection.
Reqs: EE 4660 or equivalent and knowledge of programming language

Name: Geometric and Visual Computing
Desc: Theory ad design in graphics modeling and processing; 3D shape representation and manipulation; Interactive 3D shape design, deformation and editing.

Name: Internetworking Principles
Desc: Internet concepts, networks, and transport layers, IP switching, Routing techniques, Internet security, Firewalls.

Name: Software Design Principles
Desc: Engineering approach to computer software development; structured and modular programming concepts; software design and management; program testing and correctness proofs; diagnostic tools; software measures; other topics from software engineering.

Name: Program Parallelization
Desc: Analysis and optimization of programs for a variety of architectures; impact on architectural design.

Name: Structure of Computers and Computations II
Desc: Mathematical treatment of space and time complexity of computations; formal models of computers and computations.

Name: Models and Methods for Parallel Computation
Desc: Abstract models of parallel computation; algorithms, complexity and simulations.

Name: Distributed Computing
Desc: Distributed computing models, algorithms, and applications.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Introduction to Scholarship in Education
Desc: Restricted to PhD students in the department or permission of instructor. Introduction to scholarship in education and to demands and expectations of doctoral study.

Name: P-12 Career and College Readiness
Desc: Designed to link elements of career, ecosystems, and lifespan development theory to practical interventions for career education and college counseling in P-12 school.

Name: Student Development Theory
Desc: Explores the development of students in the higher education environment, including theories and research related to intellectual, moral, ego, psychosocial, career and spiritual development.

Name: Seminar in Current Trends in Education
Desc: Open only to students who have completed qualifying examination for the doctoral degree. Current issues and trends; sources, bibliography and research in the student’s major.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Open to advanced graduate students. Directed individual study under the guidance of a graduate faculty member.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Introduction to School Counseling
Desc: Introduction to the design, implementation, management and evaluation of comprehensive programs.

Name: Counseling Children
Desc: Introduction to methods and procedures.

Name: Basic Course in Interpersonal Communication
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ELRC 7345. Introduction to basic communication skills and counseling techniques.

Name: Counseling Girls and Women
Desc: Study of biological, psychological, and social issues that disproportionately impact girls and women’s health across the lifespan. Development of skills required to address the unique counseling needs of girls and women.

Name: Counseling for Disabling Conditions
Desc: Etiology, identification and counseling interventions for conditions and disorders which result in disablement and impaired functioning.

Name: Introduction to Counseling Services
Desc: Overview of counseling profession; ethical and legal issues in counseling.

Name: Crisis Intervention and Traumatology
Desc: Advanced topics in crisis counseling of children, adolescents, and adults. Emphasis is placed on learning interventions for those clients who experience a crisis or a trauma. The basics of traumatology will also be covered. Interventions discussed will be viewed through a diversity sensitive lens.

Name: Special Problems in Guidance and Counseling
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab.

Name: Group Techniques and Dynamics in Counseling
Desc: Dynamics of small group processes, theories of group counseling and basic group leadership skills.

Name: Counseling Theory and Techniques
Desc: Review of major counseling theories and intervention methods.

Name: Analysis of the Individual
Desc: Offered in Su Overview of selection, administration, interpretation and use of assessment and evaluation instruments and techniques in counseling.

Name: Vocational Counseling
Desc: Materials and techniques in vocational counseling of adolescents and adults.

Name: Counseling Skills and Interventions
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ELRC 4365. Overview of counseling techniques and interventions to facilitate client engagement in the counseling process.

Name: Counseling Skills for Substance Use Problems
Desc: Review assessment issues and counseling interventions for those who have substance use problems. Counselor identity and the American Counseling Association’s ethical standards are examined with regards to counseling individuals with substance use problems.

Name: Advanced Issues in School Counseling
Desc: Advanced topics in counseling children and adolescents in schools. Emphasis on advocacy, leadership, collaboration and systemic change in alignment with the American School Counseling Association National Model.

Name: Practicum in School Counseling
Desc: 6-18 hrs. lab in work setting. Supervised experience in elementary, middle or high school settings.
Reqs: ELRC 4360, ELRC 4365, ELRC 7330, ELRC 7331, ELRC 7395 and consent of instructor

Name: Community Agency Counseling Practicum
Desc: 2 hrs. conf.; 1 hr. lab; 6-18 hrs. lab in a work setting. Supervised clinical experience in community agency settings (e.g., counseling center, mental health center).
Reqs: ELRC 4365, ELRC 4600, ELRC 4602, ELRC 7330, ELRC 7331, ELRC 7395 and consent of instructor

Name: Counseling Across the Lifespan
Desc: Offered in Su Assessment of the comprehensive development of clients and design of developmentally appropriate counseling interventions.

Name: Multicultural Counseling
Desc: Offered in Su Overview of cross-cultural counseling skills and review of factors which influence the behaviors of individuals from diverse populations.

Name: Family Counseling
Desc: Introduction to family system principles and their application to problem assessment, including family dynamics, family assessment, developmental stages, ethical and cultural issues.

Name: Special Topics in Counseling
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab.

Name: Couples and Marriage Counseling
Desc: Linking elements of counseling theory, family system theory, research and practical intervention for couple and marriage counseling.
Reqs: Successful completion of ELRC 7395 or by discretion of the instructor

Name: Supervised Counseling Internship
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit. 2 hrs. conf.; 20-40 hrs. per week at a clinical setting, serving children, adolescents, adults or families.
Reqs: ELRC 7362 or ELRC 7364 and consent of instructor

Name: Administration of School Personnel
Desc: Role of the school administrator in personnel planning, staff development and employee relationships.

Name: Organizational Research in Educational Administration
Desc: Primarily for doctoral students in educational administration. Research, bibliography and source materials; critical examination of organizational research studies.

Name: Internship in Educational Administration
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. For advanced graduate students qualified for internship in educational administration.

Name: Politics, Policy and Administration in Education
Desc: Primarily for doctoral students in educational administration. Critical analysis of educational policy and its development.

Name: Introduction to School Improvement/Action Research
Desc: School effectiveness research; teacher effectiveness research; school improvement; action research; based on the knowledge of these literatures, students will be required to develop a research proposal whose objective is to improve school and/or faculty performance.

Name: Advanced School Improvement/Action Research
Desc: Students refine and administer an action research project at a selected school site. Students will assess the success of their interventions through multiple measures and write a research report that reflects their experiences throughout the semester. In class discussions focusing on methodological difficulties that students encounter and how to overcome them.

Name: Best Practices of Principal Leadership I
Desc: Introduction to the knowledge and experiential base to support decision-making and action at a level of whole school responsibility.

Name: Best Practices of Principal Leadership II
Desc: Knowledge and experiential base to support decision-making and action at a level of whole school responsibility.

Name: Best Practices of Principal Leadership III
Desc: Builds upon students’ knowledge and experiential base to support decision-making and action at a level of while school responsibility.

Name: Best Practices of Principal Leadership IV
Desc: Extends the knowledge and experiential base to support decision-making and action at a level of whole school responsibility.

Name: Supervision of Instruction in Elementary and Secondary Schools
Desc: Theories, principles, and practices concerning the role of the supervisor in today’s multicultural school settings.

Name: Supervision of Student Teaching
Desc: Principles of planning, observing and evaluating student teaching; participation in student conferences.

Name: Organization and Administration of Higher Education
Desc: Organization and administration of postsecondary education in the United States and abroad; organizational theory; organization and governance structure of American higher education; patterns of institutional administration.

Name: Theory Development in Educational Administration
Desc: Primarily for doctoral students in educational administration. Critical analysis of approaches to inquiry; development of theory in educational administration.
Reqs: ELRC 7006, ELRC 7402 and ELRC 7407 or equivalent; and consent of instructor

Name: Perspectives on Leadership
Desc: Examines theories and practices of leadership from multiple perspectives.

Name: Leadership for Learning
Desc: Examination of leadership theories and practices relevant to K-12 school settings.

Name: Seminar: Educational Administration
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced topics in educational administration.

Name: Seminar in Philosophy of Education
Desc: Offered in Su Theories of education and schooling with special focus on the context of pluralistic societies.

Name: Ethics and Educational Leadership
Desc: Study of ethical theory, judgement and practice in educational contexts.

Name: Introduction to Applied Statistics in Educational Research
Desc: Basic descriptive and inferential statistics in educational research; systematic examination and interpretation of statistical information in published educational research.

Name: Understanding and Applying Research in Education
Desc: For the specialist or nonthesis master’s degree student. Instructing teachers and administrators to become intelligent consumers of research.

Name: Educational Statistics
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Descriptive and inferential statistics in educational research, computerized data analysis using SPSS or SAS; correlation and regression; normal, t, chi-square and F distributions; hypotheses testing and interval estimation; analysis of variance, nonparametric chi-square test.

Name: Principles of Testing and Measurement
Desc: Construction of measurement instruments for research purposes; utilization of standardized tests and inventories in research; measurement in multicultural and cross-cultural contexts; implications of measurement reliability and validity for research design and statistical analysis.

Name: Advanced Educational Statistics
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Advanced statistical procedures and computerized data analysis using SPSS or SAS; analysis of variance and covariance; application of multiple regression techniques in educational research.

Name: Education Program Evaluation
Desc: Current models and issues in educational evaluation as a professional practice; design and development of a comprehensive evaluation plan that includes specification of theoretical framework, problem identification, data collection/analysis procedures, report writing format and dissemination plans.
Reqs: ELRC 4249  and either ELRC 4006 or ELRC 7006

Name: Educational Research Methodology
Desc: Completion of a research proposal, preferably a pre-dissertation proposal, is required. Comprehensive and general review of qualitative and quantitative research methods in education.

Name: Qualitative Methods in Educational Research
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Introduction to qualitative research traditions and methods in education, including: ethnography, grounded theory, and case study; major methods including observational techniques, interviewing and document analysis; philosophical issues regarding the qualitative research approach; emphasis on qualitative data analysis, including the use of computer programs, such as ATLAS.ti.

Name: Introductory Research Practicum
Desc: By arrangement with a state agency, a local school system or other educational agency, students assist in the conducting of a variety of research methodologies under the supervision of the course instructor and the professional practice supervisor at the site.

Name: Advanced Research Practicum
