Desc: By arrangement with a state agency, a local school system or other educational agency, students assume a leadership role in conducting research studies under the supervision of the course instructor and the professional practice supervisor at the site.

Name: Mixed Methods Research in Education
Desc: Mixed methods as a separate research methodology integrating both the quantitative and the qualitative approaches.

Name: Content Analysis
Desc: Principles, theories and strategies for systematically examining the content of textual and other mediated communication.

Name: Seminar: Educational Research Methodology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced topics in educational research methods.

Name: Introduction to Classroom Technology
Desc: Introduction to technology tools and effective technology integration methods to enhance student learning.

Name: Utilization of Instructional Materials
Desc: Open only to candidates for teacher certification. Basic techniques for preparing effective instructional materials.

Name: Computer Technology in Education
Desc: Applications of computers in instruction; educational data processing, computer-assisted and computer-managed instruction; information storage and retrieval; use of micro/mini computers.

Name: Educational Telecommunications and the Internet
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Use of telecommunication tools found in educational settings; integration of telecommunications resources into instruction; research using the World Wide Web; design, development and evaluation of Web-based materials that include multimedia; security and legal issues; configuration of school and district networks; distance education applications; and emerging trends and research issues.

Name: Critical Analysis of Current Research in Educational Media
Desc: Analysis of current literature in the field; evaluation of current and needed research; systems approach to solving instructional problems.

Name: Administration of Technology Programs
Desc: Primarily for personnel responsible for planning, implementing and evaluating educational technology programs. Topics include applications, facilities, finances, acquisitions and staff development.

Name: Technology Leadership in Education
Desc: Theories and models of technology leadership, trends and best practices in leading education through digital technology.

Name: Educational Technology Assessment and Evaluation
Desc: Methods, trends, research and best practices regarding assessment and evaluation in educational technology.

Name: Principles of Distance Education
Desc: Applications of the principles of distance education to teaching and learning in educational and training contexts.

Name: Instructional Design
Desc: Instructional design theories and models and their application in solving real world instructional/learning problems.

Name: Design and Development of Multimedia Instructional Units
Desc: Instructional design for computer-assisted instruction; emphasis on learning theory, events of instruction, structuring instructional sequences for maximum content retention.

Name: Practicum in Educational Media
Desc: 9-18 hrs. lab. Practical experience in teaching, producing, utilizing and administering educational media.
Reqs: ELRC 7420 or ELRC 7505; or consent of instructor

Name: Seminar in Educational Media
Desc: Advanced topics in instructional technology.
Reqs: ELRC 7240 and ELRC 7420 or consent of instructor

Name: Professional Development for K-12: Technology Integration
Desc: Analyze effective professional development strategies; plan, design and implement and evaluate technology staff development activities.

Name: Advanced Telecommunications and Electronic Learning
Desc: Scope and elements of the online environment; technologies and strategies for online teaching and learning; design, development or conversion of courses for online delivery; course management, assessment and evaluation; policy issues.

Name: Theory and Research in Educational Technology
Desc: For advanced graduate students. Theoretical foundations and research in educational technology; emphasis on theories of communication, learning theories, educational psychology and behavioral sciences.

Name: Student Affairs in Higher Education
Desc: Basic concepts and issues in the college student affairs field.

Name: Issues of Race and Gender in Higher Education
Desc: Historical and socio-political perspectives on the higher education experiences of women, African-Americans, Asian-Americans and Hispanics, focusing primarily on the period from the 1960s to the present.

Name: Foundations of Higher Education
Desc: History of the sociological and philosophical foundations for higher education in the United States.

Name: Leadership in Higher Education
Desc: Analysis of leadership issues and theory relating to postsecondary education, including the college presidency and academic governance; institutional culture; student diversity, curricular change and new providers of higher education.

Name: Politics and Policy of Higher Education
Desc: Political and policy issues surrounding higher education; issues of race and gender, politics and policy of student loans; policies toward unprepared college students; collective bargaining; the accreditation process.

Name: Higher Education and the Law
Desc: Legal issues concerning higher education, including tenure, academic freedom, campus crime, sexual harassment, laws against discrimination, student discipline and liability for accidents and injuries.

Name: Curriculum and College Teaching
Desc: Critical analysis of college curriculum and approaches to teaching; historical development of curricular models; introduction to teaching and learning theories.

Name: Finance in Higher Education
Desc: Public policy and theory of financing higher education; topics include tuition, pricing, tuition policy, financial management of institutions and financial aid.

Name: Internship in Higher Education Administration
Desc: Practicum placement in a postsecondary setting in addition to seminar related to professional development, job placement, leadership, ethics, and supervision.

Name: Strategic Planning in Higher Education
Desc: Strategic plans for institutions of higher education; processes by which those plans are developed; higher education strategy within the context of the cultural and competitive environment; emphasis on current topics in organizational strategy.

Name: Assessment and Evaluation in Higher Education
Desc: Analysis of assessment and evaluation practices in higher education; role of assessment in policy development and strategic planning.

Name: College Students in the United States
Desc: Critical analysis of issues related to college students in the United States, including access, choice, climate, student organizations and development and identity.

Name: The Community College
Desc: An overview of two-year, post-secondary institutions in the United States examining historical foundations and critiquing current issues, trends, and challenges.

Name: College Access and Choice
Desc: Provides broad overview of access to postsecondary education and factors related to students’ college choice decisions. Covers policies, programs, and other initiatives aimed at addressing the college access problem in the United States.

Name: Environment and Technology: Perspective on Environmental Problems
Desc: See ENVS 1000.

Name: Analysis of Environmental Issues
Desc: An introduction to reading, writing and speaking in the sciences, with an emphasis on environmental topics.

Name: Soil Science
Desc: See AGRO 2051.

Name: Applied Environmental Management
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Applications of planning, management and decision- making to environmental policy, systems and management; evaluation of environmental decision making; environmental ethics; analysis of environmental issues at the local, state and national levels.

Name: Soil Conservation
Desc: See AGRO 3040.

Name: Environmental Regulations and Compliance
Desc: Local, state and federal environmental regulations; enforcement of and compliance with regulations; roles of regulatory agencies.

Name: Environmental Internship
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and AGRO 3090. Professional experience in some aspect of environmental management; student must submit a proposal explaining internship goals and education component; reports, employer evaluation, paper and presentation are required.
Reqs: permission of department and junior standing

Name: Applied Ecology
Desc: See ENVS 4010.

Name: Quantitative Risk Assessment
Desc: Assessment of environmental risks; interactions of pollution/toxins with the human body; managing and predicting risks.
Reqs: six hours of chemistry and six hours of biological sciences, MATH 1431 or equivalent

Name: Environmental Instrumental Analysis
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab.  Analysis of pollutants in the environment; development of analytical technique; sampling of different media including soil and water.

Name: Chemical Properties of Soil
Desc: See AGRO 4055.

Name: Microbial Ecology and Nutrient Cycling in Soils
Desc: See AGRO 4056 or BIOL 4256.

Name: Environmental Soil Physics
Desc: See AGRO 4077.

Name: Best Practices for Environmental Sustainability in Agriculture
Desc: See AGRO 4087.

Name: Senior Project in Environmental Management
Desc: 0 on all course work taken in the major. This course may be repeated for up to 6 hrs. of credit. Course may not be taken for graduate credit. Student will develop and submit a research proposal to the faculty; student will work on a specific project under the supervision of a faculty member. This course is intended to prepare students for graduate work in some area of environmental management.
Reqs: permission of department, senior standing, and a minimum GPA of 3

Name: Teaching Practicum
Desc: See AGRO 7010.

Name: Introduction to Engineering
Desc: Introduction to engineering history, disciplines and principles of design.

Name: Undergraduate Seminar
Desc: Pass-Fail grading. For engineering students only. Topics related to academic, professional and career development for engineering students. Speakers will include on-campus representatives, industrial, governmental and consulting professionals and education experts.

Name: Manufacturing, Technology & Society
Desc: Offered in Su History and development of manufacturing and technology and its influence on production, society and environment. Course available only as part of a study abroad program.

Name: Introduction to Robotics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Introduction to robotics and their applications. Sensors and DAQ; robotic actuators and mobility mechanisms; robot motion control; robot communications; behavioral control; navigation and mapping; robot coordination; human-robot interaction.
Reqs: ME 2543 or IE 2060 or CSC 1253 or CSC 1350; MATH 2070 or MATH 2085 or MATH 2090; open only to students minoring in robotics or Consent of Dean

Name: Robotics for K-12 Education
Desc: For MS Pre-Engineering Education students only. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Understanding of the principles and concepts of educational robotics and applying knowledge to instruction and curriculum. The focus is on construction and operation of robots in an educational setting. Emphasis is on teaching applications of robotics in a variety of learning environments.

Name: Industrial Robotics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Robot manipulator kinematics; dynamics; trajectory planning; motion/force control; manipulator actuators and sensors.
Reqs: ENGR 3100/KIN 3100 or equivalent; ME 3133 or CE 2460 or equivalent; experience in MATLAB

Name: Assistive Robotics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Design, application, and evaluation of human assistive, augmentation, and wearable robotics.

Name: Autonomous Vehicles
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Vehicle kinematics, motion control, perception, localization, path planning, and navigation.
Reqs: ENGR 3100/KIN 3100 or equivalent; experience in MATLAB

Name: Engineering Career Exploration and Design Process
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Through an in-depth study of the profession, ethics, and diversity in the field of engineering, this course provide students with a conceptual understanding of appropriate strategies for teaching Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) with an emphasis on the “TE”. Integrated STEM pedagogies include project/problem-based (PBL) design-based, and inquiry-based approaches to teaching.
Reqs: For MS Pre-Engineering Education students only

Name: Engineering Education for K-12 Education
Desc: Identifying appropriate curriculum, materials, assessment methods, and horizontal integration of non-engineering content for engineering student learning, engineering design, and problem solving 21st-century skills such as creativity, communication, critical-thinking, and collaboration. Teaching models will be covered for effective engineering teaching practices and curriculum standards alignment with ASEE standards for teachers of engineering by employing differentiated instruction techniques.
Reqs: For MS Pre-Engineering Education students only

Name: Computational Thinking for K-12 Education
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. This course is intended primarily for participants in teacher-training programs with little or no experience with programming. Students learn the basic ideas of computational thinking and programming by practicing exercises in a Web-based IDE environment in which they manipulate graphical objects by writing code. Students learn to recognize program code not only as a means to control a machine but also as a medium for organizing and communicating technical ideas precisely. They also learn how to foster youngsters’ creativity and how to help them develop problem solving abilities with challenging assignments that require the integration of a variety of mathematical skills along with well-established software development procedures.
Reqs: For MS Pre-Engineering Education students only

Name: Future Faculty Development Seminar
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Open to all engineering and construction management graduate students. Provides fundamental skill sets and knowledge needed to successfully prepare for an academic career in engineering.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: English for Academic Success
Desc: Graduate students graded pass-no credit. For international students admitted to LSU despite low language proficiency and whose diagnostic test results indicate the need for intensive work in college composition. Required during the first semester of residence for all such qualified international students. Not for graduate degree credit. Introduction to elements of academic writing, grammar, and style.

Name: English Composition
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 1013, English Composition I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Placement by department. Introduction to analytical writing and research-based inquiry.

Name: English Composition
Desc: Required during the first semester of residence for all international students (graduates, undergraduates and transfer students) who demonstrate on the placement examination need for work in English, but not at the intensive level of ENGL 0004. Graduate students graded pass-no credit.
Reqs: Placement by department and permission of instructor

Name: English Composition
Desc: Graduate students graded pass-no credit. Credit will not be given for both 1005 and ENGL 2000. For international students, with continued work on problems specific to international students.
Reqs: ENGL 1004 or placement by the department and permission of instructor

Name: Spoken English for International Graduate Assistants
Desc: Pass/no credit grading. May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. For current and potential international graduate assistants only. Developing spoken English skills (pronunciation, stress, intonation, rhythm); improving overall comprehensibility through tasks/activities, drills and videotaped oral presentations.
Reqs: oral interview and permission of department

Name: English Composition
Desc: Practice in argument writing and research-based inquiry.
Reqs: ENGL 1001 or equivalent and 39 total credit hours earned by the time of enrollment

Name: Advanced English Composition
Desc: Credit will not be given for both ENGL 2001 and ENGL 3101. Theory and practice of exposition, description and narration.

Name: Business Writing
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2513, Foundations of Professional Writing (Lower Level)] Credit will not be given for both ENGL 2002 and ENGL 2102. Preparing business documents such as reports, articles and letters.

Name: Intro to Writing Creative Nonfiction
Desc: 3 hr. seminar. Writing creative nonfiction for workshop criticism; introduction to reading and crafting memoir, essays and literary journalism with focus on practice and techniques in form (academic, personal, and cultural), imaginative style and structure, tone, and persona.

Name: Introduction to Writing Short Stories
Desc: Writing short stories for workshop criticism; practice in techniques of using point of view, dialogue, setting and characterization.
Reqs: ENGL 2024, ENGL 2025, ENGL 2027, ENGL 2029, ENGL 2123, ENGL 2148, ENGL 2201, ENGL 2202, ENGL 2231, ENGL 2270, ENGL 2593, ENGL 2673 or ENGL 2674

Name: Introduction to Writing Poetry
Desc: from ENGL 2024, ENGL 2025, ENGL 2027, ENGL 2029, ENGL 2123, ENGL 2148, ENGL 2201, ENGL 2202, ENGL 2231, ENGL 2270, ENGL 2593, ENGL 2673, or ENGL 2674. Writing poems for workshop criticism; practice in both open and closed forms; emphasis on contemporary techniques and prosody.

Name: Introduction to Writing Drama
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2523, Creative Writing (Various Genres)] Also offered as THTR 2008. Writing plays for workshop criticism; practice in techniques of exposition, characterization and dramatization.

Name: Introduction to Writing Screenplays
Desc: from ENGL 2024, ENGL 2025, ENGL 2027, ENGL 2029, ENGL 2123, ENGL 2148, ENGL 2201, ENGL 2202, ENGL 2220, ENGL 2231, ENGL 2270, ENGL 2593, ENGL 2673 or ENGL 2674. Writing screenplays for workshop criticism; techniques of exposition, characterization and dramatization.

Name: Practical Grammar and Usage
Desc: Practical grammar, usage and punctuation; effective word choices and sentences; elimination of common errors; use of dictionaries; current language controversies, regional and social language variation.

Name: Critical Strategies
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Credit will not be given for both this course and ENGL 2824. Skills for reading and writing about literature from a variety of critical perspectives; approaches such as reader response, psycho-analysis, myth, new historicism and feminism applied to a range of literary texts.

Name: Fiction
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2303, Introduction to Fiction] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. 2 hrs. lecture; 1 hr. recitation. Skills for reading and writing about fiction; attention to generic conventions and critical perspectives; section emphasis may vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: Poetry
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2313, Introduction to Poetry/Drama] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Skills for reading and writing about poetry; attention to generic conventions and critical perspectives; section emphasis may vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: Drama
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2313, Introduction to Poetry/Drama] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Skills for reading and writing about drama; attention to generic conventions and critical perspectives; section emphasis may vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: Science Fiction Studies
Desc: Science fiction literature, particularly that of the 20th century.

Name: Fantasy Literature
Desc: Variety of literary types employing conventions of the fantastic; uses of older literatures in modern fantasy novels; themes such as quest for identity, ideal of the hero and nature of good and evil.

Name: Business Writing for International Students
Desc: Credit will not be given for both ENGL 2002 and 2102. Preparing business documents such as reports, articles and letters; oral presentation of reports.

Name: Studies in Literary Traditions and Themes
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2103, 2113, 2153, 2163, 2323, British Literature I, II, American Literature I, II, Introduction of Literature] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Credit will not be given for both this course and ENGL 2823. 2 hrs. lecture; 1 hr. recitation. Skills for reading and writing about literature; attention to historical development, context and critical perspectives; topics such as “The Epic,” “Imagining the Family,” “Literature and the City”; section emphasis will vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: Shakespeare
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. 2 hrs. lecture; 1 hr. recitation. The more popular plays.

Name: Louisiana Literature
Desc: Fiction, poetry, essays and drama of Louisiana.

Name: Introduction to World Literary Traditions
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2203, 2223, World Literature I, Major World Writers] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. See CPLT 2201.

Name: Introduction to Modern World Literature
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2213, 2223, World Literature II, Major World Writers] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. See CPLT 2202.

Name: Major British Authors
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2103, 2113, 2123, British Literature I, II, Major British Writers] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Selected major British authors from the Anglo-Saxon period to the present.

Name: Popular Fictions
Desc: Critical analysis of popular literature, television programs, films and advertisements; emphasis on development of textual interpretative skills.

Name: Reading Film
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. 2 hrs. lecture; 1 hr. recitation. Introduction to analytical study of film; mastery of film language through formal, cultural, and theoretical approaches to film study; emphasis on writing about film.

Name: Major American Authors
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2153, 2163, 2173, American Literature I, II, Major American Writers] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Selected major American authors from the Colonial period to the present.

Name: Interpreting Discourse
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Study of and writing about discourse forms (fiction, popular and critical texts, technical and legal documents), using linguistic, rhetorical and cultural analysis.

Name: Introduction to Folklore
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2503, Mythology or Folklore] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Also offered as ANTH 2423. Folklore genres of the world; sources of folklore; literary, psychological, sociological, anthropological and historical approaches to folk material; relationships between folklore and written literature.

Name: Gender and Literature
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2413, Introduction to Women’s Literature] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Critical analysis of representation of gender and gendered roles addressing a range of literature from different genres and historical periods, and/or critical approaches; may include film or other media in addition to more traditional literary works. Section emphasis may vary.

Name: Literature and Ethnicity
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Literature of America’s ethnic cultures.

Name: Introduction to African-American Literature
Desc: [LCCN: CENL 2403, Introduction to African American Literature] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Major figures and popular texts of black American literature, including writers of fiction, poetry, drama and essays; influence of genre on the articulation of common political and social themes.

Name: Descriptive Grammar of English
Desc: Also offered as LING 2710. Examination of what every English speaker has internalized about English, including sentence structure, sound patterns and word formation.

Name: Language Diversity, Society, & Power
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Also offered as LING 2716. Social construction of language ideologies and issues of power as they relate to language variation and use. Examination of why language variation exists and how dialect intersects with race, gender, and social class, with particular focus on political and social identities. Discussion focus on how dialects and “Standard English” contribute to persistent economic and civic inequalities in contemporary American society.

Name: HONORS: Studies in Literary Traditions and Themes
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Honors equivalent of ENGL 2123. Credit will not be given for both this course and ENGL 2123.

Name: HONORS: Critical Analysis of Literature
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Honors equivalent of ENGL 2024. Credit will not be given for both this course and ENGL 2024. Study and writing about literary forms.

Name: Independent Work
Desc: 0 in all previous English courses. Consult department before registering. Reading, conferences and reports under departmental faculty direction.
Reqs: sophomore standing and an average of not less than 2

Name: Independent Work
Desc: 0 in all previous English courses. Consult department before registering. Reading, conferences and reports under departmental faculty direction.
Reqs: sophomore standing and an average of not less than 2

Name: Independent Work
Desc: 0 in all previous English courses. Consult department before registering. Reading, conferences and reports under departmental faculty direction.
Reqs: sophomore standing and an average of not less than 2

Name: HONORS: Honors Thesis
Desc: Conclusion of the English honors program; for details, consult the department.

Name: Technical Writing
Desc: Credit will be given for only one of the following: ENGL 3002, ENGL 3003 and ENGL 3102. Training in skills required of practicing scientists, engineers and technical managers.

Name: Technical Writing for Nontechnical Majors
Desc: Credit will not be given for both ENGL 3002 and 3003 and ENGL 3102. This course will not substitute for ENGL 3002 requirement. Formats and processes of writing found in business, science, government and industry.

Name: Writing with Style: Advanced Expository Prose
Desc: Experimentation with different styles of writing in a work-shop format.

Name: Composition Tutoring
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 6 hrs. lab. Composition theory as applicable to undergraduate tutoring.

Name: British Literature I: The Middle Ages, Renaissance and 18th Century
Desc: Survey of English literature from the Anglo-Saxon period through Chaucer, Shakespeare, the 17th and 18th centuries.

Name: British Literature II: Romantics, Victorians and Moderns
Desc: Survey of British literature from the French Revolution through the Industrial Revolution into the 20th century.

Name: Criticism
Desc: Influential works of literary criticism from the classical to the modern period.

Name: Readings in Pre-1800 Literature
Desc: Readings investigating a theme or era in pre-1900 literature.

Name: Special Topics Survey
Desc: Transhistorical survey of literature organized by a special topic theme, method or genre.

Name: American Literature I: Forging a Nation
Desc: Emergence of an American literature and national consciousness in major writings from the Colonial era to the Civil War.

Name: American Literature II: Coming of Age
Desc: American literature from the Civil War to the present; realism, naturalism, modernism; effects of industrialization, immigration, the women’s movement, the civil rights struggle, the world wars.

Name: Post-colonial Literature
Desc: Survey of literature from former British colonies in South Asia, Africa and the Caribbean; colonialism; nationalism; independence; diaspora; transnationalism; hybridity; women’s rights; building a new nation, etc.

Name: Modern Criticism
Desc: Influential works of literary criticism and theory written in the 20th century.

Name: Contemporary Fiction
Desc: Survey of contemporary fiction from a comparative perspective; authors such as Achebe, Bellow, Garcia Marquez, Lessing, Morrison, Pynchon, Updike; developments in magical realism, minimalism, cyberpunk.

Name: Legal Writing
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ENGL 2001. Discussions and writing assignments tailored to forms of writing common in law and in law-related fields; emphasis on writing clear, precise, effective prose.

Name: Technical Writing for International Students
Desc: Credit will be given for only one of the following: ENGL 3002, ENGL 3003, 3102. Training for non-native speakers of English in skills required of practicing scientists, engineers and technical managers.

Name: The Literature of the English Bible
Desc: Also offered as REL 3124. Literary themes and forms in the King James version; particular reference to the literary influence of the Bible on later literature.

Name: Introduction to Nonfiction Film and Video
Desc: Historical and theoretical background in the genre; filmmakers such as Grierson to Varda, Moore, McElwee, Folman, Caouette. Production work when chosen by students.

Name: Introduction to English Secondary Education
Desc: Coreq.: EDCI 3001. Introduction to central theories and topics in the teaching of Secondary English Language Arts, including language development and diversity, the multiplicity of literacy practices and platforms, and reading and writing for real world purposes.

Name: Major Themes in Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Consult department for topic to be offered. Examination of a particular theme (e.g. revolution, quest, or spiritual crisis) in the works of several authors crossing historical and cultural boundaries.

Name: Survey of Popular Genres
Desc: Survey of such genres as ballads, miracle and morality plays, broadsides, melodrama, romance, detective fiction, science fiction, westerns, situation comedies.

Name: Adolescent Literature
Desc: See also EDCI 3223. Critical analysis and survey of literatures with adolescents as main characters and written for adolescent and adult audiences.

Name: Rhetoric: Texts and Historical Contexts
Desc: Development of rhetoric and writing within their cultural contexts; modes of writing and rhetoric particular to historical periods, classical to modern.

Name: Writing: Practice, Pedagogy and History
Desc: Cultural, technological and historical influences on writing, the teaching of writing and today’s teaching practices.

Name: Special Topics in Writing and Research
Desc: Develops students’ advanced writing and research skills for the English major through investigation of a special topic in any area of English studies.

Name: Historical Perspectives on Language Issues
Desc: Also offered as LING 3310. A writing intensive course. Survey of major issues in the history of language study.

Name: Cultural and Textual Studies
Desc: Introduction to the theory and practice of cultural studies; reading of theoretical statements; analysis of exemplary texts (films, videos, literary works, autobiographies, historical and legal documents).

Name: The Study of Folklore
Desc: See ANTH 3401.

Name: Readings in Diverse Perspectives
Desc: Study of works concerning or by authors from underrepresented groups.

Name: Survey of Women and Literature
Desc: Significance of gender for the author, the reader and the work itself; connections between texts and society; literary influences and relations between mainstream and nontraditional literature.

Name: Readings in Literature and Ethnicity
Desc: Readings in the literature of one or more ethnic cultures.

Name: Survey of African-American Literature
Desc: Literature of the black experience in the U.S. from slave narratives to the present.

Name: Dialects of English
Desc: Also offered as LING 3716. Regional and/or social variation in pronunciation, grammar and vocabulary.

Name: Methods for Teaching English as a Second Language
Desc: Also offered as LING 3720. Theories and practical approaches for teaching English as a second language to elementary, secondary and adult education students.

Name: HONORS: Seminar
Desc: Normally open only to juniors and seniors. Topics vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: HONORS: Seminar
Desc: Normally open only to juniors and seniors. Topics vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: HONORS: Seminar
Desc: Normally open only to juniors and seniors. Topics vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: HONORS: Seminar
Desc: Normally open only to juniors and seniors. Topics vary, consult departmental handout.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 hrs. of credit. Readings, reports and conferences under departmental faculty direction.

Name: HONORS: Independent Work
Desc: 0 in all work taken and permission of department. May not be taken by students who have already completed ENGL 2920, ENGL 2921, ENGL 2922. Consult department before scheduling course. Reading, conferences and reports under departmental faculty direction.

Name: HONORS: Independent Work
Desc: 0 in all work taken and permission of department. May not be taken by students who have already completed ENGL 2920, ENGL 2921, ENGL 2922. Consult department before scheduling course. Reading, conferences and reports under departmental faculty direction.

Name: HONORS: Independent Work
Desc: 0 in all work taken and permission of department. May not be taken by students who have already completed ENGL 2920, ENGL 2921, ENGL 2922. Consult department before scheduling course. Reading, conferences and reports under departmental faculty direction.

Name: Internship in English
Desc: Normally open to only juniors and seniors. May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit. Program of study, research project, book discussion, conferences with faculty mentor, and work in a position related to writing and critical analysis, such as editing and publishing.

Name: Special Projects for Creative Writing Majors
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Explorations in a wide variety of projects that basic courses are unable to accommodate.
Reqs: permission of department; at least one 2000-level course in creative writing

Name: Intermediate Creative Nonfiction Workshop
Desc: Memoirs, essays and journalism as literary forms, with guided practice in techniques and form.

Name: Scientific and Professional Writing for Peers
Desc: Individual instruction. Students must have well-defined projects. Credit will not be given for this course and OCS 4038. Principles and practice of effective research writing in academic and professional settings; emphasis on translating research results into publishable articles and effective grant proposals.

Name: Intermediate Fiction Writing Workshop
Desc: Guided practice in fiction writing, especially the short story; techniques involved.

Name: Writing the Novel
Desc: Guided practice in writing the novel; techniques involved.
Reqs: at least one 2000-level course in creative writing

Name: Intermediate Poetry Writing Workshop
Desc: Guided practice in writing poetry; techniques involved.

Name: Writing Drama
Desc: Guided practice in writing plays; techniques involved.
Reqs: at least one 2000-level course in creative writing

Name: Intermediate TV & Film Writing Workshop
Desc: Practice in tv and film writing, such as full-length screenplay or television pilot, for workshop criticism. Reading scripts and watching films/tv shows for analysis and critique.

Name: Literary Publishing
Desc: Study of literary publishing and the work of editing, including hands-on experience.
Reqs: ENGL 2004, ENGL 2005, ENGL 2007, ENGL 2008, or ENGL 2009

Name: Forms of Creative Writing
Desc: May be taken for a max. 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Intensive study in a selected form of creative writing.
Reqs: ENGL 2004, ENGL 2005, ENGL 2007, ENGL 2008, or ENGL 2009, and consent of department

Name: Studies in Life Writing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as St. Augustine, Margery Kempe, Montaigne, Rousseau, Franklin, Douglass, Adams, Stein, Malcolm X; topics such as “Autobiography, Memoir, and Diary,” “Biography,” “Slave Narrative,” “Autobiographical Fiction.”

Name: Studies in Lyric, Epic and Other Poetic Forms
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Poets such as Sidney, Spenser, Milton, Wordsworth, Keats, Dickinson, Whitman, Yeats, Stevens, Wheatley, Rich; topics such as “Development of the English Epic,” “Love Lyrics and the Representation of Women.”

Name: Studies in Drama
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Marlowe, Jonson, Congreve, Sheridan, Shaw, Synge, O’Neill, Miller; topics such as “The Beginnings of English Drama,” “Shakespeare’s Contemporaries,” “Irish Drama,” “Women in the Theatre.”

Name: Studies in the Middle Ages
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Chaucer, Langland, the Gawain poet, Juliana of Norwich; topics such as “Love and Chivalry in Middle English Lyric and Romance,” “Dream Vision and Allegory,” “Reading Anglo-Saxon Literature.”

Name: Studies in Pre-1800 Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Seminar on a special topic in pre-1800 literature.

Name: Studies in the Age of Elizabeth
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Sidney, Spenser, Marlowe, Shakespeare; developments in romantic epic, lyric, comedy, tragedy, devotional literature; topics such as “Quest for Utopia,” “Psychology of Love,” “Theatre and Court.”

Name: Studies in the Restoration and 18th Century
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Dryden, Behn, Swift, Pope, Equiano, Fielding, Richardson, Austen; developments in satire, comedy of manners, the novel; topics such as “The Line of Wit,” “Literature and Empire.”

Name: Studies in the Novel and the Idea of Narrative
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Novels such as Tristram Shandy, Madame Bovary, The Trial, To the Lighthouse, Beloved; theorists such as Booth, Bakhtin, Kermode, Girard, Barthes, Kristeva, Said; topics such as time, structure, voicing, self-reflexivity.

Name: Studies in the Romantic Movement
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Blake, Wollstonecraft, William and Dorothy Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, Percy and Mary Shelley, Keats; topics such as “Romanticism and the French Revolution,” “The Poetic Imagination,” “The Romantic Novel.”

Name: Studies in the Victorian Age
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Dickens, the Brontës, Thackeray, Eliot, Tennyson, Browning, Arnold, Ruskin, Wilde; topics such as “The Bildungsroman,” “London, Crime, and Victorian Literature,” “The Victorian Heroine.”

Name: Studies in American Literature to 1865
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Franklin, Poe, Emerson, Hawthorne, Douglass, Melville, Whitman, Dickinson; themes such as American identity, nature and culture; topics such as “The Puritan Imagination,” “Rethinking the American Renaissance.”

Name: Studies in American Literature since 1865
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Twain, James, Wharton, Eliot, Moore, Hughes, Cather, Ellison, Faulkner; developments in the novel, poetry, nonfiction prose; topics such as “The American Self,” “Naturalism,” “Postmodernism.”

Name: Studies in Modernism
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Pound, Eliot, Stein, Joyce, Woolf, and Faulkner; topics such as “The Avant-Garde Movements in the Arts,” “Nationalism and Literature,” “War Poetry,” “The Expatriates.”

Name: Studies in the Short Story
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Chekhov, Joyce, Hemingway, Cather, Wright, Garcia Marquez, Flannery O’Connor; theorists such as Poe, Frank O’Connor, Friedman, Pratt; problems such as short story sequences, beginnings and endings, compression, conflict.

Name: Capstone in Writing Creative Nonfiction
Desc: Advanced workshop in which students consolidate their knowledge in writing creative nonfiction and obtain a perspective on the significance of that knowledge.

Name: Capstone Seminar in Writing Poetry
Desc: and 27 hrs. in English beyond ENGL 2000 or permission of instructor. Advanced seminar in which students consolidate their knowledge in writing poetry and obtain a perspective on the significance of that knowledge. Independent research project.

Name: Capstone Seminar in Literature
Desc: and 27 hrs. in English beyond ENGL 2000, including three hours from ENGL 3024 or ENGL 3084 or permission of instructor. Advanced seminar in which students consolidate their knowledge of English and obtain a perspective on the significance of that knowledge. Independent research project. Course topics will vary.
Reqs: for English Majors with 92 total credit hrs

Name: Capstone Seminar in Writing Fiction
Desc: and 27 hrs. in English beyond ENGL 2000, ENGL 3024 or ENGL 3084 or permission of instructor. Advanced seminar in which students consolidate their knowledge in writing fiction and obtain a perspective on the significance of that knowledge. Independent research project.

Name: Capstone Seminar in TV & Film Writing
Desc: and 27 hrs. in English beyond ENGL 2000 or permission of instructor. Advanced seminar in which students consolidate their knowledge in television & film writing with a focus on the re-writing process for tv or film scripts.

Name: Studies in Major Authors
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Detailed study of works by one or two authors from Spenser and Donne to Joyce and Morrison; attention to the author’s life and times, predecessors and influence.

Name: Studies in Literary History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics such as “Literature and the King’s Peace,” “The Development of the Pastoral,” “From Romantic to Victorian: A Study of Influence,” “Self and Society.”

Name: Topics in Interdisciplinary Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Literature in cultural contexts and/or in relation to other academic disciplines; topics such as “Fictions of the Working Class,” “Race in Literature and Culture,” “Modernism in Fiction and Painting.”

Name: Studies in Nonfiction Film and Video
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced study in nonfiction film and video; topics such as “Nonfiction Film Essays,” “Documentary Auteurs,” “Women and Nonfiction Film,” “Experimental Nonfiction Film.” Production work when chosen by students.

Name: Studies in Chaucer
Desc: Attention to The Canterbury Tales, their literary and cultural significance; topics such as “Chaucer, Boccaccio and Framed Tales,” “`The olde daunce’: Chaucer on Love, Sex and Marriage.”

Name: Studies in Milton
Desc: Attention to Paradise Lost, Paradise Regained and Samson Agonistes; their literary and cultural significance; topics such as “Paradise Lost and the Christianization of the Epic,” “Milton and Women,” “Milton and Revolution.”

Name: Studies in Shakespeare
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Attention to poetry and plays, literary and cultural significance; topics such as “The Comedies and Histories,” “The Tragedies,” “Shakespeare and Film,” “Shakespeare and Gender.”

Name: Studies in Southern Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Chopin, Faulkner, Wright, Welty, Tennessee Williams; topics such as “Survey of Southern Literature,” “Civil Rights Literature,” “Historical Fiction,” “Southern Women Writers.”

Name: Writing and Research in the Teaching of English
Desc: Current methods of teaching research and writing in middle school and high school English Language Arts classrooms.

Name: Capstone Seminar in English Education
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4004 and EDCI 4005. For English majors in the Secondary Education Concentration. Independent research project. Course topics will vary. Usually offered in spring semester only.

Name: Drama of Africa and African Diaspora
Desc: See THTR 4220.

Name: Studies in Popular Fictions
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics such as “Louisiana Popular Fictions,” “Images of Women and Minorities in Popular Texts,” “Popular Culture and Folklore,” “The Literature of Horror.”

Name: Studies in Literature and Film
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Comparative study of literature and film as art forms; literary bases of film; topics such as “Film Authors,” “Film and Ideology,” “Adaptations of Literary Classics,” “Film Genres,” “Film and Gender.”

Name: Studies in Literature and Politics
Desc: Also offered as POLI 4234. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Literary representations of politics; historical role of literature in politics; topics such as “Literature and Politics of the Modern American South,” “Revolution and the Avante-Garde.”

Name: Studies in Literature and Religion
Desc: Also offered as REL 4236. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Sophocles, Dante, Shakespeare, Donne, Hawthorne, Eliot, O’Conner, Morrison; topics such as “Major Religious Novelists,” “Literature of Illness and Death,” “Moral Universes of Greek and Christian Tragedy,” “Creation Stories.”

Name: Studies in Rhetorical Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics such as “Rhetoric of/in Literary Studies,” “Rhetoric of Political Discourse.”

Name: Studies in Composition Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Modern composition theory as it relates to the teaching of writing; topics such as “Social Theories of Composition.”

Name: Studies in Literacy
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Varied perspectives on literacy, especially written literacy; issues raised by its complex and problematic nature.

Name: Capstone Seminar in Rhetoric, Writing, and Culture
Desc: and 27 hrs. in English beyond ENGL 2000, including three hours from ENGL 3024 or ENGL 3084 or ENGL 3384 or permission of instructor. Advanced seminar in which students consolidate their knowledge in English and obtain a perspective on the significance of that knowledge. Independent research project. Course topics will vary.
Reqs: for English Majors with 92 total credit hrs

Name: Studies in Language
Desc: Also offered as LING 4310. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. A writing intensive course. Devoted to special topics, such as “African-American English,” “English-based Pidgins and Creoles,” “Current Trends in Linguistic Theory,” “Issues in Applied Linguistics and Language Learning.”

Name: Studies in African Literature
Desc: See AAAS 4322.

Name: Studies in Caribbean Literature
Desc: See AAAS 4323.

Name: American Folklore
Desc: Also offered as ANTH 4475. Folklore of the U.S., including regional, racial, ethnic and occupational groups; relation of folklore to other aspects of American vernacular culture and to American literature.

Name: Women and Folklore
Desc: Examination of folk materials, including oral genres, music, art and artifacts and rituals; focus on how and why information about women in folklore is communicated.

Name: Studies in Diverse Perspectives
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Special topics focused on works concerning or by authors from underrepresented communities.

Name: Studies in Women and Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Behn, Woolf, Chopin, Atwood, Cliff; topics such as “Reading and Writing About Women’s Lives,” “The Female Gothic,” “Women and Ethnicity,” “Early Modern Women Writers.”

Name: Studies in African-American Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Authors such as Douglass, Hurston, Wright, Morrison; topics such as “Slave Narratives,” “The Harlem Renaissance,” “The Black Arts Movement,” “The Black Diaspora,” “African Survivals.”

Name: Studies in Post-colonial Literature & Culture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics may include “Imagining India,” “Black British Cultures,” “Islam and Literature,” “Politics and Post-colonial Literature,” “Atlantic Studies,” etc.

Name: Introduction to Linguistics
Desc: Also offered as LING 4710. Introduction to the major fields of linguistic study: phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics.

Name: History of the English Language
Desc: Also offered as LING 4711. Survey of the development of the English language from its Germanic roots to the present day.

Name: Roots of English
Desc: Also offered as LING 4712. The use of language to reconstruct the ancient Indo-European physical and cultural world: myth, religion, ritual, law and medicine.

Name: Syntax
Desc: Also offered as LING 4713. Basic principles of syntactic structure; topics include constituency, subordinate clauses, coordinate structures, question formation, topicalization and the passive.

Name: Phonology
Desc: Also offered as LING 4714. Introduction to phonology, concentrating on the English language; phonetic and phonemic inventories; feature-analysis and rules; examination of linear, nonlinear and metrical paradigm.

Name: Semantics
Desc: Also offered as LING 4715. Approaches to the study of meaning: theories of the lexicon, word-formation and meaning; the interaction between sentence structure and signification; pragmatics.

Name: Second Language Acquisition
Desc: Also offered as LING 4720. Key issues in second language acquisition (SLA) including age, native language, and environment on language learning.

Name: Independent Research and Practice
Desc: Advanced independent research and practice.
Reqs: Consent of instructor and department required

Name: Literary Nonfiction Workshop
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Creative writing of nonfiction essays.
Reqs: admission to the MFA program or consent of instructor

Name: Fiction Writing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit. Intensive composition and critical evaluation of fiction; fictional techniques and forms.
Reqs: admission to the MFA program or permission of instructor

Name: Poetry Writing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit. Composition and critical evaluation of poetry; poetic forms and problems of poetry writing.
Reqs: admission to the MFA program or permission of instructor

Name: Drama Writing
Desc: Also offered as THTR 7008. May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Composition and critical evaluation of drama; techniques of dramatic composition and dialogue.

Name: Advanced Screenwriting Workshop
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit. Composition and critical evaluation of screen and teleplays; screenwriting composition and dialogue.
Reqs: admission to the MFA program or permission of instructor

Name: Proseminar in Graduate Study
Desc: Introduction to the profession of English through an examination of the central theoretical issues and institutional questions that currently organize the field and instruction in basic research practices.

Name: Medieval Literature
Desc: Survey of major Medieval works (exclusive of Chaucer) in lyrical, poetic narrative, dramatic and prose genres.

Name: Renaissance Literature
Desc: Survey of representative works of English literature in poetry and prose in the 16th and 17th centuries.

Name: Restoration and 18th Century Literature
Desc: Comprehensive survey of major authors, contexts, and genres from Dryden to Blake.

Name: American Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Survey of American poetry and prose in the 17th and 18th centuries, the 19th century, or the 20th and 21st centuries.

Name: Forms of Prose Fiction
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Fictional techniques in conventional and experimental short stories, novellas and novels; elements of plot, characterization, theme, setting and tone; formal analysis of literary texts related o specific problems of writing.

Name: Prosody and Poetic Forms
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Representative forms of poetry from early sagas to contemporary free verse; relationship to principles of versification; some concurrent practice in writing poetry in specific forms.

Name: Forms of Film Writing
Desc: Examination of screenplays and teleplays; techniques of exposition, characterization and dramatization.

Name: Chaucer
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Poetry and prose in Middle English.

Name: Milton
Desc: Readings and critical analysis of the poetry and prose of John Milton.

Name: Ethnic Literatures of the United States
Desc: Survey of the literature of America’s diverse ethnic cultures; theories of ethnicity, cultural studies and critical race studies.

Name: Literature of the American South
Desc: Southern writing from colonial times to the present.

Name: Survey of African-American Literature I
Desc: Writings of African Americans from the colonial/slavery experience to 1915.

Name: Postcolonial Literatures
Desc: Survey of Anglophone literatures from formerly colonized nations.

Name: Topics in Critical Theory and Cultural Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Specialized explorations in critical theory and cultural studies; topics include “Derrida and American Deconstruction,” “Critical Theory and Science Fiction,” “Marxism and the Western,” “Reader-Response Theory and Popular Romance,” “Postmodernism.”

Name: Topics in Literacy Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Intensive study of a topic in history or theories of literacy; topics include “Technology and Literacy,” “Gender and Literacy,” “Orality and Literacy,” “Theory and Politics of Literacy,” “Working-Class Literacy.”

Name: Topics in Gender Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Analysis of an aspect of gender theory in relation to literary or cultural study; topics such as “Gender, Narrative, and Property,” “Film and Gender,” “Psychoanalysis and Sexuality.”

Name: Topics in Folklore
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Examination of particular folk genres, issues or methods in the study of folklore.

Name: Topics in the History of Rhetoric and Poetics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics may cover any aspect of the historical relationship between formal rhetoric, poetic theory and English literature from the Middle Ages to the present.

Name: Topics in Rhetoric, Media and Representation
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Analysis of literature, film and media as cultural representations of societal norms, beliefs and needs.

Name: Topics in Rhetorics of Class and Gender
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Analysis of writing and language in light of their contextual and material influences and the methods for their study; emphasis on class and gender.

Name: Research Methods in Composition, Literacy and Rhetorical Studies
Desc: Survey and theoretical discussion of research methodologies such as discourse analysis, rhetorical analysis, interviews, talk-aloud protocols and ethnography in the fields of composition studies, literacy studies or rhetorical studies.

Name: Topics in Composition Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Historical survey of the theoretical, research and pedagogical issues in the field of composition studies or special topics such as “Genre Theory,” “Assessment,” “Technology and Composition.”

Name: Topics in Professional Writing and Technical Communication
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. History or theories of professional writing or technical communication; topics include “Writing in the Profession,” “Workplace Literacy,” “Computers and Writing,” or “Technical Writing Methodology.”

Name: Forms of Early English
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Languages and linguistic structures of early forms of English: Old English, Middle English, and Early Modern English; period focus will vary.

Name: Topics in Historical Linguistics
Desc: Also offered as LING 7712. May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. An exploration of a topic or topics in the history of English, of the Germanic language or of the Indo-European language family.

Name: Topics in Syntax and Semantics
Desc: Also offered as LING 7713. May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. An exploration of a topic or topics in the structure and/or the interpretation of Modern English and related languages.

Name: Topics in Sociolinguistics
Desc: Also offered as LING 7714. May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. An exploration of a topic or topics in the sociolinguistics of English and related languages, including English-based pidgins and creoles.

Name: Topics in Film and Video Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Intensive examination of a topic in the history or theory of film, television or other video productions, or in the relation of such productions to literature.

Name: Language
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Teaching College Composition
Desc: Course is designed for graduate students teaching in the First-Year Writing program. Theoretical and pedagogical issues in the teaching of college writing.
Reqs: students must be graduate teaching assistants in the English Department

Name: English Seminar
Desc: May be taken twice for credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Genres
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Intensive study of works in a literary genre from different national and cultural traditions and from different historical periods; topics include “Medieval and Renaissance Drama,” “The Long Poem in English,” “The Origins of the Novel,” “The Short Story.”

Name: Authors Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Detailed study of one or two authors in American, British or other Anglophone literatures; attention to the life and time, predecessors and influence.

Name: Topics in Renaissance Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Studies in Shakespeare
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Restoration and 18th Century Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Studies in the Romantic Period
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics such as “Romanticism and Place,” “Literature and Revolution,” “Romanticism and Linguistic Theory.”

Name: Studies in the Victorian Period
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics such as “Victorian Literature and Race,” “Victorian Literature and Economics,” “Victorian Literature and the City.”

Name: Topics in 19th Century British Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics such as “19th Century British Women Poets,” “Youth and Identity in 19th Century Literature,” “British Working-Class Writing.”

Name: Topics in American Genres
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Focused study of genres in the American context; genres may include the novel, the short story, drama, poetry, the captivity narrative or the essay.

Name: Topics in Southern Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Interdisciplinary approaches to southern literature and culture; topics such as “Southern Sexualities,” “The Color Line in the American South,” “Media Made Dixie.”

Name: Topics in Southern Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in American Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in African-American Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Intensive study of works in modern and contemporary literature; topics include “Modern Irish Literature,” “Modernism,” “Postmodern Literature,” “Contemporary Australian Literature.”

Name: Topics in Ethnic and Postcolonial Literatures
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Detailed study of different aspects of American ethnic literatures such as Asian American, Native American, Latino/Chicano and postcolonial literatures such as Indian, African, West Indian, Transnational.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. in an MA program, 6 sem. hrs. in an MFA program and 9 sem. hrs. in a PhD program. Directed individual readings guided by the graduate faculty.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Insects and Society
Desc: Introduction to insect effects on agriculture, human health, and the environment.

Name: Principles of Plant Health Management
Desc: Also offered as PLHL 1005. Students will gain an understanding of plant health as affected by abiotic and biotic stresses and recognize management practices used to preserve plant health.

Name: Plants, Microbes, and Society
Desc: See PLHL 2000.

Name: Insects in the Environment
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Insect recognition, classification and life cycles; factors affecting insect diversity and abundance; interactions between insects and the natural environment.
Reqs: BIOL 1201, BIOL 1208; and either BIOL 1001, BIOL 1002 or equivalent

Name: Pest Management Internship
Desc: Offered in Su See PLHL 3000.

Name: Pesticides in the Environment
Desc: The impact of environment on the efficacy and residual activity of pesticides, and the effects of pesticide use on the environment will be discussed. Topics include technology for safe and effective application of pesticides, movement of pesticides in the plant and environment, and resistance to pesticides in target plant pathogens, insect pests and weeds.

Name: Pest Management Seminar
Desc: See PLHL 3002.

Name: Insect Biology
Desc: No entomology training necessary. Biological, biochemical and ecological principles as they relate to the success of insects.

Name: Insect Taxonomy
Desc: A collection is required. 2 hrs. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Identification, nomenclature, phylogenetic relationships and life histories of insects at the family level.

Name: Fundamentals of Applied Entomology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles and methodology of managing insect pests; emphasis on field crops insect pest management; interdisciplinary perspective.

Name: Forensic Entomology
Desc: No entomology training necessary. 2hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Determining the succession and species composition of necrophilous insects and other arthropods on carcasses; estimate time of death using insects; learning investigative procedures used by police and wildlife officers in human and animal deaths; review of case studies from crime scene to courtroom.

Name: Biology and Management of the Honey Bee
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Behavior, genetics, pollination, pathology and practical management of honey bees for agricultural and scientific purposes.
Reqs: BIOL 1201, BIOL 1208; or BIOL 1001, BIOL 1002 or consent of instructor

Name: Fundamentals of Horticultural Entomology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles of insect control; recognition of major pest species of insects and mites and their injury to horticultural plants; economic and aesthetic injury thresholds; methods of control, including identification and utilization of beneficial species.

Name: Forest Insects and Diseases
Desc: One day-long field trip. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Identification, ecology, epidemiology and control of forest insects and diseases.

Name: Invasive Species Ecology
Desc: Stages involved in the invasion of an organism; examples covered include insects, weeds, reptiles, fish, and mammals.

Name: Insect Ecology
Desc: Two Saturday field trips. Ecological principles pertaining to insect individuals, populations, communities and their role in ecosystems; emphasis on life history strategies and behavior.
Reqs: BIOL 1201 and BIOL 1208 or equivalent or consent of instructor

Name: Plant Health Diagnostics
Desc: See PLHL 4050.

Name: Undergraduate Entomological Research
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 hrs. of credit. Not for graduate credit. Supervised entomological research in a laboratory or field setting; data collection and interpretation of results.

Name: Insect Behavior
Desc: Current and classical concepts in behavioral theory; communication systems; stimuli orientation, social interaction; aspects of insect control using behavior modification.

Name: Introduction to Aquatic Entomology
Desc: Occasional extended field trips. A collection is required. No entomology training is necessary. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course.  3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. lab. Provides a general understanding of global aquatic insect diversity and ecology with an emphasis on Louisiana and Gulf of Mexico Coastal Plains and lower Mississippi alluvial valley faunas. Provide students with practical skills of aquatic insect collection, curation, and identification.

Name: Special Topics in Entomology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Lab/field trip may be required. Subjects not covered in other entomology courses.

Name: General Entomology
Desc: No entomology training necessary. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Provides a framework of information about the evolution of insects and related arthropods, anatomy, functional morphology and physiology and an introduction to insect diversity at the ordinal level.

Name: Plant Resistance to Arthropods
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Detailed examination of the mechanistic basis of plant-insect interactions, with special reference to host-plant resistance in agricultural systems; integrates relevant concepts from diverse fields including insect physiology, plant physiology, plant biochemistry and ecology; evaluation of the current theoretical basis for research in plant-insect interactions; laboratory demonstrations and exercises emphasize the techniques used in host-plant resistance research.

Name: Medical/Veterinary Entomology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Relationship of insects and other arthropods to human and animal health.

Name: Classification of Immature Forms of Insects
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab.

Name: Advanced Insect Pest Management
Desc: Ecological and economic basis of pest management; advances in major pest management tactics; insect sampling; system analysis, biotechnology and geographical information system in pest management.
Reqs: ENTM 4006 and one 4000 or higher level statistical course (EXST 4050, EXST 7003, EXST 7004, EXST 7005, EXST 7013, EXST 7014, EXST 7015, and EXST 7031) or consent of the coordinator

Name: Seminar in Entomology
Desc: May be repeated for credit. 1 sem. hr. of credit required for each graduate degree in entomology.

Name: Special Topics in Entomology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary for 6 sem. hrs. credit for M.S. and 9 sem. hrs. credit for PhD. Lectures and/or labs on advanced topics in entomology not covered in other entomology courses.

Name: Teaching Practicum
Desc: Pass/fail grading based on a written evaluation by the supervisor and a written report by the student. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Open only to entomology PhD students. Teaching practicum and learning experience under the supervision of a graduate faculty member. Support one faculty member’s teaching through grading assignments and exams, delivering material and preparing and conducting laboratories, as needed and directed by the supervising faculty. Student will be exposed to different learning styles and various teaching approaches. Course credit will range from 1-3 hrs. depending on anticipated involvement.
Reqs: students whose native language is not English must pass the Michigan Test of English proficiency or equivalent, and receive prior approval of student’s graduate committee and supervising faculty

Name: Biological Control
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Theory and practice of biological control of insects, mites, and weeds in natural and managed ecosystems.

Name: Introduction to Insecticide Toxicology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles of toxicology as they relate to insecticides; bioassays, risk assessment, mode of action, pharmacokinetics, insecticide resistance and selectivity.

Name: Insect Physiology
Desc: 3 hr. lecture, 3 hr. lab. Physiology and biochemistry of insect organ systems. Topics include circulation, digestion, respiration, excretion, hormonal regulation, pheromones, intermediary metabolism, and nerve and muscle physiology. Laboratories provide exposure to instrumentation and techniques used in physiological research.

Name: Aquatic Entomology
Desc: Also offered as RNR 7030. 3 hrs lecture; 3 hrs lab. Provides a general understanding of aquatic insect diversity and ecology, with emphasis on Gulf of Mexico Coastal Plain and lower Mississippi alluvial valley faunas. Training includes methodologies for aquatic insect field sampling, curation, and identification and application of analytical techniques to aquatic insect data.

Name: Population Ecology
Desc: See BIOL 7080.

Name: Entomology Extension Practicum
Desc: This course may be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. Students will gain knowledge, training and experience in extension entomology. Emphasis on land-grant institution service, technology transfer and initiating and evaluating an entomology extension project.

Name: Seminar: Current Topics in Molecular Evolution
Desc: See BIOL 7946.

Name: Tropical Biology: An Ecological Approach
Desc: See BIOL 7979.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Research Problems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Innovation and Creativity
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Focuses on the role of creativity and innovation in product, service or idea generation that may eventually lead to business formation and commercialization; barriers to creativity and innovation; alternative problem-solving approaches.

Name: Basics on Business for Non-Business Majors
Desc: An introductory overview of the basic components of contemporary business from a decidedly entrepreneurial perspective, designed specifically for students who are not majoring in a business discipline. Credit for this course cannot be used to satisfy the requirements of a business degree.

Name: Intrapreneurship
Desc: Examination of creativity and innovation within companies and how intrapreneurship provides a framework for growth and change for companies competing in the global marketplace.

Name: Entrepreneurship
Desc: Principles of entrepreneurship; Understand how to develop successful ideas and how to move those ideas toward the development of a new venture or business.

Name: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship
Desc: May be taken for up to 6 credit hrs. when topics vary.
Reqs: Open only to Entrepreneurship majors admitted to the College of Business or permission of department

Name: Internship in Entrepreneurship
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. Gaining first-hand knowledge of the business start-up process: practical hands-on experience in business-plan formation.

Name: Independent Study in Entrepreneurship
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Detailed study of a specific aspect of entrepreneurship.

Name: Advanced Entrepreneurship for SEI Fellows
Desc: May be repeated for up to 6 hrs. credit. Detailed study of a specific aspect of entrepreneurship.

Name: Business Planning
Desc: Components, examples, and the creation of comprehensive business plans for beginning small businesses; integration of clear theoretical frameworks with action-oriented examples and exercises.

Name: Entrepreneurship in China
Desc: Characteristics of the Chinese energy industry: entrepreneurs, new venture financing, innovation and creativity, franchising, family businesses, technological entrepreneurs, technological intrapreneurs, entrepreneurship education and incubators.

Name: Consulting Field Project
Desc: Strategic focused field based project learning experiences and opportunities in public and private organizations. Team-based approach to offering consulting advice to organizations with the goal of improving their performance. Emphasis on experiential approaches that provide a participative type of learning about the crucial issues faced by organizations.

Name: Small and Family Business Management
Desc: [LCCN: CMGM 3413, Small Business Management (Upper Level)] A multidisciplinary approach to small and family businesses, examining business startups, accounting, finance, marketing, management (to include family issues), promotion, layout, retail management, location analysis, internationalization, and growth.

Name: Franchising Management
Desc: Understanding the franchising process; becoming a franchiser or franchisee; franchiser start-up, venture capital, finance, legal compliance, disclosure documents, franchise agreements, franchisee start-ups, franchiser-franchisee relationships, anti-trust laws and international franchising.

Name: Social Entrepreneurship
Desc: The course provides a broad theoretical perspective and practical framework for understanding social entrepreneurs and the social ventures they create ranging from local social organizations to large international social ventures leading global change. Introduction to the possibilities of social entrepreneurship and an introduction to the entire social venture creation process and life cycle.

Name: Entrepreneurship in Early Stage Technology Based Startups
Desc: Decision making, intellectual property, business plans, and customer discovery in early stage technology based start-ups.

Name: Technological Entrepreneurship
Desc: This course requires programming knowledge and a solid understanding of web development. Fundamentals of technology entrepreneurship; creating a technology idea, developing a minimal viable product (MVP), marketing, and managing growth.

Name: Managing Technology Transfer
Desc: Models of technological transfer; mechanisms and barriers to technological transfer; technological transfer and industrial innovation; domestic and international aspects of technology transfer.

Name: Entrepreneurship Management
Desc: Investigation, analysis and development of entrepreneurial feasibility studies and business plans.

Name: Environment and Technology: Perspective on Environmental Problems
Desc: Also offered as EMS 1011. Environmental quality problems involving water, air and land, and society’s response to such problems; analysis of the interrelationships and nature of ecological stresses.

Name: Introduction to Coastal Environmental Science
Desc: See OCS 1010.

Name: Introduction to Environmental Sciences
Desc: [LCCN: CEVS 1103, Environmental Science] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, ENVS 1127, is also available. Credit will not be given for both this course and ENVS 1127. Essential principles of environmental sciences; comprehensive and fundamental understanding of sound science, stewardship and sustainability in environmental sciences; interactions and relations between humans and earth; an up-to-date look at today’s global, national and regional environmental issues.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Environmental Sciences
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Similar to ENVS 1126 with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for both this course and ENVS 1126.

Name: Environmental Thought
Desc: See PHIL 2021.

Name: Environmental and Anthropogenic Impacts of Microbes
Desc: Application of basic principles of environmental science to the fundamental understanding of the relationship of microbes with the environment and the humans with emphasis on the impacts and importance of microbial communities; introduction to cutting edge research through peer-reviewed literature; critique, formulation, and testing of hypotheses.

Name: Mathematical Methods in Science
Desc: Introduction to numerical methods, data analysis, error propagation, box models, linear and nonlinear least squares, perturbation theory, numerical integration.
Reqs: MATH 1550, MATH 1552 and EXST 2201 or equivalent

Name: Undergraduate Research
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Individual study of a specific environmental problem or individual laboratory research.

Name: Environmental Campaigns
Desc: Application of social marketing and strategic communication campaign planning to address environmental issues.

Name: Cancer: A Family of Environmental Diseases
Desc: Introduction and characterization of the basic components of cancer including causes and molecular disease processes, environmental and genetic etiological factors, biomarkers, and therapeutic approaches.
Reqs: ENVS 4477; BIOL 4087 or BIOL 4093, or consent of instructor

Name: Applied Ecology
Desc: hrs. of biological and/or physical science. Field service fee.  2 hr lecture, 3 hr. lab. The biosphere, air, land and aquatic environments; development of alternative techniques for correcting environmental pollution; environmental risk assessment analysis and management.

Name: Physical Climatology
Desc: See GEOG 4015.

Name: Aquatic Pollution
