Desc: Introduction and overview of emergency management functions and processes in federal, state and local governments; roles of nonprofit and private organizations in disaster planning, response and recovery; critical management issues in effective response and recovery to natural and man made hazards.

Name: Coastal and Shallow-Marine Depositional Systems
Desc: May be taken for elective geology credit. See GEOL 4023.

Name: Political Geography
Desc: Political geography concerns how politics is geographical and geography is political. Topics include international relations and geopolitics, electoral geography and redistricting, the nation-state and other forms of political organization, and practices of political territorialization and bordering.

Name: The History of Geography
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture and proseminar discussion. Development of geography since ancient times; emphasis on the 19th and 20th centuries.

Name: Deltaic Geology
Desc: See GEOL 4164.

Name: Hazard Risk Reduction
Desc: Exploration of advanced concepts and practices in the geography of hazard risk reduction.

Name: Internship
Desc: Faculty supervised field study with an agency or organization whose mission is considered relevant to the emergency management system or disaster planning, response or mitigation.

Name: Special Topics in Geography
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Permission of instructor.

Name: Independent Study and Research in Geography
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit.

Name: HONORS: Independent Reading and Research in Geography
Desc: Same as GEOG 4998, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Permission of instructor. Credit will not be given for this course and GEOG 4998.

Name: Poetics of Place
Desc: Same as ANTH 7074.

Name: Introduction to Graduate Study
Desc: Same as ANTH 7901. Techniques and methods of their profession for incoming graduate students.

Name: Introduction to Research Methods in Geography
Desc: No description provided

Name: Settlement Geography: Exploration
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit with consent of department.

Name: Selected Topics in Geography
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. when topics vary. Permission of department.

Name: Advanced Physical Geography
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit with consent of department.

Name: Research and Field Work in Geography
Desc: Each course may be repeated for credit. Permission of instructor.

Name: Research and Field Work in Geography
Desc: Each course may be repeated for credit.

Name: Research and Field Work in Geography
Desc: Each course may be repeated for credit. Permission of instructor.

Name: Quantitative Methods for Geographical Analysis
Desc: Spatial analytical methods for handling and interpreting data related to geography.

Name: Advanced Qualitative Research in Geography and Anthropology
Desc: Also offered as ANTH 7936. Explores the varied tools, techniques and methodologies of qualitative inquiry. Students gain practical experience creating and working with multiple forms of qualitative data and engaging in qualitative analysis and interpretation.

Name: Geographical Literature
Desc: No description provided

Name: Culture History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit with consent of department.

Name: Seminar in Cultural Geography
Desc: May be repeated for max. of 9 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Explores different theoretical, methodological and empirical approaches in cultural geography.

Name: Paleoclimatology
Desc: Theory and methods of reconstructing climatic variability from biological and geological proxy records as well as historical archives.
Reqs: GEOG 2050 and GEOG 2051 or GEOL 1001 and GEOL 1003 or consent of instructor

Name: Socioeconomic Applications of GIS
Desc: Applications of Geographic Information Systems in business, social, economic, and public policy studies.

Name: Coastal and Estuarine Resources
Desc: Nature of coastal and estuarine resources and their perception, evaluation and exploitation.

Name: Advanced Geographic Information Systems
Desc: Theory and methods of design, development, implementation and applications of geographic information systems.

Name: Advanced Remote Sensing Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics in remote sensing.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading. Permission of instructor.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading. Permission of instructor.

Name: General Geology: Physical
Desc: [LCCN: CGEO 1103, Physical Geology] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, GEOL 1002, is also available. Credit will not be given for both this course and GEOL 1002 or GEOL 1111. Earth materials and land forms; processes at work on and within the earth.

Name: HONORS: General Geology: Physical
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as GEOL 1001, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for both this course and GEOL 1001 or GEOL 1111.

Name: General Geology: Historical
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and GEOL 1004. History of the earth and life on it, as deciphered from study of its rocks and fossils.

Name: HONORS: General Geology: Historical
Desc: Same as GEOL 1003, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and GEOL 1003.

Name: Dinosaurs, Catastrophes and Extinctions
Desc: Not for major credit for geology majors. History of dinosaur discoveries and methods of study; dinosaurs’ relationship to birds and mammals; place of dinosaurs in earth’s geological history; emphasis on catastrophes and patterns of extinction.

Name: Geology of National Park Areas
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and either GEOL 1001 or GEOL 1002. Geological study of areas supervised by the National Park Service. Areas covered will include most of the National Parks and Monuments, and many other federally owned lands.

Name: Principles of Geology I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and for GEOL 1001 and GEOL 1601 or GEOL 1002 and GEOL 1601. 3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. lab. For Geology majors and minors. Principles of physical geology with a focus on plate tectonics and on applying the mathematics to solve geolgic problems.
Reqs: Credit or registration in MATH 1021, MATH 1022, MATH 1023, MATH 1550, or MATH 1551

Name: Principles of Geology II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and GEOL 1003 and GEOL 1602 or GEOL 1004 and GEOL 1602. 3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. lab. For geology majors and minors. Principles of and techniques used in reconstructing Earth’s history.
Reqs: GEOL 1001 and GEOL 1601 or GEOL 1201 and credit or registration in MATH 1022, MATH 1023, MATH 1550 or MATH 1551

Name: Physical Geology Laboratory
Desc: Lab related to GEOL 1001. Properties of minerals and rocks; practical application of geological principles, using topographic and geological maps; geological factors relating to energy exploration and environmental problems, with emphasis on south Louisiana.
Reqs: credit or concurrent enrollment in GEOL 1001

Name: Historical Geology Laboratory
Desc: Lab related to GEOL 1003. Sedimentary rocks and environments, geobiological sequences, fossils and the historical geological record as interpreted from maps.
Reqs: GEOL 1601; credit or concurrent enrollment in GEOL 1003

Name: The Earth as a Planetary System
Desc: Introduction to the ways of the earth functions as an integrated system through quantitative exploration of the solid earth interactions with the atmosphere, the ocean, and the biosphere.
Reqs: Credit or registration in GEOL 1202 or GEOL 1602 or permission of department

Name: Introductory Special Topics in Geosciences
Desc: May be taken for a max of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics in the geosciences.
Reqs: GEOL 1201 or GEOL 1601 or permission of department

Name: Geology and the Environment
Desc: Interaction between human activities and geological processes, hazards and materials; emphasis on environmental geology of Louisiana and the Gulf Coast region.

Name: History of the Biosphere
Desc: One or two field trips required. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Characteristics and geologic history of selected taxa with significant fossil records; use of paleontologic data (paleobiologic, paleoenvironmental, geochemical and biostratigraphic) in geology and evolutionary studies; influence of the biosphere on Earth over geologic time.

Name: Mineralogy
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and GEOL 3200. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Elementary crystallography; mineral identification; general chemical and physical properties of minerals; environments of minerals.
Reqs: GEOL 1201 or GEOL 1601; CHEM 1201 or consent of instructor

Name: Introduction to Research in Geosciences
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Introduction to the breadth of professional and research opportunities within geosciences.
Reqs: GEOL 1201 or GEOL 1601 or permission of department

Name: Introduction to Sedimentology and Depositional Environments
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and GEOL 3200. One field trip and one field exercise in nearby area. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Sediment types, textures, sedimentary structures and major minerals used to understand sedimentary processes leading to different depositional environments.
Reqs: GEOL 1202 or GEOL 1602; credit or registration in GEOL 2081 or consent of instructor

Name: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and GEOL 3200. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Classification, theoretical background and tectonic processes related to development of igneous and metamorphic rocks; and optical petrographic methods.
Reqs: GEOL 2081; credit or registration in CHEM 1202

Name: Evolution of the Biosphere
Desc: One or two field trips required.  3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Characteristics and geologic history of selected taxa with significant fossil records; use of paleontologic data (paleobiologic, paleoenvironmental, geochemical and biostratigraphic) in geology and evolutionary studies; influence of the biosphere on Earth over geologic time.
Reqs: GEOL 1202 or GEOL 1602; credit or registration in GEOL 2081; BIOL 1201 or BIOL 1001

Name: Structural Geology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab and a one week field-based project. Geometric, kinematic and dynamic analysis of geologic structures and structural systems resulting from deformation; introduction to tectonics; introduction to field techniques and geologic maps; generation of geologic maps and cross-sections.
Reqs: GEOL 1202 or GEOL 1602; PHYS 2001 or PHYS 2110 or PHYS 1201; MATH 1550

Name: Earth Materials for Petroleum Engineers
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and GEOL 2081 or GEOL 3032 or GEOL 3041. May not be taken by geology majors for credit. Introduction to the classification, occurrence and origin of rocks and rock forming minerals.
Reqs: GEOL 1001 and GEOL 1601,or GEOL 1002 and GEOL 1601, or GEOL 1201

Name: Field Geology
Desc: Students planning to take this course should apply to the camp director no later than March 15. Camp and trip fees. Six weeks of field-based projects in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado, New Mexico and Wyoming; fundamentals of the study of rocks and geologic features in their natural settings.
Reqs: GEOL 3032, GEOL 3041, GEOL 3061 and GEOL 3071 or equivalent with grades of C or better in all prerequisite courses

Name: Geological Research
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit. Provides opportunities for individual research experiences under the direction of faculty. The Department’s expectation is that the course provides meaningful research experiences that will enhance student learning and preparation for advanced training and not be limited to day-to-day laboratory tasks.

Name: Undergraduate Thesis in Geology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Defense committee of three faculty members must be approved by the department. Individual research on problems in the geological sciences. Includes writing, public presentation and defense of a research thesis.

Name: Special Topics in Geology and Geophysics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced and/or emerging topics in the geosciences.
Reqs: senior standing in geology or consent of instructor

Name: Introduction to Micropaleontology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Morphology, classification, stratigraphy, paleoecology and evolutionary patterns of common marine microfossils.

Name: Geoarchaeology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture plus equivalent of 3 hrs of lab per week devoted to an applied fieldwork problem. Geological, stratigraphical, geochemical and geophysical techniques employed in the study of archaeological sites and materials.
Reqs: GEOL 1001 orGEOL 1201 or ANTH 2015 or GEOG 2051 or permission of instructor

Name: Principles of Environmental Geochemistry
Desc: Principles of equilibrium and kinetics of chemical reactions and the application of those principles to the natural environment with an emphasis on the chemistry of natural waters and environmental geochemistry.

Name: Coastal and Shallow-Marine Depositional Systems
Desc: Also offered as GEOG 4023. Dynamics of sediment transport in coastal zones and on continental shelves; sea- level changes; morphological, sedimentary and stratigraphic attributes of coastal and shallow-marine lithosomes.

Name: Fluvial Geomorphology
Desc: See GEOG 4025.

Name: Advanced Sedimentology
Desc: Students should expect to participate in field trip(s) of varying duration. Physical sedimentary processes in non-marine and marine depositional systems, including fluvial, alluvial fan, lacustrine eolian, and carbonate and clastic marine environments; influence of tectonics, climate, and sea level on sedimentary architecture and sequences.

Name: Earth Materials and the Environment
Desc: Earth materials as problems and solutions in environmental issues; physiochemical behavior of asbestiform silicates, silica, zeolites and associated health hazards; potential geological repositories for hazardous waste.
Reqs: CHEM 1202, GEOL 2081 or permission of instructor

Name: Petroleum Geology
Reqs: GEOL 3032 or GEOL 3200 or permission of instructor

Name: Stratigraphy
Desc: The succession and age relationships of rock strata including their form, lithologic components, fossil content, geophysical and geochemical properties and their interpretation in terms of environment, mode of origin and geologic history.

Name: Computer Programming and Data Analysis in Earth Sciences
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Computer programming and application of data analysis principles to problems in Earth Sciences.
Reqs: MATH 1552 and GEOL 2081, or permission of instructor

Name: Exploration and Environmental Geophysics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles and methods of acquisition, processing and interpretation of geophysical data used to investigate the shallow subsurface; seismic refraction, seismic reflection, gravity, magnetics, electrical resistivity, well logs and ground penetrating radar.
Reqs: GEOL 3071 and MATH 1552 or permission of instructor

Name: Plate Tectonics
Desc: Contemporary concepts of plate tectonics; geophysical observations and geological implications.

Name: Reflection Seismology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Seismic reflection techniques used to investigate shallow earth structure; waves in layered media, correlation, convolution, deconvolution and spectral analysis; interpretation of seismic record sections.
Reqs: MATH 1550 and PHYS 1202 or PHYS 2113 or PHYS 2002 or consent of instructor

Name: Chemical Oceanography
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture/seminar. Controls on the mass balance and distribution of major elements, trace elements, heavy metals, dissolved gases and nutrients in estuarine and open-ocean systems.

Name: Geomicrobiology
Desc: Microbial effects and controls on geologic, geochemical and ecological processes; biochemical tracers and fossils of microbially mediated processes through time; introduction to biogeochemical processes.
Reqs: GEOL 3032 or BIOL 2051 or consent of instructor

Name: Geochemistry of Sediments and Natural Waters
Desc: Controls on the composition of natural waters and the role of fluid-rock interactions in the geochemical evolution of sedimentary rocks, the ocean and the atmosphere; major geochemical cycles.

Name: Introduction to Seismology
Desc: Introduction and overview of seismology, seismological concepts, intellectual frameworks, and investigation techniques; Studying seismic sources and earth structures using seismograms; Characterization and interpretation of seismograms.
Reqs: PHYS 1201, PHYS 2001, or PHYS 2110, MATH 1550 or MATH 1551, and GEOL 3071 or permission of the instructor

Name: Vertebrate Paleontology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Phylogenetic survey of fossil vertebrates; their origins and transitions; vertebrate taphonomy, biostratigraphy and fossil collection and preparation.

Name: Basin Analysis
Desc: Basic environment of sediment deposition; sedimentological models and their relationships within depositional basins; analysis of theoretical basin models and comparison with modern and ancient sedimentary basins.
Reqs: GEOL 3071 and GEOL 3032 or GEOL 3200 or permission of instructor

Name: Hydrology & Hydrogeology
Desc: Students will be required to participate in weekend field trip(s). 3 hrs. lecture, 1 hr. recitation. Contemporary concepts of surface and groundwater flow including contaminant transport, aquifer tests, and Darcy’s law.

Name: Deltaic Geology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Processes of deltaic sedimentation and the nature of deltaic sediments; Mississippi River delta compared to other modern and ancient deltas.

Name: Subsurface Geology
Reqs: GEOL 3032 or GEOL 3071 or GEOL 3200 or PETE 3036

Name: Physical Hydrogeology
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in GEOL 3032, GEOL 3071, and MATH 1552 or permission of instructor

Name: Topics in Earth Sciences for Teachers
Desc: Offered in Su May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Consent of instructor is required for the second and third times. Various aspects of the earth sciences for elementary, middle and high school teachers of science.

Name: Advanced Metamorphic Petrology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Facies concept, theoretical and field relations, textures and their significance.

Name: Sequence Stratigraphy
Desc: One week field trip to the southern Rocky Mountains is required. Principles of physical stratigraphy with emphasis on contemporary concepts about the interaction of tectonics, sea level and sediment supply in generating a predictable architecture of sedimentary basin fills.
Reqs: introductory course in sedimentology, GEOL 3032 or equivalent

Name: Seismic Stratigraphy
Desc: Interpretation of seismic reflection data in terms of sedimentary facies, stratigraphic sequences and implications for local and eustatic sea-level fluctuations.

Name: Isotope Geochemistry
Desc: Stable isotope fractionation in natural systems; emphasis on oxygen, hydrogen, and carbon isotope-ratio variation in natural waters, carbonates and silicates with application to the solution of petrologic problems.

Name: Petroleum Seismology
Desc: Fundamentals of mathematical physics, seismology, and signal theory used to understand resources, including petroleum, geological processes, and structure in the earth.

Name: Paleoecology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab; field trip. Diversity, structure, taphonomy and evolution of fossil and modern marine assemblages; adaptations and functional morphology; organism-sediment relationships.

Name: Permian Basin
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture per week; equivalent of 2 hrs. lab per week devoted to a required four-day field trip. An in-depth study of the Permian Basin including biostratigraphy, sequence stratigraphy, oil and gas production, and includes a required four-day field trip.

Name: Dynamics of Sedimentation
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Fluid mechanics as applied to sedimentation, fluid-particle interactions, erosion, mechanics of sediment transport including fluid and sediment flows, deposition and the origin of primary structures, and hydrodynamic instability and soft-sediment deformation.

Name: Sedimentary Petrography of Carbonates
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles governing formation, deposition and diagenesis of carbonate sediments and sedimentary rocks; lab stresses textural, fabric and mineral relationship and interpretation of depositional environments and mineral paragenesis of ancient carbonate sequences.

Name: Clay Mineralogy
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab/discussion. Mineralogy; geochemistry and geology of clay minerals; argillaceous sediments and rocks.

Name: Oil and Gas Exploration
Desc: 1 hrs. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Focus on oil and gas exploration techniques, such as paleogeographic reconstructions, understanding of the regional geological setting, interpretation of seismic data and well-log data, basin modeling incorporating thermal history, determining critical moments, and an assessment of exploration risks.
Reqs: Graduate standing in Geology & Geophysics and permission of instructor

Name: Reservoir Characterization
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Origin, description, exploration and development of oil and gas reservoirs; topics include accommodation space, reservoir occurrence, origin of petroleum, oil and gas properties, rock properties, drilling, exploration and appraisal, reservoir flow modeling and production engineering; emphasis on integration of geology, geophysics and petroleum engineering.
Reqs: GEOL 4182 or PETE 4051 or consent of instructor

Name: Scientific Communication and Visualization
Desc: Methods for written, oral and visual communication with an emphasis on scientific approaches, analysis and presentation of scientific quantitative information.

Name: Special Topics in Geology and Geophysics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced and/or emerging topics in geology and geophysics.

Name: Directed Research in Geology and Geophysics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. General student-selected research topics and focused group research, including all topics in geology and geophysics.

Name: Seminar in Geology: Paleontology
Desc: May be repeated for credit.

Name: Departmental Seminar in Geology and Geophysics
Desc: Presentations on specialized subjects of current interest in geological sciences.

Name: Seminar in Geology: Sedimentology
Desc: May be repeated for credit. Fall semester: carbonate sedimentology; spring semester: clastic sedimentology and sedimentary environments.

Name: Seminar in Geology: Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology
Desc: May be repeated for credit.

Name: Paleoclimatology
Desc: See GEOG 7943.

Name: Seminar in Geology: Structural Geology
Desc: May be repeated for credit.

Name: Field Work
Desc: Field work and field trips mandatory. Collection of field data, including samples of ice, rock, water, sediment from remote location(s), generation of field maps, in association with required research projects.

Name: Seminar in Tectonics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Plate tectonics, diapirism, isostasy and the tectonics of specific areas.

Name: Seminar in Geophysics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Structure and composition of the mantle; physical processes at ridges, trenches and transform faults; dynamics of plate interiors; intraplate stress; and thermal histories of the earth and other terrestrial planets; physics of rock magnetism; and hydrodynamics of sedimentary basins.

Name: Seminar in Geochemistry
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Mineralogy, paragenesis, geochemistry and natural occurrence of authigenic silica in sediments; other topics such as hydro geochemistry, isotope geochemistry and the geochemistry of carbonates.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Elementary Greek
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Introduction to the core vocabulary and grammar for reading and writing Ancient Greek; basic readings in Classical and Biblical Greek.

Name: Intermediate Greek
Desc: Completion of core vocabulary and grammar for reading and writing Ancient Greek; basic readings in Classical and Biblical Greek.

Name: Intermediate Greek Prose
Desc: Application of grammar, vocabulary and concepts from the first year of Greek. Readings in basic ancient Greek prose.

Name: Intermediate Greek 2
Desc: May be taken for a max. 9 sem. hrs. when topics vary, by permission of department. Intermediate-level readings in Classical and/or Koine Greek.

Name: Homer
Desc: Readings from the Iliad or Odyssey; selected passages from various books; some attention to aesthetic and historical problems.

Name: Greek Drama
Desc: Readings in Greek drama including a representative play of Sophocles or Euripides.

Name: New Testament
Desc: Selected readings from the New Testament.

Name: Plato’s Dialogues
Desc: Readings from Plato’s dialogues.

Name: Attic Oratory
Desc: Readings from Attic orators such as Demonsthenes, Andocides, Antiphon, Lysias.

Name: Special Topics in Greek Poetry
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Readings and studies in one or more of the following: Homer, Hesiod, Pindar, Greek lyric poetry, Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, Aristophanes.

Name: Special Topics in Greek Prose
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Readings and studies in one or more of the following: Herodotus, Thucydides, the Pre-Socratics, the orators, Plato, Aristotle.

Name: Independent Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Permission of department required. Readings in Greek literature directed by a senior faculty member.

Name: Elementary German
Desc: [LCCN:CGRM 1014, Elementary German I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structures of German; emphasis on communicative language use; supplementary work in language and computer laboratories.

Name: Elementary German
Desc: Continuation of GERM 1101. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structures of German; emphasis on communicative language use. Supplementary work in language and computer laboratories.

Name: German for Travelers
Desc: German for travelers is not applicable towards a major or minor in German and does not fulfill foreign language requirements for undergraduates. The course introduces basic communication patterns, focuses on practical everyday vocabulary through exercises role-playing and situational activities.

Name: German Civilization
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Also offered as HIST 2075. Knowledge of German not required. Development of the modern German states from early Germanic times; art, literature, music and philosophy in an historical context.

Name: Intermediate German
Desc: Native speakers of German will not receive credit for this course. Reading, conversation, composition; review of lexicon and structure; supplementary work in language and computer laboratories.

Name: Intermediate German
Desc: Continuation of GERM 2101. Native speakers of German will not receive credit for this course. Reading, conversation, composition; emphasis on lexicon of spoken German; supplementary work in language and computer laboratories.

Name: Readings in German Literature
Desc: Native speakers of German will not receive credit for this course. Analysis of literary texts; expansion of lexicon, comprehension and composition skills.

Name: German for Business
Desc: Introduction to German in a business environment: focus on linguistic structures and vocabulary, forms of business communication, reading of business text and social customs.

Name: German Discourse
Desc: Intensive practice in listening comprehension, oral and written communication; special problems in German structure; thematic treatment of contemporary issues in German speaking countries.

Name: Survey of German Literature and Culture: 1700-1830
Desc: Readings from, and an overview of, the Enlightment, Storm and Stress, Weimer Classicism and Romanticism.

Name: Survey of German Literature and Culture: 1830-1890
Desc: Readings from, and a historical overview of, Biedermeier/Vormarz, Realism and Naturalism.

Name: Survey of German Literature and Culture: 1890-to the Present
Desc: Readings from, and a historical overview of, Expressionism, New Objectivity, the Group 47, GDR literature and Post-Modernism.

Name: Friedrich Nietzsche
Desc: Also offered as PHIL 3090. Knowledge of German not required. Major works of Nietzsche studied in the context of the three periods of productivity and evolution of his thought.

Name: Special Topics in German Literature in Translation
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Knowledge of German not required.

Name: Special Topics in German Film
Desc: May be taken for 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Knowledge of German not required. In-depth study of various aspects of German cinema.

Name: German for Reading Knowledge
Desc: Undergraduates may enroll on a Pass-fail basis only. Specialized course intended to satisfy departmental foreign language reading requirement for graduate students. This course will not count toward a graduate degree. Does not count toward satisfying foreign language requirements for undergraduates, although hours may count toward baccalaureate.

Name: Questions in Jewish Thought
Desc: See REL 4014.

Name: German Poetry
Desc: Study of German poetic expression.

Name: Special Topics in 19th Century German Literature and Culture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in 20th Century German Literature and Culture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in Contemporary German Literature and Culture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Advanced German Film
Desc: Knowledge of German not required. In-depth study of German film in its socio-historic contexts with attention to cinematic technique.

Name: Advanced German Discourse
Desc: Continued intensive practice in complex grammar and structures. Analysis and synthesis of authentic German material with focus on reading and writing.

Name: Special Topics in German Literature and Culture in Translation
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Knowledge of German not required.

Name: Independent Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. credit. Permission of department required.

Name: Beginning Hebrew
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. The alphabet, basic grammar and vocabulary of classical Hebrew; simple prose passages from the Bible.

Name: Beginning Hebrew
Desc: Basic grammar and vocabulary of classical Hebrew; simple prose readings from the Bible.

Name: Intermediate Hebrew
Desc: Biblical narratives; details of syntax; development of vocabulary.

Name: Intermediate Hebrew
Desc: Biblical narratives and poetry; details of syntax; development of vocabulary; textual criticism.

Name: Western Civilization to 1500
Desc: [LCCN: CHIS 1013, Western Civilization I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, HIST 1002, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 1002. Ideas, trends and institutions in western civilization from earliest times to the Reformation.

Name: HONORS: Western Civilization to 1500
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as HIST 1001, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 1001. Supervised reading, discussion, research and writing.

Name: Western Civilization Since 1500
Desc: [LCCN: CHIS 1023, Western Civilization II] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, HIST 1004, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 1004, Development of western civilization from the Reformation to the present.

Name: HONORS: Western Civilization Since 1500
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as HIST 1003, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 1003. Supervised reading, discussion, research and writing.

Name: World History to 1500
Desc: [LCCN: CHIS 1113, World Civilization I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Developments and interactions among Asian, African, European, American and Oceanian cultures in the pre-modern age.

Name: World History Since 1500
Desc: [LCCN: CHIS 1123, World Civilization II] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Interactions among Asian, Middle Eastern, African, European and American cultures in the modern era.

Name: Britain from 1689 to the Present
Desc: No description provided

Name: Goddesses to Witches: Women in Europe 500 BCE -1700 CE
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Womens’ lives and ideas about gender from Greece and Rome to the beginning of the modern era.

Name: Medieval Europe
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social, cultural, religious and political history of medieval Europe from the reign of Constantine in the fourth century to the fall of Constantinople in 1453.

Name: Modern Europe
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Political, economic and social developments and diplomacy from 1848 to the present.

Name: The World Since 1960
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Major events since 1960 in the U.S., U.S.S.R., and selected nations of Europe, the Middle East, Latin America, Africa and Asia; emphasis on social, economic, political and national security issues.

Name: No title provided
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social, cultural, religious and political history of Europe from the Renaissance to the French Revolution.

Name: War, Mass Violence, and Genocide
Desc: Selected cases of genocide, ethnic cleansing, and other forms of mass violence against civilians in world history studied in the context of warfare or postwar settlements.

Name: Home Fronts
Desc: Comparative Study of the social, cultural, political and economic impact of war.

Name: No title provided
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Encounters between cultures west of the Mississippi River and the significance of the frontier in American History.

Name: The United States to 1865
Desc: [LCCN: CHIS 2013, American History I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, HIST 2056, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 2056.

Name: HONORS: The United States to 1865
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as HIST 2055, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 2055.

Name: The United States from 1865 to the Present
Desc: [LCCN: CHIS 2023, American History II] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, HIST 2058, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 2058.

Name: HONORS: The United States from 1865 to the Present
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as HIST 2057, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and HIST 2057.

Name: African American History
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social, cultural and economic role of African Americans in the U.S. from 1619 to the present.

Name: History of Popular Culture in the United States
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. The history of popular culture in the United States from the mid-nineteenth century to the present.

Name: German Civilization
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. See GERM 2075.

Name: Colonial Latin America
Desc: Colonial period emphasizing the European background, explorations, political and economic systems and wars of independence.

Name: East Asian Civilization Since 1800
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Modern Asian civilization; emphasis on contact with the West and the rise of nationalism and communism.

Name: Introduction to Asia
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social, cultural, and religious history of eastern civilizations from origins to the present.

Name: The History of Premodern Cities
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social, cultural, and political history of cities before 1500.

Name: Cities in European History since 1500
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Cities in European social, cultural, and economic history since 1500.

Name: Contemporary Middle East
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social and political history of the Middle East, from the late eighteenth century to the present.

Name: Introduction to African Civilizations
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social, cultural, religious and political history of Africa from pre-historic period to 1800.

Name: African Colonialism 1800-1960
Desc: Political, economic and social developments in Africa from 1880 to 1960.

Name: Post-Colonial Africa
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Major events in the history of Africa since 1960 with emphasis on social, economic, political and cultural issues.

Name: No title provided
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Social and political history of South Asia, covering the establishment of British colonialism in India, to the postcolonial era of independent nation-states of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh.

Name: Topics in European History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in U.S. History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in World History: Asia, Africa, or Latin America
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Comparative History
Desc: May be taken for a max.of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: History and the Social Sciences I
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3001. Supervised tutorial experience in local middle or high schools. Introduction to the role of the social sciences in the study of history.

Name: History and the Social Sciences II
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3136.

Name: Louisiana
Desc: [LCCN: CHIS 2033, Louisiana History] Political, economic, social and cultural development.

Name: Undergraduate Proseminar in World History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Open to students with at least 6 sem. hrs. of credit in history and with an overall 3.00 GPA. Supervised reading and research in an assigned field of historical study.

Name: Undergraduate Proseminar in European History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Open to students with at least 6 sem. hrs. of credit in history and with an overall 3.00 GPA. Supervised reading and research in an assigned field of historical study.

Name: Undergraduate Proseminar in United States History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Open to students with at least 6 sem. hrs. of credit in history and with an overall 3.00 GPA. Supervised reading and research in an assigned field of historical study.

Name: Greece of the City State
Desc: Political, social and cultural evolution of the Greek world from the Bronze Age to the foundation of the Macedonian Empire of Alexander the Great; attention to growth of democratic institutions.

Name: The Roman Republic
Desc: The Roman state, culture and society from the origin of the city to the dictatorship of Julius Caesar.

Name: Rome of the Caesars
Desc: The growth of absolute government, spread of Christianity and other political, cultural, and social movements from the establishment of the Principate to the fall of the Western Empire.

Name: The Early Middle Ages, 300-1000
Desc: History of Europe from Constantine the Great to the end of the Carolingians; development of medieval society and institutions.

Name: The Later Middle Ages, 1000-1500
Desc: History of Europe from the Investiture Controversy to the voyages of Columbus; developments in social, cultural and political institutions.

Name: The Renaissance
Desc: Italian society and thought from Dante to Machiavelli, with emphasis on the medieval foundations of Renaissance culture; northern Europe from the Hundred Years War to the Reformation, with emphasis on political and economic development.

Name: The Age of the Reformation
Desc: Also offered as REL 4011. Sixteenth century Europe with emphasis on Protestant and Catholic reform movements.

Name: History of Modern Christian Thought
Desc: See REL 4012.

Name: Women in Early Modern Europe
Desc: Major problems in the history of women in Europe during the period 1400-1700 with particular emphasis on the Renaissance and Reformation.

Name: Questions in Jewish Thought
Desc: See REL 4014.

Name: Modern European Jewish History
Desc: See REL 4015.

Name: 19th Century Europe
Desc: The period 1815-1870.

Name: 20th Century Europe
Desc: Survey of 20th century European history; emphasis on the role of total war in social, political and cultural change and the impact of modern nationalist ideologies.

Name: France Before 1770
Desc: French society and politics in the early modern through Revolutionary eras.

Name: France since 1770
Desc: Cultural, political, economic, social and intellectual survey of France from the pre-revolution to the present.

Name: Spain since 1469
Desc: Political, economic and social development from the marriage of Ferdinand and Isabella to the present.

Name: The Dutch Republic and Empire: 1500-1800
Desc: Political, economic, social and cultural history of one of the great powers of early modern Europe; emphasis on the Golden Age of Rembrant and Vermeer.

Name: 20th Century Germany
Desc: The states that have existed in Germany since 1890; the Wilhelminian Empire; the Weimar Republic; the Third Reich; and the Germany of today.

Name: The First World War
Desc: The First World War, 1914-1918, including controversies regarding its origin and aftermath.

Name: Eastern Europe: 1914-Present
Desc: Emphasis on the independent nation-states after World War I, impact of totalitarianism and the current liberalization.

Name: The Balkans: 1453-1878
Desc: Origins of the Balkan peoples, development of the Ottoman Empire and rise of the autonomous Balkan nation-states.

Name: The Balkans: 1879-Present
Desc: Events leading up to and including World War I, problems of the inter-war period, World War II and rise and decline of Communism in Southeastern Europe.

Name: Russia Since 1861
Desc: Reaction and reform from 1861 to 1905; failure of parliamentary democracy amid war and revolution; Leninism and Stalinism; relaxation of totalitarian rule since Stalin’s death.

Name: Tudor England
Desc: Political, economic and cultural history of 16th century England.

Name: Stuart England
Desc: Period of transition from kings who would be absolutist, through the crisis of civil wars, to the beginnings of parliamentary dominance.

Name: 19th Century Britain
Desc: Emphasis on the acquisition of Empire, emergence of industrial society, and the rise of Victorianism between 1780 and 1900.

Name: 20th Century Britain
Desc: Intellectual, political, social, and economic developments since 1900, including the experience of total war, construction of the welfare state, imperial decline and the significance of Thatcherism.

Name: Modern Irish History: 1600-Present
Desc: Development of communities and conflicts in Ireland from the Tudors to the European community; emphasis on cultural, political and military affairs.

Name: The British Empire and Commonwealth
Desc: British Empire and development of the British Commonwealth of Nations.

Name: British Colonialism in South Asia
Desc: Political, economic and cultural history of the British Empire in South Asia from the founding of the East India Company in 1600 to the end of the British imperial role in 1947.

Name: Colonial America: 1607-1763
Desc: Political, economic, cultural and military developments in the 13 colonies.

Name: The American Revolution, 1763-1789
Desc: Political, intellectual, economic and military developments in the formation of a permanent American union.

Name: The Age of Jefferson and Hamilton: 1789-1820
Desc: Implementation of the Constitution, adoption of the Bill of Rights, formation of a political party system and economic and social change.

Name: The Age of Jackson: 1820-1860
Desc: Examination of democratization, economic transformation, party development, the reform movement, slavery and the sectional crisis.

Name: Civil War
Desc: Secession; social and economic conditions, principal military campaigns.

Name: The American Teens and Twenties
Desc: From the inaugural of Woodrow Wilson to the Crash of 1929; Wilson and reform at home and revolution abroad; the Great War and its impact; the Jazz Age, its tension and its collapse.

Name: The Age of Roosevelt
Desc: From the inaugural of FDR to the surrender of Japan: the Great Depression and the New Deal; the thirties’ search for an American culture; the road to Pearl Harbor; America in World War II, at home and abroad.

Name: Diplomatic History of the United States, 1914 to the Present
Desc: Interpretations of American foreign policy in the 20th century; emphasis on public opinion and relationship of business investment to foreign policy.

Name: History of Contemporary America
Desc: History of America since 1945, focusing on domestic affairs.

Name: Military History of the United States
Desc: Military policy and campaigns, war economy and organization of the armed forces.

Name: The Antebellum South
Desc: Economic, social, intellectual and political development of the South to 1860.

Name: The New South
Desc: Political, economic, social and intellectual history of the South since 1877.

Name: Louisiana to 1815
Desc: Political, economic and social-development of early Louisiana.

Name: American Economic History to 1860
Desc: Also offered as ECON 4075. American economic growth and development from the colonial period to 1860, including the railroad, slavery, technology and nature of the industrial revolution; findings and method of the “new” or quantitative economic history.

Name: American Economic History: 1860 to the Present
Desc: Also offered as ECON 4076. American economic growth and development from 1860 to the present; economic impact of the Civil War, technological change, mechanization of agriculture, railroads, automobiles, war, the Great Depression and multinational corporations; findings and method of the “new” or quantitative economic history.

Name: American Popular Culture
Desc: Examination of popular culture forms from 19th-century vaudeville to today’s music videos; emphasis on development of mass media.

Name: Asian-American History
Desc: History of Asian peoples in the United States; topics including immigration, community development, cultural conflict, racism and stereotypes.

Name: Women in American History
Desc: Survey of political, social, economic and cultural development of American women from colonial times to present; topics include nineteenth century women’s rights movement, woman suffrage, women in civil rights movement, birth control, the modern feminist movement and southern women.

Name: No title provided
Desc: How immigrant families have shaped, and been shaped by, American politics and culture.

Name: The Caribbean: 1492-1830
Desc: Nature of and changes in economic and political institutions after European colonization, international conflicts, and abolition of slavery, primarily in the Greater and Lesser Antilles.

Name: Mexico: The National Period
Desc: Political, economic and social development since Independence.

Name: West Africa to 1800
Desc: The geography, ethnicity, social, economic and political development of West Africa from the prehistoric period to 1800.

Name: West Africa from 1800
Desc: The rise of Islamic orthodoxy, the role of imperialism, the rise of African nationalism and other themes in the history of West Africa since 1800.

Name: Atlantic History: ca. 1300-1888
Desc: Introduction to the historical relations between Europe, Africa and the Americas, 1300 to 1888, with particular attention to the roles of African peoples in the formation of the “Atlantic World.”

Name: China to 1600
Desc: History and civilization, including a survey of religion and philosophy, language and literature, art and archaeology and popular culture.

Name: Modern China
Desc: Chinese history of the Late Imperial and Republican period 1644-1949.

Name: Pre-Modern Japan
Desc: Political and cultural history and civilization from the beginnings to the close of the Japanese middle ages.

Name: Modern Japan
Desc: From 1600 to the present; emphasis on historical and cultural roots of Japan’s modernization in the late 19th century and quest for empire in the 20th century; cultural and intellectual developments in modern Japan.

Name: The Modern Middle East
Desc: Also offered as REL 4096 and INTL 4096. Major problems of the Middle East and North Africa in the modern period; internal Arab social, economic and intellectual developments; Muslim responses to European colonialism; modern Arab nationalism and political trends; Islamic reformist and revivalist movements; problem of Palestine.

Name: History of South Asia
Desc: Social, political, economic and cultural evolution of South Asia from the Bronze Age to the creation of India and Pakistan in 1947.

Name: Contemporary China
Desc: History of the People’s Republic of China from its establishment in 1949 to today.

Name: No title provided
Desc: The course explores sport, spectacle, and entertainment primarily in the ancient Roman and Medieval period of European history. It explores the role of sport, entertianment, and spectacle in the politics, society, and culture of the premodern world.

Name: HONORS: Proseminar
Desc: Open to qualified honors students having 12 hrs. credit in history and consent of instructor. Candidates for the honors degree in history will select an honors thesis before the end of the semester. Supervised reading in an assigned field of historical study; discussion of historical methods and research.

Name: Modern European Intellectual History: the Enlightenment to 1850
Desc: Modern thought in cultural,social, political contexts from Voltaire to Marx.

Name: Modern European Intellectual History Since 1850
Desc: European thought affecting society in the industrial age; realism, psychoanalysis, existentialism, the information explosion.

Name: History of Ancient Israel
Desc: See REL 4125.

Name: World War II
Desc: Global crisis of the 1930s; Axis and Allied strategies; major military campaigns; great power diplomacy; life on the home-fronts; the Holocaust; espionage and resistance; the experience of combat; social, political and scientific consequences.

Name: The Vietnam War
Desc: French colonial rule and Vietnamese nationalism; Ho Chi Minh and the war against the French (1946-54); the National Liberation Front (Vietcong); process of American involvement and disengagement; counter-insurgency and the air war; anti-war movement in the United States; reasons for failure of American policy; Vietnam since 1975; lessons and legacies for the U.S.

Name: Historical Archaeology
Desc: See ANTH 4018.

Name: Religion in the United States
Desc: Also offered as REL 4161. From the colonial period to the present; relation between changing religious beliefs and behavior of Americans and political, social, economic and intellectual developments; Puritanism, revivalism, response to Darwinian evolution, social gospel and civil religion.

Name: Religions of China and Japan
Desc: Also offered as REL 4191. Major religious traditions of East Asia; Confucianism, Taoism, Mahayana Buddhism, Shinto and Chinese and Japanese folk religion; religion in the context of Chinese and Japanese cultural history.

Name: Special Studies in World History
Desc: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Studies in European History
Desc: May be taken for a maximum of 9 semester hours of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Studies in United States History
Desc: May be repeated for credit when topics vary.

Name: History and the Social Sciences III
Desc: The role of social sciences in the study of history; course will assist students in the teaching of social studies to full classes of middle and high schools.
Reqs: HIST 3002 and EDCI 3136; concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4003

Name: Seminar in History and the Social Sciences
Desc: How history and the social sciences view issues of importance in the contemporary world; course will assist students who are enrolled in student teaching.
Reqs: EDCI 4003 and HIST 4403; concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4004 and EDCI 4005

Name: The Rise of Christianity
Desc: See REL 4505.

Name: Topics in the History of Christianity
Desc: See REL 4507.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: Reading and research on selected topics.
Reqs: open to advanced students of high academic standing by consent of department

Name: Independent Study
Desc: Reading and research on selected topics.
Reqs: open to advanced students of high academic standing by consent of department

Name: Independent Study in History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit.

Name: American Historiography and Criticism
Desc: American historical writing from the colonial period to the present.

Name: Introduction to Historical Research
Desc: General methods of and approaches to historical research and writing in European and American history, including theories, current approaches, problems and debates.

Name: Research Seminar in European History
Desc: Sources, bibliography; reports on original research.

Name: Reading Seminar in Early Modern Europe
Desc: No description provided

Name: Reading Seminar in European History to 1650
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Reading Seminar in European History from 1500
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Reading Seminar in British History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Reading Seminar in American History, 1607 to 1815
Desc: No description provided

Name: Reading Seminar in American History from 1890 to the Present
Desc: No description provided

Name: Research Seminar in American History
Desc: Introduction to research methods, sources and bibliography; reports on original research.

Name: Research Seminar: Special Topics in American History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Reports on original research.

Name: Reading Seminar: Special Topics in American History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Reading Seminar in Comparative History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Sources and bibliography; reports on original research.

Name: Seminar: Special Studies in History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. A reading and research seminar. Topic and emphasis will vary.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Honors Foundations
Desc: Introduction to Honors at LSU. Orientation to four-year Honors program and Honors College community includes: service, research, leadership and cultural events; strategies for academic and personal success.

Name: Introduction to Life Sciences
Desc: Not open to students who have had BIOL 1001, BIOL 1002, BIOL 1201, BIOL 1202, BIOL 1207, BIOL 1208, BIOL 1209 or BIOL 1503. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. A basic course, organized in accordance with the principle of organic evolution, emphasizing the chemical basis of life and cell biology.

Name: Introduction to the Life Sciences
Desc: Not open to students who have had BIOL 1001, BIOL 1002, BIOL 1201, BIOL 1202, BIOL 1207, BIOL 1208, BIOL 1209 or BIOL 1503. Continuation of HNRS 1007. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. A basic course, organized in accordance with the principle of organic evolution, emphasizing phylogeny, morphology, function of multicellular organisms and people’s relation to their environment.

Name: Life Science Seminar
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. credit when topics vary. For non-science majors only. Special topics in the Life Sciences.

Name: Physical Science Seminar
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. credit when topics vary. For non-science majors only. Special topics in the Physical Sciences.

Name: Critical Analysis
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Course for first-year Honors College students. Introduction to various practices of academic discourse and research methods. Interdisciplinary approach to a specific topic.

Name: The 19th Century
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Perspectives fundamental to 19th century culture; relevant works of literature, philosophy, art, science.

Name: The 20th Century
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Selected themes in 20th century civilization.

Name: Contemporary Studies
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Selected themes in contemporary civilization.

Name: Colloquium in the Arts
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Art forms and their cultural significance; particular themes involving examination of art works.

Name: Humanities Colloquium
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected themes and materials in literature, philosophy, history and art.

Name: Social Science Colloquium
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics of significance from the standpoint of various social sciences.

Name: Classical Civilization in the Mediterranean World
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. The civilizations of classical Greece and Rome. Includes literature, history, philosophy, religion, government, and fine arts.

Name: Medieval Civilization in Western Europe
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. European civilization from ancient Rome through the Middle Ages. Includes literature, history, philosophy, religion, government, and fine arts.

Name: European Civilization from 1400 to 1789
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. European civilization from the Renaissance through the Enlightenment. Includes literature, history, philosophy, religion, government, and fine arts.

Name: Modern Europe
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. European civilization from 1789 to the present. Includes literature, history, philosophy, religion, government, and fine arts.

Name: Research Methodologies
Desc: Honors introduction to undergraduate research methods. Theory, ethics, networking, proposal preparation, data collection and presentation of findings specific to student’s discipline; disciplinary emphasis varies by section.

Name: Leaders and Scholarship
Desc: Analysis of classical and modern foundations and principles of leadership. Practice in scholarship essay writing, interviewing, debate and critical thinking. Intended for national and international scholarship applicants.

Name: Advanced Seminar in Social Science and Humanities
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced topics of significance from the social sciences and humanities.

Name: Advanced Seminar in Natural Science
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics illustrative of developing concepts of the natural and physical universe and of living organisms.
Reqs: completion of one-year course in a physical science and one-year course in a biological science, at least one with laboratory; or consent of instructor

Name: Internships, Field Work and Off-Campus Programs
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. For special learning opportunities.
Reqs: consent of dean of Honors College

Name: Experiential Leadership Workshop
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Honors students engage in academically-related leadership experiences.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.
Reqs: proposal for course of study, approved by supervising faculty member and with the consent of the Honors College

Name: Thesis
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Independent research and writing toward the honors thesis.

Name: Interdisciplinary Fluid Dynamics: Physical Concepts
Desc: See ME 4813.

Name: Interdisciplinary Fluid Dynamics: Computational Methods
Desc: See ME 4823.

Name: Analysis of Environmental Issues
Desc: See EMS 2011.

Name: Introduction to Medicinal Plants
Desc: See RNR 2018.

Name: Installation and Maintenance of Ornamentals in the Landscape I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Introduction to soil analysis and preparation; installation and maintenance of landscape plants including trees, shrubs, perennials and annuals; irrigation installation and repair.

Name: Introduction to the Green Industry
Desc: Defining the general management structure and use of horticultural concepts specific to the “green agribusiness” sector; topics include entrepreneurial entry; specialized green industry labor; regulatory oversight; applied use of permits, waivers, and variances; cost effect of regulatory compliance; acquired use of patent and proprietary licensing.

Name: General Horticulture
Desc: Science and art of modern horticultural plant production, including plant anatomy, growth, propagation, nutrition and pest management; review of the horticulture industry, including fruit, vegetable and ornamental crop production.

Name: Plant Propagation
Desc: Principles of sexual and clonal propagation of plants; commercial production of horticultural crops.

Name: Horticulture Lab
Desc: Required for all horticulture majors. 3 hrs. lab. Application of horticultural principles including propagation, greenhouse production, fertilization and pest management.

Name: Introduction to Turfgrass Management
Desc: Required field trips. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Turfgrass identification and adaptation; establishment and maintenance of high quality turf areas; turfgrass pests and their control.
Reqs: BIOL 1202 or BIOL 1002; AGRO 2051 or equivalent

Name: Woody Plant Materials I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. lab. Identification and study of trees, shrubs, vines and groundcovers; cultural and visual characteristics of plants used in landscape design.

Name: Woody Plant Materials II
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. lab. Continuation of HORT 2120 with an introduction to interior plants, native plants and nursery production.

Name: Survey of Arboriculture
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Review of the biology, growth, environment and management practices for trees in the landscape.

Name: Organic Gardening and Sustainable Crop Production
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles and practices of organic vegetable and sustainable crop production; encompasses the ecological, economic, and social components of organic and sustainable crop farming systems.

Name: Growth and Development of Agricultural Crops
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. Physiology of agricultural plants, including water relations, respiration, photosynthesis and growth and development.
Reqs: CHEM 1002 or CHEM 1202 and BIOL 1002 or BIOL 1202

Name: Horticultural Botany
Desc: See RNR 2900.

Name: Horticultural Internship
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Work experience in horticultural industries culminating in acceptable written reports and a seminar presentation.
Reqs: HORT 2050 and written consent of instructor

Name: Horticulture Applications
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture. Calculations and measurements used in applied horticulture.

Name: Research Problems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Written consent of the instructor. Independent research under a faculty member culminating in an oral and written research report.

Name: Urban Landscape Management
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. Methods for sustainable management of the landscape through proper installation, soil management, plant care, pesticide management, employee management and cost accounting.

Name: Installation and Maintenance of Ornamentals in the Landscape II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. lab Introduction to the management of interior plants; disease, insect and weed management; pruning techniques for trees, shrubs, palms and roses.

Name: Landscape Construction
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Survey of construction techniques and materials used in landscape contracting including drainage systems, paving, retaining walls, decking and fencing.

Name: Natural Products from Medicinal Plants
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Medicinal plant natural products; classification of natural products, general methods of extraction and purification; alkaloids and related compounds; terpenes, flavonoids, steroids and related compounds; aspects of natural product biosynthesis.
Reqs: RNR 2018 or HORT 2018, and CHEM 2060 or equivalent

Name: Herbaceous Plant Materials
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. lab. Identification and study of herbaceous plant materials used in ornamental horticulture and landscaping.

Name: Sustainable Horticulture
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. This course will provide base knowledge of the principles and practices of sustainable, organic and alternative horticulture management systems. The class will review and evaluate topics including soil biological processes (compost, humus and fertility), pest management, alternative farming systems and organic agriculture.

Name: Tropical/Subtropical Horticulture
Desc: Current status of cultivation throughout the world; production practices; postharvest handling; international trade of tropical/subtropical horticultural crops.

Name: Special Topics in Horticulture
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Lab/field trip may be required. Subject areas not covered in other horticulture courses.

Name: Greenhouse Management and Controlled Environment Agriculture
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Operation and management of greenhouses and other controlled environments with emphasis on system design and construction, control of light intensity and photoperiod heating and cooling systems, substrates, mineral nutrition, water quality and irrigation systems.

Name: Advanced Controlled Environment Production
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Management of environmental factors and production techniques for specific crops in a protected or controlled environment.
Reqs: HORT 2860 or BIOL 3060 or PLHL 3060 or equivalent

Name: Plantation, Beverage and Tropical Nut Crops
Desc: World situations, production practices, pest management, harvesting, postharvest care, agro-processing and international trade of rubber, oil palm, cocoa, coconut, olive, coffee, tea, wine grapes, vanilla and various tropical/subtropical nut crops.

Name: International Horticulture
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. This course will provide an overview of the horticulture industry worldwide. Export, marketing and international trade issues will be covered in a global horticultural context.

Name: Temperature Stress Physiology
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. Principles of plant physiology and biochemistry as affected by abiotic stress with a focus on temperature. Basic principles of plant physiology, thermodynamics, temperature, and its effects on the growth and development of horticultural plants including specialty crops, ornamentals, and turfgrasses. Mechanisms of plant response to heat, chilling, and freezing stress including injury, acclimation, protection, and resistance.

Name: Plant Growth and Development
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. Structure of plant developmental processes; how environmental factors interact to affect and control plant growth and development and how production practices are used to regulate, control, and increase or improve crop production. Topics include embryogenesis, structure of the shoot apex, organogenesis of the leaf and shoot system, reproductive development, fruit development, dormancy, influence of light on growth, and tropisms.

Name: Advanced Plant Propagation
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Advanced sexual and asexual propagation techniques used for propagation of various horticultural and agronomic plant species.
Reqs: HORT 2061 and BIOL 1202 or permission of the instructor

Name: Principles of Plant Breeding
Desc: See AGRO 4064.

Name: Nursery Management
Desc: Required field trips. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles and practices involved in commercial production, management and marketing of nursery crops.

Name: Sustainable Ornamental Production
Desc: This course is part of ACCEPtS. This course addresses a variety of topics including, sustainable practices in locating a nursery, nursery layout, plant nutrition, plant water relations and irrigation needs, shipping and managing people and resources to produce the crop.

Name: Principles and Practices in Olericulture
Desc: Required field trips. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Review of U.S. commercial vegetable industry; seed handling, field microclimate modification, transplant handling, stand establishment, influence of soil chemical and physical properties and greenhouse vegetable production.

Name: Principles and Practices in Fruit and Nut Production
Desc: Required field trips. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Physiological principles involved in growing pomological crops; overview of state, U.S., and worldwide fruit and nut industry; marketing and production strategies.

Name: Advanced Turfgrass Management
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture. Physiology and cultural management of turfgrass in the environment.

Name: Postharvest Physiology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Physiological changes associated with storage and handling of fruits and vegetables; current practices used in extending shelf-life; basic and applied laboratory analysis techniques.

Name: Horticulture Capstone
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture. Develop critical thinking, oral, and written skills in applied plant sciences.

Name: Sustainable Agriculture
Desc: Also offered as AGEC 4545. 3 hrs. lecture. The social, economic and environmental dimensions of agriculture and the emerging global challenges involved with climate change, food security, resource depletion, and various recent movements within agriculture.

Name: Teaching Practicum
Desc: See AGRO 7010.

Name: Quantitative Genetics in Plant Improvement
Desc: See AGRO 7074.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Research Problems in Horticulture
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Students minoring in horticulture may take this course only once.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Seminar in Human Sciences and Education
Desc: Critical discussions of topics related to human sciences and education. Overview of historical, professional, and philosophical foundations related to the field.

Name: Introduction to Research
Desc: Introduction to research topics and approaches in the humanities and social sciences. Students will be exposed to research through readings, databases and attendance at on-campus research talks.
Reqs: Only for first year students pursuing a major in the College of Humanities & Social Sciences

Name: Introduction to Career Pathways in the Humanities and Social Sciences
Desc: Introduction to tools and skills required to succeed in post-graduate careers in the humanities and social sciences

Name: Research Methodologies in the Humanities and Social Sciences
Desc: Coverage of a variety of specific methodologies in the humanities and social sciences; methods applied to existing data sets.

Name: Professional Development in the Humanities and Social Sciences
Desc: Benefits of the skills and knowledge you acquire in the humanities and social sciences.

Name: Applying Research to a Real World Problem in HSS
Desc: Topics vary. Topic is explored through background readings in both the humanities and social sciences. Independent research project completed using a humanities or social sciences approach.

Name: Introduction to Interior Design
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Contemporary practice of interior design as a profession; responsibilities of the interior designer.

Name: Design Foundation I
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Basic design problems with an emphasis on two-dimensional principles and elements; development of basic skills in interior design drawing and modeling.
Reqs: controlled admission to program in interior design at first year entry level or permission of department

Name: Design Foundation II
Desc: 6 hr. studio. Basic design problems with an emphasis on three-dimensional principles and form; development of skills in interior design drawing and modeling.
Reqs: controlled admission to program in interior design at first year entry level or permission of department

Name: Interior Design Technical Drawing
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. studio. Introduction to the graphic tools, techniques and conventions designers use to communicate architectural ideas; an immersion in the graphic language of drawing.
Reqs: controlled admission to program in interior design at first year entry or permission of department

Name: HONORS: Interior Design Studio I
Desc: Same as ID 2750, with special emphasis for qualified Honors students. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 2750. 12 hrs. studio.
Reqs: admission to professional program in interior design or permission of department

Name: HONORS: Interior Design Studio II
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio.

Name: Interior Design Studio I
Desc: An Honors course, ID 2650, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 2650. 12 hrs. studio. Basic design problems in the built environment; emphasis on design process, form and principles of spatial organization.
Reqs: admission to professional program in interior design or permission of department

Name: Interior Design Studio II
Desc: An Honors course, ID 2651, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 2651. Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course.

Name: Color and Illumination I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. studio. Nature, theory and art of color and light applied to two- and three-dimensional basic design projects.
Reqs: sophomore standing in the major; nonmajors by consent of instructor only

Name: Interior Construction and Systems
Desc: Building systems and construction methods; code requirements for interiors.

Name: Interior Materials, Finishes and Furnishings
Desc: Types and sources of materials, finishes and furnishings used in interior spaces.
Reqs: admission to professional program in interior design or consent of instructor

Name: Interior Design Human Factors
Desc: Human interaction in the built environment; theories; principles and methods for optimizing human wellbeing and performance.
Reqs: admission to professional program in interior design or consent of instructor

Name: Interior Design Graphics
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Graphic representation methods used to illustrate and investigate form, spatial order and the design process.

Name: Computer Visualization
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Computer drafting and three-dimensional modeling for spatial designers.
Reqs: admission to professional program or consent of instructor

Name: HONORS: Interior Design Studio III
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course.  12 hrs. studio.

Name: HONORS: Interior Design Studio IV
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Same as ID 3753, with special emphasis for qualified Honors students. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 3753.

Name: Interior Design Studio III
Desc: An Honors course, ID 3652, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 3652. Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio. Formulation of design concept/image; design implications of function, space and scale; emphasis on human factors for design, and interior materials, finishes and furnishings.

Name: Interior Design Studio IV
Desc: An Honors course, ID 3653, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 3653. 12 hrs. studio. Advanced application of the design process; development of comprehensive solutions to complex interior design problems, emphasis on design for health and wellbeing.

Name: Special Studies in Interior Design
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Advanced studio work in predetermined areas of specialization.

Name: Career Development
