Desc: Fundamentals of the interior design profession; career preparation, planning, and development.
Reqs: admission to the professional program in interior design or consent of instructor

Name: Interior Design Internship
Desc: Pass-fail grading. At least 20 hours of work per week (35 hours per week in summer session) supervised by an interior design faculty member and a professional designer in an approved firm.
Reqs: completion of all 2000-level interior design courses and consent of instructor

Name: Field Studies in Interior Design
Desc: Intensive travel experiences in a variety of locales; participation in local, national and/or international studies with an emphasis on the built environment.
Reqs: Selective admission to professional program in interior design at the sophomore year or permission of instructor

Name: Color and Illumination II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. studio. Quantitative and qualitative aspects of color/light; application to interior design.
Reqs: junior standing in major; nonmajors by consent of instructor only

Name: Design for Health and Wellbeing
Desc: Exploration of indoor environmental quality principles, processes, and practices to promote human health and wellbeing in the interior environment.
Reqs: admission to professional program in interior design or consent of instructor

Name: Interior Design Construction Documents
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. studio. Development of construction documents for interior projects; design and documentation of interior architectural details.

Name: Interior Design Studio
Desc: 8 hrs. studio. Special topics studio developed around faculty expertise or opportunities in the profession.
Reqs: ID 3753 or equivalent and consent of department

Name: HONORS: Seminar in Interior Design
Desc: Same as ID 4720, with special emphasis for qualified Honors students. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 4720.

Name: HONORS: Interior Design Studio V
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Same as ID 4754, with special emphasis for qualified Honors students. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 4754.

Name: HONORS: Interior Design Studio VI
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in ID 4756. 8 hrs. studio. Same as ID 4755, with special emphasis for qualified Honors students. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 4755.

Name: Seminar in Interior Design
Desc: An Honors course, ID 4620, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 4620.  Explore contemporary issues in interior design and related topics; develop a capstone design proposal to be completed in ID 4754 or ID 4654.

Name: History of Interior Design
Desc: Development of interior design; decoration and furnishings throughout history; examining design as an expression of cultural values and its social, industrial and technological influences.

Name: Interior Design Contemporary Issues and Theory
Desc: Research, discussions and presentations related to the contemporary issues in interior design.

Name: Interior Component Design
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. studio. Design, materials and construction techniques of interior components; scale, model and computer-simulated design prototypes.

Name: Interior Design Studio V
Desc: An Honors course, ID 4654, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course ID 4654. 12 hrs. studio. Design synthesis in a comprehensive capstone project.

Name: Interior Design Studio VI
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in ID 4756. An Honors course, ID 4655, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and ID 4655. 8 hrs. studio. Design synthesis in a comprehensive capstone project.

Name: Independent Study Project
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in ID 4755. 6 hrs. studio. Execution of a project selected by the advanced student with guidance from an advisory committee.

Name: Advanced Studies in Interior Design
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced studio work in a predetermined area of specialization at upper level status.

Name: Professional Practice
Desc: Entering the profession; interior design business practices; ethics and project management.
Reqs: senior standing in the major or consent of instructor

Name: Interior Design Professional Residency
Desc: Pass-fail grading. At least 360 hours of work per semester (or semester and summer session) supervised by an interior design faculty member and a professional designer in an approved firm.
Reqs: completion of all 2000-level interior design courses and consent of instructor

Name: Sustainable Design Practice
Desc: Introduction to high performance green building assessment systems with emphasis on interior design, construction, and operations.

Name: Principles of Sustainability
Desc: The principles, theory, and application of sustainability to advance environmentally responsible interior environments; introduction to natural systems, interior environmental quality, systems, ethics, and stewardship.

Name: Advanced Computer Visualization
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Advanced topics in computer drafting and three-dimensional modeling for spatial designers.
Reqs: admission to professional program or permission of instructor

Name: Industrial Engineering Fundamentals
Desc: Introduction to industrial engineering design process and concepts.

Name: Computing in Industrial Engineering
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Introduction to object-oriented programming, information systems, and data analysis; use of Microsoft office tools in industrial engineering.
Reqs: eligibility to take MATH 1550 or equivalent and credit or registration in IE 1002

Name: Methods and Systems Engineering
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. System and work design concepts; time studies; performance rating and allowances; standard and pre-determined times; work methods improvement; design of manual work, equipment and tools and work environments; line balancing; manpower determinations, job analysis and incentives; business systems analysis, lean and value analysis.

Name: Principles of Engineering Economy
Desc: Planning economy studies for decision-making, including considerations of rate of return, cost and yield studies, depreciation and tax relationships, increment costs, replacement and introduction to multivariate alternative studies.

Name: Engineering Statistics
Desc: Probability, discrete and continuous distributions, functions of random variables, estimation theory, tests of hypotheses including goodness-of-fit and independence.
Reqs: grade of C or better required in MATH 1552 and PHYS 2112 or CSC 2259

Name: Supply Chain Logistics I
Desc: Introduction to resources and systems; Logistics resource optimization: linear programming; Logistics network and flow problems: transportation problems, shortest path and vehicle routing, maximum flow problems; project and resources management and operations sequencing and resource scheduling.
Reqs: IE 2400, MATH 2090; credit or registration in IE 3302

Name: Engineering Practice
Desc: Pass-fail grading. A minimum of 6 weeks of full-time employment in industry on Industrial Engineering related design problems. Selected engineering problems in an industrial environment.

Name: Project Management
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ISDS 4113. Project management and theory practice. Practical approach to organizing, planning, and controlling projects in information systems, healthcare, manufacturing and services.

Name: Healthcare Engineering
Desc: Overview of the current healthcare system in the United States, applications of industrial engineering tools to the healthcare domain, and a review of current topics in industrial engineering in healthcare.

Name: Advanced Engineering Statistics
Desc: Linear regression and correlation, curvilinear regression, analysis of variance and factorial experiments.
Reqs: grade of C or better in IE 3302

Name: Information Systems Engineering
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Analysis and design of information systems; projects relating comprehensive computer systems to typical industrial and service applications; ethics and professionalism.

Name: Distributed Information Systems Engineering
Reqs: IE 2060 or CSC 1253 or CSC 1350 or ISDS 3107 and credit or registration in IE 4425 or CSC 4402 or ISDS 3110

Name: Ecommerce Engineering
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Business processes underlying modern commerce and supply chain systems and the information technologies used to implement them.
Reqs: IE 2060 or CSC 1253 or CSC 1350 or ISDS 3107, and credit or registration in IE 4425 or CSC 4402 or ISDS 3110

Name: Quality Control & Six Sigma
Desc: Principles and practice of quality assurance and control; theory of statistical sampling and control and related economic analysis; Quality Systems; Six Sigma principles and practice.
Reqs: grade of C or better in IE 3302

Name: Human Factors Engineering
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and IE 7460. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Human performance in human-machine systems, including information processing, display and control design, workplace design and environmental effects on worker performance.

Name: Safety Engineering
Desc: Occupational safety and health and accident prevention management; design and implementation of safety programs; cost analysis; control of hazardous physical and environmental conditions.

Name: Biomechanics for Engineers
Desc: See BE 4323.

Name: Human Computer Interaction
Desc: Systems approach to the identification, de-sign, analysis and development of human-operated information processing systems; applications to practical problems in industry, military, health systems and education.

Name: Systems Integration in Manufacturing
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles and application of information technologies to monitoring, control and integration of manufacturing operations at all levels within the organization.

Name: Industry 4.0 & Smart Manufacturing
Desc: Introduction to and survey of industry 4.0 concepts, technologies and approaches utilized in modern smart manufacturing and supply chain systems.
Reqs: IE 2060 or ME 2543 or CSC 1253 or CSC 1350 or ISDS 3107

Name: Plant and Systems Design
Reqs: IE 3201 and credit or registration in IE 3520 and IE 4113/ISDS 4113

Name: Supply Chain Logistics II
Desc: Production logistics: forecasting, aggregate production, inventory systems and materials requirement planning; lean supply system and supply chain management; warehousing and distribution systems; supply chain information technologies and government policies/regulations.
Reqs: grade of C or better in IE 3520

Name: Lean Manufacturing Systems
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles of Lean Manufacturing Systems; Queuing Theory and Analysis; Measurement and Assessment-Industrial Process Mapping, Workflow Analysis; Improvement Activities-Process and Operational Variability Reduction, Resource Reduction, Work-in-Process Reduction, Waste Reduction, Zero Inventory and Just-in-time Production Systems; Design for Lean Manufacturing; Material and Shop Floor Flow Control; Simulation Modeling and Analysis of Lean Systems.
Reqs: IE 2060 and credit or registration in IE 3520 and IE 4362

Name: Reliability Engineering
Desc: Reliability in design; reliability models; reliability assessment during pre-production development and testing; and special problems in maintenance, spare parts and Markov processes.

Name: Industrial Engineering Capstone Design I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Senior design projects.
Reqs: IE 4425, IE 4453, IE 4461, IE 4520, ME 3633, senior standing in College of Engineering and credit or registration in IE 4516 and IE 4530

Name: Industrial Engineering Capstone Design II
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Continuation of senior design projects from IE 4597.

Name: Special Topics in Industrial Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Two sections may be taken concurrently if topics vary. Topics in industrial engineering not sufficiently covered in other undergraduate courses.
Reqs: senior standing and consent of department

Name: Master Project in Industrial Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit towards degree requirements. Special project with a formal report for students pursuing the MS Project (non-thesis) option of the industrial engineering master’s degree.

Name: Project Engineering
Desc: Large-scale engineering construction or development projects from schematic to online condition.

Name: Industrial Engineering Research Methods
Desc: Analyzing industrial engineering research and improvement initiatives through planned data collection using laboratory and field studies, basic approaches to data presentation and analysis, IRB, HIPAA and other regulatory policies, and practical aspects of experiment execution.

Name: Advanced Information Systems Engineering
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Advanced concepts of information systems engineering with emphasis on middleware architectures/technologies for integrating databases; design issues and methodology for developing and implementing distributed information systems; and design and implementation of data-warehouses and online analytical precessing (OLAP) systems.

Name: Semantic Analysis
Desc: Automated determination of semantic content (a.k.a. meaning) of text and speech and applications to human-computer and human-machine interfaces and task automation.

Name: Analytics and Data Science in Industrial Engineering
Desc: Analytics and machine learning techniques and applications within Industrial Engineering. Topics include overview of the analytics process, data management & preparation, descriptive analytics (including business intelligence and data visualization techniques), clustering, classification, predictive analytics (regression & time series), text mining, and prescriptive methods.

Name: Lean Process Improvement
Desc: Philosophy and concepts of quality and process improvement, organization for quality, quality improvement (QI) tools and techniques, advanced QI techniques and quality improvement systems. Application of advanced Six Sigma and Lean tools and techniques to case studies related to the construction industry. Investigation, learning and application of current research related to the course topics.

Name: Applied Occupational Ergonomics
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and IE 4461. Application of ergonomics principals to design and evaluation of tools, workplace, and work environment considering the physical, physiological and mental capabilities of workers.

Name: Work Physiology
Desc: Study of worker’s physiological responses (cardiovascular, pulmonary, muscular) to work applicable to task design and evaluation, employee selection and placement and work-rest scheduling.

Name: Occupational Biomechanics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles of biomechanics applied to human movement; applications to work systems such as manual materials handling and tool design.

Name: Human Interaction with Computers
Desc: Ergonomics of the use of interactive computer systems; general characteristics and requirements of people-oriented computer systems from the perspective of different disciplines and tasks, e.g., text editing.

Name: Cognitive Ergonomics and Work Environments
Desc: Topics in cognitive ergonomics relating to information processing, visual and auditory displays and aspects of the work environment such as noise, socio-technical systems and psychosocial factors. Application to various work settings including construction, healthcare and the service sector.

Name: Linear Programming Algorithms
Desc: Optimization of linear objective functions subject to linear constraints; vector spaces, convex analysis, polyhedral sets; matrix versions of simplex, revised simplex, bounded variables; duality theory and primal-dual simplex algorithms; postoptimal and parametric analysis; decomposition and cutting plane algorithms.

Name: Programming Methods in Operations Research
Desc: Aspects of advanced programming methods for unconstrained and constrained problems; development of goal, zero-one, gert and multiple objective programming with application to industrial processes and planning.

Name: Metaheuristics
Desc: Introduction of the principles, algorithms and real world applications of metaheuristic algorithms including projection based methods such as simulated annealing, tabu search, variable neighborhood search, guided local search, iterated local search and population based methods such as particle swarm optimization, differential evolution, ant colony optimization, genetic algorithm and evolutionary programming.

Name: Special Topics in Industrial Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. Hrs. when topics vary. Special topic courses in specialized areas such as design and analysis of complex production systems, supply-chain control, maintenance, quality control, reliability, ergonomics and human-computer interaction, information systems, safety and construction management.

Name: Independent Study in Industrial Engineering
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Independent study in specialized areas such as design and analysis of complex production systems, supply-chain control, maintenance, quality control, reliability, ergonomics and human-computer interaction, information systems, safety and construction management.

Name: Waiting Line Models and Applications
Desc: Principles of queuing theory and analysis.

Name: Supply Chain Systems
Desc: Components in supply chain systems; product life-cycle modeling, rotational production and supply, integrated component supply systems, multi-source supplier and buyer systems, just-in-time supply chain systems, warehousing and distribution systems, supply transportation system and information technology for supply chain systems.

Name: Industrial Supply and Logistics Systems
Desc: Concept of supply, logistics and distribution; large scale operational logistics, materials handling systems, warehousing and refurbishing logistics, logistics, designing logistics network and distribution systems, convoy movements, multi-modal long- and short-haul freight transportation, and industrial practices.

Name: Logistics & Distribution Systems
Desc: Concept of logistics and distribution, large scale operational logistics, materials refurbishing logistics, warehousing logistics, designing logistics network and distribution systems, convoy movements, long- and short-haul freight transportation and industrial practices.

Name: Lean Production Systems
Desc: Principles and components of lean production systems; industrial process mapping, workflow analysis; resource reduction; market characterization, logistics information and error propagation; reduction of work-in-process, waster reduction, zero inventory and just-in-time production systems; material flow control; process and operational variability reduction; role of buffers and process stabilization.

Name: Sequencing and Scheduling
Desc: Measures of scheduling; deterministic models for single and parallel machines, job shops, flow shops, and open shops; stochastic scheduling models for machines, job shops, flow shops and open shops; computational complexity and industrial applications.

Name: Design of Manufacturing Systems
Desc: Principles in modeling, analysis, design and operations; mass production, cellular manufacturing, machine location and layout, job routing and loading strategy; material handling and storage/retrieval systems.

Name: Quality Management
Desc: Philosophy and concepts of quality management, organization for quality, quality cost, quality audits and corrective actions, tools and techniques for improvement.

Name: Seminar
Desc: Pass/Fail grading. All graduate students are expected to attend this course every semester; only 1 sem. hr. of credit in this course allowed toward degree.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Introduction to Study Abroad
Desc: Principal themes of study abroad including development of skills and perceptives to transact, communicate, and engage across cultures.

Name: Contemporary Global Issues
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, INTL 2001, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and INTL 2001. Survey of current world issues from an interdisciplinary perspective.

Name: HONORS: Contemporary Global Issues
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as INTL 2000, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and INTL 2000. Survey of world issues from an interdisciplinary perspective.

Name: Gateway to International Studies
Desc: Required for all international studies majors. Modernity, colonialism and globalization in regional perspective.

Name: Independent Study in International Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Independent study relevant to the field of international studies.

Name: Fundamentalisms and Religious Nationalism
Desc: See REL 3092.

Name: Undergraduate Internship in International Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Open to undergraduate students approved by the International Studies Program. May be counted toward the total number of hours required for a major in International Studies but not toward fulfilling field requirements. Program of study, research and work in governmental or private agencies concerned with international policy.

Name: Religion of Islam
Desc: See REL 3786.

Name: Study Abroad in Africa
Desc: May be repeated for up to 12 hours credit when topics vary. Studies in the history, culture, economics, politics or geography of Africa.

Name: Study Abroad in the Middle East
Desc: May be repeated for up to 12 hours credit when topics vary. Studies in the history, culture, economics, politics or geography of the Middle East.

Name: Study Abroad in Asia
Desc: May be repeated for up to 12 hours credit when topics vary. Studies in the history, culture, economics, politics or geography of Asia.

Name: Study Abroad in Europe
Desc: May be repeated for up to 12 hours credit when topics vary. Studies in the history, culture, economics, politics or geography of Europe.

Name: Study Abroad in Latin America
Desc: May be repeated for up to 12 hours credit when topics vary. Studies in the history, culture, economics, politics or geography of Latin America.

Name: Study Abroad in Russia and Central Asia
Desc: May be repeated for up to 12 hours credit when topics vary. Studies in the history, culture, economics, politics or geography of Russia and/or Central Asia.

Name: South Asian Society, Polity and Culture
Desc: Cross-listed with ANTH 4002, GEOG 4002, and REL 4001. Historical anthropology of South Asia examining the four major cultural traditions (Hindu/Buddhist, Islamic, British and nationalist) which currently shape the politics of nationalism, development, ethnicity, caste and gender in the region.

Name: International Studies Senior Seminar
Desc: of additional upper level courses in an area of concentration. Required for all international studies majors, seniors only. Advanced theory and case studies of globalization in an interdisciplinary perspective.

Name: Geography of Central Asia and Afghanistan
Desc: See GEOG 4033.

Name: North Africa and the Middle East
Desc: See GEOG 4051.

Name: The Modern Middle East
Desc: See HIST 4096.

Name: Migration, Diasporas and Identity
Desc: An interdisciplinary survey of global migration in the modern era and the resultant subnational and transnational forms of community, identity, and subjectivity: colonists, exiles, immigrants, refugees and transients.

Name: Global Drug Trade
Desc: Examination of international drug trafficking from an interdisciplinary perspective. Illicit drugs as a political and social construction. Economic, political, and cultural impacts of the drug trade. Regional emphasis may vary by instructor.

Name: Special Topics in International Studies
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Introduction to Management Information Systems
Desc: [LCCN: CBUS 2203, Computer Applications] An honors course, ISDS 1101, is also available. Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 1101, ISDS 1102, ISDS 1103, CSC 1100, LIS 2001, EXST 2000. 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Examine the expanding role of information technology in organizations including the development and use of information systems, hardware and software, the strategic impact of IT and the nature of the IT career; utilization of management information systems to improve managerial decision-making.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Management Information Systems
Desc: Same as ISDS 1100 with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 1100 or ISDS 1102 or ISDS 1103.

Name: Introduction to Management Information Systems for Business Majors
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 1100 or ISDS 1101 or ISDS 1103. Role of information technology in business including the development and use of information systems, hardware and software, the strategic impact of IT for businesses and the nature of the IT career; utilization of management information systems to improve managerial decision-making.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Management Information Systems for Business Majors
Desc: Same as ISDS 1102, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 1101 or ISDS 1102 or ISDS 1103.

Name: Business Statistics and Analytics I
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 2010. Descriptive analytics; sampling, probabilities and distributions, sampling distributions; inferential statistics including estimation, hypothesis tests; regression.

Name: Business Statistics and Analytics II
Desc: Continuation of ISDS 2000. Credit will not be given for both this and ISDS 2011. Advanced statistical methods; ANOVA and multiple linear regression; predictive analytics; decision analysis.

Name: HONORS: Business Statistics and Analytics I
Desc: Same as ISDS 2000, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and ISDS 2000.

Name: HONORS: Business Statistics and Analytics II
Desc: Same as ISDS 2001, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and ISDS 2001.

Name: Introduction to Business Information Systems
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 3100. Developing an understanding of what information systems are and an awareness of the role of information systems in organizations including the development of and use of information systems, and their operational and strategic impact.

Name: Introduction to Programming in Business
Desc: Credit will not be give for both this course and ISDS 3107. Provide an understanding of Information System Solutions and an awareness of the development process, and the application of technologies used to solve business problems.

Name: Introduction to Business Data Querying
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 3110. Developing an understanding of what database management systems are and an awareness of data models and query language, and their application in the development of modern business information systems.

Name: Database Management Systems for Business Analytics
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ISDS 3110. Intended primarily for business majors, not ISDS majors, enrolled in the Analytics minor. Concepts and methods associated with database management systems, especially as it relates to users of business analytics.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Information Systems and Decision Sciences
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Student is responsible for registering with a faculty member and selecting an area of reading and/or research.

Name: Internship in Information Systems and Decision Sciences
Desc: Pass/fail grading. At least the equivalent of 144 hours per semester (3 credits) of learning experience in information systems under the general supervision of an ISDS faculty member and direct supervision of an information systems or decision sciences professional. Grading based on the faculty member’s evaluation, a written report by the professional supervisor and a written report by the student.
Reqs: permission of instructor and department chair required

Name: Foundations of Information Systems
Desc: Open only to ISDS majors.  Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 3001. The role of information systems in organizations including the development of and use of information systems, operational and strategic impact, and inter-organizational implications.

Name: Internet Development Tools
Desc: Understanding of the Internet and its structure for use in business; technologies employed to develop Internet applications; development of business applications for the Internet.

Name: Design of Information Systems Solutions
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 3002. Fundamentals of programming, program design, application development interfaces, debugging, testing and implementation. Design and development of information systems solutions.

Name: Data and Information Management
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ISDS 3003 .  Concepts and methods associated with the definition, structure, creation, and utilization of databases for computer-based information systems.

Name: Introduction to Operations Management
Desc: Principles and methodologies concerning productivity and quality of manufacturing and service organizations; production and service systems design; process and capacity design; total quality management; systems for just-in-time and purchasing management; inventory and materials management.
Reqs: Credit or concurrent enrollment in ISDS 2001

Name: Management of the IT Function
Desc: Issues in managing the Information Technology (IT) function, including the discussion of how technology has underpinned the “new Economy,” formulating an IT strategy, structuring and managing the IT function and emerging trends in IT.

Name: Cloud Computing for Business I
Desc: May not be taken by students in the BS ISDS major. Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 4120. Fundamentals of cloud computing for business including: cloud, cloud types, services and architectures, and the applications of the cloud in business and industry.

Name: Advanced Business Programming
Desc: Computer programming methods for business systems emphasizing contemporary programming environments and applications development interfaces.
Reqs: “C” or better in ISDS 3107; and credit or registration in ISDS 3110

Name: Predictive Modeling and Optimization
Desc: Covers business forecasting methods and applications including coverage of various contemporary topics such as machine learning, time series regression, decomposition methods, exponential smoothing, Box-Jenkins models, and time-to-event analysis.

Name: Special Topics in Information Systems & Decision Sciences
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Individual and group study of selected ISDS topics under the direction of a faculty member.

Name: Data Warehousing
Desc: Data warehouses for business; topics include: business intelligence, data charts, multidimensional data, data mining, Web-enabled data warehouse, knowledge management.
Reqs: “C” or better in ISDS 3110, ISDS 3003, or ISDS 3009

Name: Management of Information Systems Projects
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and IE 4113. Topics on effectively managing information technology projects including: setting goals and objectives; work breakdown structures; project scheduling; managing project resources; evaluation and review; incentives and qualitative analysis; project accounting; extensive use of cases involving hands-on computer analyses with state-of-the-art project management software.
Reqs: “C” or better in ISDS 3100, ISDS 3107, and ISDS 3110, or consent of instructor

Name: Management of E-Commerce and Internet Information Systems
Desc: Management of e-commerce and Internet systems including: business models and strategies; performance and evaluation; navigation and content; security, trust and legal issues; integration of managerial, technical, and legal perspectives for intra-business systems, B2B systems, e-supply chains, portals, B2C systems, electronic markets and e-government.

Name: Web Analytics
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ISDS 4119. Principles of web analytics; key performance indicators, benchmarks, A/B testing, personalized content, customer-centric website design, process flow analysis, usability, research design and statistical methods.

Name: Introduction to Web Analytics
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ISDS 4118. Principles of web analytics; key performance indicators, benchmarks, A/B testing, personalized content, customer-centric website design, process flow analysis, usability, research design and statistical methods.

Name: Enterprise Architecture
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and ISDS 3130. Coordination if the hardware and software components of enterprise communication systems.
Reqs: “C” or better in ISDS 3100, ISDS 3107, and ISDS 3110

Name: Computer and Networking Security
Desc: Security management, corporate risk assessment, access control, authentication, transmission control protocol and Internet protocol packet content analysis, firewall hardware and software, types of encryption, cryptographic systems, application security issues and laws governing security and privacy.

Name: Analysis and Design of Information Systems
Desc: Methods for analyzing information needs and designing, evaluating, implementing computer-based information systems.
Reqs: Credit or registration in ISDS 4113 and credit or registration in ISDS 4120 AND ”C” or better in ISDS 3100, ISDS 3110, and ISDS 3107

Name: Cloud Computing for Business II
Desc: Problems and challenges of defining, developing, and building a cloud system in business and industry. Upon completion of this course students will have the opportunity to earn the AWS Solutions Architect certification.
Reqs: “C” or better in ISDS 3130, or “C” or better in ISDS 4120, or consent of instructor

Name: Introduction to Data Mining
Desc: Fundamental methodology and techniques used in data mining, with particular emphasis on business applications; topics include market basket analysis, memory-based reasoning, cluster detection, link analysis, decision trees and rule induction, neural networks and genetic algorithms.

Name: Sourcing in China
Desc: Energy and network clusters; cost competitiveness; choosing strategic partners and suppliers; negotiation style; brand, design and manufacturing; factory and supply chain audits; protecting intellectual property; vulnerability assessments; energy and global sourcing repositioning; energy and sourcing practices; and cases in the energy industry.

Name: Supply Chain Management
Desc: Planning, implementing, and controlling the efficient, cost-effective flow and storage of raw material, in-process products, finished products and related information in a supply channel; resource/material management; supplier strategy; inventory planning and control; just-in-time systems; customer service; logistics and interfaces with other functional areas; emphasis on concepts, model development and analysis.

Name: Business Analysis in Practice
Desc: Contemporary problems encountered by the business analysis professional; emphasis on case analysis and use of business analysis skills and computer technology to solve business problems.
Reqs: “C” or better in ISDS 3110 , ISDS 3003, or ISDS 3009

Name: Information Systems Auditing
Desc: The class will focus on the IS Audit process, IT Governance, Systems and Infrastructure Life Cycle Management, Service Delivery and Support, Protection of Information Assets and Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery. Emphasis will be placed on current practices and technologies used in today’s IT Audit environment.

Name: Advanced Statistical Analysis for Research I
Desc: Methods of statistical inference; statistical estimation; testing hypotheses about single and multiple means and proportions; simple and multiple linear regression; design of simple random, stratified, and cluster samples; extensive use of statistical computer programs.
Reqs: proficiency in calculus, linear algebra, basic statistical methods and computer programming

Name: Advanced Statistical Analysis for Research II
Desc: Continuation of ISDS 7024. Advanced regression analysis; experimental design and analysis of variance; nonparametric methods; multivariate techniques; extensive use of statistical computer programs.

Name: Seminar in Advanced Business Problems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Special topics in statistics and quantitative methods.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Information Systems & Decision Sciences
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit.  Student is responsible for registering with a faculty member and selecting an area of reading and/or research.

Name: Survey of Information Systems Research
Desc: Exploration of current research streams in information systems; relationships of IS to other disciplines; historical overview of the field.
Reqs: advanced PhD standing or consent of instructor

Name: Critical Analysis of Information Systems Research
Desc: Development of skills in theory building, research design, writing research papers and evaluating research in the field of information systems.
Reqs: advanced PhD standing or consent of instructor

Name: Survey of Operations Research: Stochastic Methods
Desc: Extensions of decision theory, game theory, dynamic programming, Markovian decision processes, reliability models and queuing models; probabilistic methods in operations research.

Name: Emerging Markets Energy Supply Chain Management
Desc: Emerging markets; global energy supply chain; entrepreneurial opportunities in energy; opportunities in retail global supply chain, product life cycle and global supply chain, energy supplier clusters and emerging markets, and information technology and global supply chain; life-saving supply chain and disaster management; greening the global supply chain; industry studies; and opportunities for the growing Louisiana economy.

Name: Supply Chain Management
Desc: Supply chain process analysis and control; critical issues in revolutionizing management of the entire supply chain; system productivity analysis, demand management, inventory management, distribution planning, integration in supply chain; emphasis on case study, spreadsheets and software applications; network design, warehouse location, outsourcing, global supply chain and information, EDI and DSS technologies in supply chain management; case study and SCM software.

Name: Project Management
Desc: Topics of effectively managing projects including setting goals and objectives, project planning, evaluation and review; incentives and qualitative analysis and project accounting; extensive use of cases involving hands-on computer analyses with state-of-the-art project management software.

Name: Descriptive Analytics
Desc: Data warehousing; use of big data in business; storage and retrieval of data in business; descriptive analytics for business; business intelligence tools.

Name: Predictive Analytics
Desc: Predictive analytics in business; business cases in predictive analytics; data mining use in business; industry solutions for predictive analytics.

Name: Analytics Methods
Desc: Advanced analytics in business; designed experimentation; regression trees; causal inference; uplift models.

Name: Visual Analytics
Desc: Data analytics; value proposition of data in business; advanced business intelligence; data visualization; dashboards in business.

Name: Introduction to Healthcare Informatics and Healthcare Analytics
Desc: This course is an introductin to current topics and issues related to healthcare informatics and health analytics including big data in healthcare; developing basic electronic health record applications; assessment of population health; data ethics, security and privacy.

Name: Information Systems
Desc: Contemporary topics in information systems; survey of information system analysis and design; introduction to business data communication; database management systems and knowledge based systems; enterprise-wide systems and information systems control.

Name: Information Technology and Entrepreneurship
Desc: Information economy, globalization and outsourcing, information technology-based business opportunities, technological entrepreneurship, entrepreneurial process, entrepreneurial thinking, process of discovering, effectuation, causation, kownledge management, technological intrapreneurship.

Name: Database Management
Desc: Analysis, design and implementation of databases based on the relational database model; data modeling using entity-relationship (E-R) diagraming; logical and physical database design; SQL; hardware/software architecture considerations; data and database administration; emerging database technologies and advanced database applications.

Name: Advanced Database Management
Desc: Decision support systems, online analytical processing, multidimensional data modeling, web-enabled data warehousing, data marts, data mining, knowledge management, Internet business intelligence.

Name: Network Information Systems
Desc: Broad overview of network technologies including protocols, network operating systems and network management; LAN, WAN design; Internet technology; network security.

Name: Information Systems Analysis and Design
Desc: Both courses may be taken concurrently. Analysis and design of information systems from a management perspective; software development methodology; topics include requirements determination; feasibility determination; project management; evaluation of a software development strategy and application design; modeling using ER diagrams and DFDs; systems implementation.

Name: Information Technology Management
Desc: Management of the organization’s information technology (IT) resources; planning and management of IT strategy, applications; hardware/software infrastructure, information resources, and IT professionals; organization and governance of the IT function, IT policies and standards, measurement of IT investments and returns and deployment of new information technologies.

Name: Electronic Commerce
Desc: Use of information technology and the Internet in creating new forms of business organization; creating a marketspace; disintermediation/ reintermediation; and virtual organization.

Name: Enterprise Systems
Desc: Study of the broad area of Integrated Enterprise-wide Systems; emphasis on features and capabilities of enterprise systems and their related technologies, the methodologies used to implement these systems in organizations and the implications of their deployment in organizations.

Name: Social and Organizational Issues in MIS
Desc: Impact of electronic communities on organizations; implications of design choices on business; ethical considerations.

Name: Contemporary Issues in Production/Operations Management
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Philosophical foundations and con-temporary issues in production/operations management.
Reqs: advanced PhD standing or consent of instructor

Name: Contemporary Issues in Management Information Systems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Philosophical foundations and contemporary issues in management information systems.
Reqs: advanced PhD standing or consent of instructor

Name: Research Seminar in Information Systems Topics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Required for all PhD students. Contemporary research and critical issues in information systems.

Name: Project
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Pre-dissertation Research
Desc: May be repeated for credit.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Elementary Italian
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Supplementary work in language laboratory. Native speakers of Italian will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Italian; emphasis on communicative language use.

Name: Elementary Italian
Desc: Supplementary work in language laboratory. Native speakers of Italian will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Italian; emphasis on communicative language use.

Name: Italian for Travelers
Desc: Does not count toward satisfying the foreign language requirement for undergraduates. Basic communication patterns; practical everyday vocabulary; exercises in comprehension and conversation.

Name: Intermediate Italian
Desc: Supplementary work in language laboratory. Native speakers of Italian will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Italian; emphasis on communicative language use.

Name: Intermediate Italian
Desc: Supplementary work in language laboratory. Native speakers of Italian will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Italian; emphasis on communicative language use.

Name: Readings in Italian Literature
Desc: Native speakers of Italian will not receive credit for this course. Readings in contemporary and older literature of Italy; emphasis on comprehension as well as oral and written expression.

Name: Italian Culture and Civilization
Desc: Taught in English. Italian culture and civilization from the medieval era to present.

Name: Advanced Oral Communication
Desc: Enhancement of oral communication skills through debating contemporary issues.

Name: Survey of Italian Literature
Desc: Development of Italian literature from the beginnings to the Renaissance.

Name: Survey of Italian Literature
Desc: Continuation of ITAL 3071. Principal authors and literary movements from the Renaissance to the present.

Name: Special Topics in Italian Cinema
Desc: Also offered as SCRN 3502. May be taken for 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. In-depth study of various aspects of Italian cinema from different periods.

Name: Dante
Desc: Dante, with emphasis on the Inferno.

Name: Special Topics in Italian Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Study of various aspects of Italian culture and literature from different periods.

Name: Independent Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. credit. Permission of department required. Readings in Italian literature directed by a senior faculty member.

Name: Traditional East Asian Literature
Desc: See CHIN 3801.
