Name: Swimming
Desc: All basic activity courses are offered on a pass/fail grade basis. Students in these classes must furnish and wear clothing suitable to the activity.
Reqs: KIN majors only until priority scheduling ends

Name: Water Safety Instructor’s Course
Desc: Pass/fail grading.

Name: Track and Field
Desc: For kinesiology majors or minors. 3 hrs. lab.

Name: Basketball
Desc: For kinesiology majors or minors. 3 hrs. lab.

Name: Softball
Desc: For kinesiology majors or minors. 3 hrs. lab.

Name: Volleyball
Desc: For kinesiology majors or minors. 3 hrs. lab.

Name: Flag Football
Desc: For kinesiology majors or minors. 3 hrs. lab.

Name: Field Sports
Desc: For kinesiology majors or minors. 3 hrs. lab.

Name: Individual Wellness and Public Health
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Content and theory related to basic health information; critical health issues; economic, political and cultural influences on health and wellness; improving and maintaining optimal health and wellness.

Name: Movement Fundamentals for Physical Activity
Desc: For kinesiology majors. 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Movement concepts associated with space and time and how these concepts can be organized into a learning environment.

Name: Individual/Lifetime Activities
Desc: For kinesiology majors and minors. 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Identification, analysis and practice of skills, techniques and fundamental concepts associated with lifetime activities.

Name: Team Activities
Desc: For kinesiology majors and minors. 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Identification, analysis and practice of skills, techniques and fundamental concepts associated with team activities.

Name: Aerobic and Strength Activities
Desc: For kinesiology majors and minors. 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Major concepts of aerobic and strength training including safety, technique, age appropriate activities and training principles.

Name: Special Topics
Desc: All basic activity courses are offered on a pass/fail grade basis. May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Students in these classes must furnish and wear clothing suitable to the activity. 3 hrs. lab. Identification, analysis and practice of skills and techniques fundamental to sports; rules, strategies and appropriate safety procedures.
Reqs: KIN majors only until priority scheduling ends

Name: Introduction to Sports Medicine
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and ATRN 2000. Students interested in pursuing careers with recreational or competitive athletes will learn about basic aspects of health care, including the roles and responsibilities of the sports medicine team, best practices in sports safety, basic injury management, and emergency planning.

Name: Human Anatomy
Desc: Micro and macroscopic study of the human body.

Name: History and Philosophy of Kinesiology
Desc: Developments in kinesiology and health from ancient times to the present.

Name: Practicum in Sports Studies
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Credit will not be given for both this course, KIN 2513, and KIN 2999. Observation and practical application in a sport or sport-related setting. Students work in a professional capacity under the guidance of an on-site coordinator.
Reqs: For students minoring in sports studies

Name: Principles of Conditioning
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Methods and concepts of training and conditioning; physical fitness activities and current trends; participation in a fitness training lab including fitness assessments and training methods designed to promote fitness; planning physical fitness programs for community and commercial organizations, education institutions and social agencies.

Name: Medical Terminology for Kinesiology
Desc: In-depth introduction to medical terminology, with a focus on body systems, medical specialties and medical communication.

Name: Introduction to Sport and Leisure Administration
Desc: Introduction to the academic and professional field of sport administration.

Name: Sports Officiating
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Rules interpretation and techniques of officiating basketball, volleyball and softball.

Name: Classroom Culture and Organization
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. The social learning environment and organization of the physical education classroom. Emphasis on behavior management, individual and group motivation and integration of technology.

Name: Professional Development in Sport Administration
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and KIN 2502. Designed to provide an opportunity for the student to grow professionally; to enhance the educational learning process through hands-on opportunities; and to gain an appreciation of the role, duties, responsibilities, and nature of the work in the sport industry.

Name: The Coaching of Basketball
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles and techniques of coaching basketball; organization and administration of practice and various levels of competition.

Name: The Coaching of Volleyball
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Techniques of coaching volleyball; organization and administration of practice and various levels of competition.

Name: Practicum in the Coaching of Individual and Team Sports
Desc: May be taken for credit when sports vary. 3-9 hrs. lab.

Name: Psychology of Coaching
Desc: Psychological perspectives applied to the athletic situation; coaching personalities, athletic personalities, psychological injuries, motivation, mental preparation, relaxation techniques and stereotypes in athletics.

Name: Sport in Society
Desc: Interdisciplinary study of sport as a mirror of society reflecting the dynamics of human social existence; emphasizes process through which individuals formulate their identity from youth to old age.

Name: Introducing Physical Education for Individuals with Disabilities
Desc: Principles and practices of physical activity opportunities for people with disabilities; laws affecting those with disabilities; motor abilities of individuals with disabilities; adjusting programs to suit the needs and interests of these individuals.

Name: Health and Physical Education for the Elementary School
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Basic principles and concepts of a healthy lifestyle; nutrition, fitness, exercise; study and analysis of movement.

Name: Human Sexuality
Desc: Historical, semantic, religious, social, medical and comparative cultural aspects of human sexuality from childhood to senility.

Name: First Aid
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. lab.

Name: Consumer Health
Desc: Major consumer health problems; selecting, purchasing and financing health services and products.

Name: Issues in Mental Health
Desc: Issues in mental health; stress, depression, alienation, family violence, suicide, death and dying.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Reading, research or field work on selected topics.

Name: Internship in Leisure, Recreation and Sport
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit.  Gaining first-hand knowledge and practical hands-on experience in recreational or sport settings.

Name: Introduction to Robotics
Desc: See ENGR 3100.

Name: Human Anatomy Laboratory
Desc: Computer based study. 2 hrs. lab. Interactive software of the human body; gross anatomy with emphasis on muscle, bone, nerve and blood vessels.

Name: Tests and Measurements in Kinesiology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles of measurement and evaluation in kinesiology and health; emphasis on criteria for selection and evaluation of tests and techniques of testing; analyzing and interpreting motor performance and cognitive test scores.

Name: The Olympic Games: Ancient and Modern
Desc: Origins, growth, politicalization and governance of the games.

Name: Introduction to Motor Learning
Desc: Motor skills learning principles that can be applied to instructional and rehabilitation situations; psychological and physiological characteristics that influence skill learning; behavioral changes related to the stages of skill learning; the influence of various types of practice conditions on skill learning.

Name: Biomechanical Basis of Kinesiology
Desc: Education majors only. Anatomical and mechanical analysis of human movement; emphasis on structure and function of bone and muscle, statics, dynamics, kinematics, kinetics and projectile motion.

Name: The Physiological Basis of Activity
Desc: Basic physiological concepts of the muscular, metabolic, cardiovascular and circulorespiratory systems; behavior of each system in relation to exercise; determination of normal and abnormal physical responses to exercise; development of a philosophy of scientific inquiry.

Name: Cadaver Prosection
Desc: Active review of human anatomical structures using cadaveric tissues.
Reqs: Grade of “B” or better in KIN 2500, for Kinesiology majors and permission of School

Name: Laboratory Techniques in Exercise Physiology
Desc: 2 hrs. lab. Laboratory sessions examining the physiological effect of different types of exercise on the functions of the human body.

Name: Scientific Basis for Exercise
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Historical development of chronic disease risk factors; contraindications and valid uses of exercise prescription.

Name: Exercise Testing and Prescription
Desc: For kinesiology majors. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Theory and practice of fitness testing, exercise prescription, health promotion and related concerns.

Name: Severe Disabilities and Physical Activity
Desc: Substantial observations in schools required. Focus on individuals with severe intellectual, behavioral, physical and sensory disabilities.

Name: Health and the Aging Process
Desc: Health conservation of human resources; emphasis on understanding attitudes and practices related to health in the aging process.

Name: Communicable and Noncommunicable Diseases
Desc: Etiology, prophylaxis and control of communicable and noncommunicable diseases and impairments; cancer, diabetes, and cardiovascular, respiratory and sexually transmitted diseases.

Name: Methods of Teaching Wellness Education
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Requisite knowledge and skills for successful teaching of wellness education in K-12 settings.

Name: The Holistic Health Approach to Stress
Desc: Sources of stress; evaluation of stress-related diseases; techniques for promoting stress reduction; prevention of stress-related diseases.

Name: Ethical and Legal Issues in Sport
Desc: Introduction to basic ethical and legal principles required to successfully address managerial situations that arise in sport industry settings; ethical concepts and theories that provide the foundation for the rendering of comprehensive decisions, including but not limited to issues involving Title IX, the use of drugs, antitrust, labor, intellectual property and religion.

Name: Sport Strategies and Planning
Desc: Principles and procedures involved with strategies and planning of professional and intercollegiate athletics.

Name: Program and Event Management
Desc: Basic concepts pertaining to the production of amateur, professional and recreational sporting events.

Name: Financial Issues in Sport
Desc: Application of sound financial concepts in sport management and sport operation.

Name: Sales and Sponsorship in Sport
Desc: Focuses on the sales and sponsorship aspect of sport management through an introduction to the basic core concepts , presented with actual models relevant  to working in sales and sponsorship in the competitive sport environment, and actual sales and sponsorship experience working with a sport organization.

Name: Industrial Robotics
Desc: See ENGR 4100.

Name: Assistive Robotics
Desc: See ENGR 4103.

Name: Autonomous Vehicles
Desc: See ENGR 4200.

Name: Sports Economics
Desc: See ECON 4290.

Name: Special Topics in Kinesiology
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. For students interested in additional study in specific aspects of kinesiology.

Name: Imaging Techniques in Research
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. 1 hrs. lecture; 5 hrs. lab. Knowledge about imaging techniques and its application in research.
Reqs: Grade of B or better in KIN 2500 and KIN 3513, and consent of instructor

Name: Practicum in Human Movement Science
Desc: Pass/fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 6 hrs. lab. Observation and practice of skills, techniques and protocols of patient care within local clinics, hospitals, skill nursing facilities, development disability centers and private practices.
Reqs: enrollment in the College of Human Sciences & Education; at least junior standing; and permission of School

Name: Sports Supplements
Desc: Introduction to federal regulations which enable supplements to be marketed; methods used to evaluate the benefits of supplements and processes used to analyze specific supplements used in sports.

Name: Techniques and Methods of Teaching Physical Education
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in KIN 4516. Education Majors only. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Microteaching and field experience required. Current teaching methods and materials in physical education, teaching styles, aids and formulation of lesson and unit plans.
Reqs: KIN 2504 and competency in four activities

Name: Lifespan Motor Development
Desc: Analysis of changes in motor behavior from infancy to older adulthood; current theoretical perspectives; current issues; correlates of motor development.

Name: Facilities Management
Desc: Preventive maintenance, facility planning, event administration, box office management, house and ground management, systems management, marketing, finance and personnel administration.

Name: Sports Seminar
Desc: Trends and issues related to the development and maintenance of athletic abilities in a variety of sports.

Name: Curriculum Construction in Physical Education
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in KIN 4511. Education Majors only. Curriculum construction and program content for elementary and secondary schools.

Name: Sports Administration
Desc: Policies and practices in the administration of athletic programs in academic settings.

Name: Governance and Policy Development in Sport
Desc: Analysis of governance structures of sport organizations and implications for policy development.

Name: Cadaver Dissection
Desc: Active dissection of human cadavers.
Reqs: Grade of A in KIN 2500 or KIN 3519, for Kinesiology majors and permission of School

Name: Psychosocial Aspects of Physical Activity
Desc: Psychological and sociological perspectives of physical activity; theories and research related to sport and exercise behavior; and psychological factors that influence involvement and performance in physical activity settings.

Name: Human Anatomy and Functional Impairment
Desc: Anatomy of selected systems and the mechanisms and effects of impairment.
Reqs: KIN 2500, KIN 3500 or consent of instructor

Name: The Physiology of Endurance Training
Desc: 2 hrs. lec., 2 hrs. lab. Exploration of the physiological responses to endurance training. Application of physiological principles in a laboratory setting by performing standard tests and training for an endurance event.

Name: Essentials of Sport Performance Training
Desc: Basic principles and methods of testing, training, and programming related to sports performance.
Reqs: KIN 2500, KIN 2504, KIN 3515, or permission of instructor

Name: Exercise Programs and Implementation
Desc: 1 hr. lec.; 4 hrs. field experiences. Practical experience examining and implementing exercise programs and interventions.
Reqs: KIN 3535 and KIN 1801, KIN 1802, KIN 1803, or KIN 1804

Name: Practicum in Exercise Science and Human Performance
Desc: Pass-fail grading. For kinesiology majors. 12 hrs. lab. Practical application of exercise science knowledge, skills, and leadership with an internship facility.

Name: The Physical Education Curriculum for Children with Disabilities
Desc: Curriculum needs, implementation and evaluation, using the Louisiana State Regulations and P. E. Needs Assessment.

Name: Neuromotor Control of Human Movement
Desc: Muscle dynamics; sensory and motor neural pathways; subcortical reflexes; supraspinal mechanisms; behavioral issues.
Reqs: KIN 2500, senior standing or permission of instructor

Name: Student Teaching Residency in Physical Education I
Desc: Student teaching practicum in diverse, multicultural K-12 settings.

Name: Addressing Diversity and Cultural Issues in Physical Activity
Desc: Concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4630. Critical theoretical perspectives of sport and physical education in American society.

Name: Student Teaching Residency in Physical Education II
Desc: Student teaching practicum in diverse, multicultural K-12 settings.

Name: Community Health Issues
Desc: Community health aspects and implications of tobacco, alcohol, drugs, venereal disease and other communicable diseases; other community health problems.

Name: Introduction to Epidemiology
Desc: This course covers the application of epidemiologic methods and procedures to the study of the distribution and determinants of health and diseases, morbidity, injuries, disability, and mortality in populations. Topics include quantitative aspects of epidemiology such as data sources, measures of morbidity and mortality, evaluation of association and causality, study design, and screening for disease. Other topics include qualitative aspects of social determinants of health.

Name: Habituating and Addictive Drugs in Our Culture
Desc: Harmless, harmful, useful and useless chemical substances that affect physiological well-being and behavior or mood; interaction of psychological, sociological and physiological components.
Reqs: KIN 1600 and senior or graduate standing

Name: Introduction to Health Promotion
Desc: Recommended: PSYC 3083. Psychological and behavioral perspectives of health promotion; theories and research related to health behavior change; analysis of effective interventions designed to promote health behavior change.

Name: African Americans in Sport
Desc: Also offered as AAAS 4800. African American experiences in sport, including a survey of the history of African Americans in sport and its larger effect on African American culture in general; introduction to the historical, sociological, economic, psychological, anatomical and physiological aspects of sport unique to African Americans.

Name: Practicum in Sport and Leisure Administration
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Credit will not be given for this course and KIN 4836. Practical applications of administrative techniques in a sport, leisure or sport-related setting.
Reqs: Sport Administration majors only; students should be within two semesters of completing degree requirements or obtain permission of the department

Name: Internship in Sport Administration
Desc: Pass/Fail grading. May be repeated for a maximum of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Credit will not be given for both this course and KIN 4835. Practical applications of administrative techniques in a sport, leisure or sport-related setting.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Open to advanced undergraduate or graduate students. Reading, research and/or field work on selected topics.

Name: Motor Development Across the Lifespan
Desc: Typical and atypical motor development across the lifespan (infancy through older adulthood); implications for skill learning and functional ability; assessments and interventions.

Name: Practicum in Sport Management
Desc: hrs. from the sport management MS program, a letter of agreement from prospective on-site supervisor and consent of faculty advisor. Practical application of management techniques in a sport or sport-related setting; students work in a professional capacity for 10-30 hrs. per week during the semester under the guidance of the on-site supervisor.

Name: Advanced Research Methods
Desc: Analysis of multivariate research methods and statistical analysis used in kinesiology research.

Name: Curriculum Construction in Physical Education
Desc: Contemporary educational trends in curriculum theory, issues, philosophical orientation and models derived from research and experience.

Name: Dimensions of Aging
Desc: Focus on physical, cognitive and emotional aspects of biological aging; role of physical activity and lifestyle issues and their interaction with chronological aging and functional ability.

Name: Problems in Kinesiology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Consent of instructor.

Name: Practicum in Pedagogy
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Practical application of pedagogical techniques and methods in a physical education or physical education-related setting; students work in a professional capacity for 10-30 hours per week during the semester under the guidance of an on-site supervisor and/or faculty member.

Name: Analysis of Human Movement
Desc: Mechanisms involved in the production of human movement and the techniques available for scientific analysis of such movement.

Name: Motor Learning
Desc: Cognitive and motor processes influencing the learning of motor skills; emphasis on assessing learning, changes during learning, attention, augmented feedback, transfer of learning and practice conditions, with implications for a variety of skill instruction and rehabilitation contexts.

Name: Administrative Problems in Kinesiology
Desc: Organization and management theory and techniques for administration of programs in educational and fitness settings.

Name: Motor Control
Desc: Neurophysiological and behavioral issues in control of human movement; emphasis on contrast between ecological and constructionist approaches.

Name: Seminar in Physical Education Professional Preparation
Desc: Issues and trends in physical education; emphasis on undergraduate and graduate professional preparation.

Name: Pedagogy in Physical Education
Desc: Theory and research relating to systematized instruction in physical education.
Reqs: KIN 7502 and admission to the doctoral program

Name: Theories of Achievement Motivation in Physical Activity
Desc: Theories of achievement motivation as they apply in a variety of physical activity settings including motor skill acquisition, sport, exercise behavior and rehabilitation.

Name: Organizational Behavior and Development in Sport
Desc: Analysis of organizations in the sport industry using theoretical and practical applications; examining the cultural and environment within which the sport organization operates.

Name: Advanced Topics in Motor Control
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Selected topics linking advanced motor control topics across disciplines, medicine and research.

Name: Social Issues in Sport
Desc: Examination of the social construction of sport and the systemic issues connected to contemporary sport.

Name: Financial Issues in Sport
Desc: An in-depth examination of public and private financing options for professional, intercollegiate, interscholastic and recreational/commercial sport.

Name: Motor Development
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Psychomotor development of children; implications for skill learning; analyzing and planning motor development research; motor development in special children; research on youth sports; evaluation and assessment; and perceptual-motor development.

Name: Theories of Motor Skill Acquisition
Desc: For PhD students in motor learning or motor development. Issues in motor control and learning, i.e., central and peripheral mechanisms, theories of motor learning, motor programs and short-term memory.

Name: Sport Law
Desc: A study of legal issues affecting the delivery of sport services and liability in sport-related activities.

Name: Children and Sport
Desc: Open to graduate students from any area. Children’s involvement in organized sports; understanding of the present structure of youth sports; research in child development, training, injuries, social psychology, skill acquisition and coaching behavior; implications for children in sport.

Name: Advanced Topics in Biomechanics
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Selected topics linking advanced biomechanics topics across disciplines, rehabilitation and research.

Name: Sport Psychology
Desc: Problems of several areas of social psychology related to sport; research methodology and theories.

Name: Exercise Physiology
Desc: Physical, chemical and environmental factors influencing physical performance; bioenergetics, cardiovascular and respiratory adjustments to exercise; research relevant to conditioning and physiological responses to exercise.

Name: Advanced Topics in Motor Learning
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Selected topics linking motor learning concepts across different disciplines in academic and applied settings.

Name: Exercise in Health and Disease
Desc: Contraindications and valid uses of exercise in mediating risk factors.

Name: Neuromuscular Aspects of Exercise
Desc: Effects of exercise on muscle cell structure and function; neuromuscular integration and neural function in exercise.

Name: Cardiovascular and Respiratory Function in Exercise
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Mechanics of cardiovascular and respiratory function related to exercise.

Name: Exercise and Environment
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Effects of environmental conditions on performance of various types of exercise.

Name: Practicum in Cardiac Rehabilitation
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Minimum on-site requirement is 20 hours per week. Important for exercise specialist, exercise leader or graded exercise technician certification. Involvement in the practical application of exercise testing, exercise prescription and exercise leadership for cardiac patients.

Name: Laboratory Techniques in Exercise Physiology
Desc: 1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. lab Laboratory techniques in exercise physiology; principles of metabolic measurement and assay procedures for quantification of dynamic changes in blood chemistry during exercise.
Reqs: KIN 7530 exercise physiology and college chemistry recommended

Name: Current Topics in Sport Management
Desc: An examination of the current topics and issues within the sporting environment from a variety of perspectives, including but not limited to, sociological, historical, economic, and managerial.

Name: Economic Issues in Sports
Desc: In-depth examination focusing on the economic issues of professional, intercollegiate, and recreational sport around the world; examining specific areas such as competitive balance of sports leagues, discrimination, and the demand for sport.

Name: Exercise Metabolism
Desc: The study of the interactions between metabolism and substrate utilization, and how these factors impact work and exercise performance.

Name: Advanced Topics in Exercise Physiology
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 semester hours of credit when topics vary. Selected topics linking advanced exercise physiology topics across disciplines, rehabilitation, and research.

Name: Advanced Exercise Physiology
Desc: lecture; 2 hrs. lab; college chemistry, mathematics, physics recommended. Quantitative approach to both systematic and cellular control during exercise.

Name: Qualitative Research in Kinesiology
Desc: Introduction to qualitative methodologies and research in Kinesiology.

Name: Changing Health Behavior
Desc: Motivation and determinants of health behavior; behavior change strategies designed for utilization in individual and group health education programs; promoting innovative health education programs in schools and the community.

Name: Social-Ecological Influences on Physical Activity and Health
Desc: Application of the social-ecological framework to physical activity and health behaviors.

Name: Stress Management and Emotional Health
Desc: Principles, theories and coping/relaxation techniques related to stress management and the promotion of emotional health.

Name: Community-Based Public Health
Desc: Status of the health of the public; social justice in health promotion; community-based participatory research; phronesis, art, culture, and embodiment in community health.

Name: Neuromuscular Motor Control
Desc: Examine neuromuscular organization for production of limb movements; direct and indirect methods for examining neurophysiological processes underlying motor control; electromyography recording and analysis.

Name: Introduction to Research Methods
Desc: An introduction to the basic aspects of reading, evaluating and writing research. Topics include problem selection, literature review, instrumentation, methodology and types of research in physical activity.

Name: Seminar in Selected Topics in Kinesiology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Topics vary.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Independent Research
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. credit.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Landscape Representation I
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Freehand and mechanical representation and observational skills used in design conceptualization; emphasis on the development of a vocabulary, basic skills and techniques of landscape architecture representation.

Name: Landscape Representation II
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Developing skills in computer-aided visualization and illustrative documentation of landscapes; introduction to digital imaging, drafting and photo manipulation.

Name: Introduction to Landscape Architecture
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Introduction to the profession of landscape architecture for non-majors; overview of professional concerns and responsibilities; awareness of natural and planned landscapes, as well as, the importance of using land in an efficient and attractive manner.

Name: Views of the American Landscape
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. A visual tour of North American regions and histories, this course examines the views that have shaped the landscape through land development patterns, regional and national management strategies, and environmental conservation ethics. Weaving natural systems and cultural ones, this course celebrates the power and beauty of our landscapes.

Name: Gardens of the World
Desc: Exploration of the physical, social and envrironmental factors which contribute to the development of gardens from historical to contemporary perspectives.

Name: Landscape Design I
Desc: Consent of school director. 12 hrs. studio. Introduction to two-and three-dimensional design; spatial sequence, meaning and dynamic change; application to a simple design.

Name: Landscape Design II: Site Design
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Development of landscape design processes as applied to small-scale projects; introduction of earth structures, construction materials and plants.

Name: Landscape Representation III
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Advanced representation techniques developing skills of visualization and representation using freehand, mechanical and digital imaging in design projects.

Name: Landscape History I
Desc: Development of earliest landscape traditions; relationship of humans to landscape in major cultural areas of the ancient world; development of landscape traditions in western Europe and America from the 15th to 19th centuries.

Name: Landscape Technology I: Land Design
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. studio. Introduction to basic surveying for landscape architects; surveying systems and legal land descriptions; introduction to landscape architectural construction systems and the relationship among landform/earth, plants, and structures, topographic mapping conventions, grading design, drainage and water management, roadway design and alignment.
Reqs: MATH 1021 and MATH 1022 or equivalent; and LA 1102 or equivalent; consent of instructor

Name: Landscape Ecology
Desc: lass includes field trips. Application of ecological principles and relationships to resource, recreation and landscape planning, with attention to conservation ethics and legal regulations leading to sustainability of the landscape.

Name: Landscape Design III: Site Planning and Design
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio. Arrangement of buildings, circulation and other landscape design elements; emphasis on earthwork and drainage.
Reqs: LA 2002 and LA 2101 and LA 2201 or equivalent

Name: Landscape Design IV: Community Design
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Landscape planning and design at the community and neighborhood scale; emphasis on relationships of uses, transportation infrastructure, green infrastructure, public services and a mix of housing and commercial types.

Name: Landscape History II
Desc: Major landscape movements in the 19th and 20th centuries; theory and aspects of contemporary practice of landscape architecture.

Name: Landscape Technology II: Grading, Drainage and Roads
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. studio. Advanced grading and drainage with emphasis on aesthetic aspects of grading and best management practices and sustainability, landscape architectural systems and infrastructures including advanced roadway design and alignment.
Reqs: LA 2301 or equivalent; consent of instructor

Name: Landscape Technology III: Design Detailing
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. studio. Relationship between design and implementation through construction processes, detailing as an extension of design, landscape architectural materials, basic structural theory, detailing and structures, technical specifications as a means of enuring design intent.
Reqs: LA 3301 or equivalent; consent of instructor

Name: Plant Materials I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Identification and study of plant materials with specific recognition of the visual and ecological characteristics of plants used in landscape design.

Name: Plant Materials II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Continuation of LA 3401 with the inclusion of basic principles of planting design.

Name: Landscape Design V: Landscape Planning and Development
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio. Landscape planning and design from the regional to the site development scale; emphasis on generating planning and design strategies for urbanization and development that are informed by an understanding of the ecology and culture of the region and based on principles of sustainability.

Name: Landscape Design VI: Specialization
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Studio projects addressing various aspects of landscape architecture.
Reqs: LA 4001 Credit will not be given for this course and LA 4003

Name: Landscape Architecture Internship
Desc: Pass-fail grading. At least 35 hours of work per week supervised by a licensed landscape architect or professional in an approved firm or agency.
Reqs: Completion of all 3000-level Landscape Architecture courses and consent of School

Name: Advanced Topics Studio
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses related to the course. Advanced topics in landscape architecture addressing research and projects in the profession.
Reqs: LA 3002, LA 7041 or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Digital Representation
Desc: Advanced techniques in digital representation, such as 3-D modeling, terrain modeling, animation, advanced imaging and rendering.

Name: Theory and Methods of Landscape Planning
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principal theoretical literature in landscape analysis and planning; application of theories and methods; basic skills in the use of GIS, global positioning systems (GPS) and remote sensing/image processing technology.

Name: Landscape Technology IV: Specialization
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. studio. Specialty topics in landscape architecture construction and design implementation.

Name: Field Studies in Landscape Architecture
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit. Elective field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with this course. Field trip to landscape architectural office, projects, historic sites and schools throughout the U.S. and abroad.

Name: Independent Study in Landscape Architecture
Desc: Independent study proposals must be pre-approved by the supervising faculty member. Program of individual study under faculty guidance, including auditing lectures, reading and exercises as needed to develop skills in methods of inquiry related to the area of specialty.

Name: Advanced Projects in Landscape Architecture
Desc: Faculty directed projects for small groups of students investigating specific areas of research and practice.

Name: Advanced Elective in Landscape Architecture
Desc: Research practice and application in landscape architecture; small groups will use lectures, discussions, presentations and other formats to explore advanced topics.

Name: Special Studies in Landscape Architecture
Desc: Program of study under faculty guidance. Independent study proposals must be pre-approved by supervising faculty member and the School director.

Name: Landscape Design VII: Urban Landscape Design
Desc: Required field trip. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. 12 hrs. studio. Investigation of urban structures and systems and design of urban landscapes and elements.

Name: Landscape Design VIII: Capstone Project
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Intensive development of a comprehensive landscape design and/or independent design project.

Name: Research Seminar
Desc: Intensive and critical review of major landscape theories and issues; identification and preparation for a comprehensive final project.

Name: The Practice of Landscape Architecture
Desc: Professional practice for landscape architects including issues associated with licensure, practice types, professional services, business developments, contracts and project management.

Name: Site Systems I
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Recordings, analysis, topography/strata, processes of landscape design.

Name: History and Theory I
Desc: Overview of landscape movements throughout history.

Name: Ecology and Technology I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Introduction to landscape architectural construction systems and the relationship among landform/earth, plant, and structures; topographic mapping conventions; grading design; drainage and water management; and, roadway design and alignment. Introduction to basic surveying for landscape architects; surveying systems and legal land descriptions.

Name: Site Systems II
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Human systems, site scale resolution, advanced topography/strata, vegetation processes of landscape design.
Reqs: LA 7011 or consent of the school

Name: History and Theory II
Desc: Major historical influences from China, Japan, Mughals, Moors, Italy, France, England, and others up to contemporary practice.

Name: Ecology and Technology II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Field course introduces plants as a central component of organizing ecological communities, in relationship to topography and hydrology. Basic principles in plant communities, soils, landforms, and basic hydrology through on-site reading and documentation; introduces landscape architecture as a practice, focusing on site systems and the representation of plant materials and ecosystems and green infrastructures.

Name: Water Systems
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Landscape and water management regional strategies, theory, global issues, and site scale hydrology.
Reqs: LA 7021 or consent of the school

Name: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture Media
Desc: Course may be taken for 6 hours of credit when topics vary. 6 hrs. studio. Mapping water and natural resources in conjunction with studio work; exploring design alternatives using related software.

Name: History and Theory III
Desc: History of open space in the urban environment and related planning issues. The role of urban parks in the planning and design of cities.

Name: Ecology and Technology III
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Introduces stormwater management techniques and the calculations required to determine stormwater runoff and the reduction of stormwater pollution; using hydrological software to do parametric modeling of a stormwater design.

Name: Urban Systems
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. City landscapes, infrastructure, public, social, and cultural space within a temporal context.
Reqs: LA 7031 or consent of the school

Name: History and Theory IV
Desc: Course includes travel and field research. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with the course. Contemporary landscape architecture practice from the 1960’s to the present, focusing on a series of detailed case studies showing the evolution of contemporary projects and their relationship to contemporary theory.

Name: Professional Practice
Desc: Professional landscape architecture practice in a design office. Contracts, management, professional ethics and the business issues facing planning and design professionals including explorations of non-traditional careers for landscape architects.

Name: Ecology and Technology IV
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Construction practices in landscape architecture, focusing on the primary components of built environments: materials, assemblies, and technique; the principles of sustainability as it relates to construction and materials; advanced materials and emerging technologies.

Name: Advanced Topics I
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Advanced research studio focusing on specific landscape problems, sites, or topics.
Reqs: LA 7041 or consent of the school

Name: Thesis Preparation
Desc: Preparation for landscape architecture thesis on design, technology, history, or professional principles working closely with the instructor on research methods and developing an individual thesis proposal for a written or design thesis.

Name: Advanced Topics II
Desc: 12 hrs. studio. Final advanced research studio focusing on specific landscape problems, sites, or topics or an independent design project.
Reqs: LA 7051 or consent of the school

Name: GIS for Designers
Desc: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and Science (GISc) for designers.

Name: Emerging Paradigms Colloquium
Desc: This colloquium will introduce graduate students to emerging paradigms of landscape architecture. Through a series of faculty, guest, and professional interviews on a set of themes the colloquium will foster critical discourses about the directions in landscape architectural practice, research, and theory.

Name: Graduate Landscape Representation I
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Freehand and mechanical representation techniques, tools and media used in designing and illustrating landscape architectural projects; emphasis on the development of a vocabulary, basic skills and theory of landscape architectural representation.

Name: Graduate Landscape Representation II
Desc: 6 hrs. studio. Advanced representation techniques developing skills of visualization and representation using freehand, mechanical and digital imaging design projects.

Name: Research Methods
Desc: Concepts of qualitative research; skills in finding and using research material; landscape architectural research trends; evaluation of research; application of research to landscape design.

Name: Graduate Landscape Ecology
Desc: Required field trips for which a deposit is required at registration. Basic principles of ecology and environmental systems; application of ecological principles and relationships to resource, recreation and landscape planning, with attention to conservation ethics and legal regulations leading to sustainability of the landscape.

Name: Planting Design
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Field course explores the art and technology of plants with consideration for various scales of sites and site ecosystems; designs for human use; and with consideration for sustainable design and landscape management practices.

Name: Graduate Field Studies in Landscape Architecture
Desc: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 hrs. credit with the permission of the Department. Students are responsible for praying travel expenses associated with this course. This course is a field trip to landscape architectural offices, projects, historic sites, and schools throughout the US and abroad.

Name: Graduate Independent Study in Landscape Architecture
Desc: Independent study proposals must be pre-approved by the supervising faculty member.  May be repeated for maximum of 6 credit hours. A program of individual study under faculty guidance, including auditing of lectures, reading, and exercises as needed to develop skills or knowledge related to the area of specialty.

Name: Graduate Advanced Elective in Landscape Architecture
Desc: Research practice and application in landscape architecture; small groups will use lectures, discussions, presentations and other formats to explore advanced topics.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Elementary Latin
Desc: [LCCN: CLTN 1014, 1026, Elementary Latin I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Nonlaboratory reading course in classical Latin; emphasis on comprehension rather than grammar; repetition of controlled vocabulary and contextual clues used to read extensive passages of simple Latin.

Name: Intermediate Latin
Desc: Reading comprehension approach to language continued in extensive passages of moderate difficulty; vocabulary building and basic Latin grammatical constructions.

Name: Intermediate Latin
Desc: Nonlaboratory comprehension approach includes material of the difficulty of 1st century Latin poetry and prose.

Name: Golden Age Narrative Poetry
Desc: Readings from the narrative poets, including selections from Vergil’s Aeneid and/or from Ovid’s Metamorphoses.

Name: Golden Age Prose
Desc: Readings from Roman prose writers (excluding the historians); the major speeches, letters, and/or philosophical works of Cicero.

Name: Roman Historians
Desc: Readings from Roman historians; selections from Livy and/or Tacitus; prose style and philosophy of history of the author(s).

Name: Golden Age Lyric Poetry
Desc: Readings from the lyric poets; selections from the Carmina of Catullus and/or the Odes of Horace, with attention to emotional content.

Name: Intensive Latin Language
Desc: A specialized course intended to provide a reading knowledge of Latin. For graduate students and advanced undergraduates for whom a familiarity with another foreign language is strongly recommended. Successful completion of this course will be regarded as sufficient preparation for LATN 4006. Does not count toward satisfying foreign language requirement for undergraduates, although hours may count toward baccalaureate. Credit will not be given for both this course and introductory Latin courses.

Name: Roman Satire
Desc: Readings from Petronius’ Satyricon, Martial and Juvenal for their humor, with attention to evidence of the lives and language of ordinary Roman people.

Name: Readings in the History of Livy
Desc: Selections from the History of Livy; literary and historical significance.

Name: Roman Comedy
Desc: Reading of representative plays of Plautus and Terence, with attention to dramatic techniques and comic situations.

Name: Medieval and Renaissance Latin
Desc: Readings from the time of the medieval Latin writers to Milton.

Name: Special Topics in Latin Poetry
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Readings and studies in the works of one or more major poets of the Roman Republic or Roman Empire.

Name: Special Topics in Latin Prose
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Readings and studies in the works of one or more of the major prose writers of the Roman Republic or Roman Empire.

Name: Roman Elegy
Desc: Readings in the major Latin elegiac poets such as Ovid, Propertius and Tibullus; attention to poetic technique and to Roman attitudes toward love and women.

Name: Independent Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Permission of department required. Readings in Latin literature directed by a senior faculty member.

Name: Ethical & Legal Issues in Leadership & Human Resource Development
Desc: Introduction to ethics, ethical decision making, ethical and legal issues and challenges faced by leadership and human resource development professionals practicing in public and private sector organizations.

Name: Principles of Learning Experience Design
Desc: Introduction to the principles of learning experience design and its application to web-based and e-learning in the workplace.

Name: Introduction to Leadership Development
Desc: An honors course, LHRD 2724, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and LHRD 2724. Introduction to leadership and leadership development; emphasis on students understanding their personal traits, values, characteristics and development tasks as a foundation for leadership development.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Leadership Development
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and LHRD 2723.

Name: E-Learning Experience Design
Desc: Introduction to the processes of design, development, implementation and evaluation of e-learning experiences in the workplace.

Name: Learning Theory and Practice in LXD
Desc: Integration of learning theories into the practice of learning experience design and the delivery of e-learning experiences in the workplace.

Name: Principles of Human Resource Development
Desc: A comprehensive introduction to the field, principles, profession and practice of Human Resource Development (HRD) Training and Development.

Name: Instructional Design for Training
Desc: Principles and practices of instructional design for developing effective training; course, unit and lesson development.

Name: Learning Technologies in the Workplace
Desc: Survey of contemporary tools and technologies used for web-based and e-learning in organizations.

Name: Leading Learning in Human Resource Development
Desc: Introduction to the principles and practices of instructional delivery strategies to facilitate learning in training and development; methods for leading learning in traditional classroom training; on-the-job training; small group learning; and individual learning.

Name: Strategic Career Development/Planning
Desc: Career development and planning through career decision-making, networking and linking personal competencies to organizations. Applying skills required for a successful job search and making the transition from college to work.
Reqs: Sophomore standing or higher or consent of instructor

Name: Needs Analysis in Human Resource Development
Desc: Comprehensive introduction to the principles and practice of needs assessment and performance analysis for Human Resource Development (HRD) Training and Development and Adult Education.

Name: Leadership Concepts and Principles
Desc: An honors course, LHRD 3724, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and LHRD 3724. Survey of leadership theory, concepts and research; emphasis on understanding the foundational concepts of modern leadership.

Name: HONORS: Leadership Concepts and Principles
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and LHRD 3723.

Name: Principles of Adult Education
Desc: Nature and importance of adult education; social and psychological factors affecting adult motivation and learning; techniques for providing adult learning experiences.

Name: Innovative Learning Content Design for LXD
Desc: Integration of LXD design principles into use of audio and video content to promote learner engagement and training outcomes.

Name: Project Management and Team Leadership in LHRD
Desc: Introduction to the conceptualization and development of project plans, project management strategies and the leadership and development of project teams in human resource and leadership development.

Name: LXDI Capstone
Desc: Comprehensive assembly of work products into a marketable e-portfolio and creation of a personal website aligned with professional LXD and e-learning goals.

Name: Design Thinking for LXD in the Workplace
Desc: Introduction to design thinking and its application to e-learning design and implementation in the workplace.

Name: Foundations of Human Resource Development
Desc: Comprehensive introduction and overview to the field, profession, theoretical foundations and practice of Human Resource Development (HRD).

Name: Creating Change Through E-Learning in Organizations
Desc: Utilization of learning experience design, learner personas, design thinking, experience mapping, and learning analytics to foster and manage change in organizational settings.

Name: Workplace Stress & Health
Desc: Introduction to workplace health and stress including occupational stress and burnout, safety/accident prevention, psycho-social factors in disease, work-life balance, and development of a resilient workforce through employee health and wellness.

Name: Teams and Groups in Organizations
Desc: An introduction to teams and groups and their structures, processes, and functioning in organizational systems.

Name: Applied Leadership
Desc: An introduction to the use of communication, influence and persuasion in organizational leadership.

Name: Managing the Human Resource Development Function
Desc: Offered in Su Study of human resource development (HRD) in organizations with employees on practical application of principles for effective leadership, management and administration of the HRD function.

Name: Training in Global Organizations
Desc: Introduction to the problems, practices and models of cross-cultural competence and cross-cultural training; focus on the nature, content and function of cross-cultural training in organizations.

Name: Advanced Organizational Psychology & Work Behavior
Desc: Topics in organizational science derived from research in organizational psychology, management, human resources, organizational communication, and sociology; basic understanding of the conceptual and empirical knowledge that describes and defines human behavior within organizational systems, with a particular focus on workplace organizations.

Name: Consulting in Organizations
Desc: Practical look at the skills to be an effective internal or external consultant in organizations; emphasis on consulting process rather than any specific area of consulting expertise.

Name: Evaluation in Human Resource Development
Desc: Comprehensive introduction to the principles and practice of training program evaluation.

Name: Advanced Leadership Development
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and LHRD 4724. Focus on developing the leadership skills students need to effectively lead organizations and communities to achieve their vision and goals.
Reqs: LHRD 2723 and LHRD 3723 or graduate status

Name: HONORS: Advanced Leadership Development
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and LHRD 4723.
Reqs: LHRD 2723 or LHRD 2724 and LHRD 3723 or LHRD 3724; Honors College students only

Name: Professional Development Capstone
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Not for graduate credit. For Leadership and Human Resource Development and Learning Experience Design and Innovation majors only. Students complete projects, assignments or internships to gain practical experience and information related to the student’s interests and chosen career field.
Reqs: LHRD 2723, LHRD 3723, and LHRD 4723 or permission of instructor

Name: Advanced Problems in Leadership & Human Resource Development
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Permission of instructor. Individual and group problems.

Name: Diversity in Global Learning Environments
Desc: An examination of contemporary issues related to diversity, equity, and social justice across various learning environments in a global context.

Name: Global Leadership
Desc: An examination of contemporary research, practice, and development issues related to leadership in international organizations.

Name: Principles of Workforce Development
Desc: Principles of workforce education and development programs conducted by business, industry, government and educational institutions at all levels; relationships to adult education, career/technical education, human resource development, career development, general education and society.

Name: Perspectives on Leadership and Human Resource Development
Desc: Survey of the evolving perspectives and critical pillars that illuminate and link the fields of leadership and human resource development.

Name: Workforce Planning and Analysis
Desc: Examines the process of workforce planning on a macro-level to develop students’ understanding of workforce planning models, the planning process, and the capability to carry out workforce planning and analysis to meet clients’ needs.

Name: Advanced Adult Learning Theory and Practice
Desc: Advanced study of adult learning theory and research; emphasis on learning theory and research in adult learning with implications for adult learning practice.

Name: Team & Group Dynamics
Desc: Survey of team and work group dynamics.

Name: Instructional Design for Human Resource Development
Desc: Comprehensive introduction to the theory, principles, research and practices of instructional systems design (ISD) in human resource development (HRD) and training.

Name: Philosophy of Science in Leadership and Human Resource Development
Desc: Survey of the philosophy of science underlying the scientific method in the study of leadership and human resource development.

Name: Advanced Quantitative Methods in Leadership & Human Resource Development
Desc: Examination of advanced quantitative methods essential to researchers in the field of leadership and human resource development (LHRD).
Reqs: ELRC 7006 and ELRC 7016 or equivalent coursework in fundamental statistics

Name: Leading Learning in Human Resource Development
Desc: Principles, research, and practices of facilitating learning in human resource development (HRD) including facilitation skills for traditional classroom training, as well as informal work-based learning strategies.

Name: Cultural Competence and Diversity
Desc: Explores the development of cross-cultural skills through examination of culture theory, cross-cultural competence models, and experiential training methods.

Name: Performance and Needs Analysis in Human Resources Development
Desc: Theory and principles used in the analysis of performance problems in organizations; emphasis on the application of performance theory and use of tools and techniques for analyzing organizational, process and individual level performance problems.

Name: Managing Change in Organizational Systems
Desc: Introduction to the theory, methods and practice of organization change and development; emphasis on the role of the HRD practitioner as change agent and the interventions used to lead and manage organization change.

Name: Training and Development in Organizations
Desc: Survey of the training and development function in modern organizations. Particular focus is given to learning theory and strategies, program design, and evaluation in applied (field) settings. A multidisciplinary perspective is encouraged.

Name: Program Evaluation Design
Desc: Systematic application of social research procedures for evaluating the conceptualization, design, implementation and utility of human resource and organization development programs.

Name: Introduction to Leadership Development
Desc: A comprehensive look at classic and contemporary theory and research in the twin domains of leadership and leadership development.

Name: Psychological Tests and Measures in Leadership & Human Resource Development
Desc: Understanding, administering, and evaluating human behavior, personality, interest and attitudinal assessment instruments commonly used in the practice of leadership and human resource development.
Reqs: ELRC 7006 or equivalent and ELRC 7016 or equivalent

Name: Leadership and Organization
Desc: Application of relevant principles from leadership theory, group dynamics, social organization and organizational administration to problems of organizing extension education programs.

Name: Determinant Leadership & Individual Development
Desc: Identification and development of an individual’s leadership strengths, traits, and skills through research-based assessments.

Name: Leadership Development Strategies in Organizations
Desc: Introduction to the major strategies used for developing leaders in organizations; emphasis on learning theories for leadership development, formal training strategies, development through job experience, feedback intensive programs and skill-building programs.

Name: Advanced Leadership Theory and Practice
Desc: A study of theory, research, and managerial applications of leadership; in-depth examination of leadership styles and approaches, including taxonomies, personal attributes of leadership, diversity, and cultural dimensions.

Name: Current Topics in Leadership Development
Desc: Analysis and evaluation of contemporary examples of leadership in human resource education, including current trends and models.
Reqs: nine hours from LHRD 7723, LHRD 7724, LHRD 7725, LHRD 7575, or LHRD 7727

Name: Practicum in Leadership Development
Desc: Practical experience in leadership development under the guidance of in-service practitioners.
Reqs: twelve hours from LHRD 7723, LHRD 7724, LHRD 7725, LHRD 7575, LHRD 7727, or LHRD 7731

Name: Current Problems and Issues in Leadership & Human Resource Development
Desc: Legislative, societal and educational concerns affecting workforce education.

Name: Independent Study in Leadership & Human Resource Development
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Permission of instructor. Faculty directed study of relevant topics in workforce education.

Name: Seminar in Leadership & Human Resource Development
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Selected topics of interest to leadership & human resource development.

Name: Research and Theory in Human Resource Development
Desc: Doctoral seminar. The role of theory in human resource development practice and research, theory-building methodologies and key foundational theory and research in human resource development.

Name: Applied Research Methods and Analysis in Organizations
Desc: An experiential introduction to the applied research process in organizations including the conceptualization of applied research, designing studies, analyzing data, and reporting results to stakeholders.

Name: Human Resource Analytics
Desc: Human resource and organizational behavior issues will be examined through the lens of measurement, analysis, and financial impact for the organization.

Name: Applied Qualitative Research Methods
Desc: Expanding graduate students’ research skills to include knowledge of theories and methods associated with qualitative research designs.

Name: Advanced Mixed Methods Research
Desc: Systematic application of social research procedures for evaluating the conceptualization, design, implementation, and utility of human resource education and workforce development programs.
Reqs: ELRC 7006, and LHRD 7921, or equivalent coursework

Name: Data Collection and Analysis in Organizations
Desc: Introduction to the principles and fundamental methods of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data in organizations for the purpose of informing actions and decisions related to human resource development.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading. Permission of instructor.

Name: Research Problems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Permission of instructor. Research problems in programming, teaching, leadership, organization or evaluation of extension programs.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading. Permission of instructor.

Name: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Aging
Desc: Contemporary issues in aging; preparation for the study of aging in contemporary society.

Name: Liberal Arts: Methods of Inquiry
Desc: Liberal Arts 7000 is required. Interdisciplinary study in the liberal arts; modes of inquiry in different disciplines, common themes in the humanities and means of integrating these into the whole.

Name: Liberal Arts: Themes and Commonalities
Desc: Liberal Arts 7900 is required. Major ideas in the liberal arts as reflected in exemplary published studies and student research; the cultural function of the humanities.

Name: Special Topics in the Liberal Arts
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Interdisciplinary studies in the liberal arts, with attention to major periods, movements, themes or problems in Western culture.
Reqs: credit in LIBA 7000 or consent of instructor

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Directed individual readings by the graduate faculty.
Reqs: consent of department; credit or concurrent enrollment in LIBA 7000

Name: Symbolic Logic
Desc: See PHIL 2010.

Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. See COMD 2050.

Desc: See COMD 4750.

Desc: See PHIL 4914.

Desc: See ANTH 7060.

Desc: See ENGL 7712.

Desc: See ENGL 7714.

Name: Special Topics in Linguistics
Desc: See COMD 7750.

Name: Independent Research: Phonetics and Linguistics
Desc: See COMD 7756.

Name: Selected Topics in Anthropology
Desc: See ANTH 7909.

Desc: See PHIL 7910.

Name: Field Methods in Linguistics
Desc: See ANTH 7962.

Name: Research in Anthropology
Desc: See ANTH 7999.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Information Literacy and Critical Analysis
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Introduction to information creation and organization; critical analysis and evaluation of information for research and everyday life.

Name: Library Research Methods and Materials
Desc: Fundamentals of college-level research; location, evaluation and use of information for research needs; introduction to the library and to the organization, access and retrieval of information; hands-on experience in a variety of printed and electronic resources.

Name: Introduction to Information & Society
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Introduction to information as a concept and its changing roles, uses and meanings in contemporary global society.

Name: Introduction to Information Technologies
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and CSC 1100, EXST 2000 and ISDS 1100. Introduction to hardware, software, networking and telecommunications issues; use of application software, electronic databases and search engines.

Name: Information and Internet Environments
Desc: Introduction to concepts that underlies the Internet environments and related technologies; the effective and ethical use of digital information and communication; principles of information interaction and findability on the World Wide Web.

Name: Libraries in the Information Age
Desc: An overview of the historical and contemporary role of libraries and information centers in society and of career opportunities in today’s information age.

Name: Introduction to Library Public Services
Desc: An introduction to the principles, practice, and procedures of library services to the public, including effective public service, reference, circulation, and programming.

Name: Introduction to Technical Services
Desc: Introduction to the principles and practices of technical services, including cataloging, acquisitions, bindery, and serials control in libraries and information centers.

Name: Introduction to Collection Development
Desc: Overview of collection development principles and practices.

Name: Foundations of Digital Information Organization
Desc: Foundational concept rs in digital information including creation, organization, and representation in a variety of information environments.

Name: Advanced Library Research Methods and Materials
Desc: Advanced information literacy for college-level research; location, evaluation and use of information for research needs; the organization, access and retrieval of information; practical experience with resources in multiple formats.

Name: Collection Development for Children
Desc: Developing library collections for children ages birth to twelve and the uses of such literature in public and school libraries.

Name: Collection Development for Teens
Desc: Developing library collections for teens ages twelve to eighteen and the uses of such literature in public and school libraries.

Name: Collection Development of Non-Fiction
Desc: Developing collections of informational literature for children and adolescents, ages birth to eighteen years, and the uses of such literature in public and school libraries.

Name: Collection Development of Graphic Novels
Desc: Developing collections of graphic novels for children and adolescents, ages birth to eighteen years, and the uses of such literature in public and school libraries.

Name: Information Architecture
Desc: Introduction to basic concepts, principles, and practice of information architecture; tools and techniques such as labeling, navigating, searching and knowledge organization for information representation on the World Wide Web.

Name: Information Techniques for Social Media
Desc: Introduction to theories and practical approaches for analyzing social media data.

Name: Special Topics in Library & Information Science
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary with department approval.

Name: Information and Society
Desc: Information as a concept, and its uses and meanings in contemporary global society.

Name: Information Resources
Desc: Preparation for reference services; including the reference interview; selection and use of general, scholarly and specialized reference resources in various subject fields.

Name: Management of Information Organizations
Desc: Basic functions of management and their application to the operation of information organizations.

Name: Information Technologies and Systems
Desc: Identification of technology; information searching skills; evaluation of search systems.

Name: Understanding Research
Desc: Research methodologies applicable to library and information phenomena; definition of research problems, selection of inquiry tools and data collection; emphasis on evaluation of research.

Name: Organization of Information
Desc: Concepts and principles of information organization; methods and tools used for organizing information, including bibliographic control and metadata creation.

Name: Information Behavior
Desc: User-centered approaches to meeting information needs of individuals and communities; community analysis, user studies and user-centered design of services and resources.

Name: Evaluation of Information Systems
Desc: Evaluation of information system performance; systems analysis techniques; development and use of performance measures; strategies for improving system performance.

Name: Youth Services Librarianship
Desc: Administration and management of developmentally-appropriate public library services for children and teens, birth to 18 years.

Name: Adult Services in Public Libraries
Desc: Designing, planning, and providing library and information services to meet the educational, informational, and recreational needs of adults throughout their life span.

Name: Resources for Science and Technology
Desc: Information resources in major areas of pure and applied sciences.

Name: Sources of Government Information
Desc: Government publications as products of government activity and as sources of information.

Name: Business Information Resources
Desc: Information resources in major areas of business and economics.

Name: School Library Management
Desc: Management of libraries and information services in k-12 schools; emphasis on the roles and responsibilities of the school librarian.

Name: Academic Libraries
Desc: Study of libraries in higher education; their development, organization, financing and administration; human resources; collections; services; and futures.

Name: Special Libraries and Information Centers
Desc: Major types of special libraries; their purpose and function in business, government and other organizations; principles of administration; technical processing; reference services; special methods, routines and records.

Name: Health Sciences Information Centers
Desc: Administration, organization, function and services of health sciences libraries; collection development and reference emphasis on major print and electronic information resources.

Name: Public Libraries
Desc: Role of the public library in past and present American society; its relationship to the social and political communities.

Name: Introduction to Archival Theory, Principles & Practice
Desc: Introduction to the theory, principles and practices of the archival endeavor; particular focus on introducing the key archival functions of appraisal, accessioning, arrangement and description, preservation, reference and outreach.

Name: Human Computer Interaction
Desc: Study of interactions between humans and information systems, leading to more effective system design and evaluation; human cognition, user modeling, system design approaches, evaluation methods.

Name: Digital Libraries
Desc: Current activities, models, methods and tools for digital library creation and support; theoretical and practical aspects of digital library creation, using a variety of formats and approaches.

Name: Information Technology and Public Policy
Desc: Examines the impact of information technology and public policies on economic, social and political systems; focuses on major public policies related to information technologies within the United States and selected countries.

Name: Preservation Management of Physical Records
Desc: Study of preservation as a management function, highlighting causes of deterioration of print and non-print collections, as well as policies and practices that ensure their maximum usable life, and disaster planning.

Name: Introduction to Digital Curation
Desc: Introduction to archiving digital materials and the technological, ethical, and legal issues they routinely present to the archivist; includes characteristics of “good” digital materials and the role of metadata in creating and maintaining them, as well as the configuration of a trustworthy digital archival repository, and the tools and policies needed to create and maintain one.

Name: Preservation and Digitization of Audiovisual Materials
Desc: Introduction to the concepts and basic techniques for preservation and digitization of moving image and recorded audio materials.

Name: Management of Knowledge-Based Assets in Organizations
Desc: Analysis of the nature and uses of knowledge-based assets in organizations; systems for managing knowledge-based assets will be considered in the context of institutions’ overall information ecology; examination of the role of librarians and information professionals in organizing and providing knowledge-based assets.

Name: Website Design and Management
Desc: Design, produce, and manage effective websites; understanding of the World Wide Web environment and related technologies.

Name: Competitive Intelligence
Desc: Introduction to basic concepts and methods of competitive intelligence; fundamental skills and techniques to collect, analyze and distribute information about competitors and competitive environment.

Name: Principles of Records Management
Desc: Application of systematic and scientific controls to recorded information; life-cycle concept, legal requirements and implications of technology, as well as records inventory, appraisal, classification, retention and protection.

Name: Abstracting and Indexing
Desc: Principles of abstracting and indexing for print and electronic environments; controlled vocabulary and thesaurus development; manual and computerized abstracting and indexing techniques; effectiveness of abstracting and indexing methods.

Name: Introduction to Cataloging and Classification
Desc: Principles underlying description, subject analysis, classification of library resources and authority control; current national standard cataloging rules, Library of Congress Subject Headings, Dewey Decimal Classification, Library of Congress Classification, and MARC (machine readable cataloging) formats are emphasized.
Reqs: or coreq: LIS 7010 or permission of instructor

Name: Advanced Cataloging and Classification
Desc: Detailed analysis of cataloging and classification of special resources, including serials, electronic and cartographic resources, kits, music, manuscripts, realia, including formatting of bibliographic representations; intensive survey of conceptual foundations of descriptive and subject metadata.

Name: Information Retrieval Systems
Desc: See CSC 7481.

Name: Information Governance
Desc: Introduction to basic concepts, principles, strategies, and best practices of information governance.

Name: E-Discovery
Desc: An overview of processes, principles, and issues about e-discovery; introduction to ways, technologies, tools, and platforms used in identifying and handling electronic evidence for civil and criminal cases.

Name: History & Theory of Cultural Heritage Institutions
Desc: Socio-cultural history and theory of libraries, archives, museums and other cultural heritage institutions.

Name: Seminar in Archival Appraisal
Desc: Appraisal and selection of archival materials from both a theoretical and a practical perspective. Extensive reading in the archival literature to form familiarity with the evolution of appraisal theory and current practices in the field.

Name: Advanced Seminar in Archival Studies
Desc: Advanced investigation of contemporary archival topics from a theoretical and applied perspective.

Name: Archival Arrangement & Description
Desc: Development of the intellectual framework and critical evaluation skills necessary for the arrangement and description of archival collections.

Name: Introduction to Museum Management
Desc: Introduction to the purpose, functions, organization and management of museums.

Name: The Art and Practice of Library Storytelling
Desc: Role of storytelling as a form of communication; preparation and presentation of stories for all age groups; planning story programs.

Name: Information Literacy Instruction
Desc: Theories, techniques, strategies and current practice for teaching the effective and efficient use of academic, school, public and special library resources.

Name: Special Topics in Library & Information Science
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 15 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Sources of Music Study & Research
Desc: See MUS 7600.

Name: Internship in Library & Information Science
Desc: of LIS courses and permission of instructor. Preparation for course begins semester prior to registration. 120 hrs. per semester at field site. Experience in management, provision of services, and/or systems development.

Name: Directed Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit.

Name: Freshman Seminar
Desc: Open to freshmen only.
