Provides understanding of underlying principles of detection systems used in radiation therapy, radiological imaging and health physics.
Reqs: PHYS 3098 or equivalent; consent of instructor

Name: Radiation Detection Laboratory
Desc: 3 hrs. lab. laboratory exercises covering fundamental principles of radiation detection systems and data analysis techniques used for radiation measurements in radiation therapy, radiological imaging and medical health physics.

Name: Special Problems in Medical Physics and Health Physics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Theoretical or experimental problems involving the application of medical physics and health physics technology.
Reqs: thorough knowledge of mathematics, science and engineering related to the topic or proposed problem and consent of instructor

Name: Seminar
Desc: Course may be repeated on audit basis only. Elective seminar especially for undergraduate minors in nuclear science and undergraduate majors in physics and astronomy with a concentration in medical physics.

Name: Radiation Research Technology and Methods
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Practical experience and skills for measurement and calculation of radiation dose; dose measurements with ion chamber and diode; introduction to treatment planning systems; beam modeling based on Monte Carlo and deterministic algorithms; data analysis methods in support of research and clinical radiation service; statistical analysis of data; introduction to data privacy and HIPAA compliance.

Name: Advanced Medical Imaging Physics
Desc: Topics related to advanced research and clinical imaging physics; theory of image formation; quantitative analysis of imaging systems by Fourier methods and QC/acceptance testing; Radon transform and theory of image reconstruction; tracer methodology for quantitative imaging.

Name: Radiobiology
Desc: Topics in radiobiology including: introductory cell biology and cellular organization; effects of ionizing radiation on cellular, molecular, and organ systems; radiosensitivity, repair, and mediation of radiobiological effects; acute vs. late effects; radiation risks; topics specific to radiation medicine; effects of alternative radiation and non-radiation therapies.

Name: Clinical Principles of Radiation Therapy
Desc: Open only to students currently enrolled in the Master of Science in Medical Physics and Health Physics program or the PhD in Physics (Medical Physics concentration) program. Introduction by practicing radiation oncologists to the evolution of radiation therapy, general oncology considerations, tumor radiobiology, non-intentional effects of radiation and altered fractionation. Discussion of tumor biopsy and behavior, normal tissue effects and treatment planning and delivery techniques for specific organ systems.

Name: Clinical Medical Physics Rotation
Desc: Open only for students currently enrolled in the Master of Science in Medical Physics and Health Physics program or the PhD in Physics (Medical Physics concentration) program. 12 hrs. clinic. Under the direction of clinical staff, introduction to clinical duties of the medical physicist in radiation therapy and radiology. Radiation therapy physics topics include treatment planning, delivery techniques and dosimetry for brachytherapy and external beam therapy. Radiological imaging physics topics include operation and quality assurance for CT, MRI, and PET imaging systems and radiation safety.

Name: Advanced Radiation Therapy Physics
Desc: Basic principles of clinical indications, radiation delivery, treatment planning, dose calculations, dose measurements and quality assurance for advanced treatment techniques used in radiation therapy (external beam electron, proton and photon therapy and internal brachytherapy).

Name: Advanced Clinical Radiation Therapy Physics Rotation
Desc: Open only for students currently enrolled in the Master of Science in Medical Physics and Health Physics program. Under the supervision of clinical medical physics staff, introduction to the planning, delivery and dosimetric aspects of advanced radiation therapy treatments such as brachytherapy, stereotactic radiosurgery, total skin electron therapy, intensity modulated radiotherapy and image guided radiotherapy and to the advanced physical practices of accelerator quality assurance and radiation therapy shielding design.

Name: Radiation Therapy Physics
Desc: Fundamental physical principles, operation of delivery equipment, treatment planning principles, methods of dose calculations, determination of irradiation time from dose prescription, dose measurements and quality assurance for external beam therapy (photons and electrons) and internal brachytherapy.

Name: Radiation Shielding and Accelerators
Desc: Practical concepts of structural shielding design, calculation and verification, including relevant professional guidelines and regulations; applicable to facilities for radiotherapy, diagnostic imaging, and nuclear medicine. Fundamental concepts of medical accelerators and radiation-producing equipment.

Name: Radiation Interactions and Transport
Desc: Photon, neutron and electron interactions and energy deposition, the Boltzmann equation, elementary analytical solutions; deterministic computational methods including spherical harmonics and discrete ordinates techniques; continuous slowing down and Fokker-Planck approximations.
Reqs: PHYS 2203 or equivalent, CSC 2262 or equivalent experience in computer programming

Name: Monte Carlo Simulation of Radiation Transport
Desc: Radiation transport simulation by the Monte Carlo method; phase-space tracking; dose response estimators, biasing methods; integral form of the Boltzmann equation; condensed-history method for charged particles; neutron, photon and electron transport calculations for shielding and medical physics applications.
Reqs: MEDP 7537 or consent of instructor, CSC 2262 or equivalent experience in computer programming

Name: Advanced Projects in Medical Physics and Health Physics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Medical physics or health physics projects that study particular aspects of radiation therapy, medical imaging or medical health physics.
Reqs: MEDP 4111 or MEDP 7331 and consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Topics in Medical Physics and Health Physics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced treatment of a specific area of medical physics or health physics technology of current interest.

Name: Seminar
Desc: Required every semester for degree candidates in medical physics and health physics. Only 1 sem. hr. of credit may be counted toward degree.

Name: Report Investigation
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs credit. Detailed investigation of a research problem or a technical design project.
Reqs: MEDP 4111 or MEDP 7331 and consent of instructor

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Principles of Management
Desc: [LCCN: CMGM 3103, 3313, Principles of Management (Upper Level), Human Resource Management (Upper Level)] Management functions, including planning, organizing, staffing/human resource management, leading/interpersonal influence and controlling in both domestic and international spheres.

Name: Independent Study: Advanced Management Topics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Independent research under direction of a faculty member.

Name: Business and Society
Desc: Open only to College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. Social roles of organizations whose primary function is the accumulation of profits; emphasis on current issues; historical development of business-society relationships.

Name: Management Internship
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Students, supervised by a management faculty member and an approved business executive, will follow a predetermined schedule of activities while working for a business firm. Hands-on experience in the fields of management, human resource management, organizational behavior, small business management, entrepreneurship, and administrative practices.
Reqs: junior or senior standing and permission of instructor

Name: Strategic Human Resource Management
Desc: The planning and implementation of HR policy at the strategic level of an organization, including recruitment, selection, development, maintenance and reward of employees; relationships with environment and employee associations.

Name: Negotiation and Dispute Resolution
Desc: In-depth examination of various theories and processes of negotiation and alternative forms of dispute resolution relevant to the broad spectrum of conflict problems faced by employees and managers. Designed to improve students’ knowledge and skills in the areas of workplace conflict management and negotiation.
Reqs: reserved for College of Business students; open to others with permission of department

Name: Organizational Behavior
Desc: Reserved for College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. Behavioral sciences applied to understanding human dynamics in organizations; focus on individual, interpersonal, group and intergroup behavior; impact of human behavior on organizational effectiveness.

Name: Strategic Management
Desc: Open only to E. J. Ourso College of Business students. Credit will not be given for both this course and MGT 3831. May be taken only during the final 30 hours of course work. Analyzing strategic situations and decision making based on these analyses to ensure the success of for-profit and non-profit organizations.
Reqs: MGT 3200 and MKT 3401 or MKT 3402, and credit or registration in FIN 3716

Name: HONORS: Strategically Managing Organizations
Desc: Same as MGT 3830, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and MGT 3830.

Name: Contemporary Topics in Management
Desc: Open only to College of Business students or with permission of department. May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary.  In-depth examination of contemporary issues in management theory and practice; emphasis on current topics of special interest or concern in management.

Name: Human Resource Analytics
Desc: Application of quantitative methods to contemporary issues and practices in human resources management; focus on logical reasoning, statistical analyses, interpretation and reporting.

Name: Employee Selection and Placement
Desc: Staffing requirements, recruitment strategies, development and validation of selection procedures, classification and placement of employees; problems associated with person-job matching; socialization of new employees.

Name: Compensation Administration
Desc: Quantitative and nonquantitative methods of job evaluation; wage level, wage structure, incentive plans; issues of employee compensation.

Name: Managing Across Cultures
Desc: Reserved for College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. Introduction to the basic principles of cross-cultural management. Students will examine both the theory and practice of international management concepts across three modules: (1) foundations of global business, (2) the role of culture, and (3) international organizational behavior and human resource management.

Name: International Strategic Management
Desc: Reserved for College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. This course examines how businesses approach managing organizations in the global context. Students will examine the mechanisms of globalizing for businesses, including the global integration of resources and capabilities and the level of national responsiveness to adapt to foreign market demands.

Name: Global Corporate Social Responsibility
Desc: Reserved for College of Business students; open to others with permission of department.  This course introduces students to the concept of social responsibilities of organizations, the ways they can “do well” by “doing good.” Students will examine some of the world’s most pressing issues, such as environmental concerns, economic inequality, or social problems, and how organizations charter new business strategies in which social responsibility plays an important role.

Name: Introduction to Labor Relations
Desc: Management’s response to organized labor in the workplace; emphasis on U.S. unionization development; government regulation of labor-management relations; union structure, political activity, collective bargaining and contract administration.
Reqs: open only to College of Business students; open to others with permission of department

Name: Legal Issues in Human Resource Management
Desc: An examination of the most significant laws and court rulings influencing companies’ employment practices; topics include: anti-discrimination statutes, affirmative action, commonly committed workplace torts, occupational safety and health laws, workers’ compensation and wrongful termination.

Name: Understanding Management Mistakes and Failures
Desc: Reserved for College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. In-depth examination of managerial decision making, mistakes, and organizational failures. Emphasis on case studies to demonstrate course concepts.

Name: Strategic Leadership
Desc: Reserved for College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. This course examines basic principles of strategic leadership. Students will examine both the theory and practice of strategic thinking across three modules: (1) foundations of strategic leadership, (2) the role of choice and behavior, and (3) applying strategic business models to improve leadership and management skills in the self and others.

Name: Managing Change in Organizations
Desc: Open only to College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. This course examines the dynamics of change in organizations. Students are exposed to issues confronting managers during implementation, e.g. expectation setting, resource allocations, politics, and timing.

Name: Development of Management Thought
Desc: Origin and growth of managerial concepts and topics and associated research methodologies.

Name: Seminar in Contemporary Management Topics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Human Resources
Desc: Role of human resource managers; their relationships with employees, the external environment and top management.

Name: Organizational Behavior
Desc: Behavior of people within organizations; the environment within which organizations function; components of the behavioral unit; processes, interactions and outputs of organizational behavior.

Name: Strategic Management of Health Care Organizations
Current Issues in Strategic Management
Desc: Contemporary issues in strategic management theory and practice; emphasis on field projects that provide top-management problem-solving experience.

Name: Research Issues in Strategic Management
Desc: Strategic planning; issues including environmental scanning, goal formulation, strategic implementation, control and evaluation in successful organizations.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Research Methods in Management
Desc: Theory building; measurement reliability and validity; significance testing and statistical power; sampling strategies and missing data; multi-level and cross-level issues; research ethics.

Name: Pre-dissertation Research
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for credit.

Name: Proseminar in Management
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Required of all inresident PhD students. Contemporary research and critical issues in management.

Name: Seminar in Advanced Business Problems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Directed work in advanced topics.

Name: Rifle and Pistol Marksmanship
Desc: Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. lab. Restricted to freshmen and sophomores or permission of instructor. Rifle and pistol safety; breathing techniques; zeroing; physical and mental conditioning; sighting and aiming; standard firing positions; practical application on indoor firing range.

Name: Leadership and Personal Development
Desc: Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. 1 hr. lecture; 1.5 hrs. lab. Introduction to the personal challenges and competencies critical for effective leadership. Focus on developing basic knowledge and comprehension of Army leadership dimensions while gaining an understanding of the ROTC program, its purpose in the Army and its advantages for students.

Name: Intro to Tactical Leadership
Desc: Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. 1 hr. lecture; 1.5 hrs. lab. Overview of leadership fundamentals, including setting direction, problem-solving, listening, presenting briefs, providing feedback and effective writing skills.

Name: Army Physical Fitness Training
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 sem. hrs. of credit. Open to all LSU students. Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment.

Name: Innovative Team Leadership
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 1.5 hrs. lab. Explores the dimensions of creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles by studying historical case studies and engaging in interactive student exercises.
Reqs: MILS 1011 and MILS 1012 or permission of instructor; Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment

Name: Foundations of Tactical Leadership
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 1.5 hrs. lab. Examines the challenges of leading tactical teams in the complex contemporary operating environment (COE). Continued study of the theoretical basis of the Army leadership framework explores the dynamics of adaptive leadership in the context of military operations.
Reqs: MILS 2161 or permission of instructor; Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment

Name: Adaptive Tactical Leadership
Desc: Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Study, practice and evaluation of adaptive team leadership skills as presented with the demands of the ROTC Leader Development and Assessment Course (LDAC). Challenging scenarios related to small unit tactical operations are used to develop self awareness and critical thinking skills.

Name: Leadership in Changing Environments
Desc: Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Study, practice and evaluation of adaptive team leadership skills as presented with the demands of the ROTC Leader Development and Assessment Course (LDAC). Challenging scenarios related to small unit tactical operations are used to develop self awareness and critical thinking skills.

Name: ROTC Advanced Camp
Desc: Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. To receive academic credit, student must enroll in summer session prior to departure for Advanced Camp. Five week course conducted at an Army post with instructors and cadets representing ROTC programs from the United States, Puerto Rico and Guam. Intense leadership application and training in military skills; oral and written orders, light infantry tactics, weapons systems and confidence building events.

Name: Developing Adaptive Leaders
Desc: Not for graduate credit. Senior standing required. Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Development of proficiency in planning, executing and assessing complex operations, functioning as a member of a staff and providing performance feedback to subordinates. Lessons on military justice and personnel processes prepare students to make the transition to becoming an Army officer.

Name: Leadership in a Complex World
Desc: Not for graduate credit. Senior standing required. Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Explores the dynamics of leading in the complex situations of current military operations in the Contemporary Operating Environment (COE). Case studies, scenarios and exercises are also used to prepare students to face the complex ethical and practical demand of leading as a commissioned officer in the U.S. Army.

Name: Special Topics in Military History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Non-immigrant aliens require approval from their governments prior to enrollment.

Name: Principles of Marketing
Desc: [LCCN: CMKT 3003, Principles of Marketing (Upper Level)] An honors course, MKT 3402, is also available. Credit will not be given for both this course and MKT 3402. Lecture-discussion, case analysis, marketing-simulation game; the field of marketing; marketing environment, functions, and institutional structure at a macro level; marketing strategy and policies at a micro level; problems of cost and productivity; view points of society, consumer and marketing manager.

Name: HONORS: Principles of Marketing
Desc: Same as MKT 3401, with special emphasis for honors students and marketing majors.

Name: Sports Marketing
Desc: Application of marketing concepts to sports and leisure activities; emphasis on planning and strategy development.

Name: Consumer Analysis and Behavior
Desc: Open only to marketing majors; open to others with permission of the department. Dynamics of consumer markets; their significance to marketing executives; identification and measurement of market segments; analysis of their behavioral patterns as a basis for marketing strategy.

Name: Marketing Research
Desc: Open only to College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. Formulation of marketing policies; theories, concepts, and methodology involved in applying research to marketing problems.

Name: Marketing Communication: Promotion
Desc: Nature and contributions of personal selling and advertising to the firm’s problems of demand stimulation; concepts related to integration and organization of promotional effort to facilitate communication programs for products and/or services.

Name: Professional Selling
Desc: Open only to marketing majors; open to others with permission of department. Communication theory and sales principles needed for successful sales career; buyer behavior and sales tactics; sales strategies; communication in buyer-seller relationships.

Name: Retailing Management
Desc: Store organization, operation and management; retail method of inventory; problems connected with retail buying and selling.

Name: Digital Marketing Fundamentals
Desc: This course provides students broad technological marketing knowledge by focusing on Internet, social media and mobile marketing techniques.

Name: Digital Promotional Strategy
Desc: Introduction to promotional strategies designed to connect brands and consumers, including search engine websites, premium publisher websites, email marketing, over-the-top (OTT) TV, streaming radio and podcasts, virtual experiences, social media, mobile marketing, and digital out-of-home (dOOH), and that compliment non-digital channels.

Name: Marketing Tools Fundamentals
Desc: Coverage of current and emerging computer-based and other tools used by marketing practitioners.
Reqs: credit or registration in MKT 3401 and permission of department

Name: Marketing Analytics I
Desc: Introduction to marketing analytics with a focus on the processes, techniques, and tools used in the acquisition, management, and mining of marketing data.

Name: Sales Management
Desc: Open only to marketing majors; open to others with permission of department. Principles of sales planning and control; organizing sales departments, developing territories, motivating sales persons and controlling sales operations.

Name: Advanced Digital Marketing
Desc: An in-depth look at the planning, implementation and evaluation of a digital marketing campaign, with an emphasis on social media tools and platforms.

Name: International Marketing
Desc: Global marketing environment and analytical processes; global marketing as all-encompassing (import-export, joint ventures, foreign subsidiaries, licensing, management contracts); marketing systems in various countries; strategies for international and multinational operations.

Name: Internship in Marketing
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Primarily for seniors in marketing. On-the-job experience in approved marketing positions.
Reqs: senior standing or permission of department

Name: Digital Sales
Desc: This course focuses on how digital technologies augment the activities and problems of customer-facing, professional sales people. We will discuss the sales profession, customer relationship management software, sales technologies, sales analytics, sales enablement tools, and digital communications throughout the selling process.

Name: Marketing Management
Desc: Open only to College of Business students; open to others with permission of department. Analytical principles used in development of strategies for solving marketing problems; policy areas of product, price, channels and promotion integrated in development of the firm’s total marketing effort.

Name: Independent Study: Advanced Marketing Problems
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary.

Name: Professional Sales Practicum
Desc: Open only to marketing majors; open to others with permission of department. Pass/fail grading. Designed for students who want to gain real-world sales experience by preparing students for professional sales competitions.
Reqs: MKT 3401, MKT 3427, and permission of department

Name: Professional Sales Internship
Desc: Open only to marketing majors; open to others with permission of department. Pass/fail grading. The internship requires departmental approval of the sales content of the internship. Designed for students who want to gain real-world sales experience through a sales internship.
Reqs: MKT 3401, MKT 3427, and permission of department

Name: Marketing Analytics Practicum
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Designed for students who want to gain real-world experience in marketing analytics via group projects using company data.

Name: Marketing Analytics Internship
Desc: Pass-fail grading. The internship requires departmental approval of the marketing analytics content of the internship. Designed for students who want to gain real-world experience through a marketing analytics internship.

Name: Services Marketing
Desc: Developing, pricing, distributing and promoting the service; control of quality of customer encounters through service automation and/or employee selection and training; place of marketing in service organization structure; strategic implications of structure of service industries.

Name: Entrepreneurial Marketing and Sales
Desc: This course will look at the role of marketing in entrepreneurial ventures and the role of entrepreneurship in marketing efforts of all firms. Attention will be devoted to understanding the common mistakes entrepreneurs make when it comes to marketing and how to sell an idea/product in an entrepreneurship environment.
Reqs: ENTR 3111 and MKT 3401 and Entrepreneurship Minor or Entrepreneurship Concentration or permission of instructor

Name: Marketing Analytics II
Desc: Advanced treatment of marketing analytics with a focus on data analysis, visualization, and data-driven decision making.

Name: Marketing Tools Foundations and Applications
Desc: Coverage of current and emerging tools used by marketing practitioners, including customer tracking systems, market segmentation tools, market share analysis, competitive intelligence, applications to real and/or simulated market situations.
Reqs: credit or registration in BADM 7100 or equivalent

Name: Customer Decision-Making and Brand Marketing Strategy
Desc: Treatment of key elements of consumer decision-making with emphasis on formulation of brand marketing strategy based on consumer behavior models, constructs and information.

Name: Marketing Research and Brand Analysis
Desc: Applications of marketing research methods such as qualitative research techniques, marketing surveys, marketing experiments and brand analysis techniques.

Name: Global Marketing Issues and Strategies
Desc: Examination of marketing strategies and tactics available to organizations Seeking to compete with global markets.

Name: Brand Marketing Strategy
Desc: Coverage of brand marketing strategy formulation, including market and competitor analysis, plus resource allocation; emphasis on issues involved in marketing strategy formulation and implementation.

Name: Topics in Advanced Marketing Management
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Survey of marketing management areas such as distribution channels, pricing and product management.

Name: Marketing Strategy
Desc: Design, implementation and evaluation; corporate marketing models; demand forecasting; marketing programming; product, price, promotion and distribution policies; information systems; marketing audit; application of economic, quantitative, and behavioral tools as strategic aids to marketing management; model-building approach used to demonstrate tool applications in product, price, promotion and distribution strategies.

Name: Seminar in Advanced Marketing Problems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Applications of Marketing Theory
Desc: Marketing theory development and testing; theory operationalization and refinement.

Name: Fundamentals of Structural Equation Modeling
Desc: Synthesis of theory, content area and methodology in marketing through the study of modeling; modeling phenomena, functional forms and analytical techniques of path analysis, simultaneous equation systems, and structural equation modeling.

Name: Advanced Structural Equation Modeling
Desc: Synthesis of theory, methodology, and phenomena through the use of advanced structural equation modeling techniques, such as longitudinal SEM, latent growth models, nonlinear models, latent class models, and multilevel SEM.

Name: Advanced Marketing Research Techniques
Desc: Advanced designs and techniques applied to marketing research; theory and assumptions of analytical methods; marketing applications; use of computer programs; marketing strategy; interpretations of empirical results.

Name: Advanced Seminar in Consumer Behavior
Desc: Open only to doctoral students. Theoretical, conceptual and methodological issues for selected topics in this area.

Name: Seminar in Marketing Theory and Experimental Methods
Desc: Nature and importance of theory in marketing, interplay of theory and research methods; validity and implications in marketing and consumer research; experimental and quasi-experimental design; pluralism in marketing and consumer research.

Name: Pre-dissertation Research
Desc: May be repeated for credit.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.

Name: Piano Ensemble
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 2 sem. hrs. for degree credit.

Name: Woodwind Chamber Music
Desc: No description provided

Name: Brass Chamber Music
Desc: No description provided

Name: String (or Piano and Strings) Chamber Music
Desc: No description provided

Name: Collegium Musicum
Desc: An early music ensemble, focusing on music of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Emphasis on issues in performance practice, ornamentation, and notation.

Name: Percussion Ensemble
Desc: No description provided

Name: Marimba Ensemble
Desc: No description provided

Name: Harp Ensemble
Desc: No description provided

Name: Gospel Choir
Desc: No description provided

Name: LSU Tiger Glee Club
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: LSU Chorale
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement. Open to non-music majors with consent of instructor. A large ensemble class in collaborative singing, it prioritizes vocal development and artistic expression. The ensemble accepts soprano and alto voice types of all genders.

Name: University Chorus
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Chamber Choir
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: A Cappella Choir
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Opera Chorus
Desc: No description provided

Name: Tiger Marching Band
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Wind Ensemble
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Symphonic Band
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Jazz Band
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Symphonic Winds
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Chamber Jazz
Desc: No description provided

Name: Philharmonia
Desc: No description provided

Name: Symphony Orchestra
Desc: Satisfies the major ensemble requirement.

Name: Experimental Music & Digital Media Ensemble
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 credit hours. An experimental music ensemble that merges performance with technology; performing new compositions, recent works for laptop or mobile orchestra, and improvisatory music.

Name: Voice Class
Desc: Open to nonmusic majors with consent of instructor. Group instruction in voice production.

Name: Voice Class
Desc: Open to nonmusic majors with consent of instructor. Group instruction in voice production.

Name: In Concert
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 hrs. of credit. 2 hrs. lab. An elective course open to all university students; designed to develop proper audience etiquette and to expose students to a wide variety of music performances.

Name: Diction for Singers I
Desc: Required of all BM and BME majors with a voice concentration. 2 hr. lab. Entry level course covering pronunciation of Italian and French for singing, utilizing the International Phonetic Alphabet System (IPA).

Name: Diction for Singers II
Desc: Required of all BM and BME majors with a voice concentration. 2 hr. lab. Entry level course covering pronunciation of German and English for singing, utilizing the International Phonetic Alphabet System (IPA).

Name: Performance Craft for Singers
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. Preparatory for MUS 4240. Required of all voice performance majors. Workshop exploring performing artistry for the singer through individual coaching and class exercises such as movement, dance and improvisation; stage terms, stage deportment and stage etiquette; performance anxiety.

Name: Piano Class
Desc: Open only to nonmusic majors. Instruction for the beginner and lower intermediate student.

Name: Piano Class
Desc: Open only to nonmusic majors. Instruction for the beginner and lower intermediate student.

Name: Group Piano I
Desc: Open only to music majors. Required of all non-keyboard music majors who do not meet proficiency requirements. Functional use of the piano.

Name: Group Piano II
Desc: Open only to music majors. Required of all non-keyboard music majors who do not meet proficiency requirements. Functional use of the piano.
Reqs: Grade of “C” or better in MUS 1130 or successful placement

Name: Group Piano III
Desc: Open only to music majors. Required of all non-keyboard music majors who do not meet proficiency requirements. Functional use of the piano.
Reqs: Grade of “C” or better in MUS 1131 or successful placement

Name: Group Piano IV
Desc: Open only to music majors. Required of all non-keyboard music majors who do not meet proficiency requirements. Functional use of the piano.
Reqs: Grade of “C” or better in MUS 1132 or successful placement

Name: Defining the Artist
Desc: Majors only. Focuses on the role of the artist in society, including musicians’ roles in arts advocacy, public funding, and arts education, and the myriad of career opportunities available within the arts.

Name: American Popular Music
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Open to non-music majors only. Surveys the history of American popular music from artistic, cultural, political, and economic perspectives.

Name: Recital Hour
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated. Weekly student recital and music seminar.

Name: Foundations of Music Study
Desc: A concise survey of the elements of aural and written music theory, musicianship and related skills. Intended to prepare majors and minors in the School of Music for Theory I and subsequent courses.

Name: The Musician in Society
Desc: Majors or Minors only, or permission of department.  A survey of diverse roles occupied by musicians and their collaborators in societies from the past to the present, the remote to the familiar, and the global to the local. The course fosters a humanistic engagement with the musical lives of others while encouraging students to consider the contemporary opportunities afforded by a degree in the field of music. As an introduction to academic coursework at LSU, the course also cultivates practical skills necessary for success at the university level, from regular attendance and note taking to critical thinking and clear writing.

Name: Introduction to Music History I
Desc: Fundamental elements of music from historical and cultural perspectives; introduction to historical trends, musical genres, major composers and score reading; cultivation of studying and writing skills.
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in MUS 1740 is prerequisite for MUS 1741

Name: Introduction to Music History II
Desc: Fundamental elements of music from historical and cultural perspectives; introduction to historical trends, musical genres, major composers and score reading; cultivation of studying and writing skills.
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in MUS 1740 is prerequisite for MUS 1741

Name: Music Appreciation
Desc: [LCCN: CMUS 1013, Music Appreciation] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Primarily for nonmusic majors. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 1755. The art of music, with emphasis on listening skills; a nontechnical approach to understanding vocabulary and materials of music; correlation of musical literature with other disciplines in the humanities.

Name: HONORS: Music Appreciation
Desc: Primarily for qualified students not majoring in music. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 1751. Study of the musical art emphasizing the development of critical listening skills and a non-technical, but thorough musical vocabulary; additional emphasis placed on the historical correlation of both vernacular and art music to corresponding developments in the other fine arts disciplines.

Name: Rudiments of Music
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Not open to music majors. The grammar of music, including basic notation and elementary construction leading to a study of tonal harmony.

Name: Technology in Music Education
Desc: Music majors only. Introduction to the uses of technology in school music programs; includes discussion of the role and application of technology in K-12 school music settings.

Name: History of Jazz
Desc: [LCCN: CMUS 1023, Jazz Appreciation] Open to nonmusic majors. Survey of the evolution of jazz and jazz styles.

Name: Diction for Singers III
Desc: Required of all voice performance majors. 2 hr. lab. Advanced study of phonetics and pronunciation for German songs; utilizing the International Phonetic Alphabet; pronunciation concepts supported by recitation and performance of representative song repertoire.

Name: Diction for Singers IV
Desc: Required of all voice performance majors. 2 hr. lab. Advanced study of phonetics and pronunciation for French songs; utilizing the International Phonetic Alphabet; pronunciation concepts supported by recitation and performance of representative song repertoire.

Name: Survey of Music History I
Desc: Music of Western civilization to ca. 1750.
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in MUS 1705

Name: Survey of Music History II
Desc: Music of Western civilization from ca. 1750 to the present.
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in MUS 2053

Name: Instrumental and Vocal Techniques
Desc: May be repeated for credit. For prospective secondary school teachers of music. Woodwind and brass techniques for instrumental majors, and instrumental and choral techniques for vocal majors may be taken for 2 hrs. of credit; percussion, strings and voice for instrumental major may be taken for 1 hr. of credit only.

Name: Jazz Fundamentals for Teachers
Desc: For music education majors only. Basic jazz techniques and concepts necessary for jazz ensemble and jazz combo instruction in secondary school settings.

Name: Music Theory I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 2630. For music majors and minors only. 3 hrs. lecture. Basic tonal harmony and voice leading, phrase structure, analysis of music form and genre; sight-singing and keyboard harmony skills, melodic and harmonic dictation.
Reqs: Passage of placement exam or grade of C or better in MUS 1701

Name: Aural Skills I
Desc: 2 hrs. lab. Beginning Musicianship training. Sight singing, melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic dictation, conducting rudiments, keyboard harmony, and ensemble exercises.
Reqs: For music majors and minors only

Name: Music Theory II
Desc: For music majors or minors only. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 2632. Basic tonal harmony and voice leading, phrase structure, analysis of musical form and genre, sight-singing and keyboard harmony skills, melodic and harmonic dictation.
Reqs: A grade of C or better in MUS 2620 or MUS 2630, or permission of department

Name: Aural Skills II
Desc: For music majors and minors only. 2 hrs. lab. Musicianship training. Sight singing, melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic dictation, conducting rudiments, keyboard harmony, and ensemble exercises.
Reqs: Successful completion of MUS 2621 or placement exam

Name: HONORS: Music Theory I
Desc: For music majors and minors only. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 2620.

Name: HONORS: Music Theory II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 2622.
Reqs: Passing grade of C or better in MUS 2620, MUS 2630, or permission of department

Name: Intro to Music Technology
Desc: Introduction to contemporary technologies for music composition, performance, and publishing.

Name: Music Theory I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 2733. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Basic tonal harmony and voice leading, phrase structure, analysis of musical form and genre; sight-singing and keyboard harmony skills, melodic and harmonic dictation.
Reqs: Passage of placement exam or grade of “C” or better in MUS 1701

Name: Music Theory II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and  MUS 2734. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Basic tonal harmony and voice leading, phrase structure, analysis of musical form and genre; sight-singing and keyboard harmony skills, melodic and harmonic dictation.
Reqs: Grade of “C” or better in MUS 2731

Name: HONORS: Music Theory I
Desc: Same as MUS 2731, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 2731.

Name: HONORS: Music Theory II
Desc: Same as MUS 2732, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 2732.

Name: Introduction to Computer Music
Desc: Introduction to techniques and technologies in computer music; principles of digital audio, sound design, music synthesis, digital audio workstations, and sound art composition with an emphasis on musique concrète.

Name: Jazz Improvisation I
Desc: Introductory performance course in jazz improvisation; emphasis on its theoretical basis.

Name: Jazz Improvisation II
Desc: Continuation of MUS 2751.

Name: Vocal Pedagogy
Desc: hrs. of applied voice study. Principles and processes of voice production; psychology of teaching and studying singing; beginning comparative pedagogy; vocal repertoire for the beginning singer.

Name: Group Piano V
Desc: 2 hrs. lab. Functional keyboard skills for rehearsing and accompanying vocal ensembles and soloists; includes sight-reading, score reading, accompanying, playing vocal warm-ups and coaching piano/vocal ensembles.

Name: Group Piano VI
Desc: 2 hrs. lab. Functional keyboard skills for rehearsing and accompanying vocal ensembles and soloists; includes sight-reading, score reading, accompanying, playing vocal warm-ups and coaching piano/vocal ensembles.

Name: Preparing the Artist
Desc: Majors only.  Focuses on skills required to create careers as entrepreneurs such as self-promotion, career development, media, networking, and business and marketing.

Name: Music Theory III
Desc: For music majors or minors only. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 3630. Advanced tonal harmony; continued form and genre study; post-tonal compositional techniques; basic scoring and score reading; continued mastery of relevant musicianship skills.
Reqs: A grade of C or better in MUS 2622 or MUS 2632

Name: Aural Skills III
Desc: For music majors or minors only. 2 hrs. lab. Intermediate musicianship training. Sight singing, melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic dictation, conducting rudiments, keyboard harmony, and ensemble exercises.
Reqs: Successful completion of MUS 2623 or placement exam

Name: Music Theory IV
Desc: For music majors or minors only. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 3632. Advanced tonal harmony; continued form and genre study; post-tonal compositional techniques; basic scoring and score reading; continued mastery of relevant musicianship skills.
Reqs: A grade of C or better in MUS 3620 or MUS 3630

Name: Aural Skills IV
Desc: For music majors or minors only. 2 hrs. lab. Intermediate musicianship training. Sight singing, melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic dictation, conducting rudiments, keyboard harmony, and ensemble exercises.
Reqs: Successful completion of MUS 3621 or placement exam

Name: HONORS: Music Theory III
Desc: Same as MUS 3620, with special honors emphasis for qualified students.  Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 3620.

Name: HONORS: Music Theory IV
Desc: Same as MUS 3622, with a special honors emphasis for qualified students.  Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 3622.

Name: Theory Survey
Desc: Admission by placement examination. Written and aural aspects of theory.

Name: Overview of Western Music History
Desc: Survey of Western classical music from the Middle Ages to the present day.

Name: Music Theory III
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 3733. Advanced tonal harmony; continued form and genre study; post-tonal compositional techniques; basic scoring and score reading; continued mastery of relevant musicianship skills.
Reqs: grade of “C”or better in MUS 2732 is prerequisite for MUS 3731

Name: Music Theory IV
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 3734. Advanced tonal harmony; continued form and genre study; post-tonal compositional techniques; basic scoring and score reading; continued mastery of relevant musicianship skills.
Reqs: grade of “C”or better in MUS 3731 is prerequisite for MUS 3732

Name: HONORS: Music Theory III
Desc: Same as MUS 3731, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and MUS 3731.

Name: HONORS: Music Theory IV
Desc: Same as MUS 3732, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and  MUS 3732.

Name: Choral Literature and Conducting I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Elements of conducting choral groups.

Name: Choral Literature and Conducting II
Desc: Continuation of MUS 3749. 1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. lab.

Name: Organ Literature, History and Design
Desc: Evolution and development of the organ and its literature; development of keyboard (organ) forms, techniques and idiomatic styles; organ mechanism and action; tonal structure; design problems.

Name: Organ Literature, History and Design
Desc: Evolution and development of the organ and its literature; development of keyboard (organ) forms, techniques and idiomatic styles; organ mechanism and action; tonal structure; design problems.

Name: Instrumental Conducting I
Desc: Elements of conducting instrumental groups.

Name: Instrumental Conducting II
Desc: Continuation of MUS 3771. 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab.

Name: Introduction to Stage Techniques
Desc: Participants will develop the technical skills needed to successfully prepare, rehearse and perform a stage production. Exercises incorporate stage blocking, stage combat, dance, dialogues, recitatives, ensembles and movement to music.

Name: Directed Studies in Music
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. MUS 3997 cannot be used in lieu of a required course in any School of Music curriculum.
Reqs: consent of departmental faculty concerned and dean of the School of Music

Name: Musical Theatre Singing: Technique and Repertoire
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 hrs. of credit. 1 hr. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Musical theatre singing style and repertoire; emphasis on vocal and stage performance of literature appropriate to the singer.

Name: Introduction to the Alexander Technique
Desc: 2 hrs. lab. Employing the basic principles of the Alexander Technique; students will begin the process of psycho-physical re-education through experimental movement exercises and hands-on work with the instructor.

Name: Piano Accompanying
Desc: Course may be repeated for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Open to pianists by permission of instructor. Individual projects in principles and practical applications of accompanying.

Name: Reed Making for Double Reed Majors
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 sem. hrs. but with a max. of 2 hrs. credit towards any degree. Recommended for all oboe and bassoon majors. 1 hr. lab. Principles of double-reed making with development of individual skill and application of reed making and finishing.

Name: String Literature
Desc: hrs. of applied string instrument study or consent of instructor. May be repeated once. Independent study in solo and ensemble literature for stringed instruments.

Name: Woodwind Literature
Desc: hrs. of applied wind instrument study or consent of the instructor. May be repeated once. Independent study in solo and ensemble literature for woodwind instruments.

Name: Brass Literature and Pedagogy
Desc: hrs. of applied brass instrument study or consent of instructor. May be repeated once. Independent study in solo and ensemble literature and methods and materials for instruction in brass instruments.

Name: Percussion Literature and Pedagogy
Desc: hrs. of applied percussion instrument study or consent of instructor. May be repeated once. Independent study in solo and ensemble literature and methods and materials for instruction in percussion instruments.

Name: Woodwind Instrument Pedagogy
Desc: hrs. of applied wind instrument study or consent of instructor. Independent studies in methods and materials for instruction in woodwind instruments.

Name: Music Technology I
Desc: For majors only or by consent of instructor. 3 hrs. lab. Fundamentals of computer applications for educational uses in music; historical and social contexts of computer development; fundamentals in computer systems; configuring hardware; survey of commercial music software; and use of software applications.

Name: Opera Theater
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 hrs. of credit toward the master’s degree. Admission by audition. May not be taken concurrently with MUS 9007. Students must schedule this course both fall and spring semesters, unless permission to schedule only one semester is granted by the instructor. 4 hrs. lab plus individual coaching. Techniques of the musical theater; preparation and perfor-mance of operatic scenes and complete operas.

Name: Acting for Opera
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Techniques of acting for opera; training in audition skills, stage movement, state makeup and vocal and dramatic techniques for operatic roles.

Name: Song Literature
Desc: Study of the traditions and repertoire of German Lied from Beethoven through the Romantic period as well as the repertoire of French mélodie from Berlioz to Poulenc.

Name: Song Literature II
Desc: The art song repertoire from the French máelodie to contemporary English and American song.

Name: Orchestral Repertoire for Instrumentalists
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit. Standard orchestral excerpt repertoire for instrumentalists, including: preparation; score study and analysis; specialized practice techniques; and audition strategies. Emphasis on the performance of orchestral excerpts.

Name: Senior Project
Desc: Majors only. A project of a student’s musical studies. Project should have a public component and may include a lecture-recital, community project, research presentation, or other creative project, as advised by the student’s Advisory Committee.

Name: Music in Religious Services
Desc: The social, cultural, and theological roles that music has played and continues to play within a variety of religious traditions. Survey of the practical ways in which music integrated into Christian liturgical traditions and services, including studies in hymnology and psalmody.

Name: Organ Practicum
Desc: MUS 4701 is prerequisite for 4702. Techniques of service playing; techniques and materials of organ pedagogy.

Name: Advanced Aural Skills
Desc: Concentrated work in sight singing with a special emphasis upon skills needed for professional activity in performance, conducting and composition.
Reqs: a grade of “C”or better in MUS 3620 or MUS 3630

Name: Advanced Form and Analysis
Desc: Complex forms and harmonic techniques of the 19th century to the present.
Reqs: a grade of “C”or better in MUS 3622 or MUS 3632

Name: Styles and Practices of Beethoven and the Romantics
Desc: Tonality, harmony and form in music of the Romantic period; analysis of selected literature and creative writing in the Romantic style.
Reqs: a grade of “C”or better in MUS 3622 or MUS 3632

Name: Post-Tonal Styles and Practices
Desc: Study of principal currents of musical composition in the modern era; analysis of selected works and creative application of techniques, procedures and formal schemes studied.
Reqs: a grade of “C”or better in MUS 3622 or MUS 3632

Name: Survey of Contrapuntal Techniques
Desc: Writing and analysis of contrapuntal music in the modal, tonal, and post-tonal idioms.
Reqs: Grade of “C” or better in MUS 2622 or MUS 2632

Name: Elementary Orchestration
Desc: Traditional scoring practices.
Reqs: grade of “C”or better in MUS 2622 or MUS 2632

Name: Jazz Arranging
Desc: Jazz arranging styles and techniques, from Dixieland to modern jazz.
Reqs: MUS 3622 or MUS 3632 or consent of instructor

Name: Mobile Music
Desc: Creating music applications for mobile platforms, mobile application instrument design, mobile interaction design, experimental music composition and performance.

Name: Computer Music
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Digital sound design, sound synthesis and signal processing; electroacoustic music composition using computers and computer music techniques.

Name: Seminar in Computer Music and Digital Media
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Focused study of various topics in computer music and digital media such as computer music programming, sound diffusion techniques, interactive computer music and digital media systems, intermedia applications, analysis of computer music.

Name: Digital Musical Instruments
Desc: Digital musical instruments, physical modeling, sound design, acoustics, haptic interaction design, 21st century lutherie, and computer music composition.

Name: Seminar in Music History
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary.
Reqs: grade of “C”or better in MUS 2054 or equivalent or permission of instructor

Name: Piano Literature I
Desc: A survey of the keyboard repertoire from the late renaissance through Haydn and Mozart.

Name: Piano Literature II
Desc: A survey of piano literature from Beethoven to the present.

Name: History of Jazz Styles
Desc: Survey and analysis of the American Jazz idiom from the perspective of historical jazz periods and specific artists.

Name: The Care and Repair of Band and Orchestral Instruments
Desc: For students with experience in instrumental music and a practical knowledge of the problems in instrumental upkeep. 2 hrs. lab.

Name: Piano Methods and Materials
Desc: Materials and techniques for the piano teacher.

Name: Piano Methods and Materials
Desc: Materials and techniques for the piano teacher.

Name: Marching Band Techniques
Desc: Charting techniques for marching band; emphasis on contemporary drill design, practical projects in charting drill.

Name: Supervised Studio Instruction
Desc: Program tailored to needs of each student by the major applied teacher who supervised the student’s studio teaching program.

Name: Supervised Studio Instruction
Desc: Program tailored to needs of each student by the major applied teacher who supervised the student’s studio teaching program.

Name: Harp Technology and Maintenance
Desc: Required of all harp majors. Individual projects and study of harp history and development, design and regulation.

Name: Orchestral Repertoire for Harp
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 hrs. of credit. Required of all harp majors. Independent study of major orchestral excerpts; includes audition preparation.

Name: Harp Pedagogy
Desc: Required of all harp majors. Independent studies in materials and methods for the harp teacher.

Name: Senior Recital
Desc: No description provided

Name: Senior Composition Recital
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Concert of solo and chamber works.

Name: Coaching in Applied Music
Desc: May be repeated for credit. Open to music students with the recommendation of the appropriate applied music faculty. Max. amount of credit applicable toward a degree is 6 sem. hrs.

Name: Basic Techniques of Audio Recording
Desc: Basic properties of audio and various forms of sound energy; analysis of complete audio systems for recording and sound reinforcement and individual system components; aspects of stereo concert recording; emphasis on microphone placement techniques; professional music production techniques, including editing and tape duplication.

Name: Keyboard Skills for Pianists
Desc: Techniques of accompanying, including sight-reading, score reading, transposition and harmonization.

Name: Advanced German Diction for Singers
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. lab. The rules of pronunciation utilizing the International Phonetic Alphabet; coaching in the Lied and operatic literature including spoken dialogue.

Name: Advanced French Diction for Singers
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. lab. The rules of pronunciation utilizing the International Phonetic Alphabet; coaching in the French art song and operatic literature.

Name: Advanced Italian Diction for Singers
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. lab. The rules of pronunciation utilizing the International Phonetic Alphabet; coaching in operatic and song literature; some outside research expected.

Name: Seminar in String Literature
Desc: Methods, solos and chamber music for strings.

Name: Seminar in Woodwind Literature I
Desc: Methods, solos and ensemble literature for woodwinds.

Name: Seminar in Woodwind Literature II
Desc: Methods, solos and ensemble literature for woodwinds.

Name: Seminar in Brass Literature
Desc: Methods, solos and ensemble literature for brass instruments.

Name: Seminar in Percussion Literature
Desc: Methods, solos, and ensemble literature for percussion intstruments.

Name: Survey of Jazz Styles
Desc: In-depth investigation of the American Jazz idiom from the perspective of historical jazz periods and specific artists.

Name: Advanced Vocal Pedagogy
Desc: Fundamentals of anatomy, physiology and acoustics of voice production; emphasis on vocal registers, breath management and articulation; pedagogical philosophies used to train the classical singing voice in the Western tradition of art song and opera.

Name: Stringed Instrument Pedagogy
Desc: Methods and materials for instruction in string instruments.

Name: Woodwind Instrument Pedagogy
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit for the MM and 2 hrs. of credit for the DMA or PhD. Independent studies in the methods and materials for instruction in woodwind instruments.

Name: Brass Instrument Pedagogy
Desc: Methods and materials for instruction in brass instruments.

Name: Percussion Instrument Pedagogy
Desc: Methods and materials for instruction in percussion instruments.

Name: Jazz Pedagogy
Desc: Pedagogical issues in jazz idiom including effective jazz ensemble directing, selection of appropriate repertoire, improvisational performance practices, effective jazz practice habits and concepts designed to foster creativity.

Name: Solo Literature for the Voice
Desc: Solo vocal literature in German and French; emphasis on styles of performance.

Name: Solo Literature for the Voice
Desc: Solo vocal literature by English, American, Italian, Scandinavian, Eastern European, Russian, Spanish and Latin American composers; emphasis on styles of performance.

Name: Historical Perspectives of Voice
Desc: Development of vocal technique and pedagogical thought from the late 17th century to the present; definition of the bel canto style; historical schools of vocal training; examination of historical writings by Tosi, Mancini, Garcia, Marchesi, Vennard and other individuals of primary historical eminence.

Name: Principles of Voice Production
Desc: Anatomy and physiology of the respiratory, phonatory and articulatory systems used in the production of the human voice; theories of phonation; acoustics of the vocal tract; laryngeal biomechanics; control of fundamental frequency and loudness; study of life-span changes of the voice and care of the human voice.

Name: Comparative Vocal Pedagogy
Desc: Techniques for teaching collegiate level applied voice; studio structure and management.

Name: Advanced Teaching Practicum
Desc: May be repeated for credit. A total of 3 sem. hrs. is applicable to the MM degree. Supervised teaching internship of instrumental and/or vocal instruction in private and/or group settings.

Name: Piano Pedagogy and Literature I
Desc: Piano methods and literature at the elementary and intermediate levels.

Name: Piano Pedagogy and Literature II
Desc: Piano methods and literature at the intermediate and advanced levels.

Name: Instrumental Accompanying
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Repertoire and techniques of accompanying for instrumental genres.

Name: Vocal Accompanying
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Repertoire and techniques of accompanying for vocal genres.

Name: College Teaching in Music
Desc: History of music in higher education; current issues, problems and techniques of college teaching in music; development of effective college-level teaching skills.

Name: Sources of Music Study & Research
Desc: Also offered as LIS 7810. Focuses on finding, evaluating, using and citing materials in print, online and recorded sources for music research.

Name: Survey of Analytical Techniques
Desc: Survey of analytical tools and concepts for common practice and post-tonal practice.
Reqs: MUS 3703 or passing of the Music Theory Diagnostic Examination

Name: Pedagogy of Music Theory
Desc: Techniques for teaching undergraduate music theory and aural skills courses; comparisons of principal philosophies and textbooks.
Reqs: MUS 3703 or successful passing of the Music Theory Diagnostic Examination

Name: Contemporary Musical Practices
Desc: 6 sem. hrs. applicable to the MM degree when topics vary; 6 additional sem. hrs. applicable to the DMA degree when topics vary. Compositional trends in contemporary music; discussion of books on composition; analysis of major compositions.

Name: Studies in Linear Analysis
Desc: Ideas and practices of derived from Schenker and others; their effect on musical thought and performance in this century.
Reqs: MUS 3703 or successful passing of the Music Theory Diagnostic Examination

Name: Advanced Linear Analysis
Desc: Required of all doctoral students in music theory. Advanced studies in analytical techniques derived from Schenker and others, including graphing techniques and review of literature.

Name: Theory and Analysis of Tonal Music
Desc: Readings and practice in various approaches to the analysis of music of the tonal era (ca. 1600-1900).
Reqs: MUS 3703 or successful passing of the Music Theory Diagnostic Examination

Name: Seminar in Post-Tonal Musical Analysis
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Analytical study of specific composers, works or styles.
Reqs: MUS 3703 or successful passing of the Music Theory Diagnostic Examination

Name: Survey of Choral Literature I
Desc: A survey of choral literature beginning with Gregorian Chant and ending with the Baroque period of music, with emphasis on preparation for performance.

Name: Survey of Choral Literature II
Desc: A survey of choral literature beginning with the Classical period and ending with contemporary music for chorus, with emphasis on preparation for performance.

Name: Survey of Wind Literature I
Desc: A survey of chamber wind literature (6 to 20 performers) from the late Renaissance to the present.

Name: Survey of Wind Literature II
Desc: A survey of orchestra, large wind ensemble and large wind band literature (more than 20 performers) from the French Revolution to the present.

Name: Survey of Symphonic Literature I
Desc: A survey of orchestral works beginning with the Baroque period of music and ending with the early Romantic; emphasis on preparation for performance.

Name: Survey of Symphonic Literature II
Desc: A survey of orchestral works beginning with the Romantic period and ending with 20th century music for orchestra, with emphasis on preparation for performance.

Name: History of Music Theory I
Desc: History of technical writings on music, ca. 500-1600; acoustics, notes and scales, intervals, tuning systems, modes, counterpoint, mensuration, musical poetics, speculative theory.
Reqs: MUS 3703 and MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music Theory and Music History Diagnostic Examinations

Name: History of Music Theory II
Desc: Music theory from ca. 1600 to 1900; development of species counter-point and figured bass theory; the rise of harmonic theory and rhythmic/phrase analysis; 19th-century expansions of harmonic theory and formal analysis.
Reqs: MUS 3703 and MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music Theory and Music History Diagnostic Examinations

Name: Advanced Computer Music
Desc: Advanced techniques in digital sound synthesis and composition; analysis/resynthesis techniques, granular synthesis, physical modeling, interactive computer music performance and algorithmic composition using computers; survey of representative music from the genre.

Name: Graduate Seminar in Experimental Music and Digital Media
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Focused study of various topics in experimental music and digital media such as development of new computer music systems, interactive computer music, multimedia composition, alternative human-computer interfaces for music, experimental music performance, sound installations and advanced analysis of computer music.

Name: History of Electroacoustic Music
Desc: The history of electroacoustic music; developments in technology, aesthetics and style since ca. 1900 to present; survey and analysis of representative music from the genre.

Name: Special Studies in Piano Literature
Desc: Each course may be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Total amount of credit applicable to MM degree limited by student’s advisory committee. Works of certain composers for the keyboard, such as selected concertos.

Name: Special Studies in Piano Literature
Desc: Each course may be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Total amount of credit applicable to MM degree limited by student’s advisory committee. Works of certain composers for the keyboard, such as selected concertos.

Name: Ancient and Medieval Music
Desc: History of music from ancient Greeks and Hebrews through the 14th century.
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Music of the Renaissance
Desc: Music of the 15th and 16th centuries.
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Music in the Baroque Era
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Music in the Classical Era
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Music in the Romantic Era
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Music in the Modern Era
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: American Music
Desc: The most important phases in development of music in the U.S.
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Measurement and Evaluation in Music
Desc: Teacher-designed and standardized tests in music; learning theories.

Name: Comparative Methods in Music Education
Desc: Techniques in teaching music; functional projects; approaches and texts evaluated with emphasis on curriculum construction.

Name: Philosophical Bases for Music Education
Desc: Various philosophical bases for music education including their origin, function, development and implementation.

Name: Current Issues in Music Education
Desc: Develop broad perspectives from a multi-faceted review of issues affecting music education practice. Examine important contexts from which effective teachers make informed decisions.

Name: Experimental Research in Music
Desc: Primarily for doctoral students in music. Systematic investigation of musical behavior and music learning; collection, quantification and treatment of data; current research.

Name: Qualitative Research in Music
Desc: An overview of major designs, methodologies and analysis techniques within qualitative research. Topics include: research ethics, Institutional Review Board protocols, constructing and proposing a study, methods of data collection, writing literature reviews, and techniques for conducting research and writing research reports.

Name: Advanced Choral Conducting
Desc: Each course may be taken once for the MM and once for the DMA or PhD. Independent study of the techniques required to conduct all styles of choral music with emphasis on score analysis and performance practices.

Name: Advanced Choral Conducting
Desc: Each course may be taken once for the MM and once for the DMA or PhD. Independent study of the techniques required to conduct all styles of choral music with emphasis on score analysis and performance practices.

Name: Advanced Band Conducting
Desc: Each course may be taken once for the MM and once for the DMA or PhD. Independent study of the techniques required to conduct all styles of wind music with emphasis on score analysis and performance function.

Name: Advanced Band Conducting
Desc: Each course may be taken once for the MM and once for the DMA or PhD. Independent study of the techniques required to conduct all styles of wind music with emphasis on score analysis and performance function.

Name: Advanced Orchestral Conducting
Desc: Each course may be taken once for the MM and once for the DMA or PhD. Independent study of the techniques required to conduct all styles of symphonic music, with emphasis on score analysis and performance practices.

Name: Advanced Orchestral Conducting
Desc: Each course may be taken once for the MM and once for the DMA or PhD. Independent study of the techniques required to conduct all styles of symphonic music, with emphasis on score analysis and performance practices.

Name: Advanced Keyboard Literature I
Desc: Each course may be taken twice; once for the MM and once for the DMA. Genres and styles from earliest examples of keyboard literature through the most recent trends.

Name: Advanced Keyboard Literature II
Desc: Each course may be taken twice; once for the MM and once for the DMA. Genres and styles from earliest examples of keyboard literature through the most recent trends.

Name: Introduction to Musicology, Music Theory, and Ethnomusicology
Desc: Required of all master’s and doctoral students in musicology and music theory. Introduction to the history of musicology, music theory, and ethnomusicology as reflected in the development of the fields’ ideas, research tools, and scholarly methods.

Name: Master’s Pedagogy Project
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Completion of a 45-minute oral presentation and short supporting paper on a pedagogical topic.

Name: Master’s Recital
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit.

Name: Advanced Coaching in Applied Music
Desc: May be repeated for credit. Max. amount of credit applicable toward a degree is 4 sem. hrs.

Name: Introduction to Research in Music
Desc: Required of all doctoral students; recommended for master’s students who will write theses. Development of music research skills including knowledge of research resources and materials; use of library facilities; practice in a clear and logical writing style; and use of wide variety of methodologies and modes of inquiry.

Name: Psychology of Music
Desc: Physical and psychological bases of musical phenomena including physical properties of sound production, transmission, reception and perception; affective, physiological and cognitive responses to musical stimuli; and learning theories as related to musical development, ability and preference.

Name: Seminar in Music History
Desc: Each course may be taken 3 times for credit when topics vary. Only 6 sem. hrs. applicable to the MM degree; only 12 additional sem. hrs. applicable to the PhD; maximum for MM and PhD combined is 18 sem. hrs.
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Seminar in Music History
Desc: Each course may be taken 3 times for credit when topics vary. Only 6 sem. hrs. applicable to the MM degree; only 12 additional sem. hrs. applicable to the PhD; maximum for MM and PhD combined is 18 sem. hrs.
Reqs: MUS 3710 or successful passing of the Music History Diagnostic Examination

Name: Seminar in Music Education
Desc: Each course may be taken 3 times for credit when topics vary. Only 6 sem. hrs. applicable to the MMEd degree; only 12 additional sem. hrs. applicable to the PhD; maximum for MMEd and PhD combined is 18 sem. hrs.

Name: Seminar in Music Education
Desc: Each course may be taken 3 times for credit when topics vary. Only 6 sem. hrs. applicable to the MMEd degree; only 12 additional sem. hrs. applicable to the PhD; maximum for MMEd and PhD combined is 18 sem. hrs.

Name: Seminar in Music Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit applicable to the MM degree when topics vary and only 12 additional sem. hrs. of credit applicable to the PhD when topics vary. Maximum for MM and PhD combined is 18 sem. hrs. of credit.
Reqs: MUS 3703 or successful passing of the Music Theory Diagnostic Examination

Name: Seminar in Choral Repertoire
Desc: Each course may be taken 3 times for credit when topics vary. Only 6 sem. hrs. applicable to the MM degree; only 12 additional sem. hrs. applicable to the DMA; maximum for MM and DMA combined is 18 sem. hrs .

Name: Seminar in Choral Repertoire
Desc: Each course may be taken 3 times for credit when topics vary. Only 6 sem. hrs. applicable to the MM degree; only 12 additional sem. hrs. applicable to the DMA; maximum for MM and DMA combined is 18 sem. hrs .

Name: Individual Projects in Music
Desc: May be repeated for credit as follows: for master’s degree, 3 sem. hrs.; for doctoral degree, 6 sem. hrs. beyond the master’s or a total of 9 sem. hrs. if both master’s and doctoral totals included.
Reqs: consent of departmental faculty concerned and dean of the School of Music

Name: Special Topics in Music
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced studies in individual subject areas of music.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Doctoral Solo Recital
Desc: May be repeated twice (max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit). Students specializing in organ may repeat four times (max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit).

Name: Second Doctoral Solo Recital
Desc: No description provided

Name: Doctoral Lecture Recital
Desc: Does not fulfill final project requirement for DMA (MUS 9010).

Name: Concerto with Orchestra
Desc: No description provided

Name: Major Solo Part in an Oratorio or a Cantata
Desc: No description provided

Name: Doctor of Musical Arts Role in Opera
Desc: May be repeated for credit. May not be taken concurrently with MUS 4241. A max. of 4 hrs. of credit may be applied toward the DMA degree.

Name: Doctor of Musical Arts Chamber Music Recital
Desc: May be repeated for credit.

Name: Research and Monograph
Desc: “S/U” grading. May be repeated until monograph is completed. For DMA candidates in performance only.

Name: Lecture Recital with Written Document
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated. Research, preparation, and presentation of a lecture recital and corollary written document.

Name: Repertoire
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit; however, amount of credit applicable to a degree is determined by student’s advisory committee.

Name: Repertoire
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit; however, amount of credit applicable to a degree is determined by student’s advisory committee.

Name: Seminar in Literature and Style in Performance: Voice
Desc: Historical developments of the various performance areas with concentration on their literature, important pedagogical principles, and stylistic problems related to each medium.

Name: Seminar in Literature and Style in Performance: Voice
Desc: Historical developments of the various performance areas with concentration on their literature, important pedagogical principles, and stylistic problems related to each medium.

Name: Seminar in Literature and Style in Performance: Organ
Desc: Historical developments of the various performance areas with concentration on their literature, important pedagogical principles, and stylistic problems related to each medium.

Desc: Historical developments of the various performance areas with concentration on their literature, important pedagogical principles, and stylistic problems related to each medium.

Desc: Historical developments of the various performance areas with concentration on their literature, important pedagogical principles, and stylistic problems related to each medium.

Name: Seminar in Literature and Style in Performance: Percussion
Desc: Historical developments of the various performance areas with concentration on their literature, important pedagogical principles, and stylistic problems related to each medium.

Name: Foundations of Music Education
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and EDCI 1000. Course is for music majors only. 2 hrs. lecture; 1 hr. lab.
