Reqs: May be offered as LING 7910 when topic is appropriate

Name: Independent Reading and Research
Desc: Total credit earned as a graduate student in PHIL 4991 and PHIL 7991 combined may not exceed 9 sem. hrs.
Reqs: written consent of instructor and departmental director of graduate studies

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Physical Science
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and any other college-level physics course. First half of a two-semester survey course in the physical sciences; topics in the first semester are taken primarily from the field of physics.

Name: Physical Science
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and any other college-level astronomy course. Second half of a two-semester survey course in the physical sciences; topics in the second semester are taken primarily from the fields of astronomy, chemistry and geology.

Name: Physical Science with Laboratory
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and PHSC 1001. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Exposition of physical science concepts through laboratory investigations; topics such as nature of matter, forces and motion, electricity and magnetism and sound.

Name: Physical Science with Laboratory
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and PHSC 1001. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Exposition of physical science concepts through laboratory investigations; topics such as changes in matter, light and color, energy and observational astronomy.

Name: General Physics for Physics Majors
Desc: Primarily for students intending to major in physics. Credit will not be given for this course and PHYS 2001, PHYS 2110, PHYS 2112. 4 hrs. lecture/demonstration. Fundamentals of classical physics and some concepts of modern physics; calculus and vector analysis introduced and used in development of subject matter.
Reqs: credit or registration in MATH 1550 or MATH 1551

Name: General Physics for Physics Majors
Desc: Primarily for students intending to major in physics. Credit will not be given for this course and PHYS 2002 or PHYS 2113. 4 hrs. lecture/demonstration. Fundamentals of classical physics and some concepts of modern physics; calculus and vector analysis introduced and used in development of subject matter.
Reqs: PHYS 1201 and credit or registration in MATH 1552 or MATH 1553

Name: General Physics Laboratory for Physics Majors
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and PHYS 2108. Laboratory to accompany PHYS 1201.

Name: General Physics Laboratory for Physics Majors
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and  PHYS 2109. Laboratory to accompany PHYS 1202. 3 hrs. lab.

Name: General Physics I
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and PHYS 1201, PHYS 2110, PHYS 2112. Mechanics, heat, sound, light, electricity and magnetism; topics in modern physics.
Reqs: MATH 1022 or MATH 1023 or MATH 1550 or MATH 1551

Name: General Physics II
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and PHYS 1202 or PHYS 2112, PHYS 2113. 3 hrs. lecture/demonstration. Mechanics, heat, sound, light, electricity and magnetism; topics in modern physics.
Reqs: PHYS 2001 and MATH 1022 or MATH 1023 or MATH 1550 or MATH 1551

Name: Introductory Physics Laboratory
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and PHYS 1208. Laboratory to accompany PHYS 2001 or PHYS 2110.
Reqs: credit or registration in PHYS 2001 or PHYS 2110

Name: General Physics Laboratory
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and PHYS 1209. Laboratory to accompany PHYS 2002 and PHYS 2113. Electricity, magnetism, geometrical and physical optics and other topics in modern physics.
Reqs: PHYS 2108 and credit or registration in PHYS 2002 or PHYS 2113

Name: Particle Mechanics
Desc: Vectors, forces and motion, Newton’s Laws, conservation of energy and momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics, equilibrium and elasticity, oscillations.
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in MATH 1550; credit or registration in MATH 1552 or MATH 1553

Name: Fluids, Thermodynamics, Waves, and Modern Physics
Desc: Fluids, oscillations and waves, thermodynamics, modern physics.
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in PHYS 2110 and MATH 1552 or MATH 1553

Name: Fields: Gravity, Electricity, and Magnetism
Desc: Gravitation and electromagnetism, gravitational fields, electric and magnetic fields, currents and circuits, induction, Maxwell’s Equations.
Reqs: grade of “C” or better in PHYS 2110 and MATH 1552 or MATH 1553

Name: Introductory Modern Physics
Desc: Elementary modern physics; special relativity, wave/particle duality, quantum mechanics, hydrogen atom, many-electron atoms, nuclear structure elementary particles, solid state, astrophysics and cosmology.

Name: Introductory Modern Physics Laboratory
Desc: Coreq.: PHYS 2203. For physics majors only. Laboratory to accompany PHYS 2203.

Name: Introduction to Mechanics
Reqs: MATH 2057; PHYS 1202 or both PHYS 2112 and PHYS 2113

Name: Electricity and Magnetism
Desc: Electricity and magnetism; static and quasistatic electromagnetic fields in vacua and in dielectric and magnetic media.
Reqs: PHYS 2221 or CHEM 4581 and credit or registration in MATH 2065 or MATH 2090

Name: Introduction to Concepts in Physics
Desc: Primarily for students in liberal arts and education. Historical evolution and underlying philosophy of principles of physics; provides appreciation of physics; does not develop technical skill.
Reqs: MATH 1021 or an ACT math score of at least 25

Name: Computational Science I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Introduction to symbolic manipulation and numerical techniques used to analyze or simulate a broad range of physical systems.
Reqs: CSC 1253 or equivalent and one of the following three choices: PHYS 2221; or MATH 2057 and PHYS 1202 or both PHYS 2112 and PHYS 2113; or CHEM 4581 and credit or registration in MATH 2065 (or MATH 2090)

Name: Undergraduate Seminar
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Individual reading in current areas of physics, topics in professional development and presentation of undergraduate research.
Reqs: consent of instructor and department chair

Name: Instrumentation Electronics for Scientists
Desc: For physics majors only. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Basic electronic technology and circuits used in scientific instrumentation; circuit analysis, discrete components, operational amplifiers, digital electronics and microcontrollers.
Reqs: PHYS 1202 or both PHYS 2112 and PHYS 2113; PHYS 2207; CSC 1253 or equivalent

Name: Science Research Methods
Desc: See BIOL 4005.

Name: Intermediate Mathematical Physics
Desc: Mathematical methods of physics, with application to selected problems.
Reqs: PHYS 2221 or CHEM 4581 and credit or registration in MATH 2065 or MATH 2090

Name: Intermediate Mechanics
Desc: Lagrangian mechanics; central force motion; rigid body dynamics; small oscillations.

Name: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
Desc: Basic physical concepts and methods appropriate for description of systems involving many particles; unified view point of thermodynamics, statistical mechanics and kinetic theory.
Reqs: PHYS 2203 or CHEM 3491; PHYS 2221 or CHEM 4581; credit or registration in MATH 2065 or MATH 2090

Name: Electromagnetism and Electromagnetic Waves
Desc: Continuation of PHYS 2231. Emphasis on electromagnetic waves and radiation.

Name: Modern Optics
Desc: Review of geometrical optics and optical instruments, scalar diffraction theory, spatial filtering and holography, Gaussian beam optics, optical resonators, lasers and optical properties of materials.
Reqs: PHYS 2221 and MATH 2065 or MATH 2090; or CHEM 4581 and MATH 2065 or MATH 2090

Name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
Desc: Elementary principles of quantum mechanics, including Schrodinger equation, one-dimensional problems, harmonic oscillator, angular momentum, perturbation theory, matrix mechanics and spin.
Reqs: PHYS 2221 and credit or registration in MATH 2065 or MATH 2090; or CHEM 4581 and credit or registration in MATH 2065 or MATH 2090

Name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
Desc: Elementary principles of quantum mechanics, including Schrodinger equation, one-dimensional problems, harmonic oscillator, angular momentum, perturbation theory, matrix mechanics and spin.

Name: Atomic Physics
Desc: Modern theory of atomic structure, radiations, and processes.
Reqs: PHYS 4142 and credit or registration in PHYS 4132

Name: Introduction to Solid-State Physics
Desc: Properties of the crystalline state and the free-electron; band theories of metals, insulators and semiconductors.

Name: Subatomic Physics
Desc: Nuclear and particle properties, abundance and stability of nuclei, strong, weak and electromagnetic forces, nuclear instrumentation, particle accelerators and detectors, nuclear reactions and particle and nuclear astrophysics.

Name: Undergraduate Research
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Recommended for students who will take PHYS 4399. Research project conducted under supervision of individually selected faculty member.
Reqs: consent of instructor and department chair

Name: Senior Thesis
Desc: Students should consider taking PHYS 4398 as preparation for this course. Individual research project conducted and reported under supervision of individually selected faculty member.
Reqs: consent of instructor and department chair

Name: Special Topics in Physics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit if topics vary.

Name: Special Problems in Physics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Individual reading and theoretical and/or experimental work on advanced problems in physics.
Reqs: thorough knowledge of the fundamentals of physics and mathematics, demonstrated ability in science and consent of instructor and department chair

Name: Undergraduate Senior Seminar
Desc: For junior and senior students. May not be taken concurrently with PHYS 2995. May be repeated for a max. of 4 hrs. of credit. Individual reading in current topics, professional development, presentations of research articles and student research projects.
Reqs: consent of instructor and department chair

Name: Classical Physics for Teachers
Desc: For high school and junior college teachers; part of the MNS degree program. Application of conservation principles to development of classical physics.
Reqs: PHYS 2002 or both PHYS 2112 and PHYS 2113

Name: Laboratory Methods for Teachers
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit. For high school and junior college teachers; part of the MNS degree program. 1 hr. lecture; 6 hrs. lab. Analysis of laboratory experiments in current high school physics curricula; selected experiments in modern physics.
Reqs: PHYS 2002 or both PHYS 2112 and PHYS 2113

Name: Seminar in Current Developments in Physics Curriculum Materials
Desc: For high school and junior college teachers; part of the MNS degree program. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit.
Reqs: PHYS 2002 or both PHYS 2112 and PHYS 2113

Name: Mathematical Methods of Theoretical Physics
Desc: Advanced topics in mathematical methods of theoretical physics; mathematical foundations of quantum mechanics.

Name: Mathematical Methods of Theoretical Physics
Desc: Advanced topics in mathematical methods of theoretical physics; mathematical foundations of quantum mechanics.

Name: Classical Mechanics
Desc: Offered in Su Study of particle mechanics and rigid body mechanics using the methods of Lagrange’s equations, Hamilton’s equations, canonical transformations and Hamilton-Jacobi theory.

Name: Statistical Mechanics
Desc: Principles of classical and quantum statistics, with application to special problems.

Name: Classical Electrodynamics
Desc: Problems in electrostatics and magnetostatics; Maxwell’s equations, electromagnetic waves, wave guides, and antennas; relativistic electrodynamics and radiation from moving charges.

Name: Classical Electrodynamics
Desc: Problems in electrostatics and magnetostatics; Maxwell’s equations, electromagnetic waves, wave guides, and antennas; relativistic electrodynamics and radiation from moving charges.

Name: Quantum Mechanics
Desc: Basic concepts of nonrelativistic quantum mechanics, operators and matrices, intrinsic and orbital angular momenta, perturbation theory, atomic structure, second quantization and scattering theory.

Name: Quantum Mechanics
Desc: Basic concepts of nonrelativistic quantum mechanics, operators and matrices, intrinsic and orbital angular momenta, perturbation theory, atomic structure, second quantization and scattering theory.

Name: General Relativity
Desc: General tensor analysis; postulates of general relativity, field equations, equations of motion, interior and exterior Schwarzchild solutions; cosmology.

Name: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
Desc: The Lorentz group, relativistic wave equations, introduction to quantum field theory.

Name: Quantum Information Theory
Desc: Classical and quantum methods for data compression and communication over channels; measurement theory and entropy.

Name: Quantum Computation
Desc: Turing machines, classical and quantum models of computation, NP-completeness, theorems and algorithms for quantum computation.

Name: Atomic and Optical Physics I
Reqs: PHYS 7242 Applications of quantum mechanics to atomic systems and their interaction with radiation; spectral levels, photo-absorption and collisions with charged particles

Name: Atomic and Optical Physics II
Desc: Applications of quantum mechanics to atomic systems and their interaction with radiation; spectral levels, photo-absorption and collisions with charged particles.

Name: Low-Temperature Physics
Desc: Properties of matter at temperatures near absolute zero; methods of producing low temperatures; superfluidity of liquid helium, superconductivity, magnetic effects and adiabatic demagnetization.

Name: Condensed Matter Physics
Desc: Application of quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics to condensed matter; lattice vibrations, energy bands in crystals, transport properties, collective excitations, ferromagnetism and superconductivity; theory of Fermi and Bose quantum fluids, phase transitions and critical phenomena.

Name: Condensed Matter Physics
Desc: Application of quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics to condensed matter; lattice vibrations, energy bands in crystals, transport properties, collective excitations, ferromagnetism and superconductivity; theory of Fermi and Bose quantum fluids, phase transitions and critical phenomena.

Name: Nuclear Physics
Desc: Applications of quantum mechanics to the two-nucleon system, to a system of many nucleons and to nuclear reactions, with comparisons between theory and experimental results.

Name: High Energy Particle Physics
Desc: Strong electromagnetic and weak interactions of hadrons and leptons, including symmetries and selection rules; quantum chromodynamics and electroweak theory; accelerator and nonaccelerator experiments including cosmic rays and high energy astrophysics.

Name: Graduate Laboratory
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 6 hrs. lab. Practical experience in modern experimental physics laboratory techniques.

Name: Computational Physics
Desc: Basic numerical techniques for solution of mathematical equations, including coupled linear algebraic and differential equations and numerical simulation techniques; emphasis on application to physical problems.

Name: Computational Physics
Desc: Basic numerical techniques for solution of mathematical equations, including coupled linear algebraic and differential equations and numerical simulation techniques; emphasis on application to physical problems.

Name: Theoretical Condensed Matter Physics
Desc: Density functional theory of electronic structure, mean field and renormalization group theory of phase transitions; linear response theory; quantum transport, Landau theory of Fermi liquids; systems of strongly interacting electrons, superconductivity.

Name: Theoretical Condensed Matter Physics
Desc: Density functional theory of electronic structure, mean field and renormalization group theory of phase transitions; linear response theory; quantum transport, Landau theory of Fermi liquids; systems of strongly interacting electrons, superconductivity.

Name: Radiation Interactions and Transport
Reqs: PHYS 2203 or equivalent, CSC 2262 or equivalent

Name: Monte Carlo Simulation of Radiation Transport
Desc: Same as MEDP 7538.

Name: Stellar Astrophysics
Desc: See ASTR 7741.

Name: Stellar Astrophysics
Desc: See ASTR 7742.

Name: Advanced Quantum Theory of Particles and Fields
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 hrs. of credit.

Name: Galactic Astrophysics
Desc: See ASTR 7751.

Name: Galactic Astrophysics
Desc: See ASTR 7752.

Name: Seminar in Astronomy and Astrophysics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. See ASTR 7777.

Name: Topics in Astronomy and Astrophysics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. See ASTR 7783.

Name: Graduate Student Seminar
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for credit. Introduction to research areas in the department; training for presentation of scientific talks; preparation of research proposals.

Name: Many-Body Theory
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Diagrammatic techniques, thermal Green’s functions, transport theory, Fermi liquids, collective excitations, phase transitions.

Name: Selected Topics in Advanced Physics
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for credit.

Name: Current Developments
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be repeated for credit.

Name: Independent Research in Physics
Desc: An approved independent research project in experimental or theoretical physics; final written report and an oral presentation to a faculty committee is required.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Principles of Plant Health Management
Desc: See ENTM 1005.

Name: Plants, Microbes, and Society
Desc: Also offered as ENTM 2000. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. This course will explore the interactions between humans and plants through the lens of the microbes inhabiting plants.

Name: Pest Management Internship
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Work experience in an agricultural or urban pest management industry or in a pest management research area culminating in acceptable written reports.

Name: Pesticides in the Environment
Desc: See ENTM 3001.

Name: Pest Management Seminar
Desc: Review and discussion of internship experiences including topics in agricultural pest management and urban entomology; development of professional skills.

Name: Introductory Plant Physiology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Life processes of plants.
Reqs: BIOL 1202 and BIOL 1209; CHEM 2060, CHEM 2261 or CHEM 2461

Name: Undergraduate Research in Plant Pathology
Desc: May not be repeated for credit. Research experience for students contemplating graduate study in plant pathology.
Reqs: PLHL 4000 or equivalent and consent of instructor

Name: Undergraduate Research in Crop Physiology and Weed Science
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Research experience for students contemplating graduate study in crop physiology or weed science.
Reqs: PLHL 3060 or equivalent and consent of instructor

Name: General Plant Pathology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Nature and cause of disease in plants; relation of environment and host-parasite interactions to development of disease symptoms caused by plant pathogenic fungi, bacteria, viruses, mycoplasms and nematodes; abiotic causes of disease; methods of disease control; diseases affecting Louisiana crops and ornamentals.

Name: Plant Disease Management and Control
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. demonstration/lab. Plant disease management and control using cultural practices, disease resistance, biological control, legislation, therapy, pesticides; identity, properties, chemistry, mode of action, toxicity and application of fungicides, bactericides and nematicides; evaluation of chemicals for plant disease control.
Reqs: PLHL 4000 and either CHEM 2060 or CHEM 2261

Name: Forest Insects and Diseases
Desc: See ENTM 4018.

Name: Plant Health Diagnostics
Desc: Also offered as ENTM 4050. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Introduction to plant health problems and investigation of cause through identifying biotic or abiotic factors in real-world situations.

Name: Introductory Mycology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab.

Name: Seed Physiology
Desc: BIOL 3060 recommended. Introduction to the life processes of Seeds: their development, germination, dormancy, ecology, vigor and viability.
Reqs: BIOL 1201, BIOL 1208 and 1402 and either CHEM 2060 or CHEM 2261

Name: Phytonematology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Taxonomy, identification and control of plant parasitic nematodes.

Name: Plant Molecular Biology
Desc: Molecular biology, biochemistry and genetics of higher plants and plant-associated microorganisms; genome organization and structure in nuclei, chloroplasts and mitochondria; structure and expression of plant genes under control of developmental and environmental signals; plant interactions with pathogenic and symbiotic microorganisms.
Reqs: BIOL 3060, BIOL 4093 and BIOL 4094; or equivalent

Name: Phytobacteriology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Taxonomy, biology, mechanisms of pathogenesis; control of prokaryotic plant pathogens.

Name: Plant Virology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Viruses as causal agents of plant diseases; biological, chemical and physiological properties of plant viruses; methods of transmission; host-virus and vector-virus relationship.

Name: Advanced Topics in Plant Pathology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 sem. hrs. of credit.

Name: Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 hrs. of credit for each graduate degree. Topics announced prior to registration.

Name: Plant Growth and Development
Desc: Effects of naturally occurring growth substances and environmental conditions on plant growth.
Reqs: BIOL 3060 or PLHL 3060 and BIOL 4093; or equivalent

Name: Plant Metabolism
Desc: Major metabolic systems of plants and their control.

Name: Selected Topics in Plant Physiology
Desc: May be repeated for credit. Mineral nutrition, metabolism, growth and development and herbicides.

Name: Host-Parasite Interaction and Disease Resistance
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Genetics, physiology and biochemistry of disease development and disease resistance in plants; mechanisms of pathogenicity and infectivity, tumorigenesis, metabolic consequences of infection, nature of disease resistance and parasitism.

Name: Soilborne Plant Pathogens
Desc: Physiology, ecology and pathology of soilborne plant pathogens; control strategies including cultural, biological and genetic; disease suppressive soils.

Name: Epidemiology and Crop Loss Assessment
Desc: Interactions between pathogen and host populations and the environment; measurement and prediction of disease spread and increase; disease management strategies; techniques to assess losses due to plant disease.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Practicum in Plant Pathology
Desc: Pass/fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. 1 hr. lecture; 4 hours clinic/practicum. Faculty-supervised experiences in plant pathology research, disease diagnosis and control.

Name: Special Research Problems
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. credit. Faculty supervised, independent research other than thesis or dissertation.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Fundamental Issues of Politics
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Credit will not be given for this course and POLI 1002. Central questions at issue in politics; their significance.

Name: Honors: Fundamental Issues of Politics
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as POLI 1001, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and POLI 1001.

Name: Civic Engagement, Youth and Media
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. See MC 2030.

Name: American Government
Desc: [LCCN: CPOL 2013, Introduction to American Govt] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, POLI 2052, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and POLI 2052. Principles, structures, processes and functions; emphasis on national government.

Name: HONORS: American Government
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as POLI 2051, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and POLI 2051.

Name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
Desc: [LCCN: CPOL 2213, Introduction to Comparative Govt] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Survey of politics in democratic, post-communist and developing societies; emphasis on major actors and institutions.

Name: Government of Louisiana
Desc: State and local government and politics in Louisiana.

Name: Introduction to International Politics
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Basic principles, problems and concepts of international politics; evolution and nature of the nation-state; concepts of sovereignty, power and national interest; patterns of conflict and cooperation; foreign policies of the major powers.

Name: Introduction to Political Theory
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Basic concepts of analysis of normative and empirical political thought.

Name: Public Policy Making: An Introduction
Desc: Sequential process of policy making from problem identification through policy formulation, adoption, implementation and evaluation of impact; application to such areas as civil rights, welfare, urban affairs, taxation and government spending.

Name: HONORS: Thesis
Desc: Culmination of political science honors program; details available from department.

Name: Approaches to the Study of Politics
Desc: Surveys of ways political scientists try to generate knowledge about the political world.

Name: Games and Strategy in Models of Politics
Desc: Basic fundamentals of game theoretic analysis in political science.

Name: HONORS: Seminar
Desc: Students not enrolled in the honors program may be admitted with consent of the instructor. Subject matter and instructor vary. Details available from the department during registration.

Name: HONORS: Readings Course
Desc: Same as POLI 4996, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and POLI 4996.

Name: Undergraduate Internship in Political Science
Desc: Open to undergraduate students approved by the Department of Political Science. May be counted toward the total number of hours required for a major in political science but not toward fulfilling field requirements. Program of study, research and work in governmental or private agencies concerned with public policy.

Name: Contemporary Political Issues
Desc: May be repeated for credit when topics vary. For undergraduate political science or other social sciences majors having a 2.70 overall average; also open to well-qualified students in other fields, by consent of department Course content depends on interests of instructor and class.

Name: Special Topics in American Politics
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary.

Name: Research Methods in Political Science
Desc: Basic components of the research process in political science, including design and structure of research, modes of observation and techniques of analyzing data.

Name: Bureaucracy, Politics and Public Policy
Desc: Interrelationships between bureaucracy and politics in formulation and execution of public policy; forces and forms affecting these relationships.

Name: American State Politics and Policy Making
Desc: Politics and policy making in the American states; legal, cultural, socio-economic, political and institutional factors affecting the formulation, implementation and evaluation of American state public policies.

Name: Politics and Poverty Policy
Desc: Examination of key policy considerations pertaining to the problems of poverty in the United States.

Name: American Constitutional Law
Desc: Law of the Constitution and place of the Supreme Court in the American political system; separation of powers, judicial review, federalism and federal powers.

Name: The American Constitution and Civil Liberties
Desc: Political relevance of major federal constitutional limitations; property rights; First Amendment freedoms; rights of criminal defendants and ethnic minorities.

Name: Judicial Politics
Desc: Political role of U.S. state and federal courts; organization, staffing, financing; judicial policy making; public perception of the judicial process.

Name: Campaigns and Elections
Desc: Examination of campaigns and elections in the U.S. political system at the national, state and local levels.

Name: Gender and American Politics
Desc: Also offered as WGS 4028. The role of gender in the political arena in the United States.

Name: Political Psychology
Desc: We will consider how key concepts from psychology such as personality, cognition, emotions, stereotypes, and group dynamics affect political attitudes, public opinion, campaigns, and elections.

Name: Political Attitudes and Public Opinion
Desc: Beliefs and attitudes among the mass public; emphasis on attitude formation and change.

Name: Political Parties in the United States
Desc: Structure and function of political parties at local, state and national levels; voting studies of presidential elections.

Name: Interest Groups in American Politics
Desc: Interest group politics; effect of voluntary organizations on political behavior.

Name: Political Participation
Desc: Voting behavior, conventional participation and political protest and violence; political behavior and public policy.

Name: The Legislative Process
Desc: Legislative politics; emphasis on the U.S. Congress; effect of party, constituency and legislative institutions on legislative behavior and public policy; role of Congress in the American political system.

Name: The American Presidency
Desc: The presidency in the American political system; emphasis on process of presidential selection, evolving role of the president, politics of the executive apparatus of the presidency and presidential interaction with other political institutions and actors.

Name: Southern Politics
Desc: Contemporary politics of the American South.

Name: Special Topics in International Relations
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary.

Name: International Law
Desc: Development of international law; law of peace, war and neutrality; treaty law; recognition, war crimes, law enforcement, state responsibility and diplomatic immunities under the United Nations.

Name: International Organization
Desc: Origins, development and future of international organization; emphasis on the United Nations.

Name: American Foreign Policy
Desc: “National interest” as guiding consideration in development of American foreign policy from the beginning to the present; importance of the constitutional framework; presidential and congressional leadership; pressure groups and public opinion; changing world environment and American response.

Name: The Contemporary International System
Desc: Developments and trends in the international system since World War II; classical and modern versions of the balance of power; bipolarity, multipolarity and other elements of systems theory; concept of deterrence and game theory; decision-making theory; integration theory; conflict and conflict-resolution theory.

Name: International Terrorism
Desc: Examination of the causes, consequences, and outcomes of international terrorism; historical roots and governmental responses to terrorism.

Name: International Political Economy
Desc: Theories of international interdependence, dependence and integration; politics of decision making on protectionism and international finance; role of multinational corporations in world political economy; North-South debate; economic issues and national security.

Name: Political Psychology in International Relations
Desc: Cognitive personality and group psychology in international relations.

Name: International Conflict and Cooperation
Desc: Theories of international conflict, war and conflict resolution.

Name: Globalization and Politics
Desc: Overview of the concepts, theories and empirical evidence associated with the emerging phenomenon known as globalization, with particular emphasis on its political, economic and cultural dimensions.

Name: International Politics of the Middle East
Desc: International relations among Middle Eastern countries, with special emphasis on the Arab-Israeli conflict, international terrorism and U.S. policy toward the region.

Name: Special Topics in Comparative Politics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Comparative Politics of the Middle East
Desc: Government and politics of Middle Eastern countries, with special emphasis on political institutions and processes, the role of Islam and women’s conditions.

Name: Comparative Political Economy
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and POLI 7976. Cross-regional comparison on the interaction between politics and economics; topics include electoral business cycles, foreign trade, foreign investment, industrial policy and the environment.

Name: Comparative Political Institutions
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and POLI 7972. Comparative analysis of political institutions; emphasis on constitutional design, electoral and party systems, legislatures, cabinets and parliamentary and presidential structures.

Name: Comparative Politics of Developing Areas
Desc: Problems of development confronted by contemporary states and societies of the Third World; emphasis on role of ethnic pluralism, political parties, bureaucracies and the military.

Name: Latin American Governments and Politics
Desc: Governmental and political processes of Latin America; their contributions to modern government.

Name: The Politics of Asia
Desc: Governments and politics of modern Asia, with a focus on China; contemporary nationalism, political development, revolution and impact of communism, democracy and capitalism on Asian states.

Name: Russian Politics and Government
Desc: Contemporary political institutions and policies of Russia; influence of internal forces, such as culture, ideology and social structure; political economic and social problems and policies.

Name: Politics and Government of East Central Europe
Desc: Political systems of the former communist states of Eastern Europe; domestic institutions and policies; legacies of communism; political parties and elections.

Name: Politics of the European Union
Desc: The political, social, legal and economic unification of Europe.

Name: Politics of Western Europe
Desc: National political systems of Western Europe.

Name: The Politics of France and Francophone Areas
Desc: The political development, institution and culture of the French Republic and selected Francophone areas.

Name: British Politics
Desc: Contemporary British domestic politics and government; major institutions, actors, and processes of British politics.

Name: African Government and Politics
Desc: Governmental and political processes of Africa; factors affecting governmental performance in modern Africa.

Name: State, Society and Citizenship in Contemporary China
Desc: Political events in contemporary China; emphasis on the state and the citizen in the Reform Era.

Name: American Political Thought
Desc: Development of the American liberal-democratic tradition and dissent to that tradition.

Name: History of Political Theory from Plato to More
Desc: Ancient and medieval political thought.

Name: History of Political Theory from Machiavelli to Nietzsche
Desc: Early modern European political thought.

Name: Special Topics in Political Theory
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary.

Name: Contemporary Political Theory
Desc: Political thought from Nietzsche to present.

Name: Political Theology
Desc: Also offered as REL 4097. An exploration of the relationship between theology and politics, from the ancient Greeks and Hebrews to contemporary political theologians; emphasis on the Judeo-Christian tradition, but the political theology of other religious traditions, such as Islam, Hinduism and Confucianism may be included.

Name: Politics and Ethics
Desc: Also offered as PHIL 4098. Ethical theory and its application to politics, docamestic and international; ethical issues of public policy and conduct will be examined.

Name: Studies in Literature and Politics
Desc: See ENGL 4234

Name: Readings Course
Desc: An Honors course, POLI 3896, is also available. For junior, senior and graduate students in the social sciences with a 3.00 average. Credit will not be given for this course and POLI 3896. Individual reading in a specified field of political science.

Name: Readings Course
Desc: An Honors course, POLI 3896, is also available. For junior, senior and graduate students in the social sciences with a 3.00 average. Credit will not be given for this course and POLI 3896. Individual reading in a specified field of political science.

Name: HONORS: Thesis
Desc: Culmination of political science honors program; details available from the department.

Name: Professional Development
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Political scientist as teacher, researcher, citizen.

Name: Seminar in American Politics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Public Policy
Desc: Also offered as PADM 7902. Policymaking and administration in the American political system with an emphasis on the institutions of governance including their constitutional foundations; the political process of formulating, implementing, and evaluating public policy; and the public-private, intergovernmental, and international dynamics of policy.

Name: Special Topics in American Politics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in State Politics and Policy Making
Desc: No description provided

Name: Program Evaluation
Desc: See PADM 7917.

Name: Seminar in Public Law
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Political Behavior
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Legislative Politics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in International Politics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: No title provided
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Political Psychology in International Relations
Desc: Advanced study of cognitive, personality, group and identity psychology in international relations.

Name: Seminar in the Politics of International Economic Relations
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: International Conflict
Desc: Democratic peace, international terrorism, civil war, diversionary war and enduring rivalries, as well as current debates in the literature.

Name: Approaches to the Study of Politics
Desc: No description provided

Name: Seminar in Research Design and Quantitative Techniques
Desc: No description provided

Name: Advanced Research Methods in Social Science
Desc: See SOCL 7203

Name: Specialized Topics in Social Science Methods
Desc: See SOCL 7213.

Name: Seminar in Comparative Politics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in Comparative Politics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Comparative Political Institutions
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and POLI 4063. Advanced analysis of comparative political institutions, emphasis on constitutional design, electoral and party systems, legislatures and cabinets and parliamentary and presidential structures.

Name: Seminar on the State and Society
Desc: Focus on relations between the state and society; effects of social structure and social change on politics and the factors affecting political regimes and state capacity.

Name: Seminar in Comparative Political Behavior
Desc: Focus on individual level political phenomena and the relations to political institutions and social systems; topics include political culture and socialization, participation and protest, revolution and regime support, voting and voting behavior.

Name: Seminar in Comparative Political Economy
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Credit will not be given for both this course and POLI 4062. Focus on the interaction between politics and economics; topics include models of development, economic performance and the impact of global economic forces on regional and domestic politics.

Name: Seminar in American Political Thought
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Classical and Medieval Political Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Early Modern Political Theory
Desc: No description provided

Name: Political Theory: Interpretation and Analysis
Desc: No description provided

Name: Special Topics in Political Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Contemporary Political Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Readings Course
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Readings Course
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Introduction to Psychology
Desc: [LCCN: CPSY 2013, Introduction to Psychology] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. An honors course, PSYC 2001, is also available. Credit will not be given for this course and PSYC 2001. Understanding, prediction and control of human behavior.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Psychology
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as PSYC 2000, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and PSYC 2000.

Name: Introduction to the Psychology Major
Desc: This course is only offered online. Introduction and orientation to the psychology major, including information about the psychology curriculum, selecting a career path, and graduate school options.
Reqs: Credit or registration in PSYC 2000 or PSYC 2001 or equivalent

Name: Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences
Desc: Open to Psychology majors; open to other with permission of instructor. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Computation and elementary theory relating to basic statistical techniques; normal distribution, descriptive statistics, statistical inference, product moment correlations, simple rank order correlations, t-test, and simple analysis of variance.
Reqs: credit in MATH 1021 or MATH 1029 or equivalent

Name: Social Psychology
Desc: hrs. of psychology or sociology. Cultural forces affecting attitudes, social learning, perception and communication of individuals and groups.

Name: Educational Psychology
Desc: [LCCN: CPSY 2613, Educational Psychology] Principles of learning, motivation, development and evaluation as related to the educative process.

Name: Developmental Psychology of the Life Span
Desc: Survey of developmental processes across the life span.

Name: Child Psychology
Desc: Psychological and social development of the child.

Name: Adolescent Psychology
Desc: Adolescent behavior considered in terms of psychological, social and physical development.

Name: Introduction to Forensic Psychology
Desc: An introduction to the issues, research, and theories related to Forensic Psychology. Research on forensic psychology, understand relevant theories, and apply course material to an understanding of psychology and the judicial system.

Name: Undergraduate Practicum in Psychology
Desc: 0. May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit. Student responsible for registering with a faculty member. Individually supervised experience in psychological laboratories and community agencies.
Reqs: PSYC 2000 or PSYC 2060, and consent of instructor; LSU and overall GPA of at least 2

Name: Psychological Tests and Measurements
Desc: Test construction, standardization, validation; intelligence, clerical, mechanical, spatial aptitude tests; interest and personality tests; test batteries.
Reqs: PSYC 2000 or PSYC 2001 and a first course in statistics

Name: Cognitive Psychology
Desc: A survey of the psychological approaches to understanding cognition. Topics include the processes and brain mechanisms involved in perception and attention, imagery, memory, language, creativity, problem solving, reasoning and decision-making.

Name: Introduction to Industrial and Organizational Psychology
Desc: Topics include job analysis, performance evaluation, leadership, job satisfaction, motivation, testing and interviewing, employee stress and well-being, training and development, employee selection and recruitment, and groups and teams.

Name: Personality
Desc: Determinants and dynamics of personality; theory and research.

Name: Introduction to Psychological Disorders
Desc: Introduction to common psychological disorders.

Name: Psychological Counseling
Desc: Concepts of psychological treatment in adjustment problems.

Name: Advanced Social Psychology
Desc: Current theories of socialization; existing methodologies and interdisciplinary influences.

Name: Psychology Capstone
Desc: 0. Open to psychology majors; open to others with permission of instructor. This course is only offered online. Review of prominent topics in the Psychology and guidance towards applying for jobs and graduate school.
Reqs: Credit or registration in PSYC 2017 and PSYC 4008 or equivalent; LSU and overall GPA of at least 2

Name: History of Modern Psychology
Desc: of psychology; LSU and overall GPA of at least 2.50. Open to psychology majors; open to other matriculated students with permission of instructor. Historical survey of psychology, with reference to schools of psychology.
Reqs: PSYC 2000 or PSYC 2001 and 6 additional hrs

Name: Psychology of Thinking and Decision-Making
Desc: Experimental methods and research findings on human thinking, decision-making, comprehension, choice behavior and problem solving.

Name: Sensory and Perceptual Processes
Desc: Theories, data and procedures in sensation and perception.

Name: Psychology of Learning
Desc: Behavior from the standpoint of learning; recent experimental literature in the learning area; major theories of learning.

Name: Psychology of Memory and Forgetting
Desc: Major theoretical concepts; review of experimental literature in the field of memory and forgetting.

Name: Physiological Psychology
Desc: Functioning of the nervous system with respect to sensation, perception, learning and motivation.

Name: Drugs, the Brain and Behavior
Desc: Modes of action of drugs on the brain and behavioral effects of therapeutic drugs and drugs of abuse.

Name: Neuropharmacology
Desc: Primarily for students in psychology and basic sciences. Basic pharmacology; neurochemical and physiological mechanisms of drug actions on the nervous system; pharmacology of drugs of abuse and psychiatric medications.

Name: Madness and Medicine
Desc: The history of medical treatments for mental disorders.

Name: Research and Theory in Sexuality
Desc: Sexual behavior viewed from different theoretical perspectives; emphasis on empirical sexual research literature.
Reqs: PSYC 2000 or PSYC 2060 and one additional course in psychology or KIN 2600

Name: Cognitive Neuroscience
Desc: Critical topics in human neuroscience: emphasis on neural mechanisms underlying human cognition.

Name: Psychology of Emotion
Desc: Exploring the nature and function of human emotion by inquiring into the composition, purpose, and import of emotion in our daily lives.

Name: Race and Psychology
Desc: A study of the issues and influences related to race, ethnicity, and cultural identity and how they affect theoretical and research paradigms in psychology.

Name: Developmental Psychology
Desc: Theories of development, contemporary issues and research findings at successive ages of human development; psychological changes throughout the lifespan.

Name: Developmental Psychology of Adulthood and Aging
Desc: Theories, issues, and research findings on psychological changes occurring throughout adulthood and later life.

Name: Applied Behavior Analysis
Desc: Methods, analysis and intervention in the application of basic learning principles; emphasis on school applications.

Name: Intermediate Statistics
Desc: LSU and overall GPA of at least 2.50. Preparatory for graduate study in statistics and research design in psychology. Open to psychology majors; open to other students with permission of instructor. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Emphasis on inferential statistics and hypothesis testing; familiarization with common statistical analysis software and interpretation of output; major topics include simple and factorial analysis of variance, linear and multiple correlation and regression.
Reqs: PSYC 2000 or PSYC 2001 and PSYC 2016 or EXST 2201 or equivalent

Name: Advanced Child Psychology
Desc: of psychology. Psychological theories of child development, child behavior and research methodology.
Reqs: PSYC 2000 or PSYC 2001 and 3 additional hrs

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Psychology
Desc: 0 and consent of instructor. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Open to seniors and graduate students. Student responsible for registering with a faculty member and selecting an area of reading or research.
Reqs: LSU and overall GPA of at least 2

Name: Measurement of Behavior
Desc: Techniques and theories of behavior measurement; problems of data collection; reliability, validity, design and analysis of measurement instruments for the psychological sciences.
Reqs: PSYC 4111 or equivalent; graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Neurocognitive Basis of Behavior
Desc: Neurocognitive processes involved in memory, language, decision-making; role of neurocognitive variables in controlling behavior.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or other matriculated graduate students with consent of instructor

Name: Biological Basis of Behavior
Desc: Selected biological systems involved in mediation of behavior.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or other matriculated graduate students with consent of instructor

Name: Sociocultural Basis of Behavior
Desc: Social, organizational and cultural influences on human behavior; research in social and organizational psychology.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or other matriculated graduate students with consent of instructor

Name: Ethical, Legal and Professional Issues in School Psychology
Desc: Roles and functions of the school psychologist; ethical considerations across diverse roles and settings; legal bases for the practice of school psychology and students’ rights; currently accepted standards for the credentialing of school psychologists and standards for practice.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Statistics
Desc: Machine calculation, coding, measures of cen-trality and variation, regression, correlation, prediction, probability, statistical inference, analysis of variance, multi-variate techniques for the psychological sciences.
Reqs: PSYC 4111 or equivalent; graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Methodology and Research Design
Desc: Scientific approach to psychological questions, research, design and methodology; logic and philosophy underlying psychological theory and research; social psychology of the psychological experiment; experimental and quasi-experimental designs; problems in observation and measurement of behavioral variables; methodological and philosophical considerations in analysis of data.
Reqs: PSYC 4111 or PSYC 7111; graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Psychological Assessment I
Desc: Assessment theory and basic psychometric principles in test construction, evaluation, and application; administration and interpretation of clinical measures (e.g.
Reqs: graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Psychoeducational Assessment
Desc: Instruction and practicum in administration and interpretation of individually administered intellectual assessment measures and diagnostic achievement techniques.
Reqs: graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Developmental Disorders and Psychopathology of Children
Desc: Theories, research and contemporary issues related to normal and problem behaviors of children.
Reqs: graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Behavior Therapy
Desc: Modern treatment and assessment procedures based on learning theories; behavioral analysis and theoretical orientations as applied to a wide variety of clinical disorders.
Reqs: graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Clinical Neuropsychology Seminar
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Graduate students will acquire foundational knowledge in clinical neuropsychology (i.e., knowledge of brain-behavior relationships and knowledge of the practice of clinical neuropsychology) in preparation for further neuropsychology training at the internship and postdoctoral level.

Name: Psychological Assessment I Practicum
Desc: Introduction to the practical aspects associated with the use of psychological measures. An emphasis is placed on gaining competency in the administration, scoring, and interpretation of measures of intellectual functioning, academic achievement, and personality functioning.
Reqs: Credit or registration in PSYC 7125 or equivalent, graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: School Psychological Consultation
Desc: Instruction and practicum that provide psychological consultation on short-term behavior and academic problems for teachers and other school personnel.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Practicum in School Psychology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Closely supervised experience in schools in which students perform psychoeducational assessments, consult with teachers and function as members of multidisciplinary teams; cases include children with specific learning disabilities, behavior disorders and mental retardation.
Reqs: admission to doctoral program in school psychology

Name: Practicum in School Psychology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Closely supervised experience in schools in which students perform psychoeducational assessments, consult with teachers and function as members of multidisciplinary teams; cases include children with specific learning disabilities, behavior disorders and mental retardation.
Reqs: admission to doctoral program in school psychology

Name: Practicum in Clinical Psychology
Desc: 12 sem. hrs. are required. Supervised experience in the application of clinical psychological assessment and intervention techniques with behaviorally disordered populations (adult, child, medical).
Reqs: consent of instructor and enrollment in clinical psychology training program

Name: Practicum in Clinical Psychology
Desc: 12 sem. hrs. are required. Supervised experience in the application of clinical psychological assessment and intervention techniques with behaviorally disordered populations.
Reqs: consent of instructor and enrollment in clinical psychology training program

Name: Teaching of Psychology Practicum
Desc: Course May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Closely supervised experience in teaching in which students will function as the instructor of record for an undergraduate course in the Psychology department; objectives include enhanced teaching skills and the development of a philosophy of teaching.

Name: Psychological Assessment II
Desc: Administration and interpretation of objective and projective tests of personality and psychopathology; neuropsychological assessment techniques.
Reqs: PSYC 7125 or equivalent; graduate standing in clinical psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Psychotherapy and Behavior Change
Desc: Theoretical and empirical considerations relevant to psychoanalytic, humanistic, behavioral and cognitive-behavioral approaches for treating disordered behavior.
Reqs: graduate standing in clinical psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Cultural Diversity Issues in Counseling and Therapy
Desc: Issues of individual and cultural diversity training including definitions of multicultural counseling, historical perspectives, various theories and critical/ethical issues regarding counseling of diverse populations. Practical strategies of service delivery and current research will be reviewed.
Reqs: graduate standing in clinical psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Professional Development
Desc: This course may be repeated for up to 14 sem. hrs. of credit. Critical topics in professional development for cognitive and brain sciences PhD students.

Name: Seminar in Experimental Psychology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Experimental Psychology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Theories and Concepts of Behavior Analysis
Desc: This seminar is designed to provide a survey of the theoretical and experimental foundations of the practice of applied behavior analysis. Readings are selected to enhance students’ understanding of the basic principles of learning and behavior, to highlight areas of basic-oriented research which have been useful in the development of applied practices and to identify areas which may be capable of informing applied practice, but for which research has not yet bridged the gap.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Research Methodology and Application in Behavior Analysis
Desc: Examination of the methods and procedures used in applied behavior analytic practice and research with a focus on direct observation of behavior, behavioral assessment and intervention. Emphasis on clinical and school applications.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Lifespan Development: Behavioral Perspectives
Desc: Examination of the behavioral processes and environmental influences associated with typical and atypical development across the lifespan. Emphasis on verbal, motor, social, and cognitive development from the behavior analytic and competing perspectives.
Reqs: graduate standing in psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Industrial/Organizational Psychology Internship
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Open only to graduate students nominated by the Department of Psychology and accepted by an approved internship organization. Supervised experience in an organization in the application of personnel and organizational psychology principles.

Name: Competencies and Perspectives in Industrial and Organizational Psychology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.  An introduction to the 26 areas of competence suggested by the Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology to be developed during graduate training as well as current topics in I/O research and practice. Additionally, this class will prepare students for their comprehensive examination, and prompt the development of new research projects.

Name: Current Problems in Industrial Psychology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Current Problems in Industrial Psychology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Supervision and Consultation in Psychology
Desc: Focus on supervision and consultation in clinical psychology with discussion of major theories and models. Didactic and experiential methods of instruction will expose students to the implementation and practices of supervision and consultation.
Reqs: graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Current Problems in School Psychology
Desc: Research and methodological issues in school psychology; topics vary.
Reqs: graduate standing in school psychology program or consent of instructor

Name: Internship in School Psychology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. One full academic year of supervised internship that is no less than 1,200 hours, half of which must be in a school setting; internship requirement may be fulfilled by completing one full academic year or two years of one-half time internship experience; at least one hour per week is devoted to direct supervision of each intern.
Reqs: satisfactory completion of the general and language examinations and faculty approval

Name: Child Behavior Therapy
Desc: Behavioral treatment of children’s behavior problems.
Reqs: PSYC 7171 or equivalent; graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: School-Based Psychological Interventions
Desc: Survey of intervention strategies for various disorders and behavior problems displayed by children in school settings.

Name: Current Problems in Developmental Psychology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Advanced Psychopathology
Desc: Theories of psychopathology, specific etiological hypotheses and pertinent research evidence.
Reqs: Graduate standing in clinical or school psychology or consent of instructor

Name: Teaching of Psychology
Desc: Required of all doctoral candidates to become instructor of record in the department. Philosophy, theory and practice in higher education with application to undergraduate instruction in psychology.

Name: Clinical Psychology Internship
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit. Open only to graduate students nominated by the Department of Psychology and accepted by an approved internship program. Supervised evaluation and treatment of individuals manifesting mental disorders.
Reqs: completion of course work, general examination, and dissertation proposal

Name: Professional Considerations in Psychology
Desc: Required of all clinical and school doctoral candidates. Professional ethics, practice and responsibility.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Independent Research: Experimental Psychology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. This course may be repeated for credit; a max. of 15 sem. hrs. in this series is allowed toward doctoral requirements.

Name: Independent Research: Industrial Psychology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. This course may be repeated for credit; a max. of 15 sem. hrs. in this series is allowed toward doctoral requirements.

Name: Independent Research: Developmental Psychology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. This course may be repeated for credit; a max. of 15 sem. hrs. in this series is allowed toward doctoral requirements.

Name: Independent Research: Clinical Psychology
Desc: Pass-fail grading. This course may be repeated for credit; a max. of 15 sem. hrs. in this series is allowed toward doctoral requirements.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Religions of the World
Desc: [LCCN: CPHL 2213, World Religions] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Primarily for non-majors. Survey of the religions of the world such as Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, Islam and indigenous religious traditions.

Name: Old Testament
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and REL 1007. Scholarly study of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament) against the background of the history and religious life of ancient Israel.

Name: New Testament
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Introduction to the history, religion and literature of early Christianity from about 30 to 150 CE; emphasis on the writings of the New Testament and the methods by which scholars study them.

Name: HONORS: Old Testament
Desc: Same as REL 1004, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and REL 1004.

Name: Introduction to the Study of Religion
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Thematic introduction to the academic study of religion; ways of being religious; forms of religious literature; beliefs and rituals; the place of religion in human life.

Name: Faith and Doubt
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. How religious faith is challenged or supported by various factors, such as reason, morality, organized religion, and the experience of suffering.

Name: HONORS: Jesus in History and Tradition
Desc: Primarily for honors students and students concentrating in religious studies. Ideas about Jesus from antiquity to the present, including the modern quest for the historical Jesus.

Name: African American Religion
Desc: Also offered as AAAS 2025. This course will examine black religious experience in the United States from the colonial period to the present.

Name: Asian Religions
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Survey of the history, beliefs and practices of the major religions of Southern and Eastern Asia, focusing on Hinduism, Buddhism and the religions of China and Japan.

Name: Philosophy of Religion
Desc: Same as PHIL 2028. Meaning of religion as a pervasive phenomenon in human societies; faith and reason, nature of divinity, arguments for and against God’s existence, religious knowledge and experience, morality and cult, the problem of evil.

Name: Judaism, Christianity and Islam
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Survey of the history, beliefs and practices of these three related religions.

Name: American Religions
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Introduction to religions in America.

Name: Indigenous Religions
Desc: Introduction to the religions of the indigenous peoples or “First Nations” of the Americas, Africa and Australia.

Name: Magic and Religion
Desc: Examination of a variety of historical, sociological, anthropological, and psychological, attempts to define, analyze and compare magical beliefs, practices, and forms of social production across a variety of historical and cultural settings, ranging from the ancient, medieval and early-modern religious worlds, to contemporary popular culture.

Name: The Holocaust
Desc: Responses of Judaism and the Christian church to Nazi Germany’s killing of the Jews; issues about God, human morality, Western civilization and modernity.

Name: Christianity
Desc: Advanced survey of the global history of Christianity, with in-depth analysis of the diversity of Christian beliefs and practices throughout the world.

Name: Archaeology and the Bible
Desc: Also offered as ANTH 3004. Major figures and discoveries influencing the historical study of the Bible; emphasis on results of excavations and discovery of written documents and inscriptions.

Name: Special Topics in Religious Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Mysticism
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Studies of the literature and practices of particular mystical traditions, such as Christian, Kabbalistic, Sufi, Hindu, Buddhist, Taoist, Afro-Caribbean or the shamanistic traditions of the Americas, or Tibet and Central Asia.

Name: Native American Religions
Desc: Survey of native North American religious traditions from prehistory to the present; including issues of conversion and Christianization, freedom of religion and gender.

Name: Apocalypse: Then and Now
Desc: Ideas about the end of the world from antiquity to the present; emphasis on the book of Revelation and its continuing influence.

Name: Comparative Mythology
Desc: See CLST 3090.

Name: Fundamentalisms and Religious Nationalism
Desc: Also offered as INTL 3092. Investigates how the phenomenon of fundamentalism manifests itself in combinations of religion and politics in various countries around the world as a response to “modernity.”

Name: Judaism
Desc: Religious texts, faith and practice in Judaism, from antiquity to the present.

Name: American Catholic History
Desc: Roman Catholicism in its North American context: the European heritage; immigration; political, intellectual and devotional life.

Name: Ancient Hebrew Prophets
Desc: Prophetic movement in ancient Israel; different modern interpretations of prophecy.

Name: The Literature of the English Bible
Desc: Also offered as ENGL 3124.

Name: Religion and Parapsychology
Desc: Extraordinary human experiences such as faith healing, death and dying, exorcism, apparitions and witchcraft, examined from the perspective of religious phenomenology, philosophy and psychology.

Name: Women and Religion
Desc: Role of women in the religions of the world.

Name: The Religion of Islam
Desc: Also offered as INTL 3786. Introduction to the major religious and cultural dimensions of the Islamic world, both those that express its diversity and those that express its continuity; emphasis on the development of classical Islamic institutions and ideas, the diverse forms of Islamic religious and cultural life over the past fourteen centuries as the Islamicate tradition has spread around the world.

Name: South Asian Society, Polity and Culture
Desc: See INTL 4002.

Name: Selected Topics in Religious Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: The Age of Reformation
Desc: See HIST 4011.

Name: History of Modern Christian Thought
Desc: Major figures in the history of Christian thought from the Reformation through the 19th century.

Name: Questions in Jewish Thought
Desc: Also offered as GERM 4014, HIST 4014, and PHIL 4014. This is a survey of the major questions of Jewish thinkers in the Modern Period, such as, how new ideas about identity and religiousness emerged, how the social changes influenced the view of Jews and Judaism and how the Holocaust has altered everything.

Name: Modern European Jewish History
Desc: Also offered as Hist 4015. This is a survey of Modern European Jewish History discussing how new ideas about identity and religiousness emerged, how the social changes influenced the view of Jews and Judaism and how the Holocaust has altered everything.

Name: Religion and Healing
Desc: Analysis of cultural and religious influences on the concepts of illness and health and the relationship of body and mind in cross-cultural perspective, including bio-medicine and a range of Asian healing paradigms.

Name: Comparative Religions
Desc: See ANTH 4031.

Name: Religion, Gender and Society
Desc: Also offered as ANTH 4032. Examination of the link between religious ideas and gender formulations within simple and complex societies and certain religious communities.

Name: Women & Buddhism
Desc: Buddhist concepts of women in comparative socio-historical contexts. Critical analyses of practices, teachings, and interpretive frames.

Name: A History of God
Desc: Traces the development of the concept of God from antiquity to the present.

Name: Geography of Religion
Desc: See GEOG 4079.

Name: The Modern Middle East
Desc: See HIST 4096.

Name: Political Theology
Desc: See POLI 4097.

Name: Studies in African Diaspora Religions
Desc: Also offered as AAAS 4124. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Analysis of religious beliefs, rituals, and practices and their roles in the lives of African Diaspora peoples.

Name: History of Ancient Israel
Desc: Also offered as HIST 4125. Israelite history from its beginnings to the Christian era; readings from biblical and other ancient Near Eastern texts.

Name: History of Religion in the United States
Desc: See HIST 4161.

Name: Religion in Southern Culture
Desc: Religion as a component of Southern history and culture; emphasis on the religious culture of Louisiana.

Name: Religions of China and Japan
Desc: See HIST 4191.

Name: Special Topics in American Religion
Desc: Advanced examination of special topics in American religion.

Name: Contemporary Christian Thought
Desc: Major theologians and theological movements of the 20th century.

Name: Studies in Literature and Religion
Desc: See ENGL 4236.

Name: Theories of Religion
Desc: Theories about the origin, nature and function of religion from the social sciences and other disciplines.

Name: Religious Thought of Martin Luther King, Jr. & Malcolm X
Desc: Also offered as AAAS 4400. This course explores the religious thought of Martin Luther King, Jr. and Malcolm X through a close examination of their most significant writings and speeches.

Name: Seminar in Biblical Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: The Rise of Christianity
Desc: Also offered as HIST 4505. An introduction to the history, literature, and religion of ancient Christianity from its beginnings in first-century Palestine to its establishment as the mandated religion of the Roman Empire under Justinian in the sixth century.

Name: Topics in the History of Christianity
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Hinduism
Desc: A survey of Hinduism from its origins to the present.

Name: Buddhism
Desc: A survey of Buddhism from its origins to the present.

Name: Buddhist Psychology
Desc: Buddhist conceptions of mind, self, psyche and personhood in comparison to Western views of the same.

Name: Medieval Philosophy
Desc: See PHIL 4928.

Name: Kierkegaard
Desc: See PHIL 4939.

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.
Reqs: written consent of instructor and department

Name: Independent Study
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Natural Resource Conservation
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Relationship of humans to the natural environment; ecology and conservation of soil, water, forest, range, wildlife and fisheries resources.

Name: Issues in Natural Resource Management
Desc: Discussions of the ecological, economic, sociocultural and political factors that affect human relationships with the natural environment and the exploitation and conservation of water, forest, range, wildlife, wetland and fisheries resources.
Reqs: for RNR majors only; credit or registration in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071

Name: Conservation of Forest Resources
Desc: Resources of forest and range land, including wood, wildlife, recreation forage and water; techniques of multiple-use management of forest lands.

Name: Introduction to Natural Resource Ecology and Management
Desc: Majors only or permission of instructor. 3 hrs. lecture, 1 hr. discussion. Ecology, management, and conservation of forest, fish, wetland, and wildlife species and their habitats; introduction to the ecology and taxonomy of commercially, socio-culturally, recreationally, and ecologically important terrestrial and aquatic organisms.
Reqs: Credit or concurrent enrollment in BIOL 1201

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Natural Resource Ecology and Management
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture, 1 hr discussion. Ecology, management, and conservation of forest, fish, wetland, and wildlife species and their habitats; introduction to the ecology and taxonomy of commercially, socio-culturally, recreationally, and ecologically important terrestrial and aquatic organisms.
Reqs: Admission to the Honors College and credit or registration in BIOL 1207

Name: Trees and Woody Plants of the Southeast
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 1 hr. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principal trees of the southeastern U.S.; their identification, classification, nomenclature, and distribution. Emphasis on southern timber species; common shrubs, ornamentals, woody vines and some herbaceous plants will also be covered.
Reqs: “C” or better in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071, “C” or better in BIOL 1202

Name: Introduction to Fisheries and Aquaculture
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. History and scope of fisheries and aquaculture; production and harvest of economically important aquatic vertebrates and invertebrates; role of fisheries and aquaculture professionals in society.

Name: Trees and Woody Plants of the Eastern and Western United States
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 3 hr. lab. Important trees of the eastern and western U.S.; their identification, distribution and value. Emphasis on important timber species and a limited number of common woody shrubs.

Name: Introduction to Medicinal Plants
Desc: Overview of general topics including types of medicinal compounds; temporal and spatial variations; postharvest handling and processing; testing of medicinal properties; product formulation and regulation.

Name: Principles of Wildlife Management
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 2072. Wildlife conservation and management; ecology and management of wildlife in relation to the objectives of consumptive and nonconsumptive interest groups.
Reqs: RNR 2101 or RNR 2070 or concurrent enrollment

Name: Introduction to Renewable Natural Resource Policy
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 2071. Development and implementation of policies in renewable natural resources with emphasis on forestry, wildlife, fisheries, and waterfowl policies; current environmental issues.
Reqs: “C” or better in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071 or equivalent; “C” or better in BIOL 1202

Name: Wood Science and Forest Products
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Structural components of wood and identifying characteristics; basic physical properties; manufacture and uses of forest products.

Name: Problems in Natural Resource Management
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Credit varies by topic. Individual, independent, mentored, and directed study.
Reqs: permission of department; “C” or better in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071 and “C” or better in BIOL 1202

Name: Introductory Special Topics in Natural Resources
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics not covered in other renewable natural resources courses.
Reqs: permission of department; “C” or better in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071 and “C” or better in BIOL 1202

Name: Introductory Internship in Natural Resources
