Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit when projects vary. Supervised professional experience designed to integrate academic learning with professional practice.
Reqs: permission of department; “C” or better in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071; “C” or better in BIOL 1202

Name: HONORS: Ecology of Renewable Natural Resources
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 2101. Ecological principles and population dynamics; emphasis on interactions between populations in communities, ecosystems and landscapes.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Renewable Natural Resources Policy
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 2039. Development and implementation of policies in renewable natural resources; current environmental issues.
Reqs: credit or enrollment in RNR 2070 or permission of instructor; “C” or better in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071 or equivalent; “C” or better in BIOL 1202

Name: HONORS: Principles of Wildlife Management
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 2031. Population management, habitat management and policy associated with wildlife management. Sustainability of hunting and of endangered wildlife species. Indirect effects of toxins, eutrophication, human infrastructure and climate change on wildlife habitat and wildlife populations.

Name: Ecology of Renewable Natural Resources
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 2070. General ecological principles tied to the conservation and management of plant and animal populations; emphasis on how populations interact in communities and ecosystems.
Reqs: RNR 1010 or RNR 1071, “C” or better in BIOL 1202, BIOL 1209

Name: Natural Resource Measurements and GIS
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Introduction to sampling techniques in measuring renewable natural resources, such as trees, wood products, forest stands, wildlife and fisheries populations and water quality. Introduction to use of global information systems (GIS) and global positioning systems (GPS) applications in natural resource management.
Reqs: “C” or better in RNR 1010 or RNR 1071 or equivalent; “C” or better in BIOL 1202

Name: Horticultural Botany
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Introductory plant biology, including anatomy and morphology, physiology, evolution and diversity, and field botany and ecology. One Saturday field trip is required.

Name: Silviculture
Desc: Basic knowledge of personal computers and e-mail is assumed. A generalized approach to forest stand establishment and culture based on the ecological principles of regeneration and the identification of stand conditions that will satisfy specific goals and objectives for the forest.

Name: Photogrammetry, GPS and GIS
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. lab. Principles, interpretation and use of aerial photos, Global Positioning Systems (GPS) and Geographic Information Systems (GIS) in stand measurements and forest management applications.

Name: Field Studies in Wildlife Habitat and Management
Desc: Class meets 8 hrs. per day for 2 weeks at off-campus sites. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Identification of woody and herbaceous plants important to wildlife species and techniques used to manage and quantify wildlife habitat; emphasis on collecting field data and plant identification in field setting to assess habitat quality and management options for wildlife.

Name: Ecology and Management of Southeastern Wildlife
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 6 hrs. lab. Habitat selection, food habits and reproductive biology of selected species of amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals and fishes; emphasis on the diversity of niche exploitation strategies among these groups.

Name: Field Studies in Dendrology
Desc: One week of field practice. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Review of species studied in RNR 2001; 60 to 70 more species of trees, shrubs and woody vines indigenous to the southeastern U.S. studied; herbarium collection required.

Name: Field Studies in Mensuration
Desc: Two weeks of field practice. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Exercises in designing and conducting timber and multipurpose cruises; boundary location and other types of land surveying associated with forest resource management.

Name: Field Studies in Silviculture
Desc: One week of field practice. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Field tours of a range of forestry practices and field experiences in various silviculture practices.

Name: Field Studies in Timber Harvesting
Desc: One week of field practice. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. On-site studies of harvesting systems used in southern forestry; participation in timber harvesting; exercises in time and production.

Name: Field Studies in Wood Utilization
Desc: One week of field practice. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. On-site studies of wood manufacturing facilities; exercises in product/raw material relationships.

Name: Silvicultural Prescriptions
Desc: One week of field practice. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Practical development of silvicultural prescriptions incorporating elementary economic analysis and silvicultural principles.

Name: Field Studies in Forested Wetlands
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Learn about structure, functions, and ecosystem services of wetlands in forested landscapes through field experiences and field trips. Gain an appreciation for wetland and water management issues and techniques in forestry.

Name: Renewable Natural Resources Field Studies
Desc: One-week field trip. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Insight into management objectives and issues in forested ecosystems not found in the West Gulf Coastal Plain; experience gained through on-site tours and discussions with various natural resource professionals.

Name: Forest Biometrics
Desc: Principles in measuring trees, stands, wood products and other forest resources; sampling and inventory techniques; statistical inference.

Name: Forest Biology
Desc: This is an 8-week course. The general university drop/add dates do not apply. The instructor will provide students with the drop/add dates established by the Office of the University Registrar. Topics include: tree anatomy, tree growth, tree physiology, forest genetics and ecological principles specific to the understanding of forest ecosystems and sustainable management of forests.

Name: Timber Harvesting
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. This is an 8-week course, the general university drop/add dates do not apply. The instructor will provide students with the drop/add dates established by the Office of the University Registrar. 1 hr. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Methods of harvesting timber crops; logging equipment, planning, road layout, legal and social issues, environmental concerns, financial analysis of logging operations and contracts; field trips and practical exercises included.

Name: Wood Procurement
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. This is an 8-week course. The general university drop/add dates do not apply. The instructor will provide students with the drop/add dates established by the Office of the University Registrar. 1 hr. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Methods of purchasing and marketing timber crops; practicum of timber and pulpwood purchasing systems; value assessments, wood specifications, human relations, negotiations, ethics, competitive bidding; legal and social issues; contracts; records; wood storage; and global aspects; field trips and practical exercises included.

Name: Case Studies in Habitat Restoration
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 1 hr. lecture, 3 hrs. lab Principles related to the context, planning, design and implementation of habitat restoration and mitigation; evaluation of habitat restoration efforts using the case study method.
Reqs: RNR 2101 or RNR 2070; Extended length single day trips and multiple night field trip during spring break or as specified in syllabus are required

Name: Quantitative Methods in Wildlife and Fisheries
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Specialized, modern quantitative methods necessary for entry-level and early career positions in wildlife and fisheries research and management. Computer-based data analysis of GIS, remotely-sensed, and field collected experimental and observational data, including life tables, mark-recapture, matrix population expansion, and distance and detection based abundance estimation.
Reqs: RNR 1010, RNR 2101, “C” or better in RNR 2102, EXST 2201 and junior or senior status

Name: Silviculture Lab
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Working knowledge of a word processor, spreadsheet and email is assumed. 3 hrs. lab. Basic office and field techniques for assessing forest structure and controlling stand development.

Name: Wildlife Management Techniques
Desc: Weekend field trips. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Wildlife science and the scientific method, generating and testing hypotheses and predictions, statistical analysis of class generated data and scientific writing. Population inventories and analysis; harvest management; methods to capture animals and determine age and sex. Immobilization methods, marking methods, radio telemetry and assessment of nutrition and condition. Use of GPS and GIS in wildlife ecology.
Reqs: RNR 2031 or RNR 2072 and EXST 2201; RNR 3018

Name: Waterfowl Biology and Conservation
Desc: Weekend field trips. Students are responsible for paying travel expenses associated with this course. Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 7012. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Ecology, conservation, and management of North American waterfowl; overview of life history theory and behavioral ecology of waterfowl; methods of population monitoring and management, habitat management, and human dimensions of waterfowl conservation.

Name: Ecology and Management of Wetland Wildlife
Desc: Extended length single day trips and multiple day, overnight field trip over Fall Break or as described in syllabus are required. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. History and value of wetlands, waterfowl, fur animals, alligators, wetland habitat management.

Name: Conservation Biology
Desc: hrs. biological sciences; genetics recommended.

Name: Upland Game Bird Biology
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Not for graduate credit. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Biology, ecology, conservation, and management of selected upland birds found in North America.

Name: Laboratory in Conservation Biology
Desc: Same as BIOL 4017. 4 hrs. lab.

Name: Taxonomy and Ecology of Wetland Plants
Desc: See BIOL 4020.

Name: Principles of Aquaculture
Desc: hrs. of introductory chemistry and 8 sem. hrs. of introductory zoology and/or biology; or equivalent. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab with occasional extended field trips. Principles underlying aquaculture of fish, crustaceans and mollusks.

Name: Marine Fisheries Resources
Desc: Survey of the biology, harvest and management of commercially important marine organisms throughout the world; emphasis on stock trends and the effects of biological and socio- economic factors on development of management programs.

Name: Limnology
Desc: Geomorphology, physiochemistry, biology and ecology of inland waters.
Reqs: BIOL 1201, BIOL 1208 and CHEM 1201, CHEM 1202, CHEM 1212 or equivalent

Name: Forest Fire Protection and Use
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 8-week course. The general university drop/add dates do not apply. The instructor will provide students with drop/add dates established by the Office of the University Registrar. 1 hr. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Forest fire control and use; emphasis on southern forests.

Name: Silviculture and Management of Hardwoods
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. Extended field trips, one weekend field trip. 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Ecology, silviculture and management of hardwood forest ecosystems; improvement, conservation, and use for forest products, wildlife habitats and other amenities.

Name: Forest Management
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Compounding and discounting; management of a single stand, even-aged and uneven-aged management, decision criteria and decision variables, management of an existing stand; forest taxation and valuation; management of many stands; harvest scheduling.
Reqs: ECON 2030 or AGEC 2003 or equivalent, RNR 3036, RNR 3037 and RNR 3040

Name: Biology of Fishes
Desc: Morphological, physiological and behavioral adaptations of fishes to their environments; relationships between fish biology and fisheries management.

Name: Forest Resource Economics
Desc: Economic theory applied to forest resources and their utilization; structure of the forest products market, demand of forest products, timber supply and stumpage price; resource conservation and endangered species protection; taxation and government programs; international trade of forest products; demand for non-timber resources.

Name: Fisheries Management
Desc: Characteristics of fisheries; dynamics of exploited stocks; socioeconomic aspects of fisheries; fisheries management and research techniques; managing wild fisheries stocks.

Name: Wildlife Habitat Management
Desc: Extended length single day trips and multiple day, overnight field trip over Fall Break or as described in syllabus are required. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles of managing landscapes to benefit a diversity of wildlife species, as well as specific management strategies to benefit single species; management scenarios for a variety of forested, open and urban habitats will be discussed.

Name: Taxonomy and Ecology of Upland Plants
Desc: Two Saturday field trips are required. 1 hr. lec.; 3 hrs. lab. Identification of upland plants and familiarization with regional upland habitats.
Reqs: at least one of the following: RNR 2001, RNR 4020, BIOL 4041, BIOL 4055, or an approved equivalent

Name: Special Problems in Natural Resource Management
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. credit. Credit varies by topic. Individual, independent, mentored, and directed study.

Name: Special Topics in Natural Resources
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Lectures and/or laboratories on selected topics not covered in other renewable natural resources courses.

Name: Wildlife Field Study in Africa
Desc: Permission of instructor. Seminar to prepare students for field study of wildlife research and management practices in southern Africa.
Reqs: RNR 2031 or RNR 2072, RNR 2101 or RNR 2070 or equivalent, and RNR 3018

Name: Capstone: Natural Resources Management, Policy and Human Dimensions
Desc: Students are responsible for travel expenses associated with this course. Course is intended for students in the final semester. 2 hrs. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Development of problem-solving skills for the management of renewable natural resources; application and integration of renewable natural resource management theory, policy, practices and human dimensions; analysis of management and policy decisions.
Reqs: RNR 2039 or RNR 2071, RNR 3004 and senior status in School of Renewable Natural Resources

Name: Conservation Genetics
Desc: Application of genetic theory to the management of renewable natural resources; emphasis on fragmented populations, endangered species, maintenance of genetic variation.

Name: Techniques in Limnology and Fisheries
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. lab. Quantitative techniques in habitat, water quality and fish population assessment in freshwater ecosystems.
Reqs: junior, senior or graduate standing and permission of instructor

Name: Human Dimensions in Natural Resources
Desc: social science general education electives. Human behavior as related to management and use of natural resources.

Name: Outreach Methods in Natural Resource Ecology and Management
Desc: Current environmental issues including ecological, economic, sociocultural and political factors that affect human relationships with the natural environment. Introduction to general principles of environmental literacy and outreach methods for various audiences.
Reqs: For RNR majors only or permission of instructor; BIOL 1202, BIOL 1209, RNR 1001, RNR 2101 or RNR 2070

Name: African Wildlife Ecology
Desc: Permission of department. Junior, senior, or graduate student status. May be offered for up to 4 credits. Two weeks of field practice. Students are responsible for travel expenses associated with this course. Field study of wildlife ecology, research, and management practices in southern Africa.
Reqs: RNR 2031 or RNR 2072, RNR 2101 or RNR 2070 or equivalent, RNR 3018, and RNR 4064

Name: African Coastal Ecology and Field Techniques
Desc: Emphasis on skill development for coastal research in regions of low accessibility and infrastructure, underwater data collection, and project design and communication to diverse audiences. Unique ecology of southeastern Africa coast is highlighted with opportunity to study coastal processes, primary production, food web dynamics and large marine mega-fauna.

Name: Introduction to Aquatic Entomology
Desc: See: ENTM 4130.

Name: Wildlife and Fisheries Ecotoxicology
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Provides students with an overview of ecological and biological aspects of toxicology. Emphasizes the biochemical and physiological effects of pollutants on animals, effects on wildlife and fisheries population dynamics, modeling, as well as, techniques applied in wildlife and fisheries toxicology studies.

Name: Ichthyology
Desc: See BIOL 4145.

Name: Forest Hydrology and Soils
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Principles of hydrology and soils with emphasis on forest environments. Forest soil development, role of forests in the hydrologic cycle, and the role of soil and water in natural resource management.

Name: Environmental and Natural Resources Policy
Desc: See ENVS 4268.

Name: Watershed Hydrology
Desc: See ENVS 4900.

Name: Introductory Wildlife Population Dynamics
Desc: Not for graduate credit.  2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Introduction to theories of population growth and regulation, population interaction, life tables, mortality rate calculation; band data analysis, population modeling.
Reqs: MATH 1431/MATH 1550; credit or enrollment in RNR 4011

Name: Research Methodology
Desc: Planning, conducting and reporting of research in the renewable natural resources.

Name: Behavioral Ecology
Desc: Behavioral ecology of plants and animals; evolution of behavior; behavioral strategies for survival and reproduction; importance of behavior to management and conservation strategies.

Name: Policy Considerations for the Management of Natural Resources
Desc: Review of the history of U.S. natural resource policy to include the policy process and policy conflicts. Development of skills needed to evaluate natural resources policy. Focus on agricultural policy and public policy concerning land, endangered species, environmental regulations and incentive programs.

Name: Green Energy in Renewable Natural Resources
Desc: Energy derived from green sources, including wood and agronomic biomass, wind, solar, conversion technologies, gasification, ethanol, biodiesel, synthetic gas, landfill gas, manures, economic considerations, and carbon credits.

Name: Writing, Editing, and Revising Drafts for Grants and Publications in the Natural Science
Desc: 3 hrs. discussion of book chapters/readings and peer/instructor edits. Extensive reading, discussion, and editing to improve writing skills and produce text suitable for submission to granting agencies and peer-reviewed journals.

Name: Mammalian Ecology and Management
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Management, ecology and conservation of selected mammals of North America.

Name: Ecology and Management of Waterfowl
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and RNR 4012. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Behavioral and physiological adaptations of waterfowl throughout the annual cycle; population dynamics and habitat management; political and economic aspects of harvest management in North America.

Name: Wildlife Population Dynamics
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Theories of population growth and regulation, population interaction, life tables, mortality rate calculation; band data analysis; population modeling.

Name: Ecology and Management of Upland Birds
Desc: Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab Ecology and management of selected upland birds found in North America; students will develop a comprehensive management plan for a selected species.

Name: Current Topics and Techniques in Conservation Science
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Scientific basis for the preservation of biodiversity; conservation strategies of government and non-government organizations; current status of biodiversity around the world; new techniques applicable to conservation biology; quantitative exercise with predictive demography (PVA), biodiversity at the population and community levels, fragmentation and other landscape effects and genetics of small populations.

Name: Restoration and Management of Wetland Functions
Desc: Two weekend field trips; one five-day field trip. Students are responsible for paying for travel expenses associated with this course. 2 hrs. lecture, 6 hrs. lab. Wetland Ecology with a focus on functions valued by society; natural history of commonly managed wetland types; fundamentals of restoration ecology; wetland restoration programs in theory and in practice.

Name: Ecology of Fishes
Desc: Ecology of fish populations; interactions of fishes and their environment; behavioral adaptations of fishes.

Name: Advanced Topics in Renewable Natural Resources
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Aquatic Entomology
Desc: See ENTM 7030.

Name: Advanced Topics in Natural Resources Biometrics and Management
Desc: Theory and practice of modeling in natural resources applications, including populations, communities, habitats and related biological, physical and chemical processes.

Name: Environmental Law and Regulation
Desc: See ENVS 7043.

Name: International Environmental Law and Policy
Desc: See ENVS 7046.

Name: Natural Resources Law and Policy
Desc: See ENVS 7048.

Name: Watershed Biogeochemistry
Desc: See ENVS 7061.

Name: Graduate Seminar in Fisheries
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Graduate Seminar in Forestry
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 3 hrs. of credit.

Name: Graduate Seminar in Wildlife
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary. Topics of current interest in wildlife science and management.

Name: Graduate Seminar in Watershed and Water Resources
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. credit when topics vary; consent of instructor. Critical reading and discussion of current literature and major topics in watershed and water resources relating to natural resources.

Name: Potamology
Desc: Also offered as ENVS 7152. Physical, chemical, and biological processes of rivers; relationships among drainage area, runoff, discharge, floodplain, and flood risk; river-coast continuum; human impacts on river, water quality, and ecosystems; river restoration and management.

Name: Diseases of Aquatic Animals
Desc: Basic microbiology and/or parasitology strongly recommended.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Research Problems in Natural Resources
Desc: Pass-fail grading. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Becoming a Scientist
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and LSU 1001.  How to launch a science or math major at LSU. Integration into the campus; development of essential academic skills; personal growth/self-awareness; career exploration; and becoming a member of the community within science/mathematics, the campus and beyond.

Name: Inquiry Approaches to Math and Science Teaching
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and SCI 2012. Introduction to the theory and practice of inquiry-based math and science instruction; design and execution of lesson plans in elementary school under guidance of course instructor and mentoring elementary school teacher.

Name: Inquiry-Based Math and Science Lesson Design
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and SCI 2012. Design and teach lesson plans in middle school under guidance of course instructor and mentoring middle school teacher.

Name: Inquiry-Based Math and Science Teaching
Desc: Credit will not be given for both this course and SCI 2010 or SCI 2011.  Introduction to the theory and practice of inquiry-based math and science instruction; design and teach lesson plans in middle school under guidance of course instructor and mentoring middle school teacher.

Name: Introduction to Screen Arts
Desc: Study of film, television and video.

Name: Introduction to Global Cinemas
Desc: Also offered as CPLT 2203. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. when topics vary with permission of department. Comparative study of selected global, non-US cinemas in cultural and historical contexts.

Name: Special Topics in Screen Arts
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics relevant to the study of screen arts.

Name: Art of Cinematography
Desc: In-depth study of history, concepts, and methods of film and video cinematography; formal instruction and practice in filmmaking techniques such as framing, camera movement, depth of field, and other key ideas as they relate to the creation of film narrative, aesthetic communication, and rhetoric.

Name: Art of Editing
Desc: In-depth study of the history, concepts, and skills involved in film and video editing techniques; formal instruction and practice in non-linear editing along with concepts such as montage, continuity editing, and narrative.

Name: Film Directing
Desc: In-depth study of and practice in various elements, techniques, and disciplines for directing film and video. Development of such skills as on-screen storytelling; manipulating performance, mood, and emotion; logistical, technical, and artistic problem-solving; managing time and people.

Name: Film Producing
Desc: An in-depth, intensive examination of film producing as related to the business and managerial side of contemporary video and cinema production.

Name: Independent Study in Screen Arts
Desc: Program of study, research and work in areas concerned with screen arts.

Name: Internship in Screen Arts
Desc: Normally open to only juniors and seniors. Internship at Screen Arts related agency, organization, or network, and research project and discussion with faculty mentor.
Reqs: Permission of department; permission of instructor

Name: Middle Eastern Cinema: Identities in Motion
Special Topics in Italian Cinema
Desc: See ITAL 3502.

Name: Special Topics in Asian Cinema
Desc: May be taken for 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. In-depth study of various aspects of Asian cinema.

Name: Special Topics in Latin American Cinema
Desc: May be taken for 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.  In-depth study of various aspects of Latin American cinema.

Name: Horror Film
Desc: In-depth study of various aspects of the Horror Film genre.

Name: Special Topics in German Film
Desc: See: GERM 3506.

Name: Advanced Topics in Screen Arts
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Advanced topics relevant to the study of screen arts.

Name: Advanced Editing
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Study of advanced concepts and techniques in film and video editing; formal instruction and practice in advanced skills in non-linear editing such as effects techniques, chroma-keying, compositing, audio mixing, color grading, titling, etc.
Reqs: SCRN 3011 or equivalent, or permission of instructor

Name: Advanced Film Directing
Desc: Students will each make a single, semester-long ambitious short film (narrative or documentary) applying all the steps in a director’s journey from idea to finished film.
Reqs: Credit in SCRN 3010, SCRN 3012, SCRN 3014 or equivalent or permission of instructor

Name: Advanced Film Producing
Desc: Advanced study and practice in the business and managerial side of film-making.
Reqs: SCRN 3010, SCRN 3012, SCRN 3014 or equivalent or permission of instructor

Name: Advanced Film Practices
Desc: Students will select different specialties/departments on a film crew and create film scenes to increase their knowledge of and skills within the chosen specialty.
Reqs: Credit in SCRN 3010, SCRN 3011, SCRN 3012, SCRN 3014 or equivalent or permission of instructor

Name: Advanced German Film
Desc: See GERM 4046.

Name: Graduate Seminar in Screen Arts
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 hours of credit when topics vary.  Interdisciplinary graduate level study of selected topics in Screen Arts.

Name: Independent Study in Screen Arts
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.  Independent graduate level research and study of designed topics in Screen Arts.

Name: Introductory Sociology
Desc: [LCCN: CSOC 2013, Introduction to Sociology] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Credit will not be given for this course and SOCL 2002. Major subject areas and principles of sociology.

Name: HONORS: Introductory Sociology
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as SOCL 2001 with a special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and SOCL 2001.

Name: Louisiana in a Global Context
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Introduces students to the history, people and culture of Louisiana through academic learning and hands on experience.

Name: Introduction to Statistical Analysis
Desc: Open to sociology majors; open to others with permission of instructor. 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab Descriptive statistics; inferential statistical methods including confidence interval estimation and hypothesis testing for one and two population means and proportions; one-way analysis of variance; simple linear regression and correlation; analysis of categorical data.

Name: Methods of Sociological Research
Desc: Open to sociology majors; open to others with permission of instructor. Scientific methods and their application in sociological research, including problem selection, research design, measurement, data sources and evaluation of data.

Name: Sociology of Sport
Desc: Application of sociological principles, theories, and methods to the understanding of sport.

Name: Introduction to Crime Studies
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Fundamentals of the causes, correlates, consequences, and controls of crime in society, including definitional and methodological issues.

Name: Aspects of Federal, State and Local Law Enforcement
Desc: A survey of federal, state and local law enforcement agencies origins, powers, and career expectations.

Name: Industrial Sociology
Desc: Social organization in industry; relation of industry to community and society.

Name: Current Social Problems
Desc: [LCCN: CSOC 2113, Social Problems] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Sociological analysis of major social problems in contemporary society; focus on both the institutional and personal causes and consequences.

Name: Marriage and Family
Desc: [LCCN: CSOC 2213, Marriage and Family] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Current issues and trends regarding marriage and family.

Name: Race Relations
Desc: [LCCN: CSOC 2413, Race, Class & Ethnicity] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Also offered as AAAS 2511. Examines relations among persons of different racial groups in an interdisciplinary setting that includes sociological, psychological, political, anthropological and historical viewpoints.

Name: Sociological Theory
Desc: Open to sociology majors; open to others with permission of instructor. Dominant theorists and schools of thought in sociology.

Name: Sociology of the Criminal Justice System
Desc: The criminal justice system and its organizational components.

Name: Sociology of Culture
Desc: Current theoretical perspectives, methodological issues and empirical work in the sociological study of culture.

Name: Sociology of Deviance
Desc: Sociological theories of deviant behavior; sup-porting research on mental illness, crime, sexual deviance, drug abuse and suicide.

Name: Poverty in the United States
Desc: Definition of poverty, its meaning, measurement, causes, correlates and consequences; strategies for its amelioration and elimination.

Name: Criminal Violence
Desc: An in-depth study of criminal violence, including its forms, myths and facts regarding victims and offenders, and the causes, consequences and control of violence.

Name: Social Interaction
Desc: Human behavior as social interaction.

Name: Death and Dying in the US
Desc: Understanding death and dying as it relates to individuals and society in the US.

Name: Sociology Internship
Desc: 0 overall GPA, written consent of department head and supervising faculty member May be taken for a max. of 3 hrs. of credit. Faculty supervised field study/research with an agency or organization whose mission is considered relevant to the student’s curriculum.

Name: Directed Reading and Research in Sociology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. credit. Student registers with a faculty member before registration to select the area of reading or research. Topic must not substitute for regularly offered courses unless reading goes beyond a standard course’s offerings.

Name: HONORS: Senior Thesis Research
Desc: Supervised research and preparation of a senior thesis.
Reqs: SOCL 3901; Open to seniors who are candidates for a bachelor’s degree with honors in sociology

Name: Research Practicum in Sociology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. credit. Student registers with a faculty member and, in consultation, selects a research problem. Supervised research experience in sociology, including design, execution and reporting.
Reqs: SOCL 2211 and SOCL 3101; for majors only

Name: Topics in Sociology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: The Community
Desc: Classical and contemporary perspectives on the community; theoretical and methodological issues associated with community studies.

Name: Social Stratification
Desc: Class and rank structure in society; determinants of social class, mobility, and changes in class position of both individuals and groups; attitudinal and behavioral consequences of class position.

Name: The Family
Desc: The family as a social institution.

Name: Modeling Communication Within Marital and Family Relationships
Desc: See CMST 4118.

Name: Political Sociology
Desc: Social structure and politics.

Name: Sociology of Education
Desc: Theoretical approaches to understanding the roles of the institution of education, socialization processes, the linkages between education and stratification and educational change.

Name: Sociology of Religion
Desc: Nature of religion; societal and cultural factors in religion; role of religion in social change and in contemporary society.

Name: Sociology of Medicine
Desc: Sociological analysis of the structure and function of health agencies and occupations; social and cultural factors in the cause and treatment of illness.

Name: Sociology of Mental Health
Desc: Sociological analysis of mental health and its related institutions.

Name: Criminology
Desc: Crime, the criminal justice system and penology.

Name: Sociology of Youth & Crime
Desc: The sociological study of adolescent deviance and crime; the socio-demographic correlates and social psychological causes of youthful offending and the juvenile justice system.

Name: Gender and Crime
Desc: Examination of gender as a socially, culturally and historically situated accomplishment and its relationship to criminal offending and victimization.

Name: Rural Crime
Desc: Focuses on the nature, extent, causes, consequences and control of crime in rural America; topics include violence, property crime, fear of crime and agricultural and wildlife crime.

Name: Drugs and Society
Desc: An exploration of the net of social relations in which drugs, drug users, drug dealers and drug laws are embedded; involves critical analysis of popular claims about drugs and the development of a sociological understanding of substance use and abuse in the modern U.S.

Name: Crime Mapping
Desc: Also offered as GEOG 3043. Fundamentals of crime mapping and crime analysis with spatial data using geographic information systems (GIS).

Name: Crime GIS
Desc: See GEOG 4043.

Name: Sociology of Gangs
Desc: The sociological study of gangs in modern society.

Name: Policing and Race in the US
Desc: Explores the relationship between policing and race in the United States.

Name: Sociology of Law
Desc: Law and social change; evolution of legal institutions; group conflict and law; influence of legal controls and sanctions on human behavior.

Name: Sociology of Gender
Desc: Gender differences in families, education, the workplace and the state; understanding the social, economic and cultural factors that shape the lives of men and women; theoretical analysis of how different women and men experience the social world.

Name: Sexuality and Society
Desc: Sociological examination of theoretical and methodological approaches to studying sexuality and related topics.

Name: The Aged in Contemporary Society
Desc: Social, demographic, psychological, cultural and health factors related to the aging process in contemporary society.

Name: Global Society
Desc: Presents central concepts and major perspectives on international development, globalization and world poverty and income inequality.

Name: Magic and Technology
Desc: Analysis of the knowledge, practices and social interactions of humans and non-humans, including animals, spirits, cyborgs, and robots.

Name: Racial Inequality
Desc: Explores racial and ethnic inequality in the US.

Name: Small Groups
Desc: Analysis of groups, their structure and functions.

Name: Population
Desc: Processes that influence size and composition of human populations; determinants and consequences of demographic trends.

Name: Seminar: Classical Sociological Theory
Desc: Historical survey of sociology with primary emphasis on European (Marx, Weber and Durkheim) and early American (Mead and Park) sociologists.

Name: Seminar: Contemporary Sociological Theory
Desc: Current theoretical arguments in sociology.

Name: Fundamental Statistics in Sociology
Desc: Introduction to inferential methods in sociological research; emphasis on interpretation and current research.

Name: Advanced Research Methods in Social Science
Desc: Survey of advanced methodology in the social sciences; emphasis on general linear model and causal models.

Name: Seminar: Methods of Social Investigation
Desc: Research methods in the social sciences; interplay of theory and methods of research; formulation of research problems and design; measurement and scaling; sampling; ethics in research; and critiques of social science research.

Name: Specialized Topics in Social Science Methods
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar: Topics in Rural Sociology
Desc: of 9 sem. hrs. credit if topics vary. Specialized areas in rural sociology.
Reqs: consent of instructor May be taken for a max

Name: Seminar: Topics in Social Organization
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. credit if topics vary. Specialized areas in social organization.

Name: Seminar: Topics in Social Institutions
Desc: of 12 sem. hrs. credit if topics vary. Specialized areas in social institutions.
Reqs: consent of instructor May be taken for a max

Name: Seminar: Topics in Social Issues
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. credit if topics vary. Specialized areas in social issues.

Name: Seminar: Topics in Social Interaction
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. credit if topics vary. Specialized areas in social interaction.

Name: Independent Reading
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.
Reqs: successful completion of at least one year of graduate work

Name: Independent Research
Desc: “S”/”U” grading.
Reqs: successful completion of at least one year of graduate work

Name: Proseminar in Sociology I
Desc: S/U grading. Required once of both master’s and PhD candidates. Contemporary research and critical issues in sociology.

Name: Proseminar in Sociology II
Desc: S/U grading. Required once of all PhD candidates. Contemporary research, teaching, and critical issues in sociology.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Research in Sociology
Desc: “S”/”U” grading. Open only to students engaged in a specific, organized research project under faculty supervision. Student must be engaged in design and implementation of research and analysis and interpretation of data.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Elementary Spanish
Desc: For students with previous study of Spanish who did not place into SPAN 1102 through the Spanish Placement Examination. Credit will not be given for this course and SPAN 1101. Material covered in SPAN 1101 is covered in 1050. Supplementary work in language laboratory. Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Spanish; emphasis on communicative language use.

Name: Elementary Spanish
Desc: [LCCN: CSPN 1014, Elementary Spanish I] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. For students with no previous study of Spanish. Students with previous study of Spanish should enroll in SPAN 1050. Credit will not be given for this course and SPAN 1050. Supplementary work in language laboratory.

Name: Elementary Spanish
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and SPAN 1152. Supplementary work in the language laboratory. Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course. Basic lexicon and structure of Spanish; emphasis on communicative language use.

Name: Intensive Beginning Spanish
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and SPAN 1102. Credit will be awarded for SPAN 1101 upon successful completion of this course with a “C” or better. Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course. Review of basic Spanish vocabulary and grammar with emphasis on communicative language use.
Reqs: two years of high school Spanish

Name: Intermediate Spanish
Desc: Continuation of elementary Spanish. Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course. Additional emphasis on reading and writing.

Name: Intermediate Spanish
Desc: Continuation of SPAN 2101. Credit will not be given for this course and SPAN 2104. Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course.

Name: HONORS: Intermediate Spanish
Desc: Same as SPAN 2102, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and SPAN 2102. Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course.

Name: Spanish Language and Culture
Desc: Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course. Oral and written commentary on a variety of genres and nonprint media in Spanish.

Name: Intermediate Oral Communication
Desc: Native speakers of Spanish will not receive credit for this course.
Reqs: Permission of department and credit or registration in SPAN 2155

Name: Tutoring Learners of Spanish as a Second Language
Desc: A carefully monitored and evaluated Spanish tutoring experience in a local middle or high school under the guidance of the course instructor and a mentoring teacher.
Reqs: SPAN 2155 or equivalent, EDCI 2001 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3001

Name: Developing Language Lessons for Spanish as a Second Language
Reqs: EDCI 3001, SPAN 3001 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 3136

Name: Spanish Grammar and Composition
Reqs: permission of department and credit or registration in SPAN 2155

Name: Advanced Oral Communication II
Desc: Development of listening and speaking competency at the advanced level.
Reqs: SPAN 2155 and SPAN 2156 or permission of the department

Name: Literary Analysis
Desc: Literary genres and their characteristics; critical reading and commentary of Spanish texts.

Name: Introduction to Latin American Literature I
Desc: Reading and analysis of representative selections from pre-Columbian period through independence.

Name: Introduction to Latin American Literature II
Desc: Reading and analysis of representative literature from independence to the present.

Name: Spanish for Professionals
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Development of language skills for functioning in various professional contexts such as business, medicine or law.
Reqs: SPAN 2155 or equivalent and consent of instructor

Name: Survey of Spanish Literature
Desc: Spanish literature from its beginning to the 18th century.

Name: Survey of Spanish Literature
Desc: Main authors and literary movements from the 18th century to the present.

Name: Advanced Readings on Spanish Civilization
Desc: Ethnological, geographical, historical, political, economic and sociological factors necessary for understanding Spanish culture.

Name: Advanced Readings on Hispanic-American Civilization
Desc: Parallels SPAN 3073 but focuses on the Hispanic-American countries.

Name: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics
Desc: Taught in Spanish. Introduces students to major linguistic structures of the Castilian language needed to carry out further and more advanced study in Spanish and/or linguistics including phonetics, phonology, morphology, and syntax.

Name: Special Topics in Spanish
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.
Reqs: either SPAN 3043 or SPAN 3044 or SPAN 3071 or SPAN 3072

Name: Instructional Strategies for the Second Language Spanish Classroom
Desc: Teacher candidates will study and participate in activities that incorporate different classroom interactional structures, including teacher-to-whole class, task-based group activities and student-to-student (pair work); candidates will design and conduct Spanish language lessons using learner-centered activities.
Reqs: EDCI 3136, SPAN 3002 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4003

Name: Critical Issues in Teaching Spanish as a Second Language: Capstone Course
Reqs: EDCI 4003, SPAN 4003 and concurrent enrollment in EDCI 4004 and EDCI 4005

Name: Structure of the Spanish Language
Desc: Spanish morphology and syntax; structuralist, sociolinguistic and generative-transformational analyses and applications.

Name: Spanish Medieval Literature
Desc: Spanish literature from its beginnings to the end of the 14th century; emphasis on the mester de juglaría, mester de clerecía and masterpieces of prose and poetry of the 14th century.

Name: History of the Spanish Language
Desc: Origins and development of Spanish from its beginnings to the present.

Name: Special Topics in 18th and 19th Century Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in Golden Age Prose
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Spanish Renaissance and Baroque prose.

Name: Spanish Literature from 1898 to 1936
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Literature in all genres from the early Modernists to the Avant Garde.

Name: Spanish Literature Since 1936
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Literature in all genres since the Spanish Civil War.

Name: Women Writers in the Hispanic World
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Examination of selected periods, themes and genres.

Name: Latin American Literature: 1492-1810
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics in colonial Latin American literature from 1492-1810.
Reqs: one literature course in Spanish at the 3000-level or consent of instructor

Name: Latin American Literature: 1810-1915
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics in Latin American literature from independence through modernismo (1810-1915).
Reqs: one literature course in Spanish at the 3000 level or consent of instructor

Name: Latin American Literature: 1915-1960
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics in Latin American literature from the historical avante garde to 1960.
Reqs: one literature course in Spanish at the 3000 level or consent of instructor

Name: Latin American Literature: 1960-Present
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Topics in Latin American literature from 1960 to the present.
Reqs: one literature course in Spanish at the 3000 level and permission of department

Name: Literature and Culture of Hispanics in the United States
Desc: Texts may be in English or Spanish. Selected periods, themes and genres; related cultural topics.

Name: Cinema in Spanish
Desc: Screening and analysis of representative films from Spain and Latin America and their interrelations with literature.

Name: Introduction to Hispanic Cultural Studies
Desc: Overview of cultural studies theory on topics such as race, gender, nation, sexuality and mass media as applied to Hispanic cultural texts, including literature, music, art, television and cinema.
Reqs: Graduate level standing or permission of instructor

Name: Special Topics in Transatlantic Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.
Reqs: one literature course at the 3000 level or consent of instructor

Name: Spanish Phonetics
Desc: Also offered as LING 4602. Spanish phonetic systems; corrective and fluency drills in the language laboratory; problems of teaching Spanish pronunciation to English-speaking students.

Name: Applied Spanish Linguistics
Desc: Structures and communicative functions of Spanish; classroom applications.

Name: Independent Research in Spanish or Spanish-American Literature
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. credit. Permission of department required. Readings in Spanish or Spanish-American literature directed by a senior faculty member.

Name: Independent Research in Spanish or Spanish-American Linguistics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. credit. Permission of department required. Readings in Spanish or Spanish-American linguistics.

Name: Topics in Spanish American Literature: Beginnings to 19th Century
Desc: With consent of department, May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Topics in Spanish American Literature: 19th Century to the Present
Desc: With consent of department, May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in Golden Age Spanish Literature
Desc: With consent of department, May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in Modern Spanish Literature
Desc: With consent of department, May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Comparative Studies in Hispanic Literature
Desc: With consent of department, May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Special Topics in Hispanic Linguistics
Desc: When topics vary, May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit for the master’s degree and 9 hrs. of credit for the doctorate. Topics to be announced.

Name: Spanish Language Variation
Desc: May be taken for a max. of six sem. hrs. with consent of department. Socio-linguistic perspectives and methodology in the analysis of Spanish language variation.

Name: Spanish Language Acquisition
Desc: Theories and discourse perspectives in second language acquisition.

Name: Spanish in the United States
Desc: Spanish in contact with English language use, variation and change; social and individual bilingualism.

Name: Research in Hispanic Linguistics
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit with consent of department. Scholarly investigation guided by departmental graduate faculty.

Name: Special Topics in Hispanic Criticism
Desc: With consent of department, May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Literature and Politics in the Modern Hispanic World
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary by permission of department. Study of Spanish and Spanish-American cultural politics through its literary manifestations.

Name: Seminar in Hispanic Cultural Studies
Desc: With consent of department, May be taken for a maximum of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Student Success Strategies
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 1 hr. recitation. Develops Student Support Services students’ social skills and self-efficacy by presenting non-cognitive principles based on best practices supported by current research.

Name: Introduction to Social Work
Desc: An honors course, SW 2001, is also available. The profession of social work; history, description of programs in contemporary American society; role of the social worker in meeting social needs.

Name: Honors: Introduction to Social Work
Desc: Same as SW 2000, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for SW 2000 and this course.

Name: Introduction to LGBTQ+ Studies
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Surveys the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ+) experience, existence and influence, in areas of culture, theory, and research.

Name: Human Behavior and the Social Environment I
Desc: SW 2000. Coreq.: SW 3004 and SW 3005. Socio-behavioral science base for generalist social work practice. Interaction of the biological, psychological, and social factors that shape individual experiences using a multidimensional person-in-environment approach.

Name: The Child and the Community
Desc: Common and particular needs of children in the community; social welfare services developed by communities for care and training of children.

Name: Skills in Working with People
Desc: Basic skills in working with people; understanding attitudes; use of community resources.

Name: Human Diversity and Oppression
Desc: SW 2000. Coreq.: SW 3001 and SW 3005. Examining human diversity and oppression and engaging diversity and difference in practice.

Name: Practice with Individuals and Families
Desc: SW 2000. Coreq.: SW 3001 and SW 3004.  Introduction to social work theory, values, and intervention skills common to social work practice with individuals and families.

Name: Practice with Groups
Desc: SW 2000, SW 3005.  Coreq.: SW 3008 and SW 3103. Social work practice with treatment and task groups.

Name: Juvenile Justice
Desc: Examines the complexity of sociological and psychological factors in causation and treatment of children involved in the Juvenile Justice System; Provides students with the tools to analyze and evaluate juvenile justice policies and programs.

Name: Human Behavior and the Social Environment II
Desc: SW 2000, SW 3001, SW 3004, and SW 3005. Coreq.: Taken concurrently with SW 3006 and SW 3103. Socio-behavioral science base for generalist social work practice. Developmental life course perspective. Major human biopsychosocial developmental achievements and adaptations from conception through death.

Name: Community Services and the Aged
Desc: The aged population and their needs; available resources and services in the community; assisting the aged in obtaining services; implications for the future.

Name: Social Welfare History & Policy
Desc: SW 2000. Coreq.: SW 3006 and SW 3008. Historical perspective of social welfare history and policy.

Name: Practice with Organizations and Communities
Desc: SW 2000, SW 3005, SW 3006. Coreq.: SW 4009. Social work practice with organizations and communities.

Name: Human Sciences Research Methods
Desc: For SW majors or CFS majors only. Foundation research knowledge and skills representative of human science professions.

Name: Behavioral Health Assessment in Social Work
Desc: Examining current state of knowledge of mental disorders and behavioral health assessment.

Name: Special Topics in Social Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics on social work practice and social welfare services.

Name: Individual Readings in Corrections
Desc: 0 GPA, 60 hrs. of course work, consent of instructor. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit.

Name: Field Internship
Desc: SW 3001, SW 3004, SW 3005, SW 3006, SW 3008, SW 3103, SW 4007, and SW 4009. Coreq. or prereq.: SW 4200. Pass-fail grading. Field internship integrating academic coursework with social work practice under the guidance of field supervisor.

Name: HONORS: Field Internship
Desc: Coreq.: SW 4200. Field internship integrating academic coursework with social work practice under the guidance of field supervisor.

Name: Integrative Seminar
Desc: SW 3001, SW 3004, SW 3005, SW 3006, SW 3008, SW 3103, SW 4007, and SW 4009. Coreq.: SW 4100. Pass-fail grading. Integration of social work practice skills, theory, policy, research, ethics, and diversity in student’s field of practice.

Name: Crisis Intervention
Desc: Introduction to major theories and research that describes and explains the range and complexity of problems that may emerge from natural or other disaster scenarios.

Name: At-risk Youth
Desc: Provides students with knowledge of youth development with a particular focus on resiliency. At each stage of development, risk factors that are deleterious to development and protective factors that promote healthy development will be discussed. Along with being grounded in theories of resiliency, students will gain a good working knowledge of cognitive behavioral therapy.

Name: Individual Readings in Social Work
Desc: GPA, 60 hrs. of course work, consent of instructor. May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Independent study of topics related to the field of social work. Topic must not substitute for regularly offered courses.

Name: Human Behavior and the Social Environment I
Desc: Provides the content necessary to understand the complexities of human development and behavior; examines the interaction of the biological, psychological, and social factors that shape individual experiences using a multidimensional person-in-environment approach.

Name: Human Behavior and the Social Environment II
Desc: Adopts a developmental life course perspective and focuses on major human biopsychosocial developmental achievements and adaptations from conception through death.

Name: Social Welfare History & Policy
Desc: Development of Social Work as a profession; evolution of social welfare policies and programs; nature of social policy and policy formulation.
Reqs: Social Work majors only and credit for or concurrent registration in SW 7001, SW 7004, SW 7005, and SW 7007

Name: Human Diversity and Oppression
Desc: Social dynamics of human oppression; effects of institutional discrimination, inequality, stigma and prejudice stemming from abelism, ageism, cissexism, classism, ethnocentrism, heterosexism, racism, religious oppression, sexism, and xenophobia; implications of human oppression and multiculturalism for human behavior, social work practice and social policy.

Name: Practice with Individuals and Families
Desc: Introduction to social work theory, principles and intervention skills common to social work practice with individuals and families; psychosocial perspectives in intervention.

Name: Practice with Groups, Organizations and Communities
Desc: Majors only. Techniques of working with various types of groups including treatment groups and planning action groups; community organization techniques.

Name: Foundation Field Internship I
Desc: Pass-fail grading. $100 internship fee. Application of foundation knowledge, skills, values and ethics to practice in an approved internship agency. 240 clock hours.
Reqs: majors only and credit for or concurrent registration in SW 7005

Name: Foundation Field Internship II
Desc: Pass-fail grading. $100 internship fee. Continuation of SW 7007. Application of knowledge, skills, values, and ethics to practice in an approved internship agency. 240 clock hours.
Reqs: majors only and credit for or concurrent registration in SW 7006 & SW 7007

Name: Social Work Research I
Desc: Standards and methods of scientific inquiry applied in social work research; concept formulation; research design; sources, collection and presentation of data; provides the student with foundation knowledge and skills of research representative of the social work profession, mission, and ethical values.

Name: Differential Diagnosis
Desc: Introduction to the terminology and conceptual topics relating to assessment and diagnosis, the relationship of ethics to the process of assessment and diagnosis, and the evidence-informed process of differential diagnosis using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) and related clinical social work texts.

Name: Integrative Colloquium in Social Work I
Desc: Broad-ranging analysis and discussion of problems and issues in the social work profession.
Reqs: admission to the PhD program in social work or consent of instructor

Name: Integrative Colloquium in Social Work II
Desc: Broad-ranging analysis and discussion of problems and issues in the social work profession.
Reqs: admission to the PhD program in social work or consent of instructor

Name: Issues and Research Problems in Social Policy
Desc: Issues and problems in social welfare policy; research focus on policy formulation.
Reqs: admission to the PhD program in social work or consent of instructor

Name: Issues and Research Problems in Social Work Intervention
Desc: Social work intervention with individuals, families, groups and communities; formulation and development of problem-solving research agendas.
Reqs: admission to the PhD program in social work or consent of instructor

Name: Pedagogical Issues in Social Work Education
Desc: Enhancement of pedagogical knowledge, skills and values; emphasis on teaching for the social work profession.
Reqs: admission to the PhD program in social work or consent of instructor

Name: Research Practicum
Desc: No more than 6 hrs. May be taken in one semester. Hands-on supervised research experience; demonstration of collaborative and/or independent research.
Reqs: admission to the PhD program in social work or consent of instructor; and at least one of EXST 7003 or EXST 7013

Name: Integrative Seminar
Desc: Development of research questions and hypotheses, and initial drafts of the dissertation proposal, including introduction, literature review and methodology sections.
Reqs: foundation courses in PhD program and at least one research methods course, plus consent of instructor

Name: Grief & Bereavement
Desc: Contemporary theories of grief and loss; cultural, ethnic, and religious differences in beliefs and practices surrounding grief and dying; ethical issues related to social work practice with end-of life issues.

Name: Advanced Social Work Treatment of Individuals
Desc: Differential diagnostic assessment and treatment of individuals with complex intrapersonal problems.

Name: Direct Practice with Children and Adolescents
Desc: Maladaptive patterns of behavior in children and adolescents; intervention strategies with children, parents, families and groups.

Name: Advanced Methods of Group Treatment
Desc: Diagnostic and treatment procedures used in intensive group therapy.

Name: Juvenile Justice and Delinquency
Desc: Examine the nature and extent of delinquency (theories of causation, oppression, deprivation, discrimination), explores the structure, function, and problems of the justice system, and reviews programs and services for the prevention and treatment of offenders and their families (capacity/strengths of offenders and their families, peer groups, and community).

Name: Social Work in Corrections
Desc: Social work processes in corrections; population served; existing and needed delivery systems for rehabilitative services; influence of the host setting.

Name: Social Work and Aging
Desc: Demographic characteristics of the aging population; aging as a developmental process with economic, biological, psychological and socialization aspects; impact of legislative and social service systems.

Name: Social Work Practice in Schools
Desc: Implementation of social work values, purposes and methods in a school setting.

Name: Marital and Family Treatment in Social Work
Desc: Identification and modification of dysfunctional transactional patterns; facilitating communication; improving the quality of marriage and family relations.

Name: Social Work with LGBTQ+ People
Desc: Development of students’ professional competence with lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ+) people. Exploration of social work practices at the micro, mezzo and macro levels and across social, political and economic realms.

Name: Social Work in Medical Care
Desc: Nature of social work practice in the field of medical care; medical care system and consumer problems; role of medical social workers.

Name: Child/Family I
Desc: Theories and skills of assessment and communication with children and families.

Name: Child/Family II
Desc: Legal and administrative functions in working with children and families.

Name: Management in Human Services
Desc: Management used in the effective provision of social services; techniques of modern management; interdisciplinary and practical approaches; unique aspects of human service management; development of critical attitudes and management skills.

Name: Ethics in Social Work
Desc: Understanding legal implications of professional social work practice and teaching students to become more effective in responding to complex ethical issues.

Name: Social Work Research II
Desc: Focuses on expanding and deepening students’ understanding of the utility of applied scientific research in professional social work practice and their knowledge and skill in applying research methods to evaluation of practice process and outcomes to refine and advance the quality of their practice.
Reqs: Social Work Majors only; completion of all foundation courses

Name: Advanced Field Internship I
Desc: Pass-fail grading. $100 internship fee. Supervised internship in an approved agency setting where advanced knowledge, skills, values and ethics are applied in the practice setting. 240 clock hours.
Reqs: completion of all foundation courses; majors only and credit for or concurrent registration in SW 7505

Name: Advanced Field Internship II
Desc: Pass-fail grading. $100 internship fee. Continuation of SW 7502. Supervised internship in an approved agency setting where advanced knowledge, skills, values and ethics are applied in the practice setting. 240 clock hours.
Reqs: completion of all foundation courses; majors only and credit for or concurrent registration in SW 7502 & SW 7505

Name: Advanced Social Policy
Desc: Dimensions and patterns of social policy; evolution and design of provisions and services; current issues, problems and trends and skills in policy advocacy.
Reqs: completion of all foundation courses; majors only

Name: Advanced Direct Theory and Practice
Desc: Focuses on expanding and deepening students’ knowledge and professional abilities with respect to the theoretical perspectives, empirical evidence, and practice methods and skills necessary to provide direct social work services to diverse client populations within a range of human service agencies.
Reqs: Social Work Majors only; completion of all foundation courses

Name: Community Engagement and Grant Development
Desc: Community, organizational and social aspects of social work practice; indirect practice skills associated with effective social work practice in multiple service environments.
Reqs: Social Work Majors only; completion of all foundation courses

Name: Family Violence
Desc: Topics in family violence; their relevance to social work practice; program development and interventive approaches and issues.

Name: Grant and Proposal Writing for Human Service Organizations
Desc: Methods of accessing federal, state and private funds; developing grant and contract proposals.

Name: Addictive Disorders in Contemporary Society
Desc: Topics related to addictive disorders in contemporary society; their relevance to social work practice.

Name: Co-occurring Substance Use and Mental Disorders: Assessment and Intervention
Desc: Co-occurring substance use and mental disorders and their prevalence and relevance to social work practice, policy and program development and research.

Name: Special Topics in Social Work
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics on social work and social welfare theory, practice and policy.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Social Work Practice
Desc: May be repeated once by PhD students if topics vary.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Social Welfare Policy
Desc: May be repeated once by PhD students if topics vary.

Name: Research Project: Nonthesis
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Research project, state of knowledge paper or position paper.
Reqs: completion of foundation courses and consent of instructor

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.
Reqs: completion of all foundation courses and consent of instructor

Name: Dissertation Research
Reqs: successful completion of the General Examination “S”/”U”grading

Name: Fashion and Society
Desc: Definitions and exploration related to the study of fashion. important theories used to study dress practices will be highlighted, including dress as non-verbal communication and cultural concepts affecting beauty ideals, body modification, gender, ethnicity, the life cycle and sustainability.

Name: Digital Illustration for the Apparel Industry
Desc: Application of computer-aided design technology to the design and presentation of textile and apparel collections.

Name: Introductory Apparel Design
Desc: 1 hrs. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. The design process; art elements and principles applied to aesthetic, functional and structural design of textile and apparel products; introduction to fashion illustration and design.

Name: Introductory Apparel Construction
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Fundamental principles of garment assembly and production processes; analysis of fit; development of decision making skills in garment design and the selection and use of materials.
Reqs: for students in the Apparel Design concentration only or consent of instructor

Name: Intermediate Apparel Construction
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Intermediate garment assembly; emphasis placed on industry methods and equipment; introduction to working with knits.

Name: Textile Science
Desc: Basic physical, biological and chemical characteristics of fibers, yarns and fabrics; selection, maintenance and performance of textiles.

Name: Textile Science Laboratory
Desc: 3 hrs. lab. Introduction to basic physical and chemical testing of textiles.

Name: Fashion: Trends, Analysis and Assortments
Desc: Study of processes, techniques of identifying socio-cultural, technological, and economic trends, and methods for determining factors effecting trends in fashion and related industries. Apply identified key trend information and knowledge of consumer behavior to understand the importance of fashion/accessory assortment development; hands-on learning and practices.

Name: Early Experience in Textile/Apparel Industry
Desc: Pass/fail grading. 4 hrs. practicum; majors only. 32 hrs. of supervised experience. Pre-internship work in a component of the textile/apparel industry. Arranged on individu­al basis for students with limited or no industry experience.

Name: The Fashion Industry
Desc: Interrelationships of design, production and distribution; historical aspects and cyclical nature of fashion.

Name: Fashion Event Production
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Participation in an approved position in the planning and production of a live runway show.

Name: Special Topics in Textiles, Apparel & Merchandising
Reqs: consent of director for majors in textiles, apparel & merchandising

Name: No title provided
Desc: lecture, 4 hrs. lab. Application of advance 3D technology to the creation of apparel related products. Prototype development and assessment.

Name: Apparel Quality Analysis
Desc: 2 hrs lecture: 2 hrs lab. In-depth analysis of ready-to-wear apparel. Explains meaning of quality and quality control and its importance throughout the textile and apparel supply chain.

Name: Supply Chain Management in the Fashion Sector
Desc: Examine the evolution of fashion supply chain in the global fashion sector. Assess the strategies in fashion supply chain management, and gain exposure to the technical and managerial skills.

Name: Field Study in Textiles, Apparel and Retailing
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when field site varies. Offered through Continuing Education. 28 hrs. of on-campus seminars. Fee to cover expenses. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Structured educational experiences in major industry centers in the U.S. and abroad.

Name: Textile and Apparel Product Development
Reqs: TAM 3022 Processes and issues related to development of textiles and apparel products for consumers

Name: Flat Pattern Design
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Principles and application of two-dimensional or flat pattern design; development of foundation blocks for use in designing various garment styles and details; conceptualization and execution of original garment design.

Name: International Field Study in Textiles, Apparel Design and Merchandising
Desc: May be taken twice for credit when field of study site varies. 2 hrs. lecture; 3 hrs. lab. Structured educational experience in major industry centers located outside of the United States.

Name: Retail Buying and Management
Desc: Concepts and theories in retailing, consumer behavior, apparel buying and management; role and responsibilities of merchandise buyers; domestic and foreign merchandise resources and negotiation.
Reqs: majors only; TAM 2045 and MATH 1029, MATH 1100

Name: Apparel Merchandising Strategies and Assortment Planning
Desc: lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Assortment planning and sales strategies; advanced quantitative concepts and procedures used in apparel buying; management and interpretation of data related to merchandising and sales.
Reqs: majors only; TAM 2042 , TAM 3042 and computer literacy; 2 hrs

Name: Visual Merchandising and Promotion Strategies
Desc: Display elements and techniques; visual merchandising; special events strategies; public relations; Internet promotions.

Name: 3D Visual Retailing Simulation
Desc: 2 hrs. lab. Students will study industry specific software for the development of store layouts and visual merchandising. Building on the concepts learned in TAM 3045 Visual Merchandising and Promotion Strategies, emphasis will be placed on the creation of merchandising directives for innovative product display.
Reqs: Credit in TAM 3045 and credit or registration in TAM 3043

Name: Sustainability for Apparel and Textiles
Desc: Brief review of contemporary environmental, social, and economic issues associated with industry practice will be followed by a broad exploration of sustainable design theories, which may be applied in the apparel and textiles fields, from eco-efficiency to approaches that demand social change.

Name: Readings and Research in Textiles, Apparel & Merchandising
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Students are responsible for registering with a faculty member with whom they will select the area of reading and research.
Reqs: Open to advanced students of high academic standing by consent of director

Name: Pattern Design with Computer Application
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Application of two-dimensional pattern making principles to varied garment styles and details; design and execution of original garment design; introduction to proprietary computer software.

Name: Apparel Design Studio
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. studio. Fashion illustration techniques; adaptation of inspirational themes to designs for diversified apparel markets; pre-portfolio development.

Name: Emerging Technologies in Apparel Design
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Introduction to state-of-the-art technologies used in the apparel industry for product development. Emphasis on technologies such as 3D virtual fitting, digital textile printing, 3D printing, 3D body scanning, and digital knitting, Application of technologies to product development demonstrated through final printing.

Name: Couture Embellishment Techniques
Desc: Course may be taken for a maximum of 6 hours of credit with permission of department. Not for graduate credit. 6 hrs. lab. Study of advanced apparel construction techniques appropriate for the couture market; examination of inner structure and finishing details; experimentation with a variety of hang and machine embellishments.

Name: Advanced Apparel Design Studio
Desc: May be taken for a maximum of 6 sem. hrs. of credit by permission of department when topics vary. 6 hrs. lab. Study of the design process applied to structural design techniques, specialty fabrics and markets. Attention is given to design characteristics, sizing, and marketing strategies unique to selected category. Topics vary by term.

Name: Textile and Apparel Product Evaluation
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Fabric and apparel structure and their relationships to performance and end-use characteristics; textile and apparel product standards and specifications; standard test methods for evaluating physical, aesthetic comfort, performance and functional aspects.

Name: Apparel Design Through Draping
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Principles and application of three-dimensional pattern design using draping techniques.
