Name: Collection & Portfolio Development
Desc: 2 hrs. lab. Preliminary research and style development for production of senior collection; development of creative professional portfolio.

Name: History of Textiles
Desc: Cultural, functional and technological developments of textiles by selected periods and countries.

Name: Advanced Textiles
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Characteristics of natural and manufactured textile fibers; physical and chemical modifications to meet consumer needs; textile dyes and finishes; methods of fiber identification and chemical testing of textiles.

Name: Global Textile and Apparel Economics
Desc: Application and analysis of economic concepts and principles associated with the textiles and apparel industry; overview of global economics and contemporary trade policy.

Name: Senior Collection for Apparel Design
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Apparel collection development using advanced patternmaking techniques and technology.

Name: Advanced Topics in Apparel Merchandising
Desc: Application of principles of product development, buying and management of apparel merchandise; current industry issues and trends; emphasis on theory and policy related strategies.

Name: Internship in Textiles, Apparel and Merchandising
Desc: Course may be taken for a maximum of 6 semester hours of credit. Students will work a minimum of 40 hours to equate with one credit hour. Supervised professional experience designed to integrate academic learning with professional practice.
Reqs: Grade of “C” or better on all TAM classes taken at LSU and permission of instructor, TAM 3032 and TAM 3045, and participation in orientation workshops prior to enrollment

Name: Entrepreneurship in Textiles, Apparel & Merchandising
Desc: Application of principles of entrepreneurship with an emphasis on home-based and/or micro-businesses; case studies of successful entrepreneurs.

Name: History of Dress and Adornment Prior to 1800
Desc: Emphasis on styles of western civilization; how dress functions for individuals within culture and society; relationships of gender, environment, technology, economics, religion and aesthetics to dress.

Name: History of Dress and Adornment After 1800
Desc: Emphasis on styles of western civilization; how dress functions for individuals within culture and society; relationships of gender, environment, technology, economics, religion and aesthetics to dress.

Name: Special Topics in Textiles, Apparel & Merchandising
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Lectures and/or laboratories on selected topics not covered in other textiles, apparel & merchandising classes.
Reqs: consent of director for majors in textiles, apparel & merchandising

Name: Couture Embellishment Techniques
Desc: Course may be taken for a maximum of 6 hours of credit with permission of department. 6 hrs. lab. Study of advanced apparel construction techniques appropriate for the couture market; examination of inner structure and finishing details; experimentation with a variety of hand and machine embellishments.

Name: Creativity in Product Development
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Examination, enhancement and application of creativity in the product development process with interdisciplinary application. Exploration of creative innovators and their design processes resulting in design, development and execution of original product.

Name: Social-Psychological Theories of Dress, Appearance and Fashion
Desc: Examination and analysis of interdisciplinary and theoretical approaches to dress, appearance and fashion as a social and economic force.

Name: Comparative Studies in Dress and Culture
Desc: Also offered as ANTH 7032. Relationship between people and dress in different cultural settings, e.g., environment, religion, ethnicity, gender and aesthetics; impact of cultural change and western culture on world dress, ethnic and fold traditions in dress.

Name: Apparel Merchandising and Global Expansion
Desc: Internationalization of apparel merchandising; examination of theoretical foundations, principles and applications within select international settings; development of international apparel merchandising strategies; assessment of global issues that affect apparel merchandising.

Name: Consumer Behavior in the Apparel Merchandising Environment
Desc: Examination of consumer behavior theories and their applications to apparel purchase and patronage decisions and merchandising research.

Name: Merchandise Trends and Practices in Apparel and Textile Industry
Desc: Identify the current trends and issues in fashion merchandising such as e-tailing, multichannel retailing, retail technology, environmental sustainability, globalization, and experiential retailing. Introduce the theories, concepts, and processes related to management level problems.

Name: Merchandising Theory Application and Strategy Implementation in Apparel and Textile Industry
Desc: Integration of marketing, merchandising and management theories, strategies, models, and frameworks. Application of theories and implementation of strategies relevant to apparel and industries.

Name: Introduction to Research in Textiles, Apparel Design and Merchandising
Desc: Introduction to research and literature in textiles, apparel design and merchandising.

Name: Seminar: Textiles, Apparel Design and Merchandising
Desc: “S/U” grading. May be taken for a max. of 3 hrs. of credit if topics vary. Reports and discussion of current literature and research.

Name: Selected Topics in Textiles, Apparel Design and Merchandising
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Analysis and discussion of selected research and creative topics.

Name: Modern Fiber Science and Technology
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. New techniques for obtaining fiber forming polymers derived from renewable resources, such as lyocell and plant derived polyesters; examination of polymeric materials used for the development of high performance fibers for space and other industrial applications.

Name: Thermal Characterization of Fibers and Polymers
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Analysis and characterization of fibers and polymers using thermal, thermo-electrical and thermo-mechanical techniques; examination of textile fibers and fabrics including bio-derived materials and classical specimens.

Name: Advanced Individual Field Experience In Textiles, Apparel Design and Merchandising
Desc: TAM 7091 or consent of instructor. May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Advanced individual, supervised, field-based study in selected areas of textiles, apparel design and merchandising; emphasis on analysis, synthesis and application of research data and contemporary practices within selected businesses, industries, agencies and institutions.

Name: Fashion, Luxury and Lifestyle Brands
Desc: Understand and apply the principles and practices of fashion brands, and branding in connection with the fashion, luxury goods and lifestyle consumption and merchandising/retailing in a global marketplace; develop the skills required to effectively conduct comprehensive and insightful analyses for merchandising, and retailing decision.

Name: Research Methods in Textiles, Apparel and Merchandising
Desc: Philosophy of human ecology research; issues and trends; design and methodology.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Textiles, Apparel and Merchandising
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit. Directed individual reading and research in a selected area of textiles, apparel and merchandising.

Name: Scholarship Development in Textiles, Apparel and Merchandising
Desc: “P”/”F” grading. May be taken for a max. of 2 sem. hrs. of credit. 1 sem. hr. required of all doctoral students in textiles, apparel and merchandising. Research reports and discussion of current topics and issues in textiles, apparel and merchandising.

Name: Protocol for Graduate Studies in Textiles, Apparel, and Merchandising
Desc: Pass-fail grading. Required of all graduate students in textiles, apparel and merchandising. Introduction to research areas in the department; and discussion of current topics and issues in textiles, apparel and merchandising.

Name: Research and Project Development in Textiles, Apparel and Merchandising
Desc: “S”/”U” grading. May be repeated for a max. of 15 sem. hrs. credit. Credit will not be given for this course and TAM 8000. Directed research and focused project development under the supervision of the major professor.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading. Credit will not be given for this course and TAM 7900.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Independent Research for Doctoral Students
Desc: This course may be repeated for credit; a max. of 15 sem. hrs. is allowed toward doctoral requirements.
Reqs: must be a doctoral student and have consent of instructor and approval of the student’s full doctoral committee for each repetition of the course

Name: Theatre Forum
Desc: Student forum for theatre issues and professional development.

Name: Practical Elements of Stagecraft
Desc: [LCCN: CTHE 2303, Stagecraft] Introduction to the skills and techniques used by artists and craftsmen in realization of the technological elements of all areas of live production, including training sessions in each of the main areas and departmental productions.

Name: Apprentice Seminar
Desc: Anticipated skill development and outcomes for the theatre student’s academic career. Students will be required to develop an understanding of the departmental and university resources and procedures guiding and supporting their academic path, progress their ability to reflect on and articulate their goals for training and production, and to begin the cultivation of professional readiness through research on professional practices as well as resume and portfolio development.

Name: Introduction to Theatre
Desc: [LCCN: CTHE 1013, Introduction to Theatre] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Credit will not be given for this course and THTR 1021. The arts of the theatre and its artists; acting, directing, costume and scenic design; playwriting, architecture.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Theatre
Desc: Same as THTR 1020, with special emphasis for qualified student Credit will not be given for this course and THTR 1020.

Name: Acting I: Foundational Technique
Desc: [LCCN: CTHE 2103, Acting I] Foundational skills in acting technique for stage and film, including: listening, presence, imagination, partner work, and emotional life.

Name: Movement for the Actor I
Desc: Postural awareness and adjustment, ease of movement, simplicity of physical action, unwanted tension release, physicalizing of acting for stage and screen.
Reqs: Open to Theatre majors and minors only

Name: Beginning Modern Dance
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. 3 hrs. lab. Introductory level technique class for developing basic concepts of modern/contemporary dance.

Name: Beginning Ballet
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. 3 hrs. lab. Introductory level traditional ballet technique, including the governing concepts, as well as the history and basic anatomy of ballet.

Name: Beginning Jazz Dance
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. 3 hrs. lab. Introductory level jazz instruction, focusing on warm-ups, center work, and choreography.

Name: Intermediate Modern Dance
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. 3 hrs. lab. Intermediate level course for developing more advanced concepts of modern dance.

Name: Intermediate Ballet
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. 3 hrs. lab. Intermediate level ballet technique, including the governing concepts, as well as the history and basic anatomy of ballet.

Name: Intermediate Jazz Dance
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 2 hrs. of credit. 3 hrs. lab. Intermediate level jazz instruction focusing on warm-ups, center work, and choreography.

Name: Introduction to Entertainment Industries
Desc: An introduction to the structure and internal organization of the entertainment industries. Attention is given to practical application based on theoretical and historical foundations. This course also serves as an introduction to the uses and influences of technology in entertainment with attention to innovations, history, and technology’s effects on the global entertainment industries.

Name: Introduction to Dance
Desc: [LCCN: CDNC 1013, Dance Appreciation] This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Dance as a performing art.

Name: Dance Theatre
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 hrs. of credit. Admission by audition. 6 hrs. lab. Participation in dance theatre.

Name: Portfolio Preparation for the Theatre
Desc: Developing the materials and skills necessary to present students’ education and experience in theatre to employers in the most effective manner.

Name: Introduction to Writing Drama
Desc: See ENGL 2008.

Name: Journeyman Seminar
Desc: Focus on the communication and interpersonal skills needed to communicate and interact effectively with collaborators on a performing arts project.

Name: Stage Management
Desc: Introduction to the duties and responsibilities of the theatrical stage manager; emphasis on the stage manager’s place in the theatrical organization and how he/she interacts with other members of the production team.

Name: Directing I
Desc: Basic principles of script analysis, characterization and scene visualization.

Name: Introduction to Theatrical Design
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Basic principles in designing lighting, costumes, scenery and sound.

Name: Stage Makeup
Desc: Fundamentals of straight and character makeup; laws governing line, color, light and shade.

Name: Live Entertainment Technology
Desc: Introduction to all areas of theatre technology and how they affect production; areas to be covered include: production/stage management, scenery, costumes, stage properties, lighting and sound.

Name: Acting II: Building a Character
Desc: Open to Theatre majors and minors only. Training in acting tools, pertaining to the objective, action, and physical life of the character. Technique of developing an actor’s score for a role.

Name: Theatre Practicum I
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit. Participation in an approved technical position in the production of a play produced by the Department of Theatre.

Name: Voice for the Actor I
Desc: [LCCN: CTHE 2203, Voice for the Stage] Open to Theatre majors and minor only. An exploration of vocal production and speech fundamentals for the actor through physical awareness, vocal health, respiration, phonation, resonation, articulation, and contemporary text.

Name: Introduction to Dramatic Literature
Desc: Credit will not be given for this course and THTR 2128. Not open to Theatre majors. A study of representative plays from the Greek era to the present.

Name: Aerial Practice I
Desc: May be repeated twice for credit. Methods and practice of beginning techniques used on aerial apparatus.

Name: Survey of International Performing Arts
Desc: Offered during the Academic Program Abroad to an International Performing Arts Festival such as Edinburgh Festival Fringe or the Avignon Theatre Festival. Research, observation and comparison of a variety of international performances and reporting the analysis in multimedia.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Dramatic Literature
Desc: Same as THTR 2028, with special emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and THTR 2028. Not open to Theatre majors.

Name: Script Analysis
Desc: Methods of studying playscripts in preparation for their productions on stage.

Name: Properties for the Entertainment Industry
Desc: Explore facets of the Property Master and craftsperson roles in entertainment productions. Processes involved in properties research, design, and construction; projects develop research techniques, problem solving, collaboration, communication, and technical skills.

Name: Scenery Construction for the Entertainment Industry
Desc: THTR 1001 or permission of instructor. Examination and application of construction and installation techniques, methodologies and equipment usage as applied to the production of scenery.

Name: History of World Cinema
Desc: Study of significant films and film movements in non-U.S. cinema throughout the 20th and 21st Centuries. View and discuss films to increase cultural awareness and develop understanding of the broader scope of world cinema and the contributions of world filmmakers.

Name: Cinematic Language and Aesthetics
Desc: Study of the various artistic and technical elements employed to create meaningful and emotional viewing experiences in film and television.

Name: Studio Production
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. A study of the basic principles and techniques for writing, producing, and directing fiction for entertainment/studio programs either for television or web/internet/new media streaming outlets.

Name: Film and New Media Production I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. An examination of the basics of film production including pre-production which includes story writing, scripting, storyboarding, budgeting and casting; production which includes directing, lighting and shooting; and post-production which includes editing and sound.

Name: Technical Drafting for the Theatre
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Drafting conventions and techniques used for depicting common theatrical elements.

Name: Acting III: Scene Study
Desc: Open to Theatre majors and minors only. Application of foundational acting technique through scene work and rehearsal.

Name: Introduction to Acting for the Camera
Desc: Open only to Theatre Majors with a concentration in Performance or Film and Television. 1 hr. lecture; 5 hrs. lab. Introduction to theory and techniques used when acting on camera and the similarities and differences between on camera and on stage performance.

Name: Voice for the Actor II
Desc: An exploration of voice and language for the actor through continued study of vocal techniques and exercises. The course offers tools for speaking heightened language and text.

Name: Audition Technique
Desc: Open to Theatre majors and minors only. Professional and business training for auditions in theatre, film, television, commercials, and musicals.

Name: Movement for the Actor II
Desc: Physical techniques for character creation. Use of neutral and character masks and non-verbal communication into physical character choices. Basic unarmed stage combat techniques.

Name: Viewpoints and Ensemble
Desc: Method and practice in Viewpoints and other ensemble techniques as it relates to performer training and the creation of physical theatre.

Name: Theatre History and Literature I: Ancient Greece through Renaissance
Desc: Survey of theatre history and literature from Ancient Greece through the Renaissance.

Name: Theatre History and Literature II: Renaissance through Nineteenth Century
Desc: Survey of theatre history and literature from the Renaissance to the late nineteenth century.

Name: Theatre History and Literature III: 1875 to the Present
Desc: Survey of theatre history and literature from the late nineteenth century to present.

Name: Costume Construction Techniques for the Stage
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Study of the skills and techniques unique to the construction of costumes for the stage; emphasis on historical construction, cutting, finishing, design analysis and adaptation for stage performance.

Name: Tutus and Dancewear Construction
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Skills and techniques unique to the construction of costumes for dance; methods of working with stretch fabric and tutu construction; includes construction, cutting, fitting, design analysis and adaptations necessary for dance performance.

Name: Theatrical Rendering
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Drawing and painting scenery and costumes for the theatre; emphasis in color, pattern, texture, scale and proportion.

Name: Introduction to Arts Management
Desc: Overview of the organizational structure and operations of arts and cultural institutions.

Name: Arts Marketing
Desc: Lecture, discussion and case analysis of marketing concepts for arts and other creative industries.

Name: Scene Painting I
Desc: lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Contemporary scene painting for the stage; emphasis on tools, materials, basic techniques and color theory.
Reqs: THTR 1001 or permission of instructor, 2 hrs

Name: Sound Technology
Desc: Introduction to the fundamentals and operational principles involved in theatrical sound.

Name: Stage Lighting Technology
Desc: Introduction to the technical and mechanical elements of stage lighting technology in both analog and digital formats.

Name: The Process of Filmmaking
Desc: Develop and realize a film from concept to final delivery and sale, including pre-production, production management, deliverables, market strategy, pitching, working with directors, proper legal channels, and developing a personal marketing brand.

Name: Advanced Post Production
Desc: Editing analysis and practice, deconstructing and creatively manipulating visual images through the editing process - cutting, compositing, and FX editing.

Name: Film and New Media Production II
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. lab. Advanced techniques of production including: film producing, directing, cinematography, editing, and sound – including sound capture and design.

Name: Theatre or Film Internship
Desc: Pass-fail grading May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. Study with an approved theatre or film company; emphasis may be in one or all of the following areas: performance, directing, design, technology, dramaturgy, stage management, administration, box office or casting.

Name: Dance Composition
Desc: Fundamental elements and principles of choreography.

Name: Improvisation
Desc: Methods and practice of improvisation in dance and theatre.

Name: Selected Topics in Theatre
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Consult Schedule of Classes for current offering.

Name: Writing Drama
Desc: See ENGL 4008.

Name: Master Seminar
Desc: Credit or registration in THTR 2010, majors only. Capstone of the Theatre academic experience. Active learning through self-reflective examination of academic career and projection of future path; examining the integration of the academic, personal, and artistic development; development of communication skills in the preparation of multi-modal artifacts of the student’s findings.

Name: Gender and Sexuality in Performance
Desc: Survey of theories, artists, movements and texts involved with staging issues of sexuality and gender.

Name: Advanced Costume Construction Techniques for the Stage
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. A continuation of THTR 3123. Skills and techniques unique to the construction of costumes for the stage; methods of planning and construction of costumes for the theatre with emphasis on the differences between theatrical costume construction and clothing construction for the consumer market; historical construction, patterning, cutting, fitting, design analysis and adaptations for stage performance.

Name: Classical Text
Desc: Building on fundamental acting process, tools and scene study experience; an introduction to classical research and performance in a variety of styles most often performed in contemporary stage and film.

Name: Acting for the Camera II
Desc: Builds on acting principles and techniques introduced in THTR 3026. Extensive on camera scene and audition work, simulating real-world experiences across mediums and genres in film and television.

Name: Accents for the Actor
Desc: An exploration of how to prepare for acting with accents. This course gives accent application to dramatic texts, practicing the skills of accent performance.

Name: Special Topics in Stage Movement
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Special topics related to physical practices in theatre for training, research and creation.

Name: Aerial Practice II
Desc: May be repeated twice for credit. Methods and practice of research and choreography used on aerial apparatus for public performance.

Name: Composition for Physical Theatre
Desc: Methods and practice of composition in the creation of physical theatre.

Name: Devising for Physical Theatre
Desc: Methods and practice of devising for the creation of a new work of physical theatre.

Name: Costume Design
Desc: Principles of design related to stage costumes; design research, creative interpretation; adapting costumes to theatrical styles of production; inspiration from designs of the past.

Name: Scenic Design
Desc: Basic principles of scenic design for the theatre; form, style, color and lighting; sketches, renderings and models.
Reqs: THTR 2022 and THTR 2830 or permission of instructor

Name: Directing II
Desc: Principles of play selection, concept formulation, casting, rehearsal and directing plays and scenes in workshop performance.

Name: Mask Making
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Skills used in basic mask construction for theatre; includes life casting and four common mask-making techniques with their distinct properties.

Name: Approaches to the Stage
Desc: Survey of modern theoretical approaches to the stage and critical issues of performance.

Name: Seminar: Contemporary Theatre and Drama
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. Selected topics in the contemporary theatre.

Name: Advanced Stage Makeup
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Advanced principles of makeup for stage and film. Including prosthetic makeup techniques and airbrush makeup; study and execution of period makeup and hairstyles, including basic wig and facial hair construction and wig styling.

Name: Theatre Practicum II
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 3 sem. hrs. of credit. Participation in an approved capacity for the performance or production of a play produced by the Department of Theatre.

Name: Film Practicum
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 sem. hrs. of credit. Open only to Theatre Majors with a concentration in Film and Television or by permission of instructor 2 hrs. lab. Technical participation in Department of Theatre Film/TV performance classes or productions.

Name: Drama of Africa and African Diaspora
Desc: Also offered as ENGL 4220. Study of the form and characteristic features as expressed in the works of dramatists in Africa and African Diaspora.

Name: Special Topics in Arts Administration
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Advanced Arts Management
Desc: Continued study of the principles of arts management including the economics of arts industries, financial management, constituent development and arts advocacy.

Name: Fundraising for the Arts
Desc: Principles of fundraising for the not-for-profit organization including grant writing, individual and corporate giving, planned giving, capital campaigns and special events.

Name: Scene Painting II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. (IA) Contemporary scene painting for the stage; emphasis on advanced projects.

Name: History of Theatrical Period Styles and Ornament
Desc: Historical survey of period styles and adornment with emphasis on the development of clothing, makeup and hair as well as architecture and furnishings from the Greek period to the present.

Name: Sound Design
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Principles and basic techniques of sound design and its influence on staged productions.
Reqs: THTR 2022 and THTR 3530 or permission of instructor

Name: Lighting Design I
Desc: Lighting design for the theatre; emphasis on script analysis, production concepts and visual ideas.

Name: Advanced Sound Design
Desc: Explore the artistic and technical aspects of advanced sound design for a theatrical production with a focus on how to identify design choices via working on various styles and genres of theatre design and technical sound elements.

Name: Advanced Sound Technology
Desc: Advanced study on creating sound systems with various production types and continued development of skills for troubleshooting an audio system for technical production.

Name: Advanced Cinematography
Desc: Advanced techniques and execution of the discipline of cinematography including industry standards and practices.

Name: Advanced Film Practicum
Desc: Advanced techniques of production leading to the making and distribution of the Departmental Film. Develop professional practices for production, distribution, marketing, and festival organization through an assigned a major role including but not limited to: Director, Producer, DP, UPM, Location Manager, Production Coordinator, First AD, Key Grip, Gaffer, Editor, Post-Production Supervisor, and Festival Coordinator.

Name: Dance History
Desc: Development of dance from primitive cultures to the present.

Name: Dance Theatre
Desc: May be repeated for credit every semester. Admission by audition 6 hrs. lab. Experienced modern dancers participate in modern dance theatre as lead dancers and as choreographers.

Name: Advanced Stage Management
Desc: Advanced training in stage management techniques, including professional experience component with departmental approval.

Name: Selected Topics in CAD Drafting for the Theatre
Desc: Course may be repeated for up to 6 hrs. of credit with a change in platform. Introduction to the fundamentals of CAD drafting and its use in the theatre industry.
Reqs: THTR 2830 or equivalent or permission of instructor

Name: Selected Topics in Advanced CAD for the Theatre
Desc: Course may be repeated for up to 6 sem. hrs. of credit with a change in platform (AutoCAD, VectorWorks, etc.).) Continuation of THTR 4831, concentrating on the organic (non-rectilinear) drafting as well as virtual modeling and visualization and its use in the theatre industry.
Reqs: THTR 4831 or equivalent or permission of instructor

Name: Senior Capstone Seminar in Theatre
Desc: Majors only. Survey of issues and career options in theatre, focus on professional preparation; required of graduating senior Theatre majors.

Name: Special Projects in Theatrical Design
Desc: May be repeated twice for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 2-6 hrs. lab. Mentored special projects to include advanced area of study or the execution of practical production projects in theatrical design.

Name: Special Projects in Theatrical Technology
Desc: of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. 2-6 hrs. lab. Mentored special projects to include advanced area of study or the execution of practical production projects in theatrical technology.
Reqs: consent of instructor May be repeated twice for a max

Name: MFA Daily Practice
Desc: 2-3 hrs. lab. Daily warm-up for actors using such techniques as T’ai Chi, Yoga, Pilates and other techniques at the discretion of the instructor.
Reqs: Admission to the MFA Program in Theatre or consent of instructor

Name: Independent Projects in Performance Training
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 12 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Individual projects in performance training with close faculty supervision; emphasis may be in one or all of the following areas: acting, movement, voice, directing or dance.

Name: Dance for Actors
Desc: May be repeated for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. Graduate training in dance technique for the actor. Topics will vary by semester at the discretion of the instructor.
Reqs: Must be admitted into the MFA Acting program

Name: Drama Writing
Desc: See ENGL 7008.

Name: Script Analysis and Dramaturgy
Desc: Methods of studying playscripts in preparation for their production on stage, through Aristotelian, modern and postmodern approaches.

Name: MFA Acting Studio I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Intensive work in actor’s basic process and tools; text analysis; introduction to contemporary realism; introduction to Shakespeare.

Name: MFA Acting Studio II
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Applied basic process and text analysis; realism to lyric realism; Ibsen, Chekhov, Williams; scene work with selected texts.

Name: MFA Acting Studio III
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. The Tragic Impulse. Applied basic process and text analysis explored in Greek, Shakespearean and Jacobean tragedy; scene work with selected texts.

Name: MFA Acting Studio IV
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. The Comic Impulse. Basic process and text analysis explored in Commedia, Shakespeare, Moliere, Restoration, Sheridan and Shaw; scene work with selected texts.

Name: MFA Acting Studio V
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. New plays and devised drama. The Solo Performance.

Name: MFA Acting Studio VI
Desc: lab. Audition/interview techniques and professional issues.

Name: MFA Camera Studio I
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. An active, in-front-of-the-camera, studio class designed to introduce the committed actor to he skills and techniques needed to be truthful, interesting and affecting when acting in television and film. An elemental comprehension of film and television terminology, technology and process.

Name: MFA Voice Studio I
Desc: Vocal foundations. The vocal training progression begins by exploring fundamental voice skills for the actor through the mind-body-voice connection, vocal health, respiration, phonation, resonation, articulation, and contemporary text.

Name: MFA Voice Studio II
Desc: Vocal Awareness. The vocal training progression continues by reinforcing foundations and investigating vocal range, pitch variety, phonetic skills, and heightened language.

Name: MFA Voice Studio III
Desc: Vocal Freedom. The vocal training progression continues by further exploring vocal responsiveness, physical release, impulse, vocal style, text, and phonetic skills.

Name: MFA Voice Studio IV
Desc: Vocal Skill. The vocal training progression continues by investigating accent training, exploring accent histories, sociolinguistics, oral posture, phonetic application, and intonation.

Name: MFA Voice Studio V
Desc: Vocal Journey. The vocal training progression continues with an advanced study of speech skills and applications, examining actor-specific speech needs, accents, and detailed phonetics.

Name: MFA Movement Studio I
Desc: The Diagnostic Body. An intensive examination of the habits of physical use of the body through principles of T‟ai Chi, Alexander Technique, Yoga and Sports Fitness.
Reqs: admission to MFA program or consent of instructor

Name: MFA Movement Studio II
Desc: The Expressive Body. Neutral and character masks used to enhance the actor’s awareness of body language and non-verbal communication while expanding approaches to character through external physical choices.

Name: MFA Movement Studio III
Desc: The Combative Body. Basic stage combat in unarmed and rapier. Foundation in conditioning through stretching and tumbling with rolls , dives and falls. Scene presentations used to apply techniques to performance.

Name: MFA Movement Studio IV
Desc: The Inventive Body. Physical approaches to the creative impulse in interpretive and generative work.

Name: MFA Movement Studio V
Desc: The Athletic Body. This class focuses on the actor’s need to stay physically fit and active as they approach the return to the freelance professional world.

Name: MFA Movement Studio VI
Desc: Exposure to major trends in movement as performance material.

Name: MFA Camera Studio II
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Further development of skills and principles introduced in Camera Studio I; exercises and scene work focused on special acting challenges, characterizations and more demanding texts; creation and production of final DV/film project.

Name: Director/Designer Communication
Desc: Methods of communication between directors and designers explored through a series of pre-production projects.
Reqs: admission to MFA program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Scene Design I
Desc: Preparation and presentation of scene design projects; emphasis on script analysis, developing the ground plan and elevations.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Scene Design IIA
Desc: (IIA) Preparation and presentation of scene design projects; emphasis on period and style.

Name: Advanced Scene Design III
Desc: Emphasis on dramaturgically driven design. Special attention given to connection between physical world, music, and changing environment. Refine professional researching, drafting, drawing, model building, and presentation methods. Refine professional development materials including resume, cover letter, portfolio, and website.

Name: Rendering for the Theatre IA
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Drawing and rendering techniques for scenic, costume, and lighting designers; emphasis on basic design elements and use of various media.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Period Styles and Costume
Desc: Historical survey of theatre with emphasis on the development of visual design from the Greeks to the present with particular focus on the work of the actor in relationship to costume, movement and space.

Name: Computer Techniques for the Theatre
Desc: Examines the various ways the computer is used in theatre, specifically in the area of stage properties. Printing, plotting, and various computer programs are included in the curriculum.
Reqs: admission to MFA in Theatre program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Costume Design I
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. (I) Preparation of advanced costume design projects; emphasis on script analysis, characterization, and problem solving.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Costume Design II
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. (II) Emphasis on designing entire production projects to achieve unity, coherence and style.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Costume Design III
Desc: 3 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Emphasis on ballet, opera, and musical theatre.
Reqs: admission to the MFA  design technology programor consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Costume Technology I
Desc: 6 hrs. lab. Advanced problems in the planning and construction of historical costumes for the theatre, with emphasis on pattern drafting and draping.
Reqs: admission to MFA design/technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Costume Technology II
Desc: Advanced planning and construction of costumes for the theatre; emphasis on historical construction, cutting and tailoring.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Costume Technology III
Desc: (III) Emphasis on selection, modification and preparation of fabrics for stage costumes.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Costume Technology IV
Desc: (IV) Emphasis on costume accessories including millinery, footwear, armor and jewelry.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program or consent of instructor

Name: Scene Shop Technologies and Theatre Safety I: Woodworking
Desc: Introduction to traditional and modern materials (primarily wood and plastic products); construction tools; techniques for executing theatrical constructs; shop organization and management; theatre safety; and occupational health.

Name: Scene Shop Technologies and Theatre Safety II: Metalworking
Desc: Introduction to traditional and modern materials (primarily metal products); construction tools; techniques for executing theatrical constructs; shop organization and management; theatre safety; and occupational health are covered.

Name: Structural Design for the Stage I
Desc: Develops student understanding and skills for analyzing loading conditions on scenic elements and engineering a structural design for executing these elements.

Name: Structural Design for the Stage II
Desc: Continuation of the concepts presented in THTR 7610 .

Name: Theatrical Production Planning
Desc: The management of the theatrical production process. Investigation of the labor and material cost budgeting for each of the production areas.

Name: Entertainment Rigging
Desc: Introduction to traditional rigging techniques for the stage, arena and outdoor venues.

Name: Stage Machinery Physics
Desc: Examination of Newtonian dynamics to aid in determining the behavior of moving scenery. Understanding how the components of a stage machine system are specified to withstand the forces encountered.

Name: Scenery Automation
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. Examination of scenery control systems, including PLC programming, positioning control, software and all in-one control systems.

Name: Theatre Technology Seminar IA
Desc: Advanced techniques used on stage and in the scene shop.
Reqs: admission to MFA design technology program

Name: Theatre Technology Seminar IIB
Desc: Emphasis on roles and responsibilities of the technical director and on preparation to enter the professional world.
Reqs: admission to the MFA design technology program

Name: Directed Professional Internship
Desc: Pass-fail grading. 2-24 hrs. lab. A theatre-related internship with a professional organization or business (lighting manufacturer, professional theatre, computer company).
Reqs: third-year status in theatre MFA program

Name: Properties I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. A detailed examination of basic materials, techniques and procedures used by the designer and technician in the construction of stage properties.
Reqs: admission to MFA in Theatre program or consent of instructor

Name: Properties II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. A continuation of the concepts presented in THTR 7801.
Reqs: THTR 7801, admission to MFA in Theatre program or consent of instructor

Name: Furniture and Woodworking I
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Advanced studies in woodworking technologies including materials, construction techniques and styles. Care and repair of furniture is included in the curriculum.
Reqs: admission to MFA in Theatre program or consent of instructor

Name: Furniture and Woodworking II
Desc: 1 hr. lecture; 4 hrs. lab. Continuation of the concepts presented in THTR 7821.
Reqs: THTR 7821, admission to MFA in Theatre program or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Properties I
Desc: Engagement in projects that occur in productions under construction.

Name: Advanced Properties II
Desc: Continuation of concepts covered in THTR 7831.

Name: Introduction to Graduate Study in Theatre
Desc: Research and bibliographic skills for students of theatre history, dramatic literature, theory and criticism.
Reqs: admission to the MA/PhD program in theatre

Name: Issues in Ancient Theatre and Performance
Desc: Survey of issues related to history, dramatic literature and theatre criticism of the Ancient World, including Greece, Rome and Asia.

Name: Issues in Medieval and Renaissance Theatre and Performance
Desc: Survey of issues related to history, dramatic literature and theatre criticism found in Medieval and Renaissance Europe, Asia and Americas.

Name: Issues in 17th and 18th Century Theatre and Performance
Desc: Survey of issues related to history, dramatic literature and theatre criticism founded in 17th and 18th century Europe, America and Asia.

Name: Issues in 19th Century Theatre and Performance
Desc: Survey of issues related to history, dramatic literature and theatre criticism found in 19th century Europe, America and Asia.

Name: 20th Century First-Wave Avant-Garde Drama and Performance
Desc: Survey of dramatic and performance practices in the first half of the twentieth century with emphasis on European and American first-wave avant-garde.

Name: Seminar in American Drama: 18th Century to the Present
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Drama and Performance: World War II to the Millennium
Desc: Survey of world performance and drama traditions from the end of World War II to the end of the twentieth century.

Name: Seminar in Drama of the African Diaspora
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. credit when topics vary. Contextualizing forms and expressions of drama in the black cultures of the African diaspora in the New World.

Name: Seminar: Performance Theories and Criticism
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.

Name: Seminar in Gender, Sexuality and Performance
Desc: Survey of practical and theoretical approaches, attitudes, and debates regarding issues of gender and sexuality as they relate to performance.

Name: Seminar: Evolution of Dramatic Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Major concepts of dramatic theory and practice in classical, medieval and Renaissance periods.

Name: Seminar: Evolution of Dramatic Theory
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Major concepts of dramatic theory and practice in the European and American modern period.

Name: Seminar in African Drama and Theatre
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 credit hours when topics vary. Comparative study of the form and expressions of drama among the various cultures of Africa.

Name: Independent Research: Theatre
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. credit. For advanced graduate students who wish to pursue research on special problems exclusive of thesis or dissertation.

Name: Theatre Production
Desc: 2-24 hrs. lab. Major acting, directing, design or technical responsibility for one or more LSU productions.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Introduction to Mentoring, Education and Research
Desc: Pass-no credit grading. May be taken for a maximum of 4 semester hours of credit. For first-year students in HHMI Professors Program or LA-STEM Research Scholars Program only. Not for degree credit. Students will be mentored as they prepare to become mentors and researchers. Introduction to college success tools, including learning strategies, time management and organization.

Name: Pursuing Mentoring, Education and Research
Desc: Pass-no credit grading. May be taken for a maximum of 4 semester hours of credit. For second-year students in the HHMI Professors Program or LA-STEM Research Scholars Program only. Not for degree credit. Students continue to implement the college success tools gained in UC 0050 and will gain skills needed to obtain research. Students will assess various applications of terminal degrees in their chosen discipline and will engage in peer mentoring.

Name: Success in Mentoring, Education and Research
Desc: Pass-no credit grading. May be taken for a maximum of 4 semester hours of credit. For third-year students in HHMI Professors Program or LA-STEM Research Scholars Program only. Not for degree credit. Students will gain skills needed for graduate school marketability and preparation and will expand their mentoring projects and community involvement, engaging in peer mentoring.

Name: Advancing in Mentoring, Education and Research
Desc: Pass-no credit grading May be taken for a maximum of 4 semester hours of credit. For fourth or fifth year students in HHMI Professors Program or LA-STEM Research Scholars Program. Not for degree credit. Students will serve as leaders within the program and in the community. They will enhance presentation skills, finalize graduate school preparation and engage in peer mentoring.

Name: No title provided
Desc: Unique courses of timely and general interest are offered periodically as “University” courses. These courses are interdisciplinary, broad in scope and centered on topics of current concern. Permission to offer a UNIV course must be obtained from the Office of Academic Affairs and the course must be approved by the Faculty Senate Courses and Curricula Committee. University courses may not be offered more than twice (with the exception of The Boyd Professor Lecture Series). Each course carries undergraduate credit of one to three semester hours. Acceptance of such credit toward fulfillment of degree requirements is decided by the faculty of each college or school within the university. The topic, credit and class time of each university course are announced by the Office of Academic Affairs prior to the beginning of the semester in which the course is to be taught.

Name: Research Methods in the Humanities & Social Sciences
Desc: Provides an introduction to research proposal writing, research methodologies, and foundational research theories and protocols.
Reqs: For students in the College of Humanities and Social Sciences

Name: Internship
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. For students in the College of Humanities & Social Sciences. Application of skills and knowledge learned toward real world work experience.

Name: Interdisciplinarity
Desc: Study of interdisciplinary approaches in the sciences, social sciences, arts and humanities; analysis of combinations of disciplinary approaches.
Reqs: Standing in the College of Humanities & Social Sciences as an interdisciplinary studies major

Name: Seminar: Veterinary Clinical Sciences
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 hrs. of credit when topics vary. New developments in veterinary internal medicine, surgery, dermatology, ophthalmology, cardiology, neurology, theriogenology and laboratory/exotic animal medicine.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Research Techniques in Veterinary Clinical Sciences
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Specialized research techniques related to a specific discipline of veterinary clinical sciences.
Reqs: appropriate 4000- or 5000- level course in selected topic or equivalent and consent of instructor

Name: Special Topics in Veterinary Clinical Sciences
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 8 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Aspects of the biochemical, physiological, pathophysiological, epidemiological and economic basis of clinical veterinary medicine.
Reqs: appropriate 4000- and 5000- level course in selected topic or equivalent and consent of instructor

Name: Veterinary Gastroenterology
Desc: Gastrointestinal diseases and related conditions; emphasis on diagnostics, pathophysiology and management options.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Veterinary Surgical Techniques
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary. 3 hrs. lab. Advanced surgical and experimental techniques related to an organ system.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Orthopedics
Desc: Bone, muscle, tendon, and ligament diseases with emphasis on pathophysiology, diagnostics and management options.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Clinical Neurology
Desc: Diseases of the central and peripheral nervous system with emphasis on pathophysiology, diagnostics, neurosurgery and other management options.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Urogenital Disease
Desc: Urinary and reproductive tract diseases and related conditions with emphasis on pathophysiology, diagnostic and management options.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Cardiovascular Disease
Desc: Cardiovascular diseases and related conditions with emphasis on pathophysiology, diagnostic and management options.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Respiratory Disease
Desc: Respiratory diseases and related conditions with emphasis on pathophysiology, diagnostic and management options.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Veterinary Scientific Journal Review
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit. In depth critique of current veterinary journals with emphasis on appraising experimental design and analysis; and interpretation and application of results.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Cardiorespiratory Disease
Desc: Cardiovascular and respiratory diseases and related conditions with emphasis on pathophysiology, diagnostic and management options.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Biomechanics of Fractures and Fracture Fixation
Desc: Principles of biomechanics as applied to fractures and fracture fixation, including design and biomechanical testing devices for fixation of bone fractures arising in veterinary orthopedic surgery.

Name: Advanced Veterinary Diagnostic Imaging Interpretation: Small Animal
Desc: Advanced training in radiographic, ultrasonographic, computed tomographic and magnetic resonance imaging examination interpretation in common small animal diseases.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Diagnostic Imaging Interpretation: Large Animal
Desc: Advanced diagnostic imaging interpretation of radiographic, computed tomography, ultrasonographic, scintigraphic and magnetic resonance imaging examinations in large animals.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Advanced Veterinary Diagnostic Imaging: Interventional Techniques Laboratory
Desc: Interventional tissue sampling and therapeutic guided procedures performed with fluoroscopy, computed tomography (CT), and ultrasonography (US) in animals.
Reqs: DVM or equivalent degree or consent of instructor

Name: Surgical Techniques in Herpetological Medicine
Desc: 2 hrs. lecture; 2 hrs. lab. The course will combine didactic lectures with hands on laboratory sessions in herpetological medicine with primary focus on surgery and endoscopy. This course will provide exposure to the most relevant reptile and amphibian groups.

Name: How People Learn
Desc: Emphasis on social and psychological factors affecting adult motivation and learning; defining techniques for adult learning experiences.

Name: Curriculum Design and Program Evaluation for Healthcare Education
Desc: Create and evaluate curriculum for a healthcare education program. Emphasis on principles of evaluation, curriculum design, and continuous quality improvement.

Name: Student Assessment in Healthcare Professions Education
Desc: Analyze principles for design and management of learner assessment in healthcare education. Emphasis on healthcare education assessment, analysis and organization of assessment data as aligned with program evaluation.

Name: Pedagogical Principles and Best Practices of Teaching and Learning in Healthcare Education
Desc: Evaluate foundational principles of learning theory and criteria for research and scholarship in healthcare education.

Name: Educational Technology in Healthcare Education
Desc: Evaluate various strategies and techniques for technology integration, learning theory, and models of effective teaching at a distance. Emphasis on tools, techniques, and processes that facilitate active learning.

Name: Education Practicum and Current Issues in Healthcare Education: Capstone Project
Desc: Demonstration of the application of knowledge and skills acquired throughout the THCP program.

Name: Anatomy and Physiology of Farm Animals
Desc: Anatomy and physiology of farm animals; important species differences.

Name: Special Topics
Desc: Designed for students who are seeking remediation of a required course in the DVM curriculum based upon guidelines outlined by the LSU-SVM Scholastic Standards Committee.

Name: Problem Based Learning I
Desc: Small group problem-based learning using clinical veterinary cases, with emphasis on the problem-oriented approach to veterinary problem solving.

Name: Problem Based Learning II
Desc: Continuation of VMED 5001. Small group problem-based learning using clinical veterinary cases, with emphasis on the problem-oriented approach to veterinary problem solving.

Name: Special Topics in Veterinary Medicine
Desc: Pass/fail grading.

Name: Advanced Veterinary Anesthesiology and Surgery
Desc: Advanced veterinary surgery and anesthesiology.

Name: Introduction to Veterinary Medicine
Desc: Pass/fail grading. Survey of career opportunities in the veterinary profession.

Name: Introduction to Veterinary Medicine II
Desc: Pass/fail grading. Continuation of VMED 5100. Survey of career opportunities and other issues in the veterinary profession.

Name: Principles of Problem Solving
Desc: Introduction to problem solving methodology, clinical problem solving, problem-based learning, problem-oriented approach, and information management.

Name: Principles of Diagnostic Imaging
Desc: Basic principles of radiation physics, radiography, radiation safety, radiology, ultrasonography, computed tomography, and magnetic resonance imaging in veterinary medicine; emphasis on the normal radiographic anatomy of the canine, feline, equine, and bovine using selected case examples.

Name: Principles of Diagnostic Imaging II
Desc: Continuation of VMED 5104.

Name: Veterinary Physiology I
Desc: Physiology of the endocrine, reproductive, and muscular systems in veterinary species.

Name: Veterinary Physiology II
Desc: Basic cardiovascular and gastrointestinal system dynamics in veterinary species.

Name: Veterinary Physiology III
Desc: Basic respiratory and renal system dynamics in veterinary species.

Name: Basic and Applied Anatomy I
Desc: Principles of macroscopic anatomy, basic structure, and applied anatomy of the bones, muscles, and joints of the thoracic limb, pelvic limb, and trunk; dissection of the dog, with relevant comparisons to the horse and domestic ruminants.

Name: Basic and Applied Anatomy II
Desc: Introduction to the nervous system; anatomy of the blood vessels and nerves of the thoracic and pelvic limb, the equine digit; comparative anatomy of the head, including the skull and mandible, nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, ear, oral cavity, teeth, larynx, cranial nerves, surface of the brain and its coverings, and blood suppy.

Name: Basic and Applied Anatomy III
Desc: Anatomy of the neck and trunk, thoracic and pleural cavities, thoracic viscera; introduction to the autonomic nervous system; the abdominal wall, abdominal viscera, pelvic cavity, and viscera of the urinary and reproductive  systems of domestic animals.

Name: Veterinary Bacteriology and Mycology
Desc: Comparative biology of medically significant bacteria and fungi, emphasis on principles of pathogenesis and resistance to host

Name: Cell Biology
Desc: Offered in Fall. The molecular and cellular basis of animal health and diseases, and how structure and functions of cells may be inherently related to those of tissues and organs.

Name: Microscopic Anatomy
Desc: Offered in Fall. The histology of the basic tissues of the body and the microscopic anatomy of the organ systems in domestic mammals with consideration of the organ-specific microscopic structures covering the respiratory and urogenital organs, digestive system, defense and sensory organs, and skin.

Name: Developmental Morphology
Desc: Offered in Spring. The pre- and postnatal development of tissues, primitive transient and permanent structures, and the organ systems in domestic mammals (primarily cat, dog, horse, and domestic ruminants), starting at fertilization; including applied developmental knowledge of problems the mother and newborn might encounter after birth.

Name: Clinical Skills 1 Part 1
Desc: Offered in Fall. Development of clinical and technical skills in Veterinary Medicine

Name: Clinical Skills 1 Part 2
Desc: Development of clinical and technical skills in Veterinary Medicine.

Name: Neuroscience
Desc: Anatomy of the nervous system of domestic mammals; development and internal organization of the spinal cord and brain; physiology of the neuron and synapse; spinal functions, reflexes, and motor systems; proprioceptive, somatosensory, auditory, vestibular, visual, olfactory, and gustatory systems; autonomic nervous system; higher CNS functions and disease; basis for neurological examination.

Name: Veterinary Immunology
Desc: Introduction to the concepts and principles of modern

Name: Veterinary Pathology
Desc: Concepts, pathogenesis, and gross, microscopic, and ultrastructural changes associated with general pathology: cell injury and death, tissue mineralization, tissue pigmentation, disturbances of tissue growth, disturbances of circulation, and inflammation; recognition of gross, microscopic, and ultrastructural tissue changes and pathogenesis.

Name: Animals in Society I
Desc: Pass/fail grading. Human-animal relationships, human-animal bond, pet facillitated therapy, animal welfare, and animal rights.

Name: Animals in Society II
Desc: Issues in companion animal, equine, farm animal, and captive, exotic animal behavior.

Name: Veterinary Pharmacology
Desc: Fundamental principles of drug actions; drug disposition, pharmacokinetics and mechanisms of action; major classes of drugs used in veterinary practice; emphasis on fundamentals of drug action and clinical application.

Name: Veterinary Parasitology
Desc: Morphology, physiology, and taxonomy of arthropods, protozoa, and helminths of veterinary importance; agressive mechanisms of helminths, arthropods, and protozoa as well as defense mechanisms of the host; host-parasite relationships; diagnostic methods; mechanisms and factors influencing effectiveness of antiparasitic compounds and other control methods.

Name: Veterinary Virology
Desc: Comparative morphology, biochemistry, and classification of animal viruses; viral multiplication and pathogenesis; virus-host cell interactions and host responses to viral infections; rationale behind viral diagnostics and viral vaccines.

Name: Systemic Pathology I
Desc: Diseases, disease processes, and disease mechanisms in selected organ systems; emphasis on species of interest in veterinary medicine.

Name: Systemic Pathology II
Desc: Diseases, disease processes, and disease mechanisms in selected organ systems; emphasis on species of interest in veterinary medicine.

Name: Clinical Skills 2 Part 1
Desc: Mastery in Clinical Skills 2 Part 1. Development of clinical and technical skills in Veterinary Medicine.

Name: Clinical Skills 2 Part 2
Desc: Mastery in Clinical Skills 2 Part 2. Development of clinical and technical skills in Veterinary Medicine.

Name: Epidemiology and Public Health
Desc: Basics of veterinary epidemiology and public health; including regulatory medicine, environmental issues, food saffety, foreign animal disease, food- and water-borne diseases of humans, agro- and bioterrorism, and zoonotic diseases.

Name: Principles of Veterinary Surgery
Desc: Principles and fundamental techniques of veterinary surgery.

Name: Diseases of the Cardiovascular System
Desc: Principles of the diagnosis and treatment of acquired and congenital cardiovascular diseases of domestic animals.

Name: Small Animal Orthopedics
Desc: Common orthopedic problems encountered in small animal practice; developmental and traumatic abnormalities affecting the musculoskeletal system of the dog and cat.

Name: Urinary System Diseases
Desc: Clinical applications of renal physiology; characterization, diagnosis, and treatment of diseases of the urinary system of domestic animals.

Name: Diseases of Dogs and Cats
Desc: Basic principles, diagnosis, and treatment of common diseases/conditions involving small animals.

Name: Avian, Zoo, and Exotic Animal Diseases
Desc: Principles of diagnosis, treatment, medicine, surgery, and control of diseases of companion birds and rodents, raptors, ferrets, rabbits, zoo, exotic, and marine animals.

Name: Diseases of Farm Animals
Desc: Principles of diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and control of diseases/conditions of cattle, goats, sheep, and swine.

Name: Veterinary Anesthesia
Desc: An introduction to the principles and practices of veterinary anesthesiology.

Name: Clinical Pathology and Diseases of the Hemolymphatic System
Desc: Introduction and application of principles and techniques of hematology; clinical chemistry; exfoliative cytology; and body fluid analysis; diagnosis, management, and treatment of diseases of the hemolymphatic system in equine, farm animal, and companion animal species.

Name: Veterinary Clinical Oncology
Desc: Fundamentals of oncology, including the basics of mutagenesis, oncogenesis, tumor immunology, tumor epidemiology, diagnosis, and therapy in animals.

Name: Endocrine and Metabolic Diseases
Desc: Introduction to the normal structure and function of the endocrinologic and metabolic systems; overview of important endocrine diseases of veterinary species.

Name: Clinical Skills Laboratory
Desc: Basic clinical skills necessary in the practice of companion animal veterinary medicine including restraint, physical examination, advanced diagnostic and therapeutic techniques, techniques used to evaluate the eyes and skin, clinical nutrition, and client communication and medical history taking.

Name: Veterinary Radiology and Imaging
Desc: Use of radiography, ultrasound, and cross-sectional imaging to diagnose diseases of the thorax, abdomen, and neuromusculoskeletal system in small and large animals.

Name: Large Animal Clinical Nutrition
Desc: Nutrition of horses, swine, dairy cattle, beef cattle, and small ruminants; feed ingredients, commercial feeds, and feed labels; diet formulation and evaluation; nutrient requirements and feeding practices for the healthy animal; nutrient deficiencies; nutritional prevention and/or management of specific disease conditions.

Name: Small Animal Clinical Nutrition
Desc: Nutrition of dogs, cats, pet birds, and exotic species; nutrient requirements and feeding practices for the healthy animal; nutrient deficiencies; nutritional prevention and/or management of specific disease conditions.

Name: Clinical Skills 3
Desc: Mastery of clinical skills. Advanced proficiency in clinical and technical skills in Veterinary Medicine.

Name: Veterinary Neurology
Desc: Clinical and comparative anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, diagnosis, and therapy of diseases of the nervous system in domestic animals.

Name: Veterinary Ophthalmology
Desc: Clinical and comparative anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, diagnosis, and therapy of diseases of the eye in domestic animals.

Name: Comparative Theriogenology
Desc: Reproductive anatomy, endocrinology, and physiology; breeding, diagnosis, therapy, and control methods; assisted reproductive technologies in theriogenology for domestic animals (animal reproduction).

Name: Diseases of Horses
Desc: Diagnosis and management of diseases in horses; emphasis on recognition of disorders; diagnostic techniques; medical and surgical management.

Name: Emergency Medicine
Desc: Basic principles of emergency and critical care medicine across all common domestic species. Materials include a layout of approaches for patient triage, fluid therapy, environmental emergencies specific for our geographical region, and commonly encountered emergencies. Coursework contains inclusion of small companion animals, equine, farm animals, and exotics.

Name: Integumentary System
Desc: Diagnosis, treatment, and surgery of important skin and ear diseases and skin wound management in domestic animals.

Name: Population Medicine
Desc: Overview of disease control and prevention as it applies to animal populations; food and fiber production units and the equine industry are stressed.

Name: Ethics and Jurisprudence
Desc: Introduction to veterinary ethics and the law; their relationship to the veterinary profession.

Name: Business Management
Desc: 20 contact hours. Principles of analysis and decision making related to operating a professional, client-oriented practice as a business; concepts in communication, practice promotion, finance, and personnel management for optimum efficiency and return on investment.

Name: Clinical Immunology and Infectious Diseases
Desc: Principles of diagnosis, treatment, and control of infectious diseases.

Name: Toxicology
Desc: Toxicology of various natural and synthetic toxicants in relation to the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of common intoxications in domestic animals.

Name: Diagnostic Microbiology
Desc: Clinical application of laboratory services for the diagnosis of immunological and infectious diseases.

Name: Diagnostic Parasitology
Desc: Clinical application of laboratory services for the diagnosis of parasitic diseases.

Name: Anesthesiology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 hrs. of credit. Practice of anesthesia, including technical skills, monitoring tools, and pain management in a variety of species.

Name: Diagnostic Pathology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 12 hrs. of credit. Necropsy of various vertebrate animal species, with emphasis on domesticated animals; application of diagnostic procedures and techniques in anatomic and clinical pathology; case-based, problem-oriented approach to diagnostic problem solving utilizing current teaching hospital and referral cases and prepared materials that illustrate the aspects of disease mechanisms, pathogenesis, tissue changes, and factors needed for accurate diagnoses.

Name: Radiology and Diagnostic Imaging
Desc: Applications of procedures, methods, and techniques in veterinary radiography, radiology, and diagnostic ultrasound.

Name: Avian, Zoo, Exotic, and Marine Animal Medicine
Desc: Avian, zoo, exotic, and marine animal care and managemnt; clinical application of diagnostic, treatment, and control methods for avian, zoo, exotic, and marine animal diseases; client interaction related to didactic information learned in preclinical course; primary and intensive care medicine, client education, practice management review.

Name: Small Animal Medicine
Desc: Application of diagnostic, therapeutic, and control methods for canine and feline diseases; primary and intensive care medicine; preventive health care; medical techniques; problem-oriented approach, client education, practice management; case studies in small animal clinic.

Name: Small Animal Surgery
Desc: Diagnostic, treatment, and surgical techniques and procedures in small animals; surgical problems, preoperative and postoperative patient care; anesthetic techniques; client education and practice management; case studies in the small animal clinic.

Name: Equine Medicine and Surgery
Desc: Diagnostic, treatment, and control methods for equine diseases; surgical procedures, methods, and techniques in horses; study of medical and surgical cases in the large animal clinic.

Name: Applied Veterinary Dermatology
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 4 hrs. of credit. Diagnostic, treatment, and control methods for skin diseases of domestic animals; history taking; physical and dermatological examination; technical, problem-solving, and communication skills; participation in rounds, with emphasis on improving clinical proficiency; dermatological knowledge base and patient management; emphasis on responsibility and interpersonal relationships.

Name: Externship
Desc: Pass/fail grading. May be repeated for credit. Registration for this optional program must be approved by the director of Veterinary Clinics. Two- to five-week training period for fourth-year students with a private practitioner of veterinary medicine or with a qualified veterinary specialist.

Name: Special Training
Desc: May be repeated for credit. Registration for this course must be approved by the instructor and the department head involved. Training for veterinary medical students or advanced studies students in one or more clinical specialty areas of basic science disciplines.

Name: Theriogenology
Desc: Diagnostic, treatment, and control methods in theriogenology; emphasis on economics of reproductive herd health of domestic livestock and breeding management of horses and companion animals; fertility assessment of the male and female animal; obstetrics; artificial insemination and embryo transfer techniques.

Name: Applied Veterinary Ophthalmology
Desc: Special training in diseases and surgery of the eye; clinical experience in ophthalmic diagnostics, therapeutics, and surgery.

Name: Food Animal Health Management
Desc: Diagnostic, medical, surgical treatments, and herd health management of medical and surgical cases in the large animal clinic and in field services; health programs and outreach disease problem solving.

Name: Introduction to Research
Desc: Concepts and methodology in developing research programs; selection of a research problem; planning, execution and publication of original research.

Name: Thesis Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Pre-dissertation Research
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 9 sem. hrs. of credit.

Name: Dissertation Research
Desc: “S”/”U”grading.

Name: Evolution of Sex and Gender
Desc: Interdisciplinary course, team-taught by faculty in the physical and social sciences. Covers evolution as differential reproduction; reproduction-related earth history highlights; genetics of sex; animal reproduction strategies; anatomy and physiology of human reproductive systems; evolutionary trajectories in primates; sex and gender in human prehistory and in culture.

Name: Gender and Popular Culture
Desc: Popular culture forms from a women’s and gender studies perspective. Analyzes the intersections of gender, race, class, sexual orientation and age in media such as popular literature, film, television, advertisements, digital media and the Internet.

Name: Gender and Health
Desc: Health concerns that are also related to gender, including disparities and differences in health needs and responses, historical and contemporary ideas about health and gender and how gender and health intersect with class, ethnicity, age and place.

Name: Introduction to Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Credit will not be given for this course and WGS 2501. The interdisciplinary study of how gender and sexuality intersect with other social differences; analysis of how those intersections structure society, impact diverse social groups, and informed lived experience.

Name: HONORS: Introduction to Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. Same as WGS 2500, with special honors emphasis for qualified students. Credit will not be given for this course and WGS 2500.

Name: Gender, Race and Nation
Desc: This is an Integrative Learning Core (ILC) course that awards general education credit. The constructs of gender and sexuality across diverse racial, ethnic, cultural and class boundaries.

Name: Survey of Feminist Theory
Desc: Interdisciplinary study of a range of feminist theories through which to consider the roles of women, gender and sexuality.

Name: Gender and American Politics
Desc: See POLI 4028.

Name: Gender, Place and Culture
Desc: See GEOG 4087.

Name: Special Topics in Women’s & Gender Studies
Desc: of 6 sem. hrs. of credit when topics vary. Issues central to contemporary feminist inquiry.
Reqs: WGS 2500 May be taken for a max

Name: Gender and the Law
Desc: Women’s de jure and de facto legal status in U.S. jurisdictions; the history of suffrage and demands for equal rights for men and women, violence against women and violence committed by women, property rights, inheritance rights, reproductive rights, marriage, child custody, the definition of family, Title IX issues, employment discrimination, and gender issues in the legal profession.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Women’s & Gender Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. when topics vary. Reading and research on selected topics that emphasize feminist interdisciplinary approaches.
Reqs: WGS 2500 and permission of instructor and department

Name: Seminar in Feminist and Gender Theory
Desc: Topics in recent and contemporary theory in a range of disciplines including the humanities, social sciences, natural and physical sciences, design and education; students are encouraged to develop research projects relevant to their primary disciplines and to their research interests.

Name: Special Topics on Women’s and Gender and Sexuality Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 hrs. of credit when topics vary.  Topics in a range of disciplines including the humanities, social sciences, natural and physical sciences, art + design, and education; students are encouraged to develop research projects relevant to their primary disciplines and to their research interests.

Name: Independent Reading and Research in Women’s & Gender Studies
Desc: May be taken for a max. of 6 sem. hrs. of credit.
